HEADLINE: By the Book: Individuality Vs. Franchising; 
Trading Spark of Creativity For the Safety of Numbers

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: BELLINGHAM, Mass. 

 BODY:
Stephen Gurwitz is proud that his Hilltop Farms convenience store has long been a fixture here in this small town on the Rhode Island border.
 His grandfather, Milton Gurwitz, opened the little roadside building in 1955 as a place to sell milk and eggs from his farm. His father, Gary Gurwitz, expanded the store and added a deli counter. Mr. Gurwitz began working there as a boy and took business classes knowing that he would take over the family business someday. 
 Four years ago, he converted half the store to a Subway fast food franchise. 
Mr. Gurwitz, 32, said he felt no shame at trading in the old deli counter for a nationally promoted name and formulaic sandwiches that taste the same as their Subway counterparts around the world.
"For every independent convenience store that goes out of business, three chain stores open up," he explained. "The ones that close down are the ones that don't keep up with the times." 
Franchising should attract even more converts if the economy weakens further. Middle managers looking to strike out on their own often consider buying a franchise, with its tried-and-theoretically-true sales system, a safer bet when outside investors and venture capital are scarce.
But with that streamlined business plan comes the trade-off: a loss of individuality, regionalism and business creativity. In his new book "Fast Food Nation," Eric Schlosser asserts that McDonald's, the nation's largest franchise company, has homogenized not only its own restaurants, but whole swaths of the American economy, including the meat and potato industries.
"What we find with franchises is that the original creator of the franchise actually had a new idea, was actually quite dynamic and risk taking," Mr. Schlosser said. "But in order to expand the franchise he has to impose total conformity on the franchisees."
By the 1970's, when franchises became a widespread and powerful economic phenomenon, names like McDonald's and Dairy Queen were already synonymous with hamburgers and ice cream. But while fast food is still the single largest category, hundreds of lesser-known franchises that sell everything from printing services to baby clothes have emerged as well.
There are now even business-to-business franchises, which sell services like accounting, Web page design and manufacturing to other small businesses, many of them franchises themselves.
"It's a whole new story," said Don DeBolt, the president of the International Franchise Association in Washington, who estimates that the number of franchise locations in the United States has grown about 25 percent in the last decade. There are now about 320,000 franchises representing 1,200 to 1,500 companies in this country. And that growth is a result of franchises delivering what Americans want, he said.
"Today's sophisticated consumers more and more want their expectations realized on a consistent basis," Mr. DeBolt said. "Their expectations include the taste and the flavor but also the quality and price, and a brand name delivers that."
The basic relationship has not changed. Entrepreneurs looking for a "just add money" recipe still put their savings into building, buying or leasing a storefront and paying a start-up fee to the franchise headquarters. (Fees vary among companies; for example, Mr. Gurwitz paid $10,000 for use of the Subway name.)
Franchisees then pay royalties, sometimes as a flat fee but usually as a percentage of sales, to company headquarters. If royalties are tied into sales revenues, and the revenues do not meet company requirements, the franchiser can push the franchisee out of the business. In return for the fees, franchise operators receive training, advice and advertising for the brand name. Franchisees are responsible for employee salaries, taxes and tailoring the business to the needs of the local clientele.
For Mr. Gurwitz, joining Subway was a welcome respite from the myriad decisions he has to make in running the convenience store, which he co-owns with his father.
"They give you the operations manual, which is as thick as the New York City telephone book, and it tells you within a millimeter how thick to slice the onions," said Mr. Gurwitz, who spent two weeks at the Subway training center in Milford, Conn. "If you have a question about anything, you'll find it in the operations manual."
Indeed, Mr. Gurwitz discovered that many issues were no longer his sole responsibility. "Someone stubs his toe in the store, you call the Subway legal department," he said. "How many convenience stores have a legal department?"
Research and development, pricing and menus -- all are handled for him. By contrast, he said, "With the convenience store, I'm everything." 
The Subway brand also brings name recognition. Mr. Gurwitz credits it with increasing the traffic in his store about 1,000 customers a week -- roughly a 10 percent gain -- more than making up for the 11.5 percent of revenues from the sandwich operation he pays to headquarters. 
It seems enticing, but Susan P. Kezios learned to be wary of such a deal. In the 80's, she put all her money into a franchise operation of VR Business Brokers in Chicago Heights, Ill. "Two guys had already lost their money at that same location," she said. 
While she managed to keep the doors open, she struggled with what she calls "the flaws in the system." They began with the contract, which usually imposes an iron-clad form with no exceptions for a franchisee's particular needs.
"These franchise contracts are often legal works of art with franchiser attorneys determining every possible scenario during the entire length of time you'll own the franchise, to the franchiser's benefit -- not yours," she said. 
When the contract comes up for renewal, the terms often change. "If they were taking a 5 percent royalty, they might change it to 8 percent," she said. 
Ms. Kezios, who in 1993 founded the American Franchisee Association, an advocacy group in Chicago, said that franchising is no place for the "ignorant or naive." Some franchisers force their licensees to purchase from certain vendors at inflated prices, for example. They can open franchise units close by, intensifying competition. Franchisees often find it difficult to sell their businesses if they want out, or to open another business in the same industry because of "noncompete" agreements. 
Ms. Kezios counsels prospective franchisees to hire a lawyer experienced in representing franchise owners to look over the contract. She advises them to go with smaller, younger chains that need new business. 
"There is a higher probability that a smaller franchise chain will be willing to negotiate its franchise agreement with you, should you dislike some of the one-sidedness of the provisions," Ms. Kezios said. 
"The 'big boys' won't change a punctuation mark for you." 
While Mr. Gurwitz, who owned the property he needed, had minimal start-up costs, the initial investment for most fast-food franchises is $100,000 to $250,000, not including real estate costs. 
Royalties can be a burden when a franchisee is struggling toward profitability in the first few years. 
Still, many prospective entrepreneurs consider owning a franchise better than being a manager at someone else's company. And when the commodity for sale is an assembly-line product -- like paper shredders, makeup or cars -- much of the uniqueness is already forfeit.
James Marcotte, for example, has made a lot of money for other franchisees in his lifetime. He virtually grew up in the rental car business, working at Budget through high school and college. Starting as a car washer there, he became the director of United States car and truck operations in 1992, before a headhunter lured him to a competitor, Thrifty Car Rental, which hired him to travel around the country evaluating the franchise's businesses. 
But being an executive was not enough. Eventually, he made a bid for Thrifty's franchise at Logan Airport in Boston, which was not turning a profit. "I was tired of making money for other people," he said, "and wanted to make money for myself and reap the rewards of my hard work and experience in the industry."
Thrifty provided the financing under its Bootstrap Program, which lends start-up capital to experienced prospects. "At a decent rate," Mr. Marcotte added. 
As he sat in his office nestled in a vast parking lot of cars, Mr. Marcotte, 37, had the Thrifty Operating Manual II -- another "everything you wanted to know" compendium -- within reach. 
Some things, however, are not in the book. Through his own initiative, he put a Thrifty booth in the airport terminal (the location was off-site), doubled the size of his car fleet, and checked up on competitors' prices four times a day. 
He saw that to make the airport location less dependent on weekday business travelers, he needed some suburban locations to bring in extra rentals. Since taking over the airport location, Mr. Marcotte has opened three other franchises in the Boston area, with two more in the works. This time, he had to borrow the financing, about $50,000 for each location, from a bank. 
He will send more than $1 million to Thrifty this year. But his own salary, about $180,000, is almost twice the amount he was earning as an executive. 
All part of his own plan, not Thrifty's. To get ahead, he said, "You've got to take action for yourself." 
Yet franchising, says Mr. Schlosser, the author, is not about being distinctive. 
"There are certain instances in which individual franchisees come up with ideas that the home office is willing to listen to and to take, like Ronald McDonald and the Filet-O-Fish sandwich," he said. "But if you look at the big disputes between the franchisee and the franchiser, those disputes are invariably over franchisees unhappy with the direction that the main company is taking, whether it's their ad campaigns or their suppliers they have to buy from."
Although Subway allowed Mr. Gurwitz to stray from the standard menu by offering Willow Tree Farms chicken salad, a popular local brand, he has few other opportunities to personalize the business. Still, he said, that is all the sovereignty he needs. 
"If you're a free-spirited person and want to do it your own way," he advised, "you don't buy a franchise."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS AND BONDS; 
Dreary Reports On Layoffs And Earnings Afflict Markets

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors were served up another unappetizing plate of earnings and economic news yesterday and left the table in a hurry.
 Nortel Networks and Dell Computer scaled back earnings forecasts after the market closed Thursday. Both companies also announced layoffs, as the economic slowdown of the last eight months shows no immediate sign of ending. Consumer confidence fell, factory production declined and, at the same time, producer prices of finished goods jumped a startling 1.1 percent in January. 
 All this left investors with a bitter taste and less hope that the news on the economy and corporate earnings would be more palatable in the near future.
Some analysts said the surprising surge in producer prices might make the Federal Reserve less eager to cut interest rates. Others disagreed, saying the price jump was an aberration and falling consumer confidence was more worrisome to Fed policy makers.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index plunged 5 percent, and is down 1.8 percent for the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 1.9 percent, and is off 1.4 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.8 percent and is up only 0.1 percent in 2001.
Douglas R. Cliggott, the chief investment strategist at J. P. Morgan Securities, said he did not expect things to get better soon. He said corporate earnings, which are now projected to fall in the first and second quarters of this year, could decline for the rest of 2001.
He also dismissed the hope of a quick economic and earnings recovery in the second half of the year.
"If we get unemployment going up a couple of tenths of a point in the next few months, there is not going to be a second-half recovery," Mr. Cliggott said. The unemployment rate rose to 4.2 percent in January from 4.0 percent.
One positive for the market right now, he said, is the strong flow of money into domestic equity mutual funds. The four-week moving average of new inflows is $3.4 billion, according to AMG Data Services. 
"As long as the money is there its got to be put to work," he said. Buying from mutual funds may have been one reason for the afternoon rebound in stocks that reduced the losses for the day.
Yesterday's key data was the fall in consumer confidence in February. The University of Michigan index fell to 87.8, from 94.7 in January, its lowest level since November 1993.
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said on Wednesday that the economy was not in a recession. But he acknowledged that the economy's growth rate was at or near zero and that a break in consumer confidence could drag the economy lower.
At the end of the day, the S.& P. 500 index was down 25.08 points, to 1,301.53, and was off 1 percent for the week. The Dow fell 91.20 points, to 10,799.82, and was up 0.2 percent for the week. The Nasdaq finished the day down 127.53 points at 2,425.38. For the week, it was off 1.8 percent and is down 12.8 percent in the last three weeks, the ninth-worst three-week decline since the end of 1990. The eight others all came last year.
At its close yesterday, the Nasdaq composite index was just 133 points above where it closed on Jan. 2, the day the index plunged 7.2 percent. That decline was followed the next day by a surprise cut of half of a percentage point by the Fed in its benchmark short-term interest rate. The question now, if the stock market continues to decline, is whether Fed policy makers wait until their next scheduled meeting on March 20 to cut rates again or act sooner.
Among the stocks leading the market lower in addition to Nortel and Dell were Sun Microsystems, Qualcomm, JDS Uniphase, Cisco Systems, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M.
As investors sold these and others, many moved their money to energy, consumer and drug stocks, including Exxon Mobil, Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Pfizer.
The bond market fell early in the day on the news of the 1.1 percent jump in the Producer Price Index, which was led by a 15.3 percent jump in natural gas prices. Rises in tobacco and car prices also contributed to the increase. But the market rallied after the drop in consumer confidence was reported.
"The P.P.I. was clearly an aberration in a number of areas," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at J. P. Morgan Chase. "It was a very strange rise in the price of cars." But the consumer confidence data, he said, "clearly shows that consumers are becoming distressed," keeping alive the prospect of further rate cuts by the Fed. Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note first shot up to 5.23 percent, from 5.16 percent Thursday, and then fell to 5.09 percent by early afternoon, when the market closed early for the Presidents' Day weekend. The price of the 10-year note, which moves in the opposite direction, rose 19/32, to 99 11/32.
The yield on the Treasury's two-year note, which is an indication of how investors feel about the likelihood of another Fed rate cut, dropped to 4.70 percent, from 4.85 percent Thursday.
After the stock market closed Thursday, Nortel sharply cut its forecasts for both revenue and profits. The company, a Canadian manufacturer of communications equipment, also said it would cut 10,000 jobs. Nortel's stock dropped as much as 29 percent in after-hours trading Thursday, to $21. In trading yesterday it fell $9.75, to $20.00.
Dell announced the layoff of 1,700 workers Thursday. The job cuts equal about 4 percent of its work force and are the first major layoffs in the company's 16-year history. Then, after the market closed, the company said fourth-quarter earnings were up 18 cents a share, a penny short of an already lowered forecast. And Dell said earnings for the first quarter of this year would come in 2 cents below Wall Street's 19-cent forecast. Shares of Dell stock fell $1.50, to $23.50, yesterday.
Schering-Plough also offered investors a dose of bad news. It said a successor to its successful Claritin allergy drug would be delayed while the company made changes in its production process for the new drug, called Clarinex. The changes, ordered by the Food and Drug Administration, will delay production and cut first-quarter profits by 15 percent. The stock fell $7.07, to $41.25.

HEADLINE: Inflation at Wholesale Level Up a Steep 1.1% in January 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 

 BODY:
Prices paid to manufacturers and other producers for their goods climbed 1.1 percent in January in the steepest monthly gain in more than a decade, the government reported today.
 To some economists, the sharp rise in the Producer Price Index was a harbinger of higher inflation, the one crucial symptom that has mostly been absent from the nation's recent economic ills. If the Federal Reserve agrees with that diagnosis, these economists worried, it may be discouraged from lowering interest rates further. 
 Other economists countered that the spike was an aberration brought about by a confluence of high energy prices and some short-term, unworrisome factors. Those included higher cigarette prices and the removal of car dealers' customer incentive plans.
The 1.1 percent gain, raising the index to 141.6, was the steepest since the index rose 1.3 percent in September 1990, as the economy fell into recession. It followed a 0.2 percent gain in December and an even milder 0.1 percent gain in November. The January increase exceeded the 0.3 percent rise that many economists had expected.
"It could make it a lot more challenging for the Fed to drop rates," said William V. Fries, manager of the Thornburg Value Fund, which controls $1.8 billion in assets. "By dropping rates and stimulating the economy, you're just feeding inflation, which is not something the Federal Reserve wants to do."
The core producer price rate, which excludes food and energy prices, rose 0.7 percent in January, the steepest increase since 1.0 percent in December 1998, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Both increases in the core rate were attributed in part to higher cigarette prices, which rose 5.6 percent in January. In contrast, they rose 30.7 percent in December 1998.
Excluding months in which there was a big increase in cigarette prices, the core rate had not registered a monthly gain of 0.7 percent since January 1991, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
"You can't dismiss it completely," said Richard Berner, chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But our feeling is that this is a temporary blip."
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter issued a report today forecasting the increase in producer prices would have little effect on consumer prices. The firm cited the 1.2 percent increase in car prices, which added 0.1 percentage point to the core figure, and the 3.3 percent increase in energy prices, in describing overall price increases that topped estimates.
A separate report today provided more evidence of a weak economy. Industrial production fell 0.3 percent in January, its fourth consecutive decline, the Federal Reserve reported. The manufacturing industry, which has been in decline for nearly a year and offered economists other warnings last month, led the decline. Demand for natural gas fell, too.
Companies ran their factories and other operations in January at just 80.2 percent of their full capacity, its lowest level since August 1992.
In another report, the Commerce Department said that new housing construction rose by 5.3 percent in January, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.65 million units. It was the third consecutive monthly rise for housing construction, and the fastest pace since April 2000.

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Is Wild Card in the Nation's Economy 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
American consumers, shaken by a rash of layoff announcements and a weakening stock market, are losing confidence in the economy at the fastest pace since the last recession.
 The closely watched index of consumer sentiment compiled by the University of Michigan plunged in early February for the fourth consecutive month, the university reported yesterday. The February decline of 6.9 points brought the index to 87.8, about where it was at the start of the last recession, in July 1990. 
 "We are likely to find ourselves in a full-blown recession if there is another sharp drop in March," said Richard T. Curtin, director of Michigan's Surveys of Consumers. "Right now, there are lots of cross- currents. People have very positive views of mortgage rates and of interest rates in general on loans. But they are apprehensive about the future, and they tell us they plan to hold back on spending." 
Consumer confidence has emerged as the wild card in the current slowdown -- the "X factor" that can save the day or push the economy over the brink into recession. The sharp drop in the Michigan barometer helped to explain the slide in stock prices yesterday. Citing the latest falloff in confidence, some Wall Street forecasters declared that the Federal Reserve would soon cut interest rates again, despite a rise in January in the Producer Price index, a key inflation measure. And the bad news on confidence overshadowed a Commerce Department report yesterday that home construction had risen sharply in January.
"The fact is the consumer confidence index is a leading indicator, and there is no indication yet that it is bottoming out," said Ian C. Shepherdson, chief domestic economist at High Frequency Economics. "It is telling us that even if manufacturing rebounds and energy prices fall by spring, the economy could be held down by much lower consumer spending."
The chief scorekeepers for consumer confidence are Michigan and the Conference Board, a business organization whose index has tracked Michigan's, but with a lag. Both have noted that the declines in their indexes have come chiefly as a result of pessimism about the future, particularly pessimism about jobs. A majority of those surveyed in early February expect "the unemployment rate to rise during the year ahead," Mr. Curtin said. But worries about what is ahead increasingly affect consumer behavior in the present. "Buying attitudes toward furniture, appliances, home electronics and other large household durables fell in early February to their lowest levels since the early 1990's," Mr. Curtin said.
Taking the public by surprise, the Fed cut rates sharply on Jan. 3, partly because of a big drop in Michigan's consumer confidence index for December, the steepest one-month fall in a decade. Consumer confidence has been a Fed concern since. Focusing on the rapid shift in confidence, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, said in Congressional testimony on Tuesday that confidence was driven largely by "nonrational" behavior.
The "rending of confidence is one reason that recessions are so difficult to forecast," he said. "They may not be just changes in degree from a period of economic expansion, but a different process engendered by fear."
After rising or holding steady for most of last year the Michigan index has plunged 19.8 points since November. Not since the last recession, which started in July 1990 and ended the following April, has the index fallen so far in so few months. The fall came on the heels of a slowing economy and numerous downsizing announcements. 
Recent economic data has suggested that the slowdown may be ending. Retail sales were strong in January. And manufacturers cut back production sufficiently to brake the growth of inventories. The hope -- reflected in some of Mr. Greenspan's testimony on Tuesday -- is that production will revive soon as the stockpiled merchandise is sold off.
The sharp drop in consumer confidence in early February told a contradictory story. If the drop in confidence is confirmed in the final February reading and the Conference Board's survey for February matches Michigan's finding, then the odds rise that the economy will contract in the first quarter, instead of grow.
Some economists -- those at Goldman, Sachs, for example -- argue that the economy will contract slightly in the current quarter partly because "confidence appears to be starting to rupture." The economy is deemed to be in recession if the contraction lasts for at least six months, or two quarters. 
The Michigan survey is considered by some economists to be a better measure of consumer confidence than the Conference Board's. Certainly their methods are different.
Mr. Curtin and his staff at Michigan do their own polling, while the Conference Board, based in New York, farms the work out to a market research firm in Ohio. Michigan's survey draws on 500 telephone interviews spread through the month, each interview lasting 30 minutes. The Conference Board relies on questionnaires mailed out the first of each month to 5,000 households. The results are announced the middle of the following month, nearly two weeks after Michigan's final tally.
The Conference Board's questionnaire repeats the same questions month after month, while Michigan's interviewers vary some questions, to capture the changing nuances of consumer sentiment.
Whatever the method, neither survey has resolved a central issue: Whether the plunge in consumer confidence is a reaction to all the downsizing announcements and all the talk about recession, or whether people are reacting to their own experiences -- a hiring or wage freeze in their own workplaces, for example, or the layoff of someone they know, or stock market losses.
Mr. Curtin says that consumers are increasingly seeing evidence of the slowdown in their own lives or in their immediate surroundings. "We have a consumer who thinks economic growth has virtually stopped and job losses are rising," he said. 
Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting and forecasting firm, argues that confidence has fallen more quickly than actual experience warrants. "If people were not listening to the news," he said, "their own experiences would not have encouraged such a sharp drop in confidence."
Lynn Franco, director of the Conference Board's consumer research center, takes a middle road. "There is more fear than reality warrants now," she said, "but if the fear is not resolved quickly, it will become self-fulfilling."

HEADLINE: In Japan, Waiting for the Captain to Appear 

BYLINE:  By Shin'ya Fujiwara; Shin'ya Fujiwara, a Japanese writer and photographer, is a winner of the Mainichi Arts Award.

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
Before I began writing this piece, I asked a friend of mine in the United States to send me information about how the collision between an American submarine and a training ship chartered by a Japanese high school was being reported. Based on what my friend sent, I have to admit to a strange feeling. I noticed references to the collision as occurring "off Pearl Harbor." In Japan, the news media described the site as "off Hawaii."
 This difference in emphasis may be minor. But it does suggest that in America the injury and loss of life are being placed, by some, in a political, military or historical context that, from a Japanese perspective, is beside the point. The sinking of the Ehime Maru does have great political resonance here, but it is of a different kind. 
 In my country, the public has become more inward-looking after the collapse of the asset-inflated economy and the subsequent years of economic stagnation. As we look inward at our longstanding institutions, what we see is sordid. We see case after case of bribery involving politicians and bureaucrats, the sale of fraudulent products by big companies, medical mishaps and their concealment at hospitals, improper investigations and subsequent coverups by police departments, and so on. This year, government prosecutors have contributed their own corruption scandals. The distrust felt by ordinary citizens toward the state and toward each other has reached a pinnacle.
Recently we read the tragic story of two young men who lost their lives striving to help a drunken passenger who had fallen onto the tracks of a Tokyo railway station. A Japanese public that has become devoid of emotions reacted excessively to this brave act, as if it were seeking salvation.
The collision between the Greeneville, a nuclear attack submarine, and the Ehime Maru occurred as the Japanese public was thirsting for heroes, perhaps -- or for a sense of public honor, of personal, human connection between those in power and those without it. In this respect, the nonappearance of the commander of the Greeneville -- his failure to meet the families of the victims to express his feelings of apology and mourning -- is shocking, even incomprehensible to a people whose culture stresses decorum and form. Such decorum is not merely "formal" in the American sense; it is the shape in which common humanity finds expression.
Two civilians who were in the control room at the time of the accident were interviewed by an American television network to find out what had happened. They demonstrated their own sense of conscience as individual Americans -- a saving grace amid the sense of distrust felt by the Japanese toward the United States. Perhaps there is an American practice of not allowing those directly involved in such military incidents to appear before the public.
As the incident unfolded in Hawaii, the United States Marine Corps in Okinawa refused to turn over a serviceman suspected in several arson attacks last month. (The marine was finally turned over to local authorities yesterday.) These two events may seem unrelated. But from here, they appeared to be intimately linked. The responsible person was unavailable, absent from the public drama.
This is not a question of anti-American feeling, exactly, because the missing persons, so to speak, of greatest concern here are Japanese: the leaders and institutions who seem to have abandoned their ties to the daily lives of our people. In my opinion, the fierce criticism of Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori's decision to continue playing golf even after hearing about the Ehime Maru collision is a result of immense frustration at this abandonment of both decorum and responsibility. Unlike the commander of the Greeneville, Mr. Mori cannot hide. To a degree, he is a scapegoat, since the commander is not available for public admonition, and Mr. Mori is left to do the American's work. At the same time, both men have shown this capacity to go missing when they are needed, leaving us alone again in our grief and frustration.

HEADLINE: In Self-Storage Units, Art Market Thrives; 
For African Dealers, a Place to Trade

BYLINE:  By CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
The Chelsea Mini-Storage, a grimy, seven-story brick building with a loading dock at 615 West 27th Street, may well be the nation's largest transit point for wholesale African art. 
 More than 600 traders, nearly all Muslims from West Africa, cut deals with handshakes, load or unload recent purchases, chat, snooze or plan trips to Africa, where they buy artwork and send it to the United States on cargo ships. While the men trade, two women from Guinea cook chicken smothered in peanut sauce in a back room on the first floor, and the aroma mingles with the scent of smoldering incense. Men, shoeless, pray in a carpeted space near the entrance. 
 "This is the closest I can come in New York to being in Africa," said H. R. Hamilton, the publisher of African Business News. "There is a different sense of community here, a sense of trust, that is lacking outside these walls. There is something spiritual about it." 
The storage building grew into its role gradually. A few dealers in African art, many of them white, rented stalls some two decades ago to store items brought back from Africa. Over time others, especially immigrant traders from Africa, joined them.
Those who rent space pay about $190 a month for a 10-foot-by-10-foot storage room, a price traders say has doubled over the last year. The owners say the rent brings in several hundred thousand dollars a year.
The 5,000-room self-storage building, which the owners say is the largest of its kind in the United States, has some 60 first-floor "showrooms," in fact stalls with roll-up metal doors.
There, clusters of men trade and haggle in French and dozens of tribal dialects. Hundreds of families in New York, as well as people in countries like Mali, Congo, Liberia and Senegal, live off the business. 
The warehouse is as celebrated among African traders as it is unknown to those on the outside.
"I worked hard to bring Africans here," said Mohamed Dibassy, who over the last eight years has seen the traders in the building jump to 600, from 30. "You want to meet an African, from anywhere in Africa, you come to Chelsea Mini-Storage."
Under a slate-gray sky, dented vans, their back doors open, belched acrid fumes, while grunting workers loaded them with packages covered with bubble wrap. The vans pulled away, with two or three occupants to Chicago, Houston, Atlanta or Los Angeles. The items are peddled to galleries and at antique shows.
"No one knows we are here," said Mr. Dibassy, the head of the association of dealers, "so we do business mostly with dealers and traders."
Many of the works in the warehouse are contemporary copies of tribal pieces, mass produced and inexpensive. And there is no shortage of fakes, pieces smeared with dirt and weathered in an attempt to pass them off as vintage works. But mingled among them are 80- and 100-year-old objects that sell for tens of thousands of dollars. And dedicated collectors, along with gallery owners, prowl the storage building to inspect the arriving goods. 
But the tension between the established, largely white gallery dealers and the African traders is raw and flares into open spats. 
Mike Amitin, a large, bulky white man with a sandy-colored beard and an L. L. Bean vest, complained of the increasing reach of the traders. Mr. Amitan, who trolls the stalls almost daily, once had a gallery of African art that he said folded because of the traders' direct relationship with his clients.
"This place is the worst thing for African art," he said. "This is a wholesale place that sells directly to anyone. This new high-tech generation no longer makes sophisticated buys. It sees a mask for $50 and one for $10,000 and buys the cheaper one. This warehouse destroyed my business."
He turned and surveyed the stalls, many with somnolent attendants.
"There are a heap of small-time guys here," he said. "This place is a magnet for the unemployed."
There is little sympathy for gallery owners among the traders, many of whom live packed into small apartments and send money home to support families. They say that many gallery owners have kept them isolated, ordering them to remove the warehouse address from business cards and invoices, lest the location become more widely known.
Beany and Dick Wezelman, who have a gallery in California, stopped at the warehouse on a trip back from Africa, where they had bought a few hundred pounds of objects. The couple, who have been in the business for three decades, said the sons of traders in Africa had begun arriving in New York over the last few years to coordinate the family business. 
"I was with this man's father in Mali three days ago," said Mrs. Wezelman, pointing toward Ousmane Camara, 30, who stood in a small stall filled with artwork. "We have bought from his father for over 20 years. He is part of the revolution in African art, part of the new generation that is taking over the business from those who were established here." 
Mr. and Mrs. Wezelman said they knew nearly everyone in the warehouse because the traders had, at one time or another, appeared outside their California gallery with vanloads of items for sale.
Mohammed Sillah, 38, from Gambia, is one of the most established traders. His wife and five children live in Gambia and, like many traders, he travels back and forth. He arrived two weeks ago from West Africa, where for two months he made his way through remote parts of Togo, Ghana, Gambia and Senegal, buying up objects, many of them antiques. He said he speaks seven languages, including Bambara and Yoruba, allowing him to work outside urban areas. 
"If you want to make money, you need to get the special collection pieces," Mr. Sillah said, "but many of the best pieces are in villages where people will not part with them for money." 
"I arrive in the village with bags of rice, cola, small radios, blankets, kerosene and torch lamps," he continued. "I give them away as gifts. I ask people what they need. I take my time. I spend days in the right village. It is only when I leave, when they ask me what I want, that I turn my eyes to the old objects they have in their homes. Traders that try to buy these things quickly with cash usually fail. Good trading is built on trust and friendship. This is more important to many Africans than money."
Small-time vendors, including those who sell on street corners, take items from the warehouse on credit and pay the traders when the sales are completed. And for those whose credit is good, vanloads can be driven off with nothing more than a handshake.
"I turn over truckloads on credit," said Sulayman Berete, a Liberian. "It depends on how honest people are. I have watched $5,000 worth of art disappear without even $10 down payment." 
But for many, visits to the warehouse have less to do with sales and more to do with ambience.
Bamba T. Zoumana, from Ivory Coast, a slight man in a black leather jacket and a disarming grin, stood outside his shop in front of a poster that read: "Africa Must Unite." Around the outlines of the continent were pictures of Marcus Garvey, Malcolm X, Thomas Sankara, Steve Biko, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Elijah Muhammad, who was the longtime leader of the Nation of Islam.
He spoke softly with Danny Freund, 23, a student at Pennsylvania State University, who moved about on a pair of crutches, one leg lost a few years ago to cancer. Mr. Freund, who plays in an African drum band, comes to buy instruments in the warehouse. 
Mr. Zoumana fetched a variety of drums and percussion instruments from the showroom stalls, patiently allowing Mr. Freund to tap a solitary rhythm on each. He explained the origin and use of the instruments.
"What is this one called?" asked Mr. Freund, holding a hollowed rectangular piece of wood with three open slits.
"A krin," Mr. Zoumana said. "It is made of mango wood. It is used for communication." 
Mr. Freund made no purchase, acknowledging later that he often came simply because he liked the traders.
"There is no other place like this," he said. "You can feel the traditions of Africa, the strength of friendships and relationships, the welcome to all."
By the door to the street and the rows of vans, the hubris of a dying era was playing itself out.
"Who is the coolest white guy you know?" Mr. Amitan asked a group of seated traders.
No one answered.

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook; 
Fashion Week Fizzles Under the Tents

BYLINE:  By By CATHY HORYN 

 BODY:
Fashion week in New York usually ends with murmurs and cries of "Genius!" But it ended yesterday on a different note, a profound sense of despondency. Those in the industry and on its fringes who typically influence what women will wear next fall found themselves questioning the relevance of the American shows.
 There has been concern for years that the New York shows, America's most important fashion event, were failing to gain in stature -- failing even to approach the stature of the major collections in Paris and Milan -- despite repeated efforts to strengthen them. 
 Two years ago, they were scheduled earlier than the European shows in an effort to gain more of the spotlight. The collections were gathered in impressive tents in one place, Bryant Park, so the presentations would be more of a force. 
But after this week, it was apparent that so far at least, the answer has not been found. 
"We've seen a lot of salable merchandise, but not a lot of interesting trends," said Kal Ruttenstein, the fashion director of Bloomingdale's, on Thursday night before the Daryl K show. "We need excitement in the store, and so far we haven't seen too many exciting new ideas." And he expressed dismay that despite a proliferation of young talent at the New York shows, his buyers found a dearth of creativity. "It's still true that Paris is the creative center of the industry," Mr. Ruttenstein said.
Journalists covering the 10-day run of shows, which had 92 collections on the official schedule, voiced similar complaints. "We're too tired and stressed to be excited, and designers aren't giving us anything to be excited about," said Linda Griffin, the fashion editor of The Houston Chronicle. 
Criticism is common in an industry used to scrutinizing clothes ruthlessly. But there is a growing perception that despite the efforts of the Council of Fashion Designers of America to improve New York's image as an international fashion capital, the American shows are actually diminishing in prestige.
"I'll never disagree that Paris is the think tank, and Milan is the engine," said Stan Herman, the president of the council. Nevertheless, he said he believes that the valuable talent is still here, while acknowledging that "the perfect pedestal" has yet to be found. He is a proponent of allowing as many designers as possible a chance to show their stuff. 
But the result, some say, is a dull show. "They're predictable, and predictable in my book is boring, and that's the word for the shows," Bud Konheim, the president of Nicole Miller, said on Wednesday.
Two years ago, his partner, Ms. Miller, was one of the first designers to join Helmut Lang and Calvin Klein when they defiantly decided to present their collections ahead of Milan and Paris, a move intended to improve deliveries, as well as to demonstrate that American designers were not going to play second fiddle to their European rivals. That move apparently backfired, as many in the industry complain that the shows are now too distant from the fall to be relevant to consumers. The decision to strive for impact by presenting so much of the show in one place has also led to criticism. Now, it seems, shows that are praiseworthy are lost in the crowd, overwhelmed by the mediocrities. 
And even Mr. Konheim, once a proponent of the Bryant Park site, decided to forgo a runway show with all its show business flair, including front-row celebrities. Instead, he put on a small presentation in his Seventh Avenue showroom, where he invited only two journalists and his Japanese licensees. He said his reason had less to do with costs -- he reserved $300,000 for a show -- than with his belief that the shows have become overblown spectacles with "zero impact" on business.
"There are too many shows," he said. "And the second you saturate a subject you instantly denigrate the value of it."
If anything, the shows may become more action-oriented, more entertainment-driven, if a proposed sale of 7th on Sixth, the nonprofit group formed by the designers council to run the shows, to IMG goes through. IMG, the sports management and marketing company, in addition to representing models and athletes, is the largest sports producer on television. IMG sees the fashion shows' greatest value in their ability to generate sponsorships and even more televised events, the very sort of commercial development that has some of the critics most concerned. 
"Fashion is big," said Chuck Bennett, an IMG executive who expressed the company's excitement over the new possibilities. 
Part of the difference between these shows and those in Europe is historical. The French have nurtured creative talent, while America demands fashion that sells. How well even that objective -- the commercial success versus the creative -- has been met will not be clear for months, until the orders are in and counted. In any event, buyers tend more than ever to avoid risk, and they based their orders on last season's top sellers, rather than going for innovations.
And unlike Milan and Paris, where designers are invited to be part of the official show calendar based on merit, the industry in New York has never tried to impose standards. Anybody can show. That has proved to be both a plus and a minus: some unknowns are discovered, but a lot of nonentities show up, only to disappear forever. The Puffy Combs show, which drew so much attention, was a lot of fun, but more about flash and diamonds than about fashion. 
When Marc Jacobs was starting out, in 1984, with little money, the only way he could put on shows was to persuade models and hairdressers to work free. "I mean, we had a million sponsors," said Robert Duffy, his business partner. "Donald Trump let us use the Plaza Hotel. Dick Page did the makeup for free. They just didn't ask us to put their names on things."
Last week, as editors and store executives arrived for the shows, now called Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, it struck many that the creativity was hard to find, that the atmosphere had become primarily commercial. "It feels like a trade show," said Simon Doonan, the creative director of Barneys. 
Others acknowledge the benefits of the practical side: "It's business," said Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue. Be that as it may, Mr. Lang and Mr. Jacobs, two of the biggest names, choose to avoid the tents, preferring more personal show sites to distance themselves from the hoopla and conformity in Bryant Park. 
"What I think is worrying is that the shows are becoming completely part of the entertainment business, and the entertainment industry is boring" for those who come to see inspirational design, said Colin McDowell, who covers fashion for The Times of London. "I think we're in danger of boring everybody to death. And this is the industry's fault. Fashion has been completely trivialized."
The decision to make the shows earlier is not working. Store executives say deliveries are not much better. It has created confusion for consumers. "Excuse me, I don't see people rushing out in little spring outfits in February," said Donna Karan, who thinks the shows are missing consumers because they are too early or out of sync with their lives. "We've taught the customer to buy on sale," she said. "Come October, she can buy everything on sale." When Ms. Karan started her business, she showed her first collection on May 4, 1985. Now, the calendar has been moved up by three months. 
She has her own theory about a seeming dearth of creative young talent. "They don't have role models," she said. "When we were starting out, we had role models -- the society lady, whether you believed in her or not. Today, everybody dresses like a slob. Now, young designers think they can pick through the garbage, go to a vintage store, whatever, and they say, 'I'm a designer.' How many kids are paying the price? They want instant gratification."
As for the increased televising of these collections, Mr. Ruttenstein said: "On the one hand, it's great that people can see fashion, but I know a major designer who was sketching everything off the television last week. He was sitting in his apartment sketching like crazy. It just adds to the impression that American fashion is becoming more homogeneous."
The economic impact for New York of fashion shows twice a year is, in fact, sizable. The estimate from 7th on Sixth is that $247 million will be spent this year on goods and services by those attending the shows. For last week's fall 2001 shows, 1,650 members of the news media registered, including 503 foreign journalists, a slight increase over last year.
No figures are kept for retailers attending the shows, though fashion executives say the number has been steadily decreasing -- in part because fewer department stores bother to attend or even to buy the clothes. "The business is totally different today," Mr. Duffy, the president of Marc Jacobs, said before the Jacobs show on Monday. "When we were starting out, the audience for our shows was split equally between press and stores. Now I would say it's 90 percent press and celebrities."
But the perception that the New York shows are slipping in prestige -- so much so that many designers and journalists say that the atmosphere in the tents resembles a trade show -- comes at a critical time in the industry. Retail sales were off sharply in the fourth quarter last year, and while the January sales figures showed a rebound, stores are cutting their costs.
No one seems ready to kill off the New York shows, not yet, but there's a sense that something important still needs to be done. In Mr. Ruttenstein's view, "We need to be more talented than anywhere else."

HEADLINE: To Keep the Estate Tax, or Kill It? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Dozens of Rich Americans Join in Fight to Retain the Estate Tax" (front page, Feb. 14): 
 You report that some 120 wealthy Americans have started a campaign to retain the estate tax. 
This is a bad idea. 
The death tax punishes hard-working, middle-class business owners and farmers, stealing a big chunk of the savings they've spent a lifetime building. Many are forced to curtail operations, sell income-producing assets, lay off workers and even sell their entire businesses to pay this onerous tax. 
The death tax also encourages spending instead of investment, eliminating opportunities to create new jobs and stimulate economic growth.
The long arm of the Internal Revenue Service should not reach beyond the grave. American families that have worked hard to pass something on to the next generation should not be forced to sell their businesses to pay this tax.

THOMAS J. DONOHUE
President and Chief Executive
U.S. Chamber of Commerce
Washington, Feb. 14, 2001

HEADLINE: ATTACK ON IRAQ; 
In the President's Words on the Bombing: 'It's a Routine Mission'

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from a news conference with President Bush and President Vicente Fox of Mexico, as transcribed by the Federal News Service Inc. Mr. Fox spoke in Spanish, and an interpreter translated.

Q I have a question for President Bush. What is the message that you want to send right now? What does the United States want to send to the world as a message, with the new bombing of Iraq? And above all, why, Mr. Bush, at this point, when you are establishing a dialogue with the president of Mexico? . . .

PRESIDENT BUSH In answer to part B of your question, the United States is engaged in the Middle East, in the Persian Gulf. We will remain. We will remain so. Since 1991, our country has been enforcing what's called a no-fly zone. A routine mission was conducted to enforce the no-fly zone. And it is a mission about which I was informed and I authorized. But I repeat, it's a routine mission, and we will continue to enforce the no-fly zone until the world is told otherwise.

Q Sir, as you say, this is the first military action you've taken as president of the United States. I'm wondering whether it signals a hardening of the U.S. position toward Iraq and, specifically, is it your goal to drive Saddam Hussein from power? And secondly, are you putting Saddam on notice today that American and military action will be more frequent or more forceful than it was before you became president?

PRESIDENT BUSH Saddam Hussein has got to understand we expect him to conform to the agreement that he signed after Desert Storm. We will enforce the no-fly zone, both South and North. Our intention is to make sure that the world is as peaceful as possible. And we're going to watch very carefully as to whether or not he develops weapons of mass destruction. And if we catch him doing so, we'll take the appropriate action. . . .

Q Another question. Certification in Mexico -- will it continue? Will it disappear forever? Would you trust our friend, Fox?

PRESIDENT BUSH This question is on drug certification, and really about our relations with President Fox. I trust your president. He's the kind of man you can look in the eye and know he's shooting straight with you. I appreciate the fact that he was a one-time governor. I've got kind of a partiality to governors. . . .
We need to work together on the drug issue. One of the reasons why drugs are shipped -- the main reason why drugs are shipped through Mexico to the United States -- is because United States citizens use drugs, and our nation must do a better job of educating our citizenry about the dangers and evils of drug use.
Secondly, I believe there is a movement in the country to review all the certification process. I'm certainly going to take the message back to the members of Congress that I firmly believe that President Fox will do everything in his power to root out the drug lords and to halt drug trafficking as best as he possibly can. . . .

Q Since you two are working together on several actions that you want to undertake together in a short future and also the long-term future, do you support the military actions like the ones like the United States is doing bombing Iraq?

PRESIDENT FOX I do not have a position or a statement on that topic specifically, because this will be done through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in the future. . . .

Q A question for President Fox. Do you think that it is not an improper gesture in this visit that the recent bombing of Iraq is what is attracting the attention, and would put a shade -- a different shadow -- on this meeting here in Guanajuato?

PRESIDENT FOX I see no reason why we should connect one event with the other one. Here we are in the process of building up and constructing a strategy to foster the economic and human development of a complete region that is formed by three countries that have been associated under a free-trade agreement, and that the relationship between the United States and Mexico that has proven already that it has made advancements very constructively.
The levels of trade we have had are really fantastic, and they are the envy of many people. Many people have never thought that the year of 2001, with a trade balance of $250 billion -- this has meant development for the United States. It has meant employment in the United States. It has meant development and employment in Mexico, as well. 
This is what has allowed us to reduce, substantively, the level of poverty in Mexico.
In the last four years, more than four million poor people have gone beyond extreme poverty levels. This is what we have invested in, to take these people above these levels, and all the time that we have invested discussing these strategic points allow us to see that there is a possibility of going ahead to get more benefits from the relationships and to be true partners toward prosperity and to be true friends and to be true neighbors. And this purpose is something that has been clearly stated today, and we are very pleased with it and we are full of confidence that we can see the future with a more optimistic approach, as of today's meeting.

Q President Bush, if I may, another question about Iraq. As we understand it, this was in response to violations that have happened over several weeks, perhaps several months. What prompted you to take this decision at this time?

PRESIDENT BUSH The commanders on the ground rightly make the decision as to how to enforce the no-fly zone. I want to assure those who don't understand U.S. policy that this is a routine mission. Some of the missions require the commander in chief to be informed. This was such a mission. It is not the first time it has happened, regrettably so.
We will continue to enforce the no-fly zones. The no-fly zones are enforced on a daily basis. It is -- it is a part of a strategy, and until that strategy is changed, it if is changed at all, we will continue to enforce the no-fly zone.
But anyway, the decision was made on the ground.

HEADLINE: Five Haitian Senators Seek to Put End to Impasse 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Feb. 16 

 BODY:
Five senators from the governing Lavalas Family party have stopped taking part in Parliament in order to help break a political impasse that resulted from their disputed election last May, party officials said today.
 The move was an attempt to bring closer Lavalas, the party of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, and angry opposition leaders. Haiti's major opposition parties boycotted the presidential election in November to protest a tainted election in May. 
 The senators "stopped going to Parliament to support discussions between the Lavalas Family and the opposition," said Jonas Petit, a Lavalas Family spokesman. "These are the senators that should be concerned about that matter."
Haiti's latest internal political dispute arose from legislative elections held last May. International observers said election officials miscalculated the results of 6 to 10 Senate seats, giving Lavalas Family candidates outright victories when they should have been forced into runoffs.
The flawed election, which gave all but one Senate seat to Lavalas Family, angered opposition parties and Haiti's international allies. The United States and other nations asked Haiti's government to review the results and, when it refused, withdrew support for the presidential vote and withheld millions of dollars in aid.
Haiti's 7.8 million people are among the poorest in the Western Hemisphere. Eighty percent are unemployed and two-thirds are malnourished.
President Aristide, a former Roman Catholic priest who became Haiti's first democratically elected leader when he won the presidency in 1990, was sworn in for his second term on Feb. 7. He won 92 percent of the vote in the November election.
Mr. Petit said the senators' move was a show of support for Mr. Aristide and his agreement with President Clinton last December to carry out a broad range of governmental and political reforms. One measure was a re-evaluation of the disputed Senate seats.
Mr. Petit said the five senators would not participate in Parliament until they heard further word from a commission soon to be formed to evaluate the contested Senate seats. An independent senator also decided not to take part in Parliament, but his reasons were unclear.
At failed negotiations between Lavalas and the opposition and mediated by diplomats and a civil society group before the inauguration, Mr. Aristide's party proposed that a three-party commission be formed to study the senate seats.
Opposition parties have charged that Mr. Aristide, Haiti's most popular politician, is installing a new dictatorship. An opposition coalition recently formed an "alternative" government headed by a human rights activist.
Mr. Aristide rose to power a decade ago on a wave of grass-roots support but was toppled in a military coup in 1991. He lived in exile for three years before a United States-led invasion force restored him to power in 1994.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Democrats Block Attempt To Rush a Bankruptcy Bill
Democrats have blocked a Republican attempt to rush a bill through the Senate that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system and make it more difficult for people to wipe out their debts.
 The bill is championed by the banking industry but has been criticized by consumer groups as disastrous for low-income workers who will lose their jobs if the economy continues to soften. The bill is moving toward quick passage in the Republican-controlled House. Page A11. 

Steep Gain in Prices Paid Producers
Prices paid to manufacturers and other producers for their goods climbed 1.1 percent in January, marking the steepest monthly gain in more than a decade, the government reported. To some economists, the sharp rise in the Producer Price Index was a harbinger of inflation, the one key symptom that has mostly been absent from recent economic ills. If the Federal Reserve agrees, these economists worried, it may be discouraged from lowering interest rates further. C14.

A Plan for California's Power Crisis
Gov. Gray Davis of California has outlined a plan to stabilize the state's nearly bankrupt electric utilities by buying their transmission lines and letting the utilities set aside part of consumers' monthly bills to finance bonds to pay off the rest of their debts. But the governor did not put a price on the plan or offer many details, which are still subject to negotiation with the utilities. A10.

Morgan Stanley Executive Resigns
Michael L. Rankowitz, the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter executive who selected former President Bill Clinton to give a speech that later sparked a controversy, said he had resigned. Mr. Rankowitz said his decision to quit "had nothing to do" with the Clinton speech and was not demanded by Philip J. Purcell, the firm's chairman and chief executive. C2.

Talks Held on European Steel Merger
Usinor, the French steel maker, said it was in talks to merge with two European rivals, Arbed and Aceralia Corporacion Siderurgica. A deal could be reached as soon as Sunday night, with executives and directors expected to continue talks with advisers and union representatives throughout the weekend, according to people involved in the discussions. C2.

Daewoo Under Fire Over Layoffs
Daewoo Motor sent dismissal notices to 1,750 employees, beginning a long-threatened downsizing. Several hundred workers responded by protesting outside a Daewoo plant in Pupyong, 20 miles west of Seoul, as their families cheered them. The company, which was declared bankrupt and pushed into receivership by lenders in November, is under pressure to restructure and shed workers so that it can be sold to General Motors and Fiat. Creditors want one-third of the company's 16,000 jobs to be eliminated. C2.

Sotheby's Settlement Is Approved
A federal judge gave final approval to a $70 million class-action settlement between Sotheby's and shareholders who sued the auction house contending that antitrust violations still under federal investigation damaged the company and depressed its stock price. The judge approved the lawsuit agreement, which awards shareholders $30 million in cash, paid by A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's former chairman and controlling shareholder, and $40 million in company-issued Class A stock. C3.

Cuomo Joins New York Law Firm
Andrew Cuomo, the secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development under President Clinton, joined the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson. Mr. Cuomo, who recently announced his intention to run for governor of New York, will become of counsel, allowing him to pursue his political career as well. B2.

HEADLINE: U.S. Diplomats Turned Aside Israeli Push on Rich's Behalf 

BYLINE:  By JAMES RISEN with ALISON LEIGH COWAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 

 BODY:
Senior diplomats in the Clinton administration initially blocked Israeli lobbying efforts on behalf of the fugitive Marc Rich but were bypassed in the final decision-making when the president granted Mr. Rich a pardon on his last day in office, current and former United States officials said. 
 The Israeli government first approached senior American diplomats in support of Mr. Rich in 1995, the officials said. At the time, the Israeli government was not asking for a pardon for Mr. Rich but rather tacit American acceptance of a proposal to allow him to travel more freely around the globe without fear of being arrested and returned to the United States, officials said. 
 But the Israelis soon dropped the matter when they met with unified resistance from senior State Department officials. 
Israeli leaders never again raised the Rich matter with American diplomats, officials said. It was not until the final days of the Clinton administration that the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, in telephone conversations with Bill Clinton, personally asked him to pardon Mr. Rich, officials said. 
Current and former United States officials say they do not believe the matter was raised by Mr. Barak until late December or January, and they believe that was the first time the Rich case was broached in official channels since 1995.
Mr. Rich's lawyer, the former White House counsel Jack Quinn, and other defenders of Mr. Clinton's pardon of Mr. Rich have said that it grew out of Mr. Clinton's desire to help Mr. Barak and foster Middle East peace, not from political donations from Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise Rich. 
In an interview on Thursday with Geraldo Rivera, Mr. Clinton said, "Israel did influence me profoundly." 
But despite the personal requests by Mr. Barak to Mr. Clinton, clemency for Mr. Rich was never an issue in the Middle East peace talks that Mr. Clinton kept alive until he left office. 
"This was not a factor in the Middle East talks," said Dennis Ross, the Clinton administration's longtime Middle East envoy, who said he did not know about the pardon until he read about it in the newspaper after it was announced. Mr. Ross, who remained involved in Mr. Clinton's Middle East peace efforts until the final days of the administration, said that he had not been asked about the Rich pardon by the president. 
Other senior Clinton officials deeply involved in American-Israeli relations said they had not been consulted by the president, either. Through a spokeswoman, the former secretary of state, Madeleine K. Albright, said that she had not been consulted by the president about the pardon. 
George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, who played a critical role in the Israeli-Palestinian negotiations and was frequently in Israel for meetings on them, was never approached by the Israelis seeking a pardon for Mr. Rich, a spokesman said. Nor was he consulted by the president on whether to pardon Mr. Rich, the spokesman said. Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, has said he was not consulted. 
Some Justice Department officials have also complained that they were not consulted until the last minute about the Rich pardon, which was handled by the White House.
In 1995, Mr. Ross and Martin S. Indyk, the United States ambassador to Israel, both rebuffed efforts by senior Israeli officials, including the foreign minister, Shimon Peres, to persuade the United States to agree to allow Mr. Rich greater freedom of movement around the world. The Israeli officials said that Mr. Rich had proposed raising billions of dollars to help Israeli government efforts aimed at economic development of the West Bank and Gaza Strip as part of a Middle East peace agreement, and that he had said he needed to be able to travel more freely to do so. 
But after checking with State Department lawyers and the Justice Department, Mr. Ross rejected the proposal. Mr. Indyk also rebuffed the Israeli approach. 
"I had never heard of him, but I was very uneasy when I found out about Rich's background," said Mr. Ross, who recently left government. He said he turned the matter over to a State Department lawyer and never agreed to any Israeli proposals about Mr. Rich. 
Mr. Ross said he never again heard from the Israelis about Mr. Rich. He was present for conversations between Mr. Clinton and Mr. Barak at the end of Mr. Clinton's term and was aware that Mr. Clinton had told Mr. Barak he would consider his request for pardons for both Mr. Rich and the convicted Israeli spy Jonathan Pollard. 
Although Mr. Rich had the support of Mr. Barak and Mr. Peres, there was far more pressure on the White House to pardon Mr. Pollard than Mr. Rich, according to several government officials. But the White House apparently considered a pardon of Mr. Pollard impossible because of unified opposition within the United States government. In 1998, Mr. Tenet threatened to resign if Mr. Clinton bowed to Israeli pleas for clemency for Mr. Pollard.
Starting last fall, Mr. Rich also benefited from a concerted campaign by influential political figures and others in Israel to win his clemency -- a campaign less public than the one in support of Mr. Pollard. In letters they sent to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Rich's supporters offered information about his clandestine support for Mossad, the Israeli intelligence service. Among the many prominent Israelis who sent letters on behalf of Mr. Rich was Shabtai Shavit, who was chief of Mossad from 1989 to 1996. Mr. Shavit said that Mr. Rich had helped Mossad in its search for Israelis missing in action, and helped the evacuation of Jews from "enemy countries."
Mr. Rich's secret support for Israel often involved financial aid at sensitive times. According to a document provided to The New York Times by lawyers familiar with the Rich case, Mr. Rich was "instrumental" in the mid-1980's, when the relationship between Israel and Egypt suffered after an Egyptian policeman opened fire on Israeli tourists in the Sinai Desert. 
According to the document, Mr. Rich established a special $400,000 fund that was used by Egypt to compensate those Israeli families. The document also said, "Rich has also been instrumental in assisting the Israeli intelligence community in a variety of activities." The donation, which was made anonymously at the time, was also cited in a letter of support for Mr. Rich by the Israeli Foreign Minister Shlomo Ben-Ami. Mr. Rich was also a generous contributor to charitable efforts in Israel and elsewhere, donating an estimated $100 million over two decades. 
Israeli support from Mr. Rich may seem odd because he did extensive business in Iran and Iraq, two of Israel's enemies. The fugitive financier, who holds Israeli and Spanish citizenship, has lived in Switzerland since 1983, when he fled the United States after being indicted on charges of income tax evasion, fraud and illegal oil deals.
Avner Azulay, a former Mossad agent who runs Mr. Rich's charitable foundation in Israel, collected many of the letters on Mr. Rich's behalf. In an interview earlier this week, Mr. Azulay said: "He was helping evacuate Jews from countries when it was very difficult. I wouldn't be working with this man if he traded with Israel's enemies." 
United States intelligence officials say they have little information about Mr. Rich's reported involvement with Mossad. Because the State Department has not recognized Mr. Rich's efforts to renounce his citizenship, Mr. Rich is still considered a "U.S. person" and so the Central Intelligence Agency cannot legally spy on him. 
But a former C.I.A. official, Vince Cannistraro, said he was aware of Mr. Rich's Mossad connections. He said Mr. Rich's role in oil trading with Iran in the early 1980's made him attractive to Mossad as a conduit between Israel and Iran. Mr. Cannistraro said he did not believe that Mr. Rich was a paid Mossad agent but rather a wealthy international commodities trader who could provide services like carrying messages and transferring money clandestinely for operational purposes. 
"They found his ties useful in Iran," said Mr. Cannistraro, the director of intelligence programs for the National Security Council in the Reagan administration. "He was a willing collaborator." 
Today, House and Senate committees continued their investigations into the pardon. A representative of Mr. Rich's lawyer Mr. Quinn said Mr. Rich would turn down an invitation from a House committee to waive attorney-client privilege so that Mr. Quinn could testify more fully about his efforts on Mr. Rich's behalf.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
4 Candidates At the Walls Of Academe

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
THE mini-movement to get Bill Clinton to run for mayor seems to have lost all its steam, not that it had much to begin with. Can't imagine why, begging his pardon.
 So that leaves New York Democrats with the same four mayoral wannabes who have been around all along, though the number could grow should the Rev. Al Sharpton grace us with his candidacy. Thursday night provided a chance to see the present cast of characters all in a row, sort of a political equivalent to the preview of fall fashions offered this week at Bryant Park. 
 The setting was the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, in the old B. Altman building at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. The host was the Professional Staff Congress, the university's faculty union.
In alphabetical order -- a system that comes naturally to professorial types -- the candidates strutted their stuff. They were, in case you don't have the names straight yet, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president; Mark Green, the public advocate; Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller; and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker.
If ever there was an audience primed for a Democratic Restoration at City Hall, this was it.
For many at CUNY, Rudolph W. Giuliani is Ivan the Terrible, Attila the Hun and Vlad the Impaler, only less charming. They feel he has scapegoated them for too long, calling professors lazy, administrators incompetent and students half a notch short of dumb. Not surprisingly, few among the 150 or so who gathered in the Graduate Center's auditorium were about to bathe the Republican mayor in love.
The mood was set by the union's president, Barbara Bowen, who called for "a revolution in thought at the mayor's office." It was time, she said, to replace "the present regime of slander," to end the city's "calculated disinvestment" in CUNY, to reshape what had become a "politicized board of trustees" under Mr. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki.
It was, in short, a perfect arena and a perfect issue for the Democrats to pound away at Giuliani policies, free of worry that they might be seen as soft on crime or high on taxes or low on moral fiber or anything else deemed toxic in the prevailing political climate.
Pound away they did. Some of them even showed off before the crowd, using a vocabulary worthy of the SAT's but not destined for street campaigning, words and phrases like "paradigm," "remunerative," "sine qua non" and "Augean stables."
THE consensus was that Mr. Giuliani has failed New York schools, CUNY campuses included. They needed less bashing from the mayor's office and more fiscal and moral support, though no one was prepared to commit to specific dollar amounts, not in an economy that may be going wobbly.
Even at this pupa stage of the campaign, the candidates showed clearly differing styles in how they plan to deal with the inescapable shadow cast by the present steward of City Hall.
Messrs. Hevesi and Vallone, the more right-leaning Democrats, criticized Mr. Giuliani but in language not remotely inflammatory. Messrs. Ferrer and Green, tilting left, did not flinch from testing verbal bombs for possibly permanent slots in their arsenals.
"I'm not Rudy Lite," Mr. Ferrer said. "I'm not a kinder, gentler Rudy, or Rudy with a smile." As for Mr. Green, no one had to scratch his head over whom he had in mind when he denounced "government by tantrum, government by vendetta, government by enemies list."
Those lines were well received. But unintentionally, some in the audience demonstrated why Mr. Giuliani has found it easy, and politically profitable, to accuse CUNY of embracing mediocrity.
Alone among the candidates, Mr. Hevesi urged the faculty to hold students to higher standards. His appeal drew hisses. The comptroller, who once taught political science at Queens College, then suggested that professors volunteer to teach a few more hours a week -- not many, just a few. More hisses. When he said he would love to restore CUNY to its tuition-free status of long ago, but asked which municipal services people would want to cut to help pay for it, some cried, "Raise taxes."
You think maybe this was a crowd not fully in sync with the popular mood?
Still, it was a politically sophisticated group. What does it say about the dynamism of this race that the auditorium was less than half full? Sure, the election is nearly nine months away. But you knew that Bill Clinton would have filled the house.

HEADLINE: To Keep the Estate Tax, or Kill It? 

 BODY:
To the Editor: 
 You report (front page, Feb. 14) that Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor, says the estate tax promotes economic growth by helping create a society in which success is based on merit rather than on inheritance. Yet the estate tax penalizes the very thing that Americans seek through their merit: wealth. The contradiction is exquisite.
