HEADLINE: A LA CARTE; 
Great Neck Arrival Is a Step Up in Value

BYLINE:  By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM; E-mail: licarte@nytimes.com

 BODY:
REFINED, often remarkably good food at reduced prices is the story at the three-month-old Giraffe Room in the Inn at Great Neck. There have been a number of restaurants in this little hotel at 30 Cutter Mill Road (516-773-2000) in the heart of Great Neck Village -- some excellent, others disappointing and all quite expensive. This casual but still classy room, with sculptured, stuffed and carved giraffes, diverse bright china and exceptional three-course, $19.95 fixed-price dinner from Sunday through Friday ($25.95 on Saturdays), is less stuffy and far more economical than its predecessors.
 The fixed-price dinner is not a skimpy, cut-rate affair but an absolute steal of a meal, offering most of the dishes on the a la carte menu, including shrimp cocktail, she-crab soup, clams casino, prime rib of beef, salmon and seafood paella. A la carte portions were larger than those on the fixed price menu but the ones on the set meal were sufficient. Few patrons will complain about the quantity and even fewer about the quality of the food here. 
 The waiters, who knew who ordered each dish and even suggested cutting into the center of the roast beef "to be sure it's done the way you want it," the subtle Latin twists given to many offerings by Antonio Alvarado, the executive chef, and the cool jazz sounds filtering into the dining room on Wednesday through Saturday nights) from performers in the adjacent lounge -- all made dining at the Giraffe Room a lovely experience.
Patrons sit in the warm, woody, luxurious room, with its columns and sconce lighting, and tackle memorable steaks, terrific pieces of tender prime rib of beef covered with onions; flaky baked salmon in a caramelized onion crust; and a fresh red snapper with a peppy, chunky tomato-dominated sauce that enhances rather than overwhelms the fish's delicate white flesh; and memorable steaks.
The buttery filet mignon, with its seductive roasted shallot-merlot sauce, and the crusty, 14-ounce New York strip steak, with its full-bore beefy flavor and caramelized onions, were worth the additional $6.50 price. Given a boost by its mango salsa, grilled swordfish, which is often chalky-dry, was almost juicy here. Only a slightly dry cashew chicken with a drab bourbon peppercorn sauce and an otherwise exemplary paella marred by a load of dreadfully strong, old mussels (half of which didn't open) disappointed.
Appetizers were, if anything, even better than entrees. The four-piece shrimp cocktail was the equal of those at twice its price. The she-crab soup, a rich, creamy South Carolina specialty flavored with sherry and Worcestershire sauce, was as good as you'll find north of the Mason-Dixon Line. The long, slim spring rolls, given a herb-induced Southwestern spin, were worthwhile and the baby green salad, sporting crumbled goat cheese, red and yellow roasted peppers and tangy, top-notch raspberry vinaigrette, was a winner. Caesar salad, with dressing that left a bitter aftertaste, wasn't.
Those who want to dip into the a la carte menu would be well advised to try the ring of five tiny, soft meat-filled Maryland crab cakes ($6.50) or the pan-seared tuna atop a bed of soothing avocado drizzled with habanero pepper coulis that gives the fish a welcome kick.
Desserts on the fixed-price menu were small, satisfactory and limited. A warm, ripe French apple tart a la mode, a trio of mango, lemon and raspberry sorbets with a sprinkling of berries, a homey coconut custard, and especially a fresh fruit plate of sweet honeydew, pineapple and berries, all made the grade.

Openings
There will be a new eatery at the site of the former Woodshed in Bridgehampton, the Almond Bar and Restaurant, at 1970 Montauk Highway, Bridgehampton, (631-537-8885). Co-owned by Eric Lemonides and Jason Weiner, the chef, Almond will be a modern French bistro. Mr. Lemonides is a veteran of both Manhattan and the East End, who most recently sold his restaurant, Lunch, on the West Side of lower Manhattan. He also was a maitre d'hotel at Della Femina, Karen Lee's and Pacific East. Mr. Weiner was the executive sous chef at Aqua in the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas. He was also a chef at Charles Nob Hill in San Francisco after leaving Manhattan's China Grill and was the sous chef at Nick & Toni's during the summer of 1997. At Almond, classic bistro entrees like steak frites, snapper Provencal and roast chicken will be in the $14 to $19 range. It will also offer sandwiches like the croque monsieur, fish po' boy and a burger.

HEADLINE: An Intricate Bond; 
New Haven's Past and Future Are So Tied to Yale, but It Took 300 Years for the Two to Get Along

BYLINE:  By ELISSA GOOTMAN 

 BODY:
FROM behind the wheel of his silver Lincoln Town Car, Bruce Alexander turned left onto Winchester Avenue, a humble pockmarked strip that is something of a crossroad for the city of New Haven.
 To his right was a low-slung white building that houses what remains of the Winchester Repeating Arms company, once the core of the New Haven economy and one of the city's largest employers. 
 To his left was a cluster of brick office buildings with tall windows, buildings that host a smattering of biotechnology companies that Yale University spawned and that its officials say represent the new heights to which Yale has taken its commitment to the city.
For all the street's lack of aesthetic glory, Winchester Avenue, no less than the stunning Sterling Memorial Library or the well-preserved town green, tells the story of New Haven at a time when the city's Ivy League centerpiece is marking its tercentennial. And Mr. Alexander, one of Yale's seven officers and its first to focus exclusively on the university's relations with New Haven, represents the face of Yale as it assumes a greater role in the life of its oft-maligned, and at times deeply depressed, host city. 
Since New Haven outbid Hartford as home to the Collegiate School in 1716, the city and the university have become so interwoven that it is difficult to imagine one without the other. Yale, which now owns about 7 percent of all the land in the city, is its biggest employer and third-largest taxpayer. City government is stocked with Yalies: The head of the housing authority, Robert A. Solomon, is a Yale Law School professor, and Henry J. Fernandez, a graduate of the law school, is the city's economic development administrator.
Yale's significance to New Haven has ripened in the last three centuries, and what was once a feather in the cap of the local leadership has arguably emerged as the force saving New Haven from the fate of other East Coast cities abandoned by industry and grasping about for a future. 
"Bridgeport is New Haven without Yale," said Robert J. Leeney, editor emeritus of The New Haven Register.
"It's located in pretty much the same way. It was an old port," he said, adding, "The Yale presence always did something here."
Well, not always. For years, the university kept its distance from the city, not getting too involved, pretty much letting its host fend for itself. When Susan L. Hartt, the executive director of Market New Haven, told her father, Julian N. Hartt, the 89-year-old former chairman of the Yale Department of Religious Studies, that the university was starting to pay attention to the community, he told her: "Well, it's about time. It only took them about 295 years."
University officials have heralded the arrival of its president Richard C. Levin in 1993 and his appointment of Mr. Alexander in 1997 as one sign of the sea-change in Yale's approach to the world outside its imposing iron gates. Indeed, in recent years Yale has committed $10 million toward subsidies for university employees buying homes within city limits. Through taxable property like a golf course and retail strips, the university has become among the highest taxpayers in the city. 
And in what may prove to be the most impactive development, the university is nurturing the nexus of science and business to create a biotechnology sector that has already brought millions of dollars and hundreds of jobs into town.
"Yale at first did not understand that it had to fill in the gap when those industries and businesses left," said Mr. Alexander, formerly an executive with the Rouse Corporation, where he oversaw the development of Manhattan's South Street Seaport and Harborplace in Baltimore. "I don't know that the university was prepared for that role. I don't think the leadership of the university saw themselves in those terms."
Despite its academic eminence, Yale has not been able to solve New Haven's problems. In some cases, residents have accused the university of being the problem; it has had years of acrimonious labor disputes, and in other cases, the very existence of a bastion of privilege has infuriated the city's impoverished elements by the sheer power of contrast. Nonetheless, the 1,600 pounds and the offer of prime space along the town green that lured Yale here under 300 years ago have proved a priceless investment, and may yet be the city's saving grace. 
"The city isn't going to be healthy unless the people who live here and near here and work here celebrate the city," Ms. Hartt said. The university's involvement "is an expression of the change in Yale's attitude toward its homeland."
And the change in attitude of its homeland toward Yale. When Mayor Richard C. Lee ran for re-election in 1955, his opponent, Phil Mancini, circulated a cartoon depicting the mayor as Yale's quarterback. "Let's Win New Haven Back From Yale," the caption read. Although Mr. Mancini lost, the campaign highlighted a resentment, a sense that Yale's gain was the city's loss. It is a sense that seems to have diminished over time, but has not quite disappeared. 
"There are always people who will hate Harvard; there are always people who will hate Yale," Mr. Lee said in an interview at his Hamden home. "I cannot think of anything where the university was a minus factor."
Today's politics are a world away. Mayor John DeStefano Jr. sees his job as championing Yale, not fighting it. "It's not like in a mayoral campaign anymore you can run against Yale," Mr. DeStefano said. "It doesn't sell anymore."
It doesn't sell, in part, because Yale owns 800 of the city's 12,000 acres and employs 10,000 people.
And so in about 1995, when Mr. Levin, the Yale president, asked the mayor if the university could buy space in the center of town that houses the Whitney Grove Square office building, Mr. DeStefano consented. "It allows my largest employer to grow," he said. "You want your largest employer to grow."
When your largest employer is tax exempt, its growth can make for a mixed fortune, a predicament that was mitigated with passage of the state's payment in lieu of taxes program in 1978. Under the program, which university lobbyists helped push through, the state now pays New Haven 75 percent of what it would collect were educational institutions taxed.
Yale itself paid $2 million in taxes last year on nonexempt properties, plus $2 million for fire service.
Shifts in the tax arrangement have bolstered the city's coffers and the university's reputation, minimizing the disincentives to Yale's growth. Beyond budget lines, though, Yale has and continues to shape New Haven in ways that cannot be quantified, creating a town-gown synthesis that is increasingly deliberate, strategic and serious.
Across the country, universities have been investing in their host communities with renewed vigor, particularly when those communities are less idyllic than, say, Hanover, N.H. or Williamstown, Mass. The good business sense of this approach is clear: Applications dropped between 15 percent and 20 percent, for example, in the two-year period after the sophomore Christian H. Prince was murdered on his way home from an on-campus party. 
"I think that was a true wake-up call for us to recognize the need to be attentive to our larger environment," said Linda K. Lorimer, a vice president and secretary of the university and a trustee at the time of the murder.
A longtime New Haven resident who raised his children here, Mr. Levin, Yale's president, has steered the university on a course that stretches beyond adherence to a national trend. An economist known for his approachable manner, Mr. Levin has won over many longtime critics of the university, and under his leadership Yale has buttressed its commitment to the city with financial investments.
As recently as five years ago, William G. Battle, the director of the Newhallville Restoration Corporation, considered himself a "severe critic" of Yale.
"My biggest complaint now is that they don't do enough," Mr. Battle said. "Yale is very much like an inconstant mistress. You love her, but you've sure got to watch her all the time.
"If they're not well-guided by a president like President Levin, they can be very, very intrusive," he said.
When Mr. Levin arrived as a graduate student in 1970, New Haven was resisting Yale's requests to build two new residential colleges, and relations were "fairly rocky," he recalled. 
"I think that had to do largely with Yale's lack of attention to building the kind of relationship that would have made that something welcomed by the city instead of something that seemed threatening," he said. 
As president, Mr. Levin has tried to "routinize a close connection" with the city by urging new deans and directors to develop programs with an outreach component, for example, and uniting downtown merchants behind a voluntary added tax.
"We've sort of taken our seat at the table and played the role that a good corporate citizen would normally play in a small or medium-sized city, as a source of advice and counsel and often a partner in investment," he said.
Take the university's home buyer program, in which Yale employees who buy houses in town receive $25,000 over 10 years. Since 1994, 441 people have bought homes worth more than $50 million through the program, according to university figures. In recent years, 80 percent have been first-time home buyers, officials said.
While faculty housing subsidies are not uncommon, they are generally seen as a perk to lure professors and off-set high living costs. By extending the benefit to blue-collar workers and excluding New Haven's most exclusive areas, Yale has signaled that its initiative is intended less as a benefit for employees than an attempt to stabilize New Haven.
"Yale is trying to get you to buy in certain neighborhoods that will help the city," said Barbara L. Pearce, the president of H. Pearce Company Realtors. "If you want to buy in a downtown neighborhood now which is very high-end, they're not going to help you do that."
In the 20 years that have passed since Ms. Pearce returned to her hometown after attending Harvard, the change in Yale's approach to the city has been palpable. Fifteen years ago she headed an association of local business leaders, many of whom were wary of giving Yale a seat at the table because the university, they felt, did not share the private sector's concerns.
"The expectation now is if something goes on in New Haven, Yale will step up to the plate, and they'll give as much or more as anybody else," Ms. Pearce said. 
Yale's recent $200,000 contribution to a fund-raising drive for arts organizations was more generous than any corporation's, for example, and the university has committed $750,000 to a marketing campaign geared toward residents and tourists.
Also, hundreds of children benefit from academic and extracurricular programs such as the Leadership, Education and Athletics in Partnership initiative and the Amistad Academy charter school, which Yale students helped envision and establish. 
More concrete are the physical manifestations of Yale's presence in New Haven. Yale has dislodged veteran tenants in favor of lucrative chains (think Yale Co-op vs. Barnes & Noble), but it has also converted rubble-cluttered lots into heavily trafficked hot spots. Yale helped the embattled Dwight neighborhood secure a new Shaw's supermarket, the first supermarket chain to open a branch in downtown New Haven in 30 years.
The anti-gentrification cries that have at times greeted the university's attempts to reconfigure, revamp and refurbish seem to be less vocal these days, but some community leaders remain wary.
The Rev. Scott D. Marks, the lead organizer for the Connecticut Center for a New Economy, a community organization that supports labor unions, said he was ambivalent about Yale's gentrifying influence.
"You can sort of smell the wealth of Yale simmering over to the poor sections of this city," he said, riding past a strip of ramshackle houses, some lived in and others boarded up. "If biotech comes to the city and dominates in the way that they say, eventually this will become very expensive property," he said, asking of the residents: "Where on earth are they going?"
"Somewhere there needs to be a glimmer of the hope that's being kicked around by the university in the poorer areas," he said. "Yale didn't just show up here. They've been here, and they've sort of watched this happen to a city."
Yet when it comes to the Broadway area, where Yale replaced longtime local storeowners who could not afford rising rents in favor of chains, which could, Mr. Marks acknowledged the advantages of the newcomers. "I always support the creation of jobs," he said.
The people most upset about the changes on Broadway seem to be the alumni, who harbor a nostalgia for haunts like the Quality Wine Shop and the Yale Co-op. Now the block is dominated by Barnes & Noble, with Urban Outfitters on the way.
Others point out that Yale is hardly the first landlord to raise rents, and that the benefits of development outweigh the downsides of gentrification.
"It's sort of like saying, gee, the suburbs are being developed," said Mr. Solomon of the Housing Authority. "Yale is the advantage that New Haven has over other cities that would deteriorate but for someone as wealthy as Yale.
These days, business more often than not means the biotechnology boom, which is old news in places like Palo Alto, Calif., and Cambridge, Mass. Yale was slow to react, though, its officials adhering to a purist line and frowning on entrepreneurial alliances. 
That attitude began to change a few years ago, and last year Yale spinoffs raised more than $1 billion in private equity placements and created 1,000 new jobs, said E. Jonathan Soderstrom, managing director of Yale's Office of Cooperative Research. Eighteen biotech companies, six of which are publicly traded, have headquarters in New Haven, and three or four more are expected to begin this year. 
They might settle in Science Park, the nascent biotechnology hub across from the drastically downsized Winchester Repeating Arms. 
While some doubt the viability of the area, which borders blighted neighborhoods and initially failed to attract clients, several developers with sterling track records are betting on its future.
Lyme Properties plans to spend about $200 million to renovate the abandoned Winchester headquarters and, if the demand exists, another $300 million to build a new 1.5 million square-foot complex that will hold a combination of biotechnology and other companies.
"There is absolutely no question that we would not have decided to do this project were it not for the presence of Yale," said David Clem, a managing partner at Lyme.
But even if biotech does take, will it raise the city's poorer populations? 
"It makes New Haven a vibrant city, but it still leaves a group of people who need to be fully trained," said Kevin Rakin, the president and chief financial officer of Genaissance Pharmaceuticals, the largest biotech company in the area. "That is just the reality of a new economy company."
Which is why Mr. Battle, who sits on the board of Science Park, fought hard to have light industry included in the building plans and is considering how he might urge Yale to help train biotechnicians.
"We've had knock-down drag-outs, but I think we've come to a meeting of the minds," he said. "This may be the first time that certain things that are good for Yale are also good for the neighborhoods."

HEADLINE: In Baltimore's West Side, Preservation Story Unfolds 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES BELFOURE 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE 

 BODY:
TWO and half years ago a development plan that would have demolished hundreds of buildings in Baltimore and filled the cleared area with retail stores, parking garages and residential projects, seemed inevitable.
 The structures that faced demolition included many historic buildings, ranging from Federal-style row houses to an Art Deco store. But the plan involved a section of the city in deep decline, and it had the support of an impressive roster of public agencies and private interests. 
 Now, however, that strategy, known as the West Side Master Plan, has been abandoned. On Jan. 8 an agreement was signed between the city and the Maryland Historical Trust, the state's preservation agency, to scrap the original plan and approach development with an eye toward preserving the neighborhood. 
The new approach, which came about largely through the efforts of two groups, Preservation Maryland and Baltimore Heritage, will protect more than half of the historic buildings in the 28 blocks that make up the Market Center Urban Renewal Area.
For preservation advocates, the agreement is a milestone in the way in which cities handle redevelopment, using preservation instead of a bulldozer.
"This is the largest revitalization plan of its kind in the country," said Richard Moe, president of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, who worked with the groups to revise the development plan.
The plan has been changed to preserve 270 buildings out of about 400 with an additional 105 to be reviewed case by case. The remainder are likely to be demolished. The agreement also calls for any new construction to be aesthetically compatible with the neighborhood.
In addition, in any development proposals, the city must require the preservation of the designated buildings, most of which are late 19th century and early 20th century commercial structures. Among the buildings to be preserved are an S. S. Kresge Company store, which was built in 1938 and is one of the few Art Deco structures in downtown, and four other buildings with cast iron facades, including the city's most ornate, the Alberti, Brink & Company building, which was erected in 1867.
The Market Center Renewal Area straddles Howard Street, once Baltimore's most elite shopping thoroughfare, and extends west to Lexington Market and the Baltimore campus of the University of Maryland. The project is expected to cost $355 million while creating 2,500 parking spaces, 350,000 square feet of retail space and 500,000 square feet of residential space. 
Two projects -- the $56 million renovation of the Hippodrome Theater and Bank of America's Center Point project, a $50 million development of retail and residential space -- are scheduled to begin this spring. Projects that are already under way include a $12 million conversion of the former Hecht's department store into apartments and a $15 million conversion of the former Stewarts department store into a "telecom hotel," which contains space rented by telecommunication and Internet companies to house their equipment. 
The battle to preserve the area started in 1998 when the renovation plan was originally unveiled. The plan was financed not by the city but by one of the West Side's biggest property owners, the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation, a charitable trust. Harry Weinberg, an investor who died in 1990, bought up buildings in the late 1970's when the area was in decline. The foundation, which has assets of $2.5 billion, owns the Stewarts building. The plan recommended demolition for residential buildings, parking garages and "big box" retailers like T. J. Maxx and the Sports Authority. About 150 historic buildings were threatened with condemnation. 
IT was not just the destruction of the buildings but also the suburbanlike solution in the heart of downtown that dismayed residents wanting to preserve the neighborhood. Another crucial issue was the displacement of more than 100 small merchants.
"The plan responded to what the city wanted at that time," said Bernard Siegal, president of the Weinberg Foundation, which, with the University of Maryland and the Baltimore Development Corporation, helped to develop the renovation plan. 
Mr. Siegal said the mayor at the time, Kurt L. Schmoke, wanted to renovate the area quickly and change the character of the neighborhood. Along with the merchants, members of Preservation Maryland and Baltimore Heritage were among the few who spoke against the plan at the time. 
"It was definitely a David and Goliath battle," said Tyler Gearhart, executive director of Preservation Maryland. "No one initially paid any attention to us."
But gradually, the preservation groups built opposition, initially by unveiling a preservation-based development proposal that stressed two issues: the high cost of city acquisition and the economic benefits of using federal and state tax credits to preserve the neighborhood.
The National Trust entered the picture in June 1999 when it named the West Side as one of America's 11 Most Endangered Historic Places. At the same time, Preservation Maryland and Baltimore Heritage were surveying the buildings and putting together a nomination for the National Register of Historic Places.
But it was a 10-minute film, "Baltimore's West Side Story," that played an important role in turning the tide in favor of preservation explaining what would be lost if the plan went ahead. In January 2000, the film was shown before the feature film at the Senator Theater, the only remaining Art Deco movie theater in the city. 
About the same time, preservation advocates received another break. The new mayor, Martin J. O'Malley, had voted against the redevelopment plan as a city councilman. 
"O'Malley was a great ally," Mr. Gearhart said, "who understood there had to be a balance between preservation and new development."
Then in February 2000, part of the West Side was listed on the National Register, creating the Market Center Historic District, which largely coincided with the renewal area.
IN the end, State Senator Barbara A. Hoffman of Baltimore became a crucial ally. In April 2000, Senator Hoffman attached language to a bill financing the renovation of the Hippodrome that required the city to minimize demolition and offer fair financial packages to displaced merchants. That requirement led to last month's agreement along with a revised master plan.
"Historic buildings are what make a city different," Senator Hoffman said. "You can go anywhere and see a shopping mall."
The Hippodrome is considered the catalyst to the success of the entire project. The 2,300-seat vaudeville theater, built in 1914 and vacant since the early 1980's, will be combined with two adjacent late 19th century banks into a venue for Broadway-style shows. The Hippodrome block is next to the campus of the University of Maryland and is expected to be the crucial link between the rejuvenated neighborhood and the university. 
While the western edge of downtown Baltimore deteriorated, the university stayed and expanded, and both plans envision the university campus as an anchor in the neighborhood.
The new agreement means some projects like the Weinberg Foundation's proposed $150 million retail development along Lexington Street will have to be redesigned. But Mr. Siegal of the foundation is unperturbed. 
"The city's requirements have changed, and we're working to come up with a plan," he said. "One or two buildings at a time will be converted and leased."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Renovation of the Hippodrome Theater, left, is to begin in the spring. (Marty Katz for The New York Times) Map of Baltimore highlighting Market Center Urban Renewal Area.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Building at 75 Varick Street, Now 1 Hudson Square; 
A Landlord's Subtractions Lead to an Addition

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
NEW YORK CITY'S zoning rules limit the size of buildings that can be constructed on a given site. But a close reading of those rules can sometimes produce an unexpected benefit for landlords, particularly when an older building is being renovated for a more modern use.
 That is what is about to happen at the light-industrial building once known as 75 Varick Street. The owner, Trinity Real Estate, has renamed the 1.2 million square foot building between Grand and Canal Streets, calling it 1 Hudson Square, and is renovating it for office tenants, rather than for the printing companies it has housed since it was completed in 1930. 
 In the printing days, air-conditioning was limited to a few window units in the boss's office. But office tenants, paying annual rents in the mid-$40's to the mid-$50's per square foot in that part of town, can be expected to want plenty of cool filtered air. So Paul J. Rosen of Rosen Johnson Architects, the architect for the renovation, has designed three mechanical rooms on each of the building's 17 existing floors to supply air-conditioning. 
The rooms average about 1,000 square feet each. That means that about 50,000 square feet of what was formerly rentable space in the building has been set aside for infrastructure. Under zoning rules, because the space is no longer available for rent, it can be deducted from the building's allowable bulk, or floor-area ratio (for example, a building on a 15,000-square-foot lot with a floor-area ratio of 5 can have 75,000 square feet of space).
With 50,000 square feet of new space available to be built, the architects and Trinity officials have decided to add two floors of what is likely to be highly desirable penthouse space to the top of the building. The new 18th and 19th floors, each 25,000 square feet, will be combined with the now-vacant 17th floor to create a glass-walled triplex intended for executive tenants.
Because most of the buildings on the west side of Manhattan just north of Canal Street are relatively low-rise, the new floors will have good views of the rest of the city, New York harbor and the New Jersey coastline.
"It is going to be very dramatic space," said Joseph T. Palombi, executive vice president of Trinity Real Estate, which is owned by the Parish of Trinity Church, at Broadway and Wall Street. "The 18th floor will have a slab-to-slab height of 20 feet and the 19th floor will be 15 1/2 feet high," he said. (Typical floor heights in steel-framed buildings are 12 to 13 feet.)
The conversion of 75 Varick Street to 1 Hudson Square is part of Trinity's program of transforming many of the industrial buildings it acquired during the Depression of the 1930's to office use to tap into the city's seemingly relentless demand for office space.
TRINITY is putting $50 million into the building, which is the southern anchor of its properties in what it is calling the Hudson Square section of Manhattan. Brokers active in the area said that that part of the city had been so designated on old maps, but that the term had fallen into disuse when the area was remapped and the streets named for historical figures such as Richard Varick, mayor of New York City from 1789 to 1801; Rip Van Dam, a Dutch-era governor; and William Houston, a delegate to the Continental Congress. Trinity said it revived the name as a way of creating a sense of community for a neighborhood making the transition from industrial to office use.
"Young people like the SoHo-like quality of the area," said Daniel O. Horowitz, a senior managing director of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage firm that represents tenants. Mr. Horowitz, who recently arranged to move an e-commerce consulting company called Novo into nearby 10 Hudson Square, said that these are the type of tenants who provide special rooms for employees to hang their bicycles after riding to work.
Converting the building involved installing all new windows to muffle the rumble of traffic entering and leaving the Holland Tunnel and adding a special scrubber to cleanse incoming air of automotive pollutants, said Mr. Rosen, the architect. "The building had no central HVAC," he said, referring to the shorthand for heating, ventilation and air-conditioning.
He said the decision was to locate the air-distribution units deep in the interior of the floors, some of which are as big as 70,000 square feet, and to put the equivalent space on top of the building. "We took the worst space deep in the building and put it on the roof where it is the best space," Mr. Rosen said.
ALTHOUGH the addition is permitted by the zoning rules, Mr. Rosen said that convincing the city's Buildings Department that the two new floors were justified was "a long process." He said other building owners had used similar tactics to use less desirable space for mechanical functions so they could add a floor on the top of a building or enlarge a mezzanine level.
But he said that not all buildings legally eligible for such alterations were capable of doing so because some lack a structure sufficiently robust to support the additional loads. Even 1 Hudson Square, whose industrial-strength floors are capable of supporting 300 pounds per square foot (compared to less than 100 pounds a square foot for a modern office building) will need reinforcement for some of the columns on its upper levels to support the weight of the new floors.
Because of the demand for office space and the near-record rentals now being paid, Mr. Rosen said, most building owners are checking to be sure that their buildings are built to the full floor-area ratio allowance and if there is any opportunity to use mechanical alterations to add more desirable space. But, he said, in many cases the amount of space that could be added was not economical because of the high cost of construction.
Mr. Palombi of Trinity said the reinforcing work at 1 Hudson Square would take place in the next 45 days, after which construction of the new floors would begin. He said the company would be able to deliver the space to tenants within 12 months. The new floors, he added, will be the "crown" of the building.
Mr. Palombi said that because of the building's proximity to Canal Street and the Holland Tunnel, a decision was made not to draw air in from anywhere near the street, but to concentrate the air intakes and cooling towers on top of an existing mechanical penthouse on the roof. By taking air in from the roof and chemically scrubbing it, the air fed into the offices in the remodeled building will be cleaner than the air in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Rosen said. Additional vertical shafts were added to the building to assist in air distribution.
The existing mechanical penthouse, whose roof is 35 feet higher than the rest of the building, will be partly demolished and incorporated into the new 18th and 19th floors, Mr. Rosen said.
The conversion process included enlarging and remodeling the decidedly modest existing lobby of the building and the conversion of five freight elevators for passenger use. The existing passenger elevators also were furnished with new cabs.
Mr. Rosen described the building's existing electrical system as the equivalent of a bunch of extension cords. That is all being replaced with new aboveground transformer vaults for additional power and new electrical closets. In addition to new vertical shafts for air, risers were added for fiber-optic telecommunications and Internet access.
Mr. Horowitz of Julien J. Studley said that landlords in many parts of the city have tried to gain an advantage within the zoning rules. "On Park Avenue, some buildings have had space shaved off lower floors to add to the top," he said. "One Hudson Square is a version of that; you create premium space by reallocating space."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Building at 1 Hudson Square is to have two new floors added on top. Paul J. Rosen (left) and Anthony E. Johnson, the project architects. (Rosen Johnson Architects); (Steve Hart for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Berlin, a Road With an Identity Crisis 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA WEISS 

 BODY:
YOU can find almost everything on the Berlin Turnpike in Berlin, from live lobsters to live adult entertainment. One thing you can't find, however, is a road sign that reads "Berlin Turnpike." They all bear the road's official name, Wilbur Cross Highway.
 Most people in town call the road the Berlin Turnpike. Oddly, in Newington, to the north, and Meriden, to the south, that is its lawful name. But not in Berlin. There, the thoroughfare formed by Routes 5 and 15 is named for Wilbur Cross, a former Connecticut governor. 
 That may change soon if local officials and business owners have their way. They have pushed a measure in the State Legislature to change the name and a town meeting to discuss the issue is scheduled for Wednesday night. They believe naming the road consistently after their town would alleviate the complications that arise when one man's Berlin Turnpike is another man's Wilbur Cross Highway. 
"People, especially in this part of the state, have no clue what the Wilbur Cross is," said Bonnie Therrien, the town manager. Residents refer to the road as the Berlin Turnpike so routinely, she said, that many businesses list that address on their letterheads. Making that name official only makes sense to her.
"It would just seem natural that Berlin have the Berlin Turnpike going through it," Ms. Therrien said. "You should have the main drag that runs through your town named for you."
Thomas Stregowski, chairman of the town's Economic Development Commission, said he also favors the change. "I'm totally convinced it should be called the Berlin Turnpike," Mr. Stregowski said. "It's the town of Berlin. It represents the town of Berlin. Wilbur Cross was a prominent gentleman, but it doesn't do anything for the town."
Any prospective change would not be implemented for about a year, Mr. Stregowski said, so that local companies can deplete their inventory of old business cards and stationery. He expected that renaming the road will help promote local industry. "It sort of gives us a piece of identity," Mr. Stregowski said.
That identity is what makes the name change so crucial to Edward Egazarian, the local businessman who initiated the crusade. To him, the new name evokes the old days, when the Berlin Turnpike had enough name recognition to rival legendary Route 66.
"In the 50's and 60's, this was 'The Strip,' " Mr. Egazarian said. "Everyone in the state used to bring their hot rods to the 'pike to race or just drive up and down."
Mr. Egazarian is a man of such single-minded vision that Delicious Dogs, the luncheonette he runs on the highway, has only one item on the menu. He bought the land and began parking his silver hot dog-vending truck there back in 1985, when one of his franks cost 75 cents. (It now runs $1.75.) He later built Ridgeway Plaza, a commercial building in which his stand occupies a back corner, because he said he believed in the future of the highway. But he also believed in its past. 
Mr. Egazarian recalled the time a few decades ago when the highway was lined with motels, shops and restaurants, luring travelers to such attractions as a "sock hop," where roller-skating waitresses served burgers on trays they hooked to car windows. "This was basically the oasis between New York and Boston," he said.
Glenna Grelak also waxes wonderfully nostalgic for the turnpike's glory days. "Twenty-five years ago, this was Restaurant Row," said Ms. Grelak, whose family has owned the Hawthorne Inn, a restaurant on the highway, for 54 years. Along with the inn, dining options included a Manero's steak house, several Chinese restaurants and the local hot spot the Wonder Bar, she said. 
There was also enough activity to draw hordes of high school kids and young adults, Ms. Grelak said. "But they wouldn't say, 'Let's hang out on the Wilbur Cross Highway.' It was 'Let's hang out on the Berlin Turnpike.' "
This is not to suggest that Berlin's historic highway has always taken the high road. David Wattington of Waterford, a lunchtime customer at Mr. Egazarian's hot dog stand, recalled being drawn to the road in his youth for its rather randy reputation.
"I remember breaking away with all my high school buddies to go to the Berlin Turnpike in the 60's," Mr. Wattington said. "We thought it was a big deal. That's where all the strip joints were."
Built in 1717, the road was originally called the Hartford-New Haven Path, said Kathleen Murray, a volunteer in the local history room at the Berlin Peck Memorial Library. The road was just a cow path. By 1799, it had become the Hartford-New Haven Turnpike. The adjoining highway, which runs from the Housatonic River Bridge in Stratford to Route 5 in Meriden, was designated the Wilbur Cross Parkway in 1937. Neither she nor the State Department of Transportation knew when the section in Berlin was named for Governor Cross.
That honor may have kept his name alive, but not necessarily his reputation. Of more than a dozen people questioned earlier this month, not one could say who he was or anything about him.
"I know I read it. Twice," said Bogdan Burchardt, owner of a sign-making company on the highway. "I just don't remember."
Mr. Borchardt, who also favored a name change, is less concerned that people know who Mr. Cross was than where his highway is. "Most of my customers, when I tell them I'm on the Wilbur Cross Highway, they can't find it," he said. As a result, he uses two different business addresses. His business cards say he is located at 1662 Wilbur Cross Highway, but he gives out-of-towners refrigerator magnets that place him at 1662 Berlin Turnpike.
(Mr. Borchardt is another example of popular vernacular triumphing over proper names. His company is called Signs by Computer Works, but people commonly refer to it as Berlin Sign. And although his given first name is Bogdan, everyone calls him Danny.)
To give the highway the name by which it is already popularly known, no state mandate is necessary, said James Mahoney, economic development director for the town of Berlin. The transportation department researched the matter and has assured him that the name was never officially sanctioned by the state in the first place.
"We conferred with the state, and they concurred with us that they don't see any record of this being named by the legislature as the Wilbur Cross Highway," Mr. Mahoney said.
Even so, town officials have enlisted Ann Dandrow, a state representative from Berlin and Southington, to sponsor House Bill No. 5897 in the State Legislature. Scheduled to be voted on during the current legislative session, the bill will not only formalize the name change, but also preempt any future attempts to have the road renamed for someone else.
"We do have a penchant for naming highways in Connecticut," said Mr. Mahoney. They include the Taras Shevchenko Expressway, on Route 9 in Newington, and the Thaddeus Kosciuszko Highway, on Route 72 in New Britain.
Even if the bill were not to pass, Berlin is free to rename the road within its borders if it wants to. Mr. Mahoney said the Town Council is likely to approve the change if no local business owners or residents object. And so far, no one has.
Ultimately, a road by any other name is bound to smell as sweet, especially when you add the irresistible aroma of hot dogs on a grill. Just past 3 one recent Friday, a man in a faded plaid flannel shirt and jeans stepped up to the takeout window at Delicious Dogs. The customer, Joseph Serra, insisted that the road he was standing alongside was the Berlin Turnpike.
"The Wilbur Cross doesn't start until the stoplights end," Mr. Serra said. "Pass the stoplights, you can't use a commercial vehicle anymore."
Mr. Serra also had his own version of what Mr. Egazarian's restaurant is called. "No one knows this as Delicious Dogs. It's Eddie's," he said. "I always tell people, 'Want a great hot dog? Go to Eddie's on the Berlin Turnpike.' "

GRAPHIC: Photos: Edward Egazarian, a local businessman, initiated the crusade to rename the Wilbur Cross Highway, above, the Berlin Turnpike, which it is more commonly called. (Photographs by George Ruhe for The New York Times); A sign bearing the road's official name could some day change in Berlin officials and business owners get their wish in the State Legislature.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
The Dot-Com Jobless, at Play

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT is hard to feel too sorry for some of the unemployed masses of young people. Sure, it is sad that their dot-com dreams have ended. And it is unfortunate that their stock options are worthless.
 But pity them? Many of them are having entirely too much fun. 
 Yes, the boys and girls of Silicon Valley and other dot-com centers are taking their severance money and doing all sorts of exciting things now that they are jobless: traveling, renovating homes, going back to school or reveling in happy relationships. It's amazing what the dot-com downturn has done for their social lives.
Alli Ehrenberg, 28, and Myles Weissleder, 30, are engaged to be married in September -- hardly a possibility when Ms. Ehrenberg was working long hours as a brand manager at Addis.com, a design firm in the San Francisco Bay area.
"Who had the time?" she asked. "Losing my job was the best thing that could have happened to us as a couple and for me personally. I'm not stressed. I'm not worried. I can enjoy our time together instead of always thinking about work." Ms. Ehrenberg now spends her days planning her wedding, doing yoga and sleeping in. Mr. Weissleder runs a small Internet marketing company. 
Michael Feinstein is also enjoying his free time. At 26, he is the newly deposed director for business development at the now-defunct Bigwords.com, which sold college textbooks at a discount.
The way he sees it, the recent layoffs have only enhanced his personal life, and those of his high-tech comrades. "Right after we folded, two out of our three founders got engaged, one to the former C.E.O. of Petopia.com, which also failed," said Mr. Feinstein, who lives in San Francisco and is now vacationing in Southeast Asia. "Another is on the verge. My old roommate was having a long-distance relationship with a woman in New York, but after his company fell apart he asked her to move out here." She did, he said. 
Mr. Feinstein used to attend galas to introduce the newest or coolest in Web sites, gadgets or marketing concepts. Now he attends more intimate dinner parties. And people are not talking only about initial public offerings and business plans. 
"Night life used to be very homogeneous," he said. "It had a shallow feel to it -- young kids celebrating the fact that they were making money. The failure has almost brought them down to earth. People are talking about real things, exploring different ideas. It's actually interesting going out now."
Mr. Feinstein's relationship with his girlfriend, Melinda Smith, 24, a San Francisco writer whom he has been dating since last summer, has also flourished. Before his company folded, the couple were relegated to weekend and late-night dates, "but now we can hang out during the week," he said. 
One possible pitfall is that his newfound freedom may give him time to stray. "There's more opportunity for temptation because I'm exposed to more people now," he said. Still, for the most part, his unemployment has turned a casual romance more serious.
The explanation is up for debate. Mr. Feinstein, who is applying to business school, says it has to do with the need for stability in a generally unstable world, where so many young people have tied their sense of self-worth to their careers. "When someone loses a job, they often feel insecure and need something to hold on to -- an anchor," he said. "What's better than a relationship?"
PERHAPS, but it may be even deeper. Maybe these people who have spent the past two years locked in an office are realizing some things that older workers already know: that there is more to life than a computer and a mouse, that live, not virtual, connections matter, and that stock options do not. These young people may be having their midlife crises early.
Of course, not every story has a happy ending. Jennifer Thompson's relationship ended after her boyfriend's dot-com company did. "I was devastated, but I couldn't compete with his job," said Ms. Thompson, 29, a graphic designer in Manhattan.
As for Ms. Ehrenberg and Mr. Weissleder, they intend to enjoy their free time together as long as the money holds out. Ms. Ehrenberg wants her next career to offer a change in direction -- hopefully less stressful and with flexible hours. "There's more to life than just work," she said.

HEADLINE: Plenty of Students, Not Enough Staff 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA NUSSBAUM 

 BODY:
LAST winter, school administrators in Hopewell began a search for someone to teach physics and chemistry. After months of digging through files, advertising in newspapers and magazines and even holding a job fair, they finally got lucky.
 But in June, the teacher called to say he had accepted a position at another high school that was more conveniently located. The search for a science teacher at the Hopewell Valley Central High School -- a job that pays from $37,000 to $55,000 -- started all over again. 
 "He probably found four more jobs," said Patricia Priesing, a human resources supervisor in the upper-middle-class district. "We are getting massacred. We have a terrible time finding teachers in math, science, world languages and special education. We don't know what we'll do next year. We're going to lose some people to retirements, and math and science teachers are scarcer than hen's teeth." 
Around the state -- as in much of the country -- this scene is playing out repeatedly because of a bulge in enrollment in the lower grades, called the Baby Boom echo, an aging teaching force and an inability to retain teachers because of low salaries and enticing jobs in technology businesses.
Finding qualified people to teach high school math, science, technology and special education classes is particularly hard. And the pool of applicants for administrators, guidance counselors, school nurses and librarians is also shriveling.
In New Jersey -- where state testing for fourth and eighth graders will soon include a section on a foreign language -- schools are scrambling to find teachers. In fact, some districts are already delaying language training in the elementary schools because they simply cannot find the instructors. And the situation is not likely to improve any time soon.
In Hopewell, Ms. Priesing said she was panicking last summer after clawing through a stack of resumes and calling more than 15 teachers -- all of whom had found other jobs. Just before school was to begin, a woman who had recently moved to the area from out of state applied for the job and was willing to work as a substitute until she could receive state certification.
After putting up with the same kinds of frustrations, the Newark public schools went so far last month as to hire a full-time recruiter to help fill positions in a staff that, when full, numbers 4,000 teachers. This was nothing new. In 1999, the state Department of Education hired two recruiters to help lure teachers to the public schools, said Karen Harcar-Morris, director of the Office of Innovative Programs and Practices. The state has also set up a Web site -- www.njhire.com -- where schools can post openings along with recruiting events and programs. 
"We certainly acknowledge that there is a shortage," said Ms. Morris. She said that not only were more than 5,000 teachers a year leaving the state's classrooms but that the number "will increase with the graying of the teaching force."
In just 25 years, the picture has changed from one in which applicants were lined up to get each coveted teaching post to one in which districts are turning the tables on business by aggressively recruiting teachers from private industry as well as looking to the parochial schools.
There is indeed, a pressing need for the push:
*The average age of a teacher in New Jersey is 47, and of the state's 93,000 teachers, the Department of Education estimates that one-third of them will reach retirement age over the next decade.
*The number of teachers changing jobs or leaving through retirement is steadily increasing, the New Jersey Teachers Association says, noting that in the 1995-96 school year, 5.4 percent of the teaching force left, and that by the 1999-2000 school year, that percentage jumped to 8.1 percent. Moreover, a third of those left after teaching five years or less.
*Nationwide, studies show that after five years of teaching, 40 percent of the teachers leave the profession, says Dr. Richard M. Ingersoll, an associate professor in the graduate school of education at the University of Pennsylvania.
*The schools in New Jersey continue to become more crowded, with 1,289,221 students in attendance in the 1999-2000 school year, as against 1,264,259 in 1998-99.
*There are now about 212,000 students from the age of 3 to 21 receiving special education in the state's public schools now, up from 180,000 in 1990.
*In what she described as a "huge crisis," Jeanne Oswald, deputy executive director of New Jersey Commission on Higher Education, said there "was not a group of people in the schools preparing for" a 1999 court ruling affecting the state's 30 poorest districts. The ruling established new requirements for preschool teachers, mandating that by September 2004, all 3 and 4 year olds in those schools had to have a certified preschool teacher. Beginning in September, no teacher can be hired in poor districts without certification.
*The state's low unemployment rate has also drained the pool of substitutes who earn an average of $70 to $75 a day; some districts are paying $100 to $110 a day to help keep them.
"It's tight all around," said Michael Yaple, a spokesman for the New Jersey School Boards Association, "from superintendents to teachers to substitutes. The key areas are special education, world languages, math, science and technology."
But the biggest single reason for the severe personnel shortage can be summed up in a word: money. Better jobs in technology have lured many math and science teachers from the classroom.
Pay for teachers in public schools generally ranges from a starting salary of $30,000 to $60,000 or $70,000 for those who are experienced and have continued their education.
"We've lost wonderful teachers in math to computer companies," Ms. Priesing said, because in terms of pay, "the sky was the limit."
Still, Lynn Maher, a spokeswoman for the New Jersey Education Association, insisted that low pay was not the only issue.
"For some, it's the quality of the work experience itself," Ms. Maher said. "Teachers are often treated like children. There's no provision to use bathroom facilities sometimes. The workload has increased tremendously. Education has become a political football and test scores are driving the pressure. Teachers deeply resent that. They want to educate the whole child. Tests are only one measure."
In an urban district, for instance, a teacher might be judged on their students performance in tests even though more than half the students did not spend the entire year with the same teacher because of high student turnover, she said. "This creates an unhealthy atmosphere."
And money considerations aside, Dr. Ingersoll does not accept the conventional wisdom that increasing enrollment and more retirements are the crux of the problem.
"It's not so much shortages, it's turnover," he said. "There are too many bodies prematurely leaving the profession. There is a lot of dissatisfaction."
Indeed, the most alarming set of figures shows that of the 2.5 million teachers in the United States, about 40 percent of those who have been teaching five years or less will leave. Stated another way, the turnover rate for teachers is about 14.3 percent a year -- and 16 percent among math and science teachers -- Dr. Ingersoll said. Furthermore, he said research he conducted in 1995 showed that 11 percent of all the nation's teachers left after one year in the classroom, and 29 percent left after three years.
While he said higher salaries in other fields enabled teachers to quit -- since the pay "is relatively low compared to other occupations" -- he maintained that they were not the main reason. Dr. Ingersoll said student discipline and tensions in the workplace drove out many to teachers.
"Schools with more discipline problems and less tough discipline policies have higher turnover," he said. "How much say teachers have in their workplace and how schools are run make a difference. It's working-conditions issues. Support is also very important."
He said his analysis showed that more than 28 percent of the teachers who left the profession cited job dissatisfaction as their primary reason. Of that number, he said about 13 percent retired, 26 percent left to pursue other careers and 40 percent left for family or personal reasons. 
Dr. Ingersoll said that in addition to better pay, teachers needed support from their administrations as well as adequate supplies and classroom facilities. He said that when he taught high school social studies in Pennsylvania, he remembered getting a chalk allotment at the beginning of the year and being told that when the chalk was gone, he would have to buy his own.
"It's not like you're going to steal chalk," said the professor, who in 1999 presented some of his findings to the National Commission on Mathematics and Science Teaching for the 21st Century, which was headed by Senator John Glenn.
Dr. Ingersoll -- who taught in Delaware as a well as Pennsylvania over eight years -- said he finally stopped teaching public school for the same reason that many others did.
"Student discipline issues really wore me down," he said, "and I was actually a popular teacher. Student discipline needs to be addressed along with the issue of voice and power and say."
Teachers being forced to work outside their areas of expertise -- like baseball players playing out of position -- was another cause of tension among teaching staffs, he said. In fact, he said that research on that very problem had been cited by former President Bill Clinton in various speeches and mentioned in in education reports around the country.
"It's very challenging to teach things you don't know," said Dr. Ingersoll, who has written a book on the subject, "The Control of Schooling," which will be published by Princeton Press this year. "This is one of those things that drives turnover."
Until those types of issues were addressed, Dr. Ingersoll said he did not expect the teacher shortage to improve appreciably. "Take a closer look at your retention," he advised districts. "You can't afford to lose people."
In the Newark public schools, for instance -- with 44,000 students and 4,000 teachers -- there are still more than 50 openings said Randall Kanter, assistant superintendent for human resources. "Whatever is happening in other districts is happening more here because we're the biggest in the state." 
In addition to shortages in the usual fields -- science, math, foreign languages and special education, Mr. Kanter said Newark was also struggling to find English teachers, "a position that only a decade ago attracted 100 applicants for every job."
"It's definitely a seller's market out there," he said.
For that reason, Newark has begun paying more than many school districts in the state. In a contract that recently agreed on that will run through September 2003, starting teaching salaries will begin at $40,000 and go to $80,000, depending on experience. In addition, there is a tuition reimbursement provision for the teachers who are in midcareer to give them an incentive to keep working there, he said.
"Retention is key here," he said 
In addition, he said that the district had adopted a mentoring program set up by the state so that young new teachers, or those coming from other careers, would have an experienced teacher to help guide them through the first two years on the job. And the full-time recruiter started in January. 
"That's what we needed to do to be competitive," Mr. Kanter said. "You try to grab the best people out there."
In districts where salaries are lower, or there are labor disputes, staffing problems, understandably, are more acute.
For example, Monroe Township in Middlesex County, where school employees have been without a contract since July 1999 and voted down the latest contract offer in mid-December, more than 40 staff members -- mostly teachers -- have left in the past year, said Caren Castaldo, a substance abuse counselor who is co-president of the Monroe Township Education Association.
Openings in the district of about 3,100 students -- where the teaching salaries currently range from $30,535 to $57,285 -- include a high school science teacher, an industrial arts teacher, a physical education teacher, a part-time substance abuse awareness coordinator, a head for the science department in the high school and a foreign language teacher. 
"It's a crisis," Ms. Castaldo said.
Math and science teachers go elsewhere, she said, because "they can write their own ticket."
Stacy Grimaldi, who is in her seventh year teaching high school math at Monroe Township High School, said she understood why people did not want to go into teaching -- or stay in it.
"Teaching has gotten a bad rap," Ms. Grimaldi said. "People know if you want to be a millionaire, you don't become a teacher. Some people think my day ends at 2 p.m., but I'm up until 10 p.m. working." 
Instead, she said that other fields, like the computer industry, were able to lure teachers with much higher salaries and better schedules. "You don't have to work in the office five days a week in industry. A lot of people want flexibility. They want a three-day week, or to work on the weekend. I go into the office 180 days a year. I can't say, 'I'm going to work from home today.' "
But teachers do have summers and weekends off as well as every conceivable holiday.
So far, she has not considered leaving for greener pastures. "I really enjoy the interaction with the students," she said. "I don't think I'd be happy doing anything else."
Eileen Zibbe, who has been a school bus driver in Monroe Township for 25 years, agreed, though she said she, too, had seen many others leave in the past few years. In fact, Ms. Zibbe said things had gotten so bad that she that the everyone from the supervisor to a maintenance worker have had to pitch in.
The district, which is rural, has experienced a building boom in recent years, increasing the need for drivers, while low unemployment, low pay and stringent licensing restrictions have made drivers harder to find, she said. 
"There are so many kids anymore and so many homes going in here," Ms. Zibbe said. "Why come here for $11 an hour when you can go somewhere else for $13?' 
Nor is Monroe Township the only district with a shortage of bus drivers. Evesham Township, in South Jersey, has also had problems finding and keeping drivers.
"In the support end, bus drivers are the toughest hire," said John Dyer, Evesham's human resources manager. "Why? Full employment. Plain and simple."
Mr. Dyer, who was a partner in a transportation company in the 1970's, said he remembered how the pool of drivers started to "dry up as the economy got better and better."
And the same is true for those victims of unfortunate circumstances, otherwise known as substitute teachers. In Montclair, for instance, Michael Osnato, the superintendent, said substitutes used to stay in the pool for more than a year But, Mr. Osnato said, "we have rapid turnover now because people are getting full-time jobs. They are getting snapped up."
In West Windsor-Plainsboro, home to 8,300 students, substitutes now receive $70 to $75 a day, and the district is working hard to recruit and keep them, said Gerri Hutner, a spokeswoman. 
Ms. Hutner said the district had begun hiring the mothers of students with a minimum of 60 college credits. "There's a national substitute shortage," she said. "It's a great economy, and there are a lot of other jobs out there."
The substitute shortage has become so dire that services are cropping up around the state that provide substitutes. For instance, Diane Lorber, who used to teach emotionally disturbed children, now runs the Substitute Service in Lincoln Park, which does not find the substitutes but calls them and assigns them.
In 1984, the company served 8 districts in the state; now it provides about 400 substitutes a day to 32 districts.
Ms. Lorber came along and bought the business in 1994, when she decided to leave the classroom after three years at a private school.
"I was just burned out," she said. "It really took its toll on me."

HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT; 
For Rent: Office Space In Central Hackensack

BYLINE:  By GEORGE JAMES 

DATELINE: HACKENSACK 

 BODY:
John DeNoy stood at the window of his restaurant near the Bergen County courthouse and looked out at the falling snow. Normally at this hour of the morning, the place would be filled with people bantering with him over bacon and eggs or just coming in for coffee and a muffin to go. Today, John's Restaurant was as empty as a freeholders meeting.
 "I'm bored," Mr. DeNoy lamented. "No customers." 
 For more than a decade, about 550 county employees had occupied Court Plaza on lower Main Street, just across the street from John's. But for the past few months they have been migrating to the new $62 million administration building a few blocks away, which will eventually house most county offices.
In the late 1980's, when Court Plaza -- two buildings of polished gray granite and reflecting glass -- went up across from the courthouse, the $40 million complex was seen by many as a cornerstone of Hackensack's downtown redevelopment efforts.
Today there is a 160,000-square-foot-vacancy on lower Main Street -- and some concern about its effect on the downtown revitalization plan.
"I hope for the sake of Hackensack it's filled quickly," said Douglas Bern, the new chairman of the Board of Freeholders, who, along with fellow Democrats, opposed the new county building. "It's not good news for economic development in Hackensack and for the continued revitalization of the central business district."
But the county executive, William Pat Schuber, the Republican who led the drive for the new county building with the support of a then-Republican majority on the Board of Freeholders, said he did not see a problem for either Hackensack or the landlord, Alfred Sanzari Enterprises, which built Court Plaza.
"The location that Sanzari has there is such prime real estate," Mr. Schuber said. "I don't think he's going to have any problem over the long run of renting that place with prime tenants."
For his part, Mayor John Jack F. Zisa said that when the county first proposed a new office building, he was concerned about the effect on the city if Court Plaza stayed vacant too long.
"But in the long run," said Mayor Zisa, a Republican, "I believe it will have a very positive impact by housing that many more people and bringing in even more potential customers to Main Street."
Officials from Sanzari say they are equally optimistic.
Jerry L. Barta, vice president and director of leasing and marketing for Sanzari Enterprises, said that the company planned to gut the interior of Court Plaza South -- which is expected to take about four months -- to make it more appealing to corporate tenants. With rental at $28 a square foot, he said Sanzari expected to attract companies from New York, where the rents are far higher, as well as from other places in New Jersey. The county has been paying $250,000 a month on a lease that expires March 31.
For instance, office rentals in Newark range from $29 to $34 a square foot and on the Jersey City waterfront, which has been a magnet in recent years for major financial companies, from $35 to $40 a square foot, said Richard Baumstein, executive director of the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the leasing agent for Court Plaza South.
Furthermore, said Mr. Baumstein, "There is no space in Jersey City, so if you need 100,000 square feet today, you don't want to wait two years to get it," adding that more than 50,000 square feet is available on each floor.
Mr. Barta of Sanzari Enterprises put it his way: "Long term, it's going to get better as the building gets released to other users. Short term, a lot of money is going out and not as much coming in."
The complex consists of Court Plaza North, a six-story building filled primarily with lawyers as well as the district office of Representative Steven Rothman and the headquarters of the Sanzari company itself. Court Plaza South is a three-story building with two wings, which the county moved into shortly after it opened in 1988.
The exodus to the new administration building began last month and is about 95 percent complete. At first, it was only a trickle. But by early this month, the two subterranean levels where parking spaces were often scarce suddenly looked as vacant as a desert -- except for the county's filing cabinets, desks and tables, which were temporarily stored there.
The new 261,000-square-foot, five-story county administration building, along with a 1,300-car parking garage, was built on county-owned land across from the courthouse by the New Jersey Economic Development Authority, which will lease it to the county until 2026, when it becomes the county's for a dollar. The county expects to save about $73 million by not paying commercial rates, which are subject to rent increases. 
"Most major departments will be under one roof at last," said Mr. Schuber, including the county clerk's office, which had been in the courthouse; data processing, situated in Wood-Ridge; and the superintendent of schools, who had been in Paramus.
As for Court Plaza South, Mr. Barta said: "The symbol that this was to the revitalization of Hackensack doesn't change at all. The county's vacating our building creates an opportunity for other users to come to Hackensack to support the redevelopment of downtown."
Mr. DeNoy -- whose fate has ben affected by Court Plaza before -- just hopes this happens sooner rather than later. The block of buildings that included the coffee shop he opened 35 years ago, when he was 26 years old, was razed to make way for Court Plaza. At that time, he expanded his restaurant and opened across Sussex Street near Main Street, and business was good -- until a few weeks ago.
"We've lost a third of the business just in the mornings," he said. "Lunch is only off a little."
Then, for a time, at least, fortune smiled. The next morning a broken water pipe emptied the courthouse and sent hordes of county employees to wait out the repairs in John's.
"It was the second-biggest day we ever had," Mr. DeNoy said cheerfully. 
But the next day, a blackout forced him to improvise -- without electric power. "We served a lot of tuna and roast beef," he said.

John DeNoy of John's Restaurant says the revitalization effort is costing him customers. (Dith Pran/The New York Times and, below, Don Standing)
