HEADLINE: Going Back to the Mortgage Store 

BYLINE:  By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
WHEN James and Maureen Fleming bought their 2,100-square-foot Cape on one and a quarter acres in Trumbull, Conn., last April for $227,000, they took out a $202,000 30-year mortgage at 7.75 percent interest. But as mortgage rates gradually fell in the months since then, the couple decided to refinance. Two weeks ago they decided to take out another 30-year mortgage, this one at a 7 percent interest rate, and they expect to wind up with a monthly mortgage payment of $120 less than before. 
 In the process, the Flemings also flew in the face of what for years had been conventional wisdom -- that it is not usually worthwhile to refinance unless the new rate is at least two percentage points less than the existing rate. Instead, they went ahead and refinanced even though their new 7 percent loan does not come close to the once-magical two percentage point threshold. 
 In recent weeks homeowners have been rushing to take advantage of lower interest rates, though mortgage specialists say some may be waiting for the rates to drop even further, in the expectation that the Federal Reserve will shave interest rates another half point or so, as it did last month. 
Despite the timing predicament, lots of former fence sitters have already opted to refinance. "Since the first of the year refinancing has soared," said A. J. Romano, the founder and chairman of a mortgage brokerage company in Stratford, Conn., that bears his name, the company through which the Flemings obtained both loans. Joseph Romano, the founder's son and president of the family-owned financial services business, estimated that in the last couple of weeks he alone had approved at least 30 refinancing loans with a total mortgage value in excess of $11 million.
Meanwhile, in the last few weeks throughout the metropolitan area, as throughout the United States, refinancing has been heading skyward. In each of the first five weeks of 2001, refinancing loan applications nationwide have not fallen below 54.6 percent of total family home mortgages, soaring to 64.1 percent in the week that ended on Jan. 12. At that rate, refinancings are flirting with the record set in 1998, when interest rates in the 6 percent range propelled refinance loans into orbit.
"That year, 50 percent of all the loans originated for one-to-four family homes were for refinancing," said David Warner, a spokesman for the Mortgage Bankers Association in Washington. "The refinancing percentage and the $1.5 trillion amount of those loans are both all-time records. This year we expect 39 percent of the loans will be for refinancing and their value will be slightly more than $1.4 trillion, which would make both categories the second highest ever." 
There is good reason for the trend, experts say. "This is an excellent time to refinance, with mortgage rates low and a good chance for a lot of people to get out of higher rates that seemed good at the time they took them," said Keith Gumbinger, a vice president at HSH Associates in Butler, N.J., which publishes information on the mortgage market. "We expect this window of refinancing will run into the spring, spurred by a lot of people doing debt consolidation."
While lower rates have been the primary stimulus to refinancing, saturation advertising on television and on the Internet, as well as old-fashioned fliers in the mail, have also played a part. 
"We were getting all kinds of unsolicited mail telling us to refinance," said Mr. Fleming, a technology manager for DataViz Inc., a Trumbull company that specializes in software for Palm hand-held organizers. Mrs. Fleming works for the Gartner Group, a Stamford company that specializes in technology research. 
But the Flemings were more convinced by the fact that five or six co-workers had recently refinanced. And, as Mr. Fleming put it: "Since we plan on staying in our house for another 15 years or so, why not lower our mortgage payments when we can? Especially since refinancing cost us almost nothing, about $100, because there were no closing costs or points." Nor was there a penalty for repaying their existing loan early. Almost all financial advisers caution against taking out mortgages with prepayment penalties.
Similarly, there is wide agreement among mortgage lenders that the rule of thumb about two percentage points is an anachronism. "It hasn't applied for a long time," said Paul Quinn, the branch manager of Washington Mutual in White Plains. "People are financing for longer periods of time, and by doing so they're able to recoup their closing costs on the refinance and save money with each subsequent month." 
Because the rise in property values in recent years has translated into bigger mortgages, the two percentage points once seen as a minimum needed to justify refinancing has been supplanted by a drop of as little as three-quarters of a percentage point, according to Melissa Cohn, president of the Manhattan Mortgage Company.
When the Flemings decided to take out their new loan, they also made other decisions that will cut down their monthly payments. Because the value of the house had risen, their equity in the house had passed the 20 percent level, meaning that they no longer had to pay private mortgage insurance, or P.M.I. The savings of $65 each month from no longer paying P.M.I., along with the $120 savings on their new mortgage loan (which was for a slightly lower amount than their previous loan), add up to about $185. And it is not lost on them that by investing that extra $185 each month, which amounts to $2,220 a year, they could wind up with a helpful nest egg for their five-month-old daughter's education. 
But how can consumers figure out at what point they will recoup the fees associated with a refinancing loan and begin to save on their new mortgage? "Most loan officers can do that calculation in a few minutes using software," said Palmer Heenan, senior vice president of Weichert Financial Services, an arm of the New Jersey-based real estate services company. 
Another way is for borrowers to use what the Mortgage Bankers Association describes as "a crude rule of thumb": add the current principal and interest payment (but not the amount in escrow) and subtract the new principal and interest payment to find the monthly saving. Add the total of all fees and any other costs required to take out a new loan and divide that total by one month's saving. For example, if total fees are $3,000 and the monthly saving is $300, the borrower would break even in 10 months.
The Mortgage Bankers Association points out that fees and costs vary widely by state and county. The main thing to consider, according to Joseph Romano, is that "the customer has to pay those costs or brokers or lenders have to pay." In the case of the Flemings, they would have received a mortgage rate of 6.875 percent if they had paid upfront the costs involved in the refinancing, including the lawyer's bill, appraisal charge, mortgage filing fees and underwriting fees.
Mr. Heenan agrees. "Let's face it," he said. "You can roll those costs into a new 'no-charge loan,' but the borrower would have to pay a higher rate, or you can charge the borrower points. Either way, there's no free lunch." (Each point represents 1 percent of the total loan.) 
While the sharp rise in refinancing has been ignited by the prospect of getting lower monthly payments by trading in a mortgage with a higher rate for one with a lower rate, some homeowners with sufficient equity in their homes use the new loan to pay off their existing mortgages and then trade up to more expensive houses. Still others borrow more than they need to pay off their existing mortgage, in order to have money for other purposes.
For example, when Michael Kizilbash and Nancy Dubuc, a Manhattan husband and wife, decided a few weeks ago to refinance the co-op apartment they bought last spring in the West Village, they thought about borrowing a little extra to use on home improvements. 
But their main reason for wanting to refinance, said Ms. Dubuc, who works in the programming department of the History Channel on cable television, was to avail themselves of an interest rate lower than the one that came with the adjustable mortgage on the $375,000 30-year loan. They are currently paying 8.25 percent for the first seven years, after which the rate is to fluctuate depending on the prime rate. 
Mr. Kizilbash and Ms. Dubuc do not have their refinanced loan yet, because they have not signed the final papers with Manhattan Mortgage in the expectation that rates will fall again when the Federal Reserve meets next on March 20 -- an expectation widely shared by mortgage lenders, brokers and realtors. 
A. J. Romano, who is also the president of the Connecticut Society of Mortgage Brokers, is among those who think mortgage rates will drop further, but he is not expecting anything earth-shaking. "They'll probably only go down just a little," he said. "Maybe one-eighth of a point." 
MR. KIZILBASH and Ms. Dubuc, of course, would welcome any further declines, no matter how slight. Meanwhile, the couple has already filled in most of the necessary paperwork and paid about $600 in upfront closing costs with a balance of about $1,200 due at closing for various fees, including those for their application, the bank's attorney and the required credit check. If rates do surprise almost everyone by creeping back up, they will take what they believe to be the best deal available, which as of this writing is again a 30-year adjustable-rate mortgage, but this time with a 7 percent rate throughout the loan's first seven years.
"Even if interest rates stay the same before and after the Fed meets," said Mr. Kizilbash, a creative director at a Manhattan ad agency, "we'll execute the loan." No wonder. That rate reduction of 1.25 percentage points, he said, will translate into a tidy saving of more than $300 a month. 
Somewhat surprisingly, not everyone is thrilled with the likelihood of lower rates. "If rates do go down, it's going to lead to a commensurate tightening of standards, making it more difficult to get a mortgage," said Leon G. Shilton, a professor of finance at Fordham University's Graduate School of Business Administration. The reason, he explained, is that "the underwriters might force appraisers to lower their values on houses, because buyers of mortgages are hesitant to load up with low-interest-rate mortgages because of the risk that rates will go up again and will reduce the value of their mortgage holdings." 
The Mortgage Bankers Association found that although home loans of all sizes averaged $161,735 last year, refinance loans in 2000 averaged $177,162. The implication would seem to be that at least some of that $15,427 difference went for other things. 
All reputable lenders approve of refinancing so that borrowers can trim their interest rate, but refinancing can also have a sordid side in some cases where borrowers' total indebtedness increases. As recently as 10 days ago, Fannie Mae, the Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's biggest source of financing for mortgages, issued a statement about predatory lending. Such lending practices, which are usually aimed at lower-income families, the elderly and single women who are heads of households, include charging excessive fees for applicants to obtain loans, replacing the original loan with a refinanced subprime loan at a higher rate and imposing stiff penalties for borrowers who wish to pay off loans early. 
A poignant example cited by Fannie Mae, which together with several federal and local housing leaders convened a round-table discussion of predatory lending, involved the mother of an employee in Fannie Mae's Washington office. The woman, Carol Mackey, recounted how she had contacted a local mortgage company for a home equity loan to pay off $1,500 in credit card debt and remodel the condo she had owned for almost a decade. 
Instead, her new loan saddled her with a prepayment penalty, her previous 7.25 percent interest rate ballooned to 13.9 percent and her monthly mortgage payments more than doubled to $1,103 from $510.
Such abuses usually happen because certain subprime lenders -- a term that refers to those making loans to individuals with less than ideal credit ratings -- persuade unsophisticated or elderly borrowers to trade in a low cost loan for a higher cost loan, said Eric Stein, the head of the secondary market program of the North Carolina-based Coalition for Responsible Lending. And they load up the new loan with high upfront fees and with high prepayment penalties aimed at keeping borrowers from getting off the high-interest treadmill. 
While such abuses have been around for years, Mr. Stein said, they have grown in recent years as subprime lending has expanded.
Similar abuses were detailed last May before the House of Representatives Banking and Financial Services Committee by Cathy Lesser Mansfield, an associate professor of law at Drake University. One of her many examples explained how predatory lenders included the existing mortgage in the proceeds of the loan, thereby increasing the amount of money on which the borrower paid points and fees. 
Professor Mansfield concluded her testimony by saying that the subprime home equity market "demonstrates that justifications for rate limits still apply today, and that fees and rates in the market need to be regulated." 
IN a subsequent telephone conversation, Professor Mansfield said that all borrowers should be on guard against "teaser rates" -- rates that usually rise and often double within six months to two years. They should comparison shop and consult with people or community organizations that understand the refinancing market to make sure the deal they were promised is the one they are getting. 
"Some people refinance based on the promise that in a year or two they'll get a better rate," she said. "But nobody should ever take out a refinancing loan unless there is some current benefit." 
One couple certain to benefit is Charles and Lisa Mounts, who bought a vacation house in Goshen, Conn., last July and a few weeks ago arranged for a refinancing loan through Romano Mortgage that is two percentage points lower than their original mortgage. That spread is somewhat unusual in the current market, where most refinancings now range from one-half point to one and a half points.
But that is not all that is unusual about the Mounts' loan. To begin with, they found their broker on the Internet. And for another, although they are Americans, the Mounts currently live in London, where Mr. Mounts works for Goldman Sachs. "But," Mrs. Mounts said, "we managed to make the final arrangements for the loan with the help of e-mail, faxes and cell phones."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
For Schundler, the Question Is Not Why, but Just WHY?

BYLINE:  By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
Say what you will about Bret T. Schundler, the quixotic mayor of Jersey City, no one can accuse him of shying away from a fight. 
 In 1984, he worked on Gary Hart's long-shot bid for the Democratic nomination for president. By 1992 he had switched parties, opposed the powerful Hudson County Democratic machine and become the first Republican since 1917 to hold the office of mayor of Jersey City. 
 Last year, he backed Steve Forbes's short-lived run for the Republican presidential nomination. 
Mr. Schundler has now embarked on his most daunting task yet, his entry into the race to win the Republican nomination for governor. This time, the odds against Mr. Schundler are so steep that many New Jersey Republicans are left wondering just why he is running at all.
It's certainly not because the primary battle will be easy. Mr. Schundler brings some impressive attributes to the race. He is intelligent, Harvard-educated and articulate, and has a clearly defined political platform. Jersey City has enjoyed such an economic resurgence in the past decade that Mr. Schundler can reasonably claim some credit for its improvement.
Yet Mr. Schundler's Republican rival, Donald T. DiFrancesco, still seems to hold a huge political advantage. As both acting governor and president of the State Senate, Mr. DiFrancesco has an unprecedented opportunity to dictate the state's political agenda. He also has the support of party leaders in 18 of the state's 21 counties, a factor that will help him easily win the preferred position on the ballot on primary day. 
Mr. Schundler's strategy is clear, of course. He holds conservative views on a variety of incendiary social issues -- including support for school vouchers, teaching sexual abstinence in schools and severe restrictions on abortion rights -- which will help him win enthusiastic support from the right in New Jersey and beyond. Anyone who doubts the strength of the conservative vote in the state's Republican primaries need only look back to 1994, when Brian T. Kennedy, a virtual unknown, spent less than $25,000 to oppose Chuck Haytaian for the Senate nomination and came away with more than 30 percent of the vote.
To woo moderate Republicans, Mr. Schundler has also wrapped his message in a populist package, like the current White House occupant, by promising lower property taxes, school reform, a less-intrusive style of government and the fresh perspective of an outsider.
To date, there have been few signs that Mr. Schundler is tapping into some deep vein of discontent among Republican voters. He has raised nearly $1 million and spent most of it on direct mail, yet a public opinion poll taken this month showed him trailing Mr. DiFrancesco by 45 to 16 percent among likely primary voters. His official entry into the race -- announced last week in front of the New Jersey State House -- was attended by just a few dozen people, many of them who had driven down from Jersey City. Mr. Schundler then boarded a campaign bus -- the same one Senator John McCain used during last year's presidential primary -- and was met by sparse crowds.
All of which raises the question of why? Even if Mr. Schundler pulled off an improbable victory in the primary, many political analysts suspect that he would be a tough sell to New Jersey's moderate electorate.
"This is a moderate state," said Clifford Zukin, director of the Star Ledger/Eagleton-Rutgers Poll. "It's hard to envision someone too far from the center, on either side, winning a statewide election."
That argument has become a drumbeat among state Republicans, who have been pressuring Mr. Schundler to withdraw from the primary. Each day Mr. Schundler stays in the primary, they argue, he forces Mr. DiFrancesco to spend money and political capital trying to placate the party's restive right wing at a time when he should be honing a centrist message for the general election. 
Some Republicans suggest that Mr. Schundler' is less interested in this November's race than in some future contest, like next year's Senate race, and that a primary fight would help him solidify his base and build statewide name recognition. 
Mr. Schundler brushes aside suggestions that his candidacy is weakening the state's Republican Party, and instead insists he is the best chance to save it. 
"I think Don DiFrancesco will get blown out if he's the nominee this fall," he said. "And there's a good chance that the party will lose control of both the Assembly and the Senate. So if I wanted to run in 2002, my best bet would be to stay mayor of Jersey City and be one of the few Republicans who could still raise money and assemble a viable campaign. I'm running now because I think I can win and I think I can make a difference."
That kind of talk is unlikely to win Mr. Schundler many friends among the party's power structure. But Mr. Schundler said that his track record of backing political mavericks is actually better than it may appear: Gary Hart lost New Jersey in 1984 and Steve Forbes lost the state in 2000, but Mr. Schundler points out that he has won three elections in a row.
"People want someone with the courage to stand up to the special interests and make a change," he said. "There may be those who disagree with what I propose, but no one can question that I have the courage to say what I believe."

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES; 
For the Not-So-Retired, Freedom and Flexibility

BYLINE:  By DANIEL F. CUFF 

 BODY:
IN 1999, Sam Chororos turned 65 and decided to find out when he could start collecting Social Security.
 "I was in the highest tax bracket," he said. "They told me: 'You make too much money. It doesn't make sense to collect.' " 
 That was in the bad old days, when people were limited in what they could earn if they wanted to collect their Social Security checks. Mr. Chororos, an owner of J. C. Manufacturing of High Point, N.C., and a resident of Matawan, N.J., was pleased last year, however, when a new law permitted people 65 and over to collect their full benefits regardless of their earned income. Previously, people who were 65 to 69 faced income ceilings if they wanted to receive full benefits. 
Now Mr. Chororos is receiving his salary from his company, and the government deposits his Social Security check directly into his bank account.
"God bless America," he said. "What a country." 
As far as taxes go, good things have been happening for retirees. 
First came that law that frees people to stay in the work force if they so choose without a reduction in benefits. And recent regulations announced by the Internal Revenue Service lengthen life-expectancy schedules for people with tax-deferred retirement plans. As a result, retirees can take less money out of their nest eggs if they choose, allowing more of their money to grow tax-deferred for a longer time.
The freedom to work without incurring loss of Social Security benefits has ended the need for strategies to lessen or defer income, or even to work off the books. "Hopefully a lot of that has gone," said Martin Nissenbaum, national director of retirement planning at Ernst & Young in New York.
And that freedom has apparently been a bracing feeling for retirees -- even rich ones who hardly need the government money. "People really feel proprietary about their Social Security," said Mr. Nissenbaum, whose clients are high-income earners. "Even if Social Security is only $15,000 a year, and they are making a million, they want to get their money." After all, they contributed to the program throughout their working careers. 
The new rule has also given retirees more flexibility in reaching a goal that most financial planners advocate: to leave their money untouched in tax-deferred savings plans until 70 1/2, the mandatory age to start withdrawals. The freedom to work can keep retirees from having too much extra time on their hands; it can also provide the spending money that might otherwise come out of those accounts and be taxed as ordinary income.
"I strongly suggest not to take any money out" of tax-deferred retirement accounts, said Doug Stives, a certified public accountant at Wiss & Company in Red Bank, N.J. "If a client has $1 million in a stock portfolio and $1 million in a retirement plan, I plead with them to deplete the portfolio first." 
If you retire at 65, he said, you should use up your savings account or sell stock and pay capital gains taxes on it, instead of tapping those tax-deferred accounts and "paying taxes on every dime."
Mr. Nissenbaum agreed. "People are uncomfortable about using up their principal," he said. "But it makes more sense to use up these assets first."
Of course, there are exceptions, and Mr. Stives cited two of them: if you expect to come into more money later in life or if you have "a ton of deductions" and need to offset them with some income that can come from a retirement plan.
Mr. Stives praised the new federal plan that effectively cuts the amount of money that must be taken -- and taxed -- from tax-deferred retirement plans after reaching the mandatory age of 70 1/2. Any money in these plans may be removed without penalty between the ages of 59 1/2 and 70 1/2, but the problem is that the money is taxed as ordinary income -- even if some of the money in the account came from long-term capital gains (which are always taxed at a lower rate). And the government usually collects up front at the time the money is withdrawn. 
So if you do not need this money to live on, you can now slow down the withdrawal stream to allow more to accumulate tax-free and to have more to leave to beneficiaries, Mr. Stives said.
The Internal Revenue Service accomplished this by changing its rules governing minimum distributions from retirement accounts, including I.R.A.'s, 401(k)'s and the like. The agency is eliminating a complicated process for determining the minimum amount that needs to be withdrawn and replacing it with a simple chart based on longer life-expectancy period for most people. 
Under the old rules, for example, a single person who is 70 1/2 with $100,000 in a retirement account would have had to withdraw a minimum of $6,250. Under the new rules, he or she would have to withdraw only $3,816. 
The most affluent retirees may be in a particularly favorable position to let such accounts grow, if they are also receiving money from traditional defined-benefit pension plans. That is because the limit on benefits provided by defined benefit plans is rising to $140,000 in 2001 from $135,000 in 2000, after cost-of-living adjustments announced by the I.R.S.
ANOTHER adjustment may also be of interest to retirees and people planning for retirement: an increase for 2001 in the amounts of long-term care insurance premiums that may be included in any medical expense deduction. The new amounts are $230 for people 40 and under, up from $220; $430 for those 41 to 50, up from $410; $860 for those 51 to 60, up from $820; $2,290 for those 61 to 70, up from $2,200; and $2,860 for those 71 and older, up from $2,750.
Other changes will allow some people who are saving for retirement to sock away more this year than last. They may put up to $35,000 in defined-contribution plans this year, like Keogh plans for self-employed people, up from $30,000 last year. (The I.R.S., by the way, is dropping the Keogh name, referring simply to self-employed plans.) But the $10,500 limit will remain for salary-reduction contributions to 401(k) plans and 403(b) annuities.
In those plans, of course, an important consideration is how to invest the money. Many retirement accounts shrank in value last year as the stock market declined, causing some retirees to worry that stocks might be too risky for them.
"People didn't have to be too bright and terribly lucky" to have made double-digit gains in the stock market before last year's shocks, Mr. Stives said. That gave them confidence that was undone last year, he added, and many of them turned to money market funds,
But it is equally dangerous, Mr. Nissenbaum said, to put all of one's money into safe, fixed-income securities because of the risk of inflation at a time when retirees are living longer. The retirement period can last for decades, sometimes rivaling the time spent in a career, and investments must provide money that stretches to that horizon. 
"The downturn was focused on tech stocks, not on blue chips," Mr. Nissenbaum said. "The market is still the place to go on a long-term basis."

HEADLINE: Nhu An Tran, Noah Zaring 

 BODY:
Nhu An Tran and Noah Samuel Zaring, who received master's degrees in international economics and international relations from the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, where they met, were married yesterday in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington. The Rev. 
Shay Auerbach, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. On Friday, the couple held a traditional Vietnamese ceremony, in which their families were formally introduced, at the home of the bride's parents, Le thi My Nhan and Tran van Kien of Fairfax, Va.
 Ms. Tran, 32, is keeping her name. She is an economic development consultant at Development Alternatives, consultants in Bethesda, Md., and will relocate next month to Haiti, where the bridegroom, 29, a foreign service officer for the State Department, is to become a vice counsel. 
 The bride graduated from Georgetown. Her mother is a librarian at the Lauinger Library there. The bride's father, who was from 1963 to 1965 the minister of finance for the Republic of South Vietnam, retired from the Bell Multicultural High School in Washington, where he taught social studies and French. 
Mr. Zaring graduated from Grinnell College in Iowa. His parents, Jane Zaring and Dr. Philip Zaring, live in Ames, Iowa. The bridegroom's mother retired as an editor at Iowa State University Press there, and his father retired as a professor of British history at Iowa State.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CHINATOWN; 
Will a Shuttered Subway Lead to Shuttered Shops?

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
A plan to suspend service on the B and D lines at the Grand Street subway station, a major hub serving Chinatown, has community leaders worried that the area's fragile economy will be devastated by the disruption. Specifically, they fear that some mom-and-pop shops will be forced to close if the many Chinese immigrants living in Brooklyn find it more difficult to travel to these stores.
 New York City Transit has a plan to make the DeKalb Avenue station the last stop for Manhattan-bound B and D trains in Brooklyn, so that track repairs can be made on the Manhattan Bridge. Work is expected to begin in July and end in 2004. 
 Henry L. Chung, president of the Chinese Consolidated Benevolent Association, told about 40 Chinatown residents at a Community Board 2 meeting Tuesday that the plan was "irresponsible and unreasonable" and showed that the transit agency was "out of touch" with the neighborhood.
"Grand Street station is a primary subway stop for hundreds of thousands of workers, business owners and customers commuting to and from Chinatown," Mr. Chung said.
The station was built in 1967 to connect the B, D and Q trains in Brooklyn to the Sixth Avenue line in Manhattan. In recent years, the city's swelling Chinese community has made the station a bustling portal for workers and weekend shoppers, so much so that a second entrance was added in 1999.
Under the agency's detour plan, Brooklyn residents going to Chinatown would have to take new Q and W trains to Canal Street. A shuttle to the Broadway-Lafayette Street station in SoHo would link the Grand Street station to Brooklyn-bound trains.
Steve Strauss, a community liaison official at New York City Transit, said his agency would try to minimize the impact of the changes. But, he added, referring to the bridge repair work, "the options here are very limited by physical factors."
Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, who represents Lower Manhattan, was among those who offered recommendations, including running a bus shuttle between the Grand Street and DeKalb Avenue stations and delaying the shutdown until an economic impact study could be done.
"A lot of businesses are on the margins in this community," said Rocky Chin, a City Council candidate. "We're cordial here, but there is a feeling in the community that we are being blindsided." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Sebring; 
When Lightning Doesn't Strike Twice

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
WHEN the Chrysler Corporation introduced its second-generation minivans at the 1995 Detroit auto show, it did so with style, special effects and symbolism. Against a backdrop of a frog pond dotted with lily pads, the new van leaped over the old one.
 It was an apt image. In those days, Chrysler, the smallest and most nimble of the Big Three, routinely leapfrogged its competitors as it invented new types of vehicles, like the minivan, and then reinvented them in stylish new ways. By mastering and dominating a few parts of the market, Chrysler made more money per vehicle than any other mainstream automaker. 
 The company's daring designs and production agility are what attracted a German suitor, Daimler-Benz. But in the two years since the companies consummated their "merger of equals" -- it turned out to be a German takeover -- the Chrysler Group has stopped playing leapfrog. After losses estimated at nearly $2 billion in the last two quarters, Chrysler is in the midst of a grim revamping that includes 26,000 job cuts, reductions in vehicle production and demands for cost concessions from suppliers. 
The German executives now running Chrysler attribute its reversal of fortune to a faulty plan. Two key assumptions -- that the economy and vehicle sales would continue to boom, and that it could raise prices to increase its revenues -- proved inaccurate.
But Chrysler's products are a factor, too. Its innovative PT Cruiser is a home run, but the rest of its lineup consists of base hits.
Given its No. 3 status in Detroit, the pre-merger Chrysler had to take gambles to set itself apart, and it made its mark with bold designs that caught the public's imagination. Although the passage of time has made them seem less radical, vehicles like the 1992 Dodge Viper sports car, the '93 Dodge Intrepid sedan and the '94 Dodge Ram pickup were sensations when new.
But Chrysler has had trouble duplicating the initial success of its products as it brings out new versions. In part, big advances have been hard to make as engineers tried to hold down product development costs, which had been the industry's lowest. Meanwhile, competitors are moving ahead and nibbling at niches -- like minivans and Jeeps -- that Chrysler used to dominate.
"The secret to Chrysler's success was owning a segment, or doing something in a segment, that forced competitors to react," said Jim Hall, senior vice president of AutoPacific, an auto-industry consulting firm. He says he doesn't see that happening now.
Consider the Neon. When it arrived as a 1995 model, it was a breakthrough in American economy cars. Instead of plain, mundane, boring and slow, it was cute, bright, peppy, fun to drive and brimming with personality. At around $10,000, it represented a good value. And it was a hit.
When the Neon was redesigned five years later, it was undeniably improved. But the price was higher, the styling was blander and some problems with the original -- a noisy ride, for one -- persisted. The competition, which by then included several improved Korean cars, was tougher. The Neon has sold poorly of late.
Last fall, it was the minivans' turn for another revamping. Again, improvements were made: the new models are quieter and have better engines. But the market shifted faster than Chrysler: the Honda Odyssey had established itself as the minivan to beat, and buyers were waiting months, and paying premiums, to get them. In contrast, unsold Chrysler vans began to pile up right away, and the company had to offer sales incentives almost from the start.
Now, the same pattern seems to be playing out with the redesigned 2001 Dodge Stratus and Chrysler Sebring. Like the Neon and the minivans, these midsize cars are nice enough, and they are distinctly improved. But after test drives in two of them, I had to conclude that although they are competitive in their size and price range, they do not set any standards for their class. In today's fiercely competitive market, just good enough may not be good enough.
A word about the names: Gone are the Plymouth Breeze and Chrysler Cirrus sedans and the Dodge Avenger coupe. The Breeze was eliminated because the Plymouth brand is being phased out. (Only the Neon and Prowler carry the Plymouth badge for 2001.) The Stratus, formerly a sedan only, comes as a coupe, too, replacing the Avenger. The Chrysler Sebring, which had been only a coupe and convertible, is now also a sedan, replacing the Cirrus. Chrysler consolidated the names to make it easier and cheaper to market the cars.
There is another twist: Except for their names, the coupes and sedans have virtually nothing in common. Sebring and Stratus coupes are based on the design of the Mitsubishi Eclipse, and they are built by Mitsubishi in Illinois. The sedans were engineered by Chrysler and are built in Sterling Heights, Mich., as is the Sebring convertible. Oddly, the convertible was not derived from the platform of the two-door coupe, as one might expect, but from the four-door sedan.
Here are driving impressions of two cars:

Dodge Stratus Sedan
In the 1990's, Chrysler's cars didn't fit neatly into existing market categories -- its "LH" sedans (the Dodge Intrepid, Chrysler Concorde and Eagle Vision) were larger than midsize cars but not as bulky as full-size models. Its Neon was too spacious to be called a subcompact. And the first Stratus and Cirrus of 1995 (the Breeze arrived later) straddled two other segments.
Too substantial to be called compacts but not as large or expensive as the typical midsize car, they created a new class that has never been neatly labeled. A cab-forward design -- with the wheels at the car's corners and the engine and passenger cabin moved forward -- gave the sedans plenty of passenger and cargo space despite their fairly compact outside dimensions.
The redesigned 2001 Stratus still gracefully wears the cab-forward design, and it still has plenty of room and a large trunk. With its four-section grille and a body that looks wide, stocky and low, the Stratus is clearly a member of the Dodge family.
The interior has been refined, and the dashboard has few seams. Still, some of the plastic pieces seem cheap, a common trait of Chrysler products.
There are substantial improvements under the hood. The basic Stratus sedan comes with a 2.4-liter four-cylinder, revised to deliver 150 horsepower. And a new, optional
V-6, a 2.7-liter engine with 200 horsepower -- 32 more than before -- makes the Stratus one of most powerful sedans in its class. The top model, the ES, can be ordered with an AutoStick automatic that can be shifted manually (though without a clutch).
The brakes are beefier, the body is stiffer and the suspension and steering are retuned. The new Stratus is surely better than the previous one, but only incrementally. By and large, it didn't feel like an all-new car.
The ride was reasonably comfortable on smooth roads, a rarity in Michigan, but noise, especially from the tires, seemed excessive. The body showed a tendency to roll a bit on turns.
The plainest Stratus, the SE, starts at $18,425. My SE test car had the optional V-6 engine, a power driver's seat and antilock brakes, with a sticker of $20,310. Chrysler is currently offering a $1,000 rebate on all Stratus and Sebring models except the convertible, and there should be plenty of negotiating room on the price.

Chrysler Sebring Coupe
My weeklong test drive of the Chrysler Sebring coupe began inauspiciously. I flew into Detroit from sunny Mexico during one of Michigan's worst snowstorms in decades. After de-icing the car at the airport, I headed for the northwest suburbs in the wee morning hours. The trip, normally 45 minutes, became a harrowing three hours in blizzard conditions. Snow accumulated rapidly on roads that hadn't been plowed.
The Sebring held on surprisingly well until I turned into my unplowed subdivision. Snow was piled high, and the low-slung car didn't have enough ground clearance to budge even an inch. I ended up abandoning the Sebring and walking home.
I retrieved it a few days later, but with the roads icy I never had a chance to truly test its performance. Still, the Sebring's similarity to the Eclipse was clear, down to the prominent air vents in the dashboard.
The new Chrysler and Dodge coupes have different engines than the sedans. The two-door Stratus and Sebring have a 2.4-liter in-line four cylinder with a single overhead cam (142 horsepower) or a 3-liter, single-cam V-6 (200 horsepower). A five-speed manual transmission is available with the smaller engine. The top-of-the-line LXi with the V-6 can be mated to AutoStick. Two models are available: the LX and LXi.
The LX test coupe started at $20,505; options, including antilock brakes, pushed the price to $22,085.
The old Sebring seemed to have special appeal to young, single women, and the new coupe is quite attractive. One could even call it sleek and sexy. Still, as was the case with the Stratus, the Sebring didn't feel like a car that began with a clean sheet of paper. It felt like an Eclipse.
For at least a decade, Chrysler's cars had a distinct character, and that was often enough to make up for their deficiencies -- noisy cabins, inferior materials and spotty quality control. The Sebring benefits from incremental improvements, and like the Stratus it is a pretty good car, but it lacks distinction in a crowded market. With its high quality, Toyota can thrive with bland mass-market cars; Chrysler cannot.
As it retrenches, Chrysler must hold down engineering costs. But it needs again to develop fresh products -- like the PT Cruiser -- that the public can't resist. The Sebring and Stratus don't go far enough.

INSIDE TRACK: Progress measured in baby steps instead of by leaps and bounds.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
By Listening, 3 Economists Show Slums Hurt the Poor

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
HOUSING vouchers have been a ticket out of the slums for thousands of poor families since the 1980's. But only recently have researchers begun to pin down the benefits of moving to better neighborhoods. And three economists may have stumbled on the most important benefit of all -- by engaging in some unconventional economics.
 Economists rarely cast themselves as caseworkers interviewing poor people and listening to their troubles. Most are more at home with equations, computer models and other people's data about human behavior. Taking off this harness, the three economists -- Lawrence F. Katz and Jeffrey B. Liebman at Harvard, and Jeffrey R. Kling at Princeton -- took to the streets of Boston and demonstrated through their research what many people sense intuitively. 
 That does not detract from their achievement; demonstrating the accuracy of an intuition can carry weight among policy makers. What the three established in their research was that slums pull down families, damaging them emotionally and physically. That insight runs counter to current public policy, which tries to improve life in the slums by spending millions on police, schools and jobs. And now comes the finding that all this outlay misses the point. The slums themselves are the problem. The culture of poverty begins to lift only when slum dwellers move to better neighborhoods.
"Either it was the neighborhood that caused the problem, or the innate characteristics of the people themselves," Mr. Liebman said. "We had no credible way to convince someone that it was the neighborhood until we did this research."
There is a story here. The voucher program of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, called Section 8, gives residents of public housing projects rent subsidies so that they can afford homes in better neighborhoods. The families who get the limited number of rent vouchers are usually headed by single mothers with low incomes.
One goal is to give families a ticket out of segregated, inner-city projects. Another is to improve people's lives by subsidizing rent in more affluent surroundings. Most families move to working-class communities where the poverty rate is 20 percent to 30 percent of the population, compared with 40 percent or more in the projects. But the improvement in family performance was not clearly evident. So HUD ordered a study.
People who wanted to leave the projects volunteered to participate in a lottery. The winners got considerable help in using their rent vouchers to move to neighborhoods with poverty rates below 10 percent, usually in the suburbs. "Very few people without help or prodding would choose to move outside the city limits," Mr. Katz said. The lottery losers remained in the projects as a control group. The random selection implicit in a lottery meant that improvements in the lives of those who moved, compared with the control group, were not a result of superior personal characteristics that had compelled them to move in the first place.
The HUD study, which began in 1994, involved housing projects in Baltimore, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and Boston. Mr. Katz, Mr. Liebman and Mr. Kling got the research rights for Boston. They were going to focus on the usual goals -- school and job performance -- until they decided to conduct interviews. 
"I thought they were going to say they wanted access to better jobs and schools," Mr. Liebman said, "and what we came to understand was their consuming fear of random crime; the need the mothers felt to spend every minute of their day making sure their children were safe."
So the economists designed their research to see what happened when the fear of crime lifted in the new neighborhoods. Six years after the study began, there has been measurable improvement in the behavior of boys and in the mental health of mothers, who suffer less from depression. There were fewer asthma attacks and a big decline in injuries, partly from fewer fights, but also because playgrounds were no longer uniformly paved in concrete.
What did not improve markedly was school and job performance. If these had been the focus of the research, then subsidizing rents to get families out of slums would be harder to justify. Still, the research continues. The three economists are on a team working in all five cities and they are shifting their focus to schools and jobs. "We may see improvements in earnings five or six years out," Mr. Katz said, "and the kids may be less likely to drop out of high school."
But the Boston research is already significant. Dismantling slums and integrating residents into better-off neighborhoods -- never an easy process -- now has more scientific justification. That is a finding that standard economics would have missed.

HEADLINE: The Town That Gags Its Writers 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEAVITT; David Leavitt is the author, most recently, of the novel, "Martin Bauman; or, A Sure Thing," published last fall by Houghton Mifflin, and, with Mark Mitchell, of "In Maremma: Life and a House in Southern Tuscany," to be published in May by Counterpoint.

 BODY:
RECENTLY one of my students at the University of Florida wrote a story about a young writer who lives at 895 NE 107th Street in New York City. It goes without saying that this student had never been to New York. In her story, the hero, an aspiring novelist, rents a charmingly rundown flat in Manhattan, has an interesting if low-paying job and spends much of his time sitting in coffeehouses with his friends, talking about literature and philosophy.
 After I read the story, I asked my student to come and see me. I wanted to set her straight on a number of points, not the least of them how New York addresses work, but I also wanted to offer her a dose of reality -- if possible, without injuring any fragile illusions on which her education might depend. After all, I had once nurtured fantasies not unlike her own. In 1983 I moved to New York to be a writer in New York, found myself an overpriced and uncharmingly run-down flat, and got a job as a slush reader for a publisher. And New York, in a matter of weeks, managed to destroy entirely the idealism that had brought me there. 
 Herewith another version of the story, the one I told my student. 
In this version, as in the original, the fictional hero is a fledgling novelist. I shall call him Paul, after the novelist played by George Peppard in the movie "Breakfast at Tiffany's," and also after the glamour-besotted hero of Willa Cather's story "Paul's Case."
Paul, my Paul, moves to Manhattan straight out of college to hone his craft. To make a living, he takes a job in publishing. Many of the people with whom he works turn out to be writers as well, so almost instantly he finds himself living, as he had hoped he would, in a community of fellow aspirants. They eat many meals together. 
On weekends they sit in coffeehouses, sipping lattes and tea, and sometimes talking about literature. Yet more often, because they work in publishing, they talk about publishing. They talk about money. They talk about X, 23 and fresh out of the Columbia M.F.A. program, who has just gotten a six-figure advance for her first novel. Is it true that X's agent included a Marion Ettlinger head shot with her manuscript when he sent it out? Is it true . . . ? Is it true . . . ?
One evening a friend of Paul's, also a writer (but published), takes him to a book party. There he is introduced to numerous agents and editors, including X's, most of whom look over his shoulder while they talk to him, their eyes on the door through which someone more important might be about to enter. By and large the editors are smooth-talking and urbane, yet more than a few are wallflowers, lacking, it seems, in even the most basic social skills. 
As for the agents, one gives him her card and suggests that he call her. He does. Her assistant tells him that she is in a meeting. He calls again a week later, and she is still in a meeting. She is in a meeting for the next six months. Another agent tells him that if he hasn't made it by this point, he never will. A third insists that he must cement his reputation with a collection of short stories before he can even hope to publish a novel. A fourth tells him that short stories don't sell, and that he shouldn't even bother writing them.
Paul shares a chunk of his manuscript with an editor at the house where he works. She expresses guarded enthusiasm and asks to see more. Before he has a chance to show her anything, however, she takes another job. Her replacement, finding his pages in a file drawer, and not yet having learned his name, sends him a form rejection letter. Paul is too shy to explain that the pages were his.
 HE buys a season ticket to the reading series at the 92nd Street Y, and never goes once. He subscribes to The New Yorker, The New York Review of Books and Publisher's Weekly, the last of which he reads more avidly than either of the others, especially the advance reviews and the rights column, from which he learns that X has now sold the foreign rights to her book in 15 countries, that Redbook has bought first serial rights, and that two studios are vying to option one of her short stories. X is now rich; he sees her at another party, surrounded by admirers, wearing a Hermes scarf. 
In the evenings, when he is not eating with his friends, Paul attends panels on publishing issues sponsored by the Authors Guild or PEN. After a panel called "Asian Writers: New Voices," he worries that because he is white, he will never find a publisher. After a panel called "Women Writers: New Voices," he worries that because he is male, he will never find a publisher. After a panel called "Gay Writers: New Voices," he worries that because he is heterosexual, he will never find a publisher. 
A friend of his (who is also my friend, Mark Mitchell) has told him: "In New York, I worry about other people's work. Away from New York, I worry about mine." On strolls through bookstores, Paul memorizes the logos of the most famous publishers -- dogs, dolphins, ships -- and learns by heart whose books they grace and whose they do not.
X's novel comes out. It is a flop. On the other hand, the buzz about another first novel, this one by Y, could not be more enthusiastic. Although Y was not paid a six-figure advance, The New Yorker is bringing out his first chapter. Elizabeth Hardwick, Renata Adler and Susan Sontag have all given him blurbs. When Y's novel appears, it is featured on the front page of The New York Times Book Review. 
Having read the review, Paul looks in despair at the manuscript of his own unfinished novel, which could not differ more, either in tone or content, from Y's. Has he made a dreadful mistake? Should he start again? On the other hand, when he actually sits down to read Y's novel, the reading of it takes him so far from the chatter surrounding its publication that upon finishing, he has trouble coming to. For Y, despite everything, is the real thing, a writer. 
Still, a consciousness of the industry (and all that word implies) ferments just on the other side of the glossy jacket. Paul knows from friends with inside information that Y's novel will have its debut at No. 7 on the New York Times best-seller list, that Y is to be the subject of a profile in New York, that someone is thinking of composing an opera based on his book. . . . 
So it goes. All around Paul, the media make noise, in many ways louder than that of the traffic outside his window. Among other things, it tells him that he must learn to sell himself, a labor that takes him every day further from his computer, and deeper into the churning chaos of the market.
IN her wonderfully satirical story "Levitation," Cynthia Ozick gives us a couple, both novelists, called Feingold and Lucy. Feingold, in addition to writing, works as an editor. The one principle on which he and his wife agree is "the importance of never writing about writers," which they call "The Forbidden Thing." Eventually "The Forbidden Thing" is transformed into "The Forbidden City, because not only were they (but Lucy especially) tempted to write -- solipsistically, narcissistically, tediously, and without common appeal -- about writers, but more narrowly yet, about writers in New York."
As Paul, like Feingold and Lucy, is a fictional character, let us introduce him to them at a Sunday afternoon brunch whose host is Feingold's agent. Seeing something of themselves in Paul, themselves in youth, they take him under their common wing. They introduce him around. They offer him detailed editorial advice. Theirs is a city, in Ozick's words, full of people who live on "pity, and therefore on gossip . . . who had lost three successive jobs, who was in danger of being fired, which agent's prestige had fallen, who could not get her second novel published, who was persona non grata at this or that magazine . . . who was being snubbed, who counted or did not count."
The Feingolds joke that they are "secondary-level people."
"Feingold had a secondary-level job with a secondary-level house. Lucy's own publisher was secondary-level; even the address was on Second Avenue." Theirs may even be the "secondary city" of which George Steiner writes in "Real Presences," when he calls for the sweeping away of the very ephemera, the "high gossip" with its "tenor of busy vacancy" that the Feingolds personify. At night, Paul begins to dream about bombs dropping on publishing parties, wiping out every source of his anxiety.
Sometimes he wonders if he should leave. Should he leave? The truth is, after only a few months, he finds it hard to imagine living anywhere else besides Manhattan. Once he could have. But since then the island seems to have ruined him for life elsewhere. For six months, he realizes, he has not crossed either river even once. He recalls Woody Allen in "Annie Hall," driving in a daze through Beverly Hills at Christmas. To the rest of the world, even to his hometown and the town where he went to college, he has become allergic.
On weekends, when he wakes up in the morning, the first thing he does is pick up the phone to call one of his friends. "Any news?" he asks. If the refrain sounds familiar, it is because it is one of the catch phrases from E. F. Benson's Mapp and Lucia novels: New York City has become, for Paul, as hermetic, as provincial, as Benson's Tilling-by-the-Sea.
PAUL loses his apartment, which he is subletting illegally. The landlord finds him out, and the woman from whom he is renting, in a panic, evicts him. He has to find another apartment quickly, and as he refuses categorically to move to Brooklyn or Queens, he ends up on the Lower East Side, in a sixth floor walk-up, paying close to $1,000 a month for one room. He must ask for help from his parents to make his rent.
He becomes acutely conscious of real estate. In one of the design magazines to which he turns when he wants to relax, he sees a spread of X's new loft in SoHo. Y, he hears, has just bought a floor-through in a converted church in Greenwich Village. The parties he goes to seem always to take place in palatial Upper East Side duplexes full of high ceilings and views. 
In an effort to make himself feel better, he tries to remember that in living as he does he is following in a long tradition. After all, from "La Boheme" onward, literature and opera and cinema have exalted the idea of the young writer starving in a garret. 
And yet in the old days being poor in New York was easier, because New York was cheap. It's hard to lose yourself in the fog of art when you can't afford an air-conditioner, and the erratic thrum of a jackhammer rises up from the street. Through the thin walls comes the sound of techno played too loudly. Babies and sirens cry.
At a party Paul meets a novelist he has long admired. "When I'm working," she tells him, "I can disappear into my study and not come out . . . for days." As it happens, this novelist is married to a stockbroker, and lives on Central Park West. How enviously Paul envisions her study, its walls upholstered in some quieting damask fabric, its capacious oak desk overlooking the park.
WHERE does this story end? What will happen to Paul? His fate, I'm sorry to say, is uncertain. Perhaps he will publish a novel and have a great New York success, be voted into the American Academy, and win the Pulitzer Prize. Or perhaps he will get a promotion and become a powerful editor who snubs young supplicants at parties. Or perhaps he will lose his job and be forced, by economic necessity, to leave New York.
This last outcome, in my view, would be the most salutary. For once he gets out of New York (and in Paul's case he would have to be dragged kicking and screaming), he may discover, in the sudden quiet, that he can hear his own voice. No matter what the Feingolds of the world may say, writing itself is the thing that really counts.
Let's move him to Gainesville, Fla., where I write now. Let's put him in a decent apartment that rents for $500 a month. Is he happier? There aren't nearly so many movies to choose among, nor is the local independent bookstore as well stocked as the Strand. Yet the street on which he lives is tranquil and tree-lined, and if he drives a few miles, he can swim in a lake.
My purpose in telling this story is not to discourage young writers from developing the business acumen, or the instinct for fashion, or even the shell of self-protective irony that writers need in order to survive and that they have needed since the age of Dickens. These muscles matter, yet something about New York teaches us to tone them, to flex them at the expense of others that matter more: imagination and craft. 
In New York we live surrounded by monoliths, institutions both vast and self-sustaining that must convince us of our dependency on them in order to survive. Thus the myth persists in the publishing industry that publishers create writers, and not the other way around, that dog or dolphin on the spine of a book will make what he writes literature. Yet the truth is that only writers can make literature. The whole massive enterprise rests on the scrawny shoulders of novices like Paul.
If he is to learn this lesson, though -- which is really the lesson of his own power -- he will first have to get out of New York.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
The City by the Bay? To Them, It's Oakland

BYLINE:  By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: OAKLAND, Calif. 

 BODY:
WHEN John Protopappas started buying a few residential and office properties in this traditionally unfashionable blue-collar city in the early 1980's, "not many people wanted to join me," he recalled. Through the years of the city's decline, his business grew slowly.
 Today, his Madison Park Real Estate Trust owns about 2,500 residential units in Oakland and a few office buildings, including the downtown's signature Tribune Tower, which he bought in 1995 for $300,000. Although hardly a giant by the standards of major investment trusts, Madison Park, of which Mr. Protopappas is chief executive, has grown to $45 million in assets from roughly $4 million in 1985. 
 An important factor in the company's expansion, Mr. Protopappas says, has been its focus on Oakland, which is enjoying an economic resurgence. The city's new attractiveness is seen in real estate, as developers like Walter Shorenstein of San Francisco have started to buy major properties. 
Fifteen years ago, the idea of building luxury lofts or attracting high-end office developers to Oakland, where the 395,000 residents are largely poor or working class, would have seemed absurd. Yet in the last five years, Mr. Protopappas, 42, has been able to sell virtually every unit he can get his hands on. He is also developing four other major projects in the city.
The changes are most evident downtown. Despite its central location in the region -- it is the main transfer point for the Bay Area Rapid Transit system -- it was also largely characterized by deteriorating buildings and failing stores. Now smart restaurants are popping up, and stores are returning. Oakland's boomlet -- with rising property values and plummeting vacancy rates -- is a reflection of new real estate opportunities that have emerged in scores of once-neglected industrial cities across the country, from Tacoma, Wash., to Tulsa, Okla., to Baltimore. These cities all have gained favor with old- and new-economy companies, particularly as they seek lower rents in what appears to be a time of corporate retrenchment.
OAKLAND has suffered for years from comparison to San Francisco, just across the Bay Bridge. San Francisco boosters refer to their hometown as "the City" as if there were no other city in the Bay Area, or even California. (And no one ever sang about leaving his heart in Oakland.)
To be sure, Oakland's renaissance has had less to do with its intrinsic appeal than with simply being in the right neighborhood. Mr. Protopappas points out that prime office space in Oakland rents for $48 a square foot, roughly half the going rate in San Francisco and Silicon Valley. For Class B space, which includes older buildings in less-desirable areas, rents are about $18 a square foot.
"It's really about the fact that San Francisco has become so expensive, and so has the valley," Mr. Protopappas said at his offices in the 20-story Tribune Tower. "It's attracting new-economy companies and older-economy companies that want to be near the new economy."
The technology surge in the Bay Area has done much to remake Oakland. In the 1990's the area, which includes Oakland and neighboring cities, excluding San Francisco, was among the 10 fastest-growing high-tech metropolitan regions with populations of more than one million. It is now home to more than 300 high-technology companies. 
Today, the tough times affecting the Bay Area's technology industry and the businesses that service it may also be benefiting Oakland. In the last six months, as much as one million square feet of sublease space has hit the market in San Francisco, largely a result of the dot-com shakeout, while Oakland has continued to fill new space as more companies move there. Vacancy rates for top-quality office space in Oakland fell to about 3 percent this year from about 12 percent in 1996, while vacancy rates for Class B space dropped to 6 percent from about 15 percent. 
Steven Marshall, president of Marshall Associates Inc., an 11-person company that designs laundries and kitchens for large corporations, moved the company to the Tribune Tower last year, when the rent in his San Francisco building went to $75 a square foot from $25; his new rate in Oakland is $27.
Mr. Marshall cited other factors that made Oakland attractive, like lower business taxes and less-expensive parking.
Much credit for Oakland's revival, Mr. Protopappas and others say, also belongs to Edmund G. Brown Jr., the former governor of California, who became the city's mayor in June 1998. 
"Five years ago, downtown was occupied by hostile forces," Mr. Protopappas said. "What Jerry Brown is creating is an environment that has people walking around downtown with disposable income. Jerry Brown has been a very effective leader. He's been a visionary who deals well with the bureaucracy and has put the city on the map."
Mr. Brown says Oakland's comeback is a result of a "learning experience" derived from decade-long anti-business policies, which concentrated on extracting benefits from companies to support the city's social-service programs. 
In contrast, he assiduously courts developers like Mr. Protopappas. Mr. Brown has also worked to provide the kinds of efficient city services, including sanitation and public safety, that matter to prospective corporate clients, entrepreneurs and middle-income residents. Within the next few years, Mr. Brown estimates, as many as 10,000 people will move into central Oakland, many of them middle-class and above.
Not everyone in the Bay Area, even in Oakland, shares Mr. Brown's enthusiasm for the city's economy. 
Nancy Nadel, a city councilwoman who represents Oakland's downtown and adjacent areas, says the mayor's development-oriented strategy is raising residential rents and displacing many of the city's poor. "My concern is, every day I get five calls from constituents who are being evicted because they can't pay the higher rents," Ms. Nadel said. "We have to be concerned that the growth of the city helps all the residents of the city."
SAN FRANCISCO residents appear to be taking Oakland's revival in stride.
"Oakland has its place, and we're delighted with their resurgence," said Roberta Achtenberg, senior vice president for public policy at the San Francisco Chamber of Commerce. Ms. Achtenberg, a former San Francisco supervisor, said it was natural that companies with budget concerns would migrate to Oakland. "But if it's diversity and creativity of the work force you want," she added, "you still tend to want to go to San Francisco."
Claudine Osipow, president of DCO International, a seven-person plastics-trading company that moved from San Francisco to the Tribune Building in July, acknowledged that clients were surprised when she told them of the move. Yet Ms. Osipow, a San Francisco resident, said she had no regrets.
"It's still a bit limited for restaurants," she said, "but I can always take the train to San Francisco and be there in 20 minutes."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
Not in My Backyard? That Depends on the Payroll

BYLINE:  By BEN SPIESS 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE 

 BODY:
THE Yukon and Northwest Territories, the beautiful but forlorn territories in Canada's distant northern corner near Alaska, have coexisted as peacefully as the caribou that crisscross their vast expanses of tundra and scrubby spruce forests. But the prospect of a multibillion-dollar Alaskan natural-gas pipeline snaking southeast to feed the lower 48 states has touched off a quiet struggle between the two territories to win the project, which could mean prosperity for just one of them.
 In what could be the biggest economic boom for northwest Canada since the Gold Rush more than a century ago, a consortium of oil companies hopes to build a pipe up to 1,800 miles long that would carry natural gas from Alaska's North Slope; the deposit is the largest known undeveloped gas reserve in the United States. The rising value of natural gas -- it has tripled in price in the last year -- may make such a pipeline commercially profitable. 
 "For most big oil-and-gas projects, the feeling is, 'not in my backyard,' " said Ken Konrad, the head of the gas development team in Anchorage for BP Amoco, a consortium member. "With this project, everyone wants it in their backyard."
BP and its partners, ExxonMobil and Phillips Petroleum, are spending $75 million just to determine the project's viability and the potential route. Their decisions are expected late this year.
Both territories are increasingly looking at the pipeline as an economic salvation, largely because they see few alternatives. Combined, the Yukon and Northwest Territories are about one-fifth the size of the continental United States, but have a combined population of about 70,000 -- only slightly larger than that of Portland, Me.
Unemployment rates in both territories are near 12 percent, roughly double the national average. Falling metal prices -- gold prices in particular -- have severely depressed the mainstay industry, mining.
The premiers of the two territories, Pat Duncan of the Yukon and Stephen Kakfwi of the Northwest Territories, have been crisscrossing North America on rival selling tours. Both met last month with Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada. Mr. Kakfwi swung through Washington in October to talk to officials of the Energy and Interior departments. Ms. Duncan has met with oil executives in Anchorage and with Gov. Tony Knowles of Alaska in Juneau.
The competition has created an awkward relationship between the two premiers, whose interests are usually aligned. Both say publicly that a pipeline would inevitably be good for all. "We're not degrading anyone's project," Ms. Duncan said last month. 
But the spirit of the rivalry comes through, reflecting the big stakes. "It's no secret where we want Alaskans to put the pipeline," Mr. Kakfwi has said.
Both territories have been auctioning exploration leases, betting that if a big pipeline were built nearby, it would spur development of their own, smaller reserves.
Local construction companies, which have little work now but are virtually assured years of full-time employment if the pipeline is built within driving range, follow each snippet of pipeline news. In the Yukon capital, Whitehorse, where 22,000 of the territory's 32,000 residents live, Jon Rudolph, owner of the Golden Hill Ventures construction company, said things were so bad that he had laid off most of his employees.
Asked what would happen to the Yukon if the project went to the Northwest Territories instead, he said, "Well, this territory will just continue to decline."
ABOUT 600 miles away in Inuvik, Northwest Territories, the hopes of Nellie Cournoyea also rest on natural gas. Inuvik, population 3,000, sits on the northern edge of the territory, in the Mackenzie River delta. Ms. Cournoyea is the chief executive of the corporation that manages the Inuit local economic interests.
The Inuit in the region still depend on caribou and fish for food. But with a decline in the fur business, few people can live comfortably. "Everyone struggles to find work," Ms. Cournoyea said.
She hopes that the pipeline will run nearby, because the Mackenzie delta has eight trillion cubic feet of its own gas reserves. 
Many people believe that Mackenzie could get its own, separate pipeline. But Mackenzie's reserves pale in comparison with Alaska's 35 trillion cubic feet. 
ExxonMobil, BP and Phillips have given no clue about their preference. The companies envision a pipeline that would begin operation in 2007 and deliver up to four billion cubic feet a day to the lower 48 states over 30 years, augmenting current supplies by about 7 percent.
At first glance, the Northwest Territories route, which would follow the Arctic coast to the Mackenzie River delta and south to Alberta, makes more sense. At 1,400 miles and costing an estimated $5.5 billion, a pipeline on that route would be about 300 miles shorter and 30 percent cheaper than one on the Yukon route, which would likely follow the Alaska Highway.
With lower transportation costs, the route would also likely mean more money for the Alaskan government, which owns a royalty share of North Slope gas. 
BUT Alaska's governor and Congressional delegation support the Alaska Highway route via the Yukon because it would bring natural gas to cities like Fairbanks. With memories still fresh of the oil pipeline that made Alaska rich, a project across the state to the Yukon conjures visions of a second bonanza. 
The Northwest Territories route may also draw opposition from environmental groups, because it would border the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. But officials in Northwest Territories see lower costs and shorter distance as their best advantages.
"When I look at a map, the straightest line from the North Slope to the lower 48 is through Northwest Territories," said Joe Handley, the territories' finance minister. Mr. Kakfwi has predicted that "ultimately, this is going to be decided by which project delivers gas at the lowest cost."
Alaska's producers are not alone in trying to bring big reserves to market. Other large reserves in the deep water of the Gulf of Mexico and off Nova Scotia are also under consideration. As fresh supplies reach the market, prices will fall, said Bill Gwozd, an analyst at Ziff Energy in Calgary, Alberta. But over the longer term, Mr. Gwozd forecast, prices will strengthen.
But prices are not necessarily predictable. During the last natural-gas price shock, in the mid-1970's, an Alaska natural-gas pipeline seemed certain. In the Northwest Territories, companies poured hundreds of millions of dollars into exploration. 
In the Yukon, developers built a subdivision to house an expected influx of workers. Ms. Duncan, the Yukon premier, remembered neighbors in Whitehorse who bought welding trucks and supplies, ready for the boom. In the mid-1980's, prices collapsed. The Alaska pipeline never happened.
"Some of those trucks are still sitting there," Ms. Duncan said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Canada's Northwest Territories, where tundra like this near Yellowknife alternates with vast pine forests, is vying with the Yukon for a pipeline to carry natural gas from Alaska. (Jiri Hermann for The New York Times) Map of Canada and Alaska highlights proposed route of gas pipeline.
