HEADLINE: The World: Entanglements; 
A New View of Where America Fits in the World

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
PRESIDENTIAL campaigns are a notoriously bad environment for debating how America will approach the world. During the cold war, every candidate sought to prove he would be tough on the Communists, and his opponent a wimp. In this murkier age of global markets, globe-trotting terrorists, disintegrating superpowers and distended peacekeeping missions, George W. Bush made realists happy by assuring them he would protect America's "national interests," while assuring allies that America would stop lecturing and conduct a "more humble foreign policy." 
 No one was quite certain what it all meant. 
 But in the past few weeks, Mr. Bush has begun defining his terms, setting his priorities -- and in the case of Iraq, giving notice that he may be new to this, but he doesn't plan to show it.
Last week, Mr. Bush set a broad new direction for America's military, told reservists that he would bring a halt to the "overdeployments" of troops around the world, and talked about gas exploration and new immigration policy with President Vincente Fox in Mexico. Most dramatically, he approved an air raid on radar control facilities near Baghdad that he hopes will chasten Saddam Hussein on the eve of Gen. Colin L. Powell's first visit to the Middle East as secretary of state. The raid underscored Mr. Bush's first foreign policy objective: to take command of events overseas, while being far more selective than the Clinton administration about which thickets to enter. That is more an inclination than a strategy, and there are plenty of rough edges.
So far, for example, Mr. Bush's approach to Russia has been somewhat less than humble. In the past few days Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld has declared that Moscow's role as an "active proliferator" of missile technology helped propel the White House toward developing a national missile defense -- a plan the Russians and Chinese detest. Then there is Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, who has bluntly declared that the Clinton administration's loans to Russia were "crazy" and has told the Kremlin to pay off the old Soviet Union's debts and forget about new aid until it cleans up rampant corruption. 
Mr. O'Neill also says countries like Russia that mismanage their currencies and economies are on their own, and should expect no cash from Washington. On the other hand, he says, Japan will no longer get Clinton-like lectures about how to reverse its decade-long economic decline.
This may not add up to a global vision. But it sure sends a message: don't expect us to leave home as often, and don't expect us to whip out our American Express card when we do. It's not isolationist -- but it's far less activist than the let's-have-a-summit approach of Bill Clinton. (Iraq, of course, is a special case.)
One of Mr. Bush's senior foreign policy aides put it this way: "The point Bush makes to us in meeting after meeting is that while the U.S. is indeed very powerful and influential, if we are using that power everywhere, we will either cause a backlash or not prove very effective." It is a sentiment Mr. Bush himself expressed last month, just before the inauguration, while touring his ranch in Crawford, Tex., with two reporters. "I worry about our ugly-American problem," he said.
BUT can he trust that Japan will change the way it runs its economy, or persuade the Arabs and Israelis to talk rather than shoot, without keeping the United States in the prescription-writing business?
"You would be misreading the new administration to think that there is an aggregate decision to ratchet down," said Philip D. Zelikow, the director of the Miller Center of Public Affairs at the University of Virginia and a longtime friend and associate of Condoleezza Rice, Mr. Bush's national security adviser. "The two words they use the most often are discipline and strategy. It comes out of a sense that the Clinton people were too undisciplined, and they let events drive them."
Mr. Bush's team, he argued, is "trying hard to recover choice." That is why this president has no intention of playing the middle in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and why he abhors tying up the military in "nation-building," which in his view hurts readiness for emergencies.
All this fits nicely into Mr. Bush's preference for pragmatism over ideology. Like his father, he tends toattack problems through personal relationships -- which is what the ranch diplomacy with Mr. Fox was all about. Perhaps this was Mr. Bush's idea of humility: he talked about a "North American energy policy" rather than one the United States presumes to dominate, and he appeared to be taking seriously proposals for a guest worker program that sends shivers up the backs of some conservatives in his own party.
The flip side of the Bush team's predilection for the personal is a lack of much real enthusiasm for the multilateral institutions that Mr. Clinton saw as the vital wiring of a globalized world.
In his last speech to the United Nations, Mr. Clinton talked about promoting a global rapid-reaction force that, with American help, could intervene inside national borders before civil war turned to genocide. Don't hold your breath for Mr. Bush to repeat those words. As a close military adviser to Vice President Cheney notes, "There's a real sense in this White House that the Haitis and Rwandas and Kosovos of the world are not materially better off after our interventions than they would have been without them."
IF that's the analysis, though, Mr. Bush's few weeks in the Oval Office have already taught him to speak with a lot more subtlety than he did on the campaign trail. 
For example, there he was last week at NATO's Atlantic headquarters in Norfolk, Va., repeating that he would consult, consult and consult some more before doing anything precipitous about pulling troops out of the Balkans. Similarly, in an exchange of letters with President Jiang Zemin of China last week, he said Beijing had nothing to fear from an American missile defense. He says he is certain he will convince the Chinese, over time, that his plan is not aimed at them.
The fear in Europe and Asia, of course, is that the talk of consultation is just for show -- that Mr. Bush wants to put a multinational patina on views he's already arrived at.
"That's not the case," a senior adviser argues. "I am certain that the consultations will affect our plans in a variety of areas."
Of course, the real test of America's new management won't come until grand pronouncements confront some global reality. Iraq is just a start. The first time a Rwanda-like carnage unfolds on CNN, or a Russia-like financial crisis threatens to take out the Nasdaq, the conversations about "overdeployment" and "crazy" financial interventions will get truly interesting. That's also when the president who has been overseas three times in his adult life gets his first real tour of the world.

HEADLINE: The World; 
America's Dream: A Mexico Like Itself

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY 

 BODY:
WE stopped in wonderment," wrote Bernal Diaz del Castillo, chronicler of the Spanish conquest of Mexico, after entering this Aztec capital in 1519. "Some of our soldiers even said that perhaps they were seeing all of this as though in a dream."
 People from the United States have had a hard time seeing Mexico straight, too. Millions come here and never see it at all, spending their days in tourist enclaves speaking English and spending dollars. Others gaze down from on high and see an image of their own devising. Now President Bush has come to Mexico seeking "a closer partnership with the United States" based on everything from natural gas to migrant labor. 
 For two decades, the distorting prisms of the wars on migrants and drugs and communism have made American panjandrums paint Mexico as a pretty scary place, but one that could be tamed by projecting American political and economic power.
In 1980, The New York Times published an opinion article by a conservative writer and editor named Constantine C. Menges warning that Communist advances in Central America threatened to make Mexico the "Iran next door": a revolutionary state wracked by "leftist terror" and "destabilization by a coalition of reformist, radical and Communist groups." William J. Casey, the director of central intelligence under President Reagan, believed all that and worse. He hired the man and together they pushed that view very, very hard.
None of it ever happened. "It is as though the cold war had been a mask that blinded us to the reality of the world," the late Mexican poet and Nobel laureate Octavio Paz told The New York Times in 1992.
When selling widgets became more important than shipping weapons in Latin America, American foreign policy smiled on Carlos Salinas de Gortari, president of Mexico from 1988 to 1994. Those smiles helped push the North American Free Trade Agreement to passage. Mr. Salinas and his team were just like us, American policymakers thought: they had gone to Ivy League schools and spoke English, so they thought and acted just like us.
I KNOW no government anywhere that is more competent," Henry Kissinger said in 1993. Hindsight suggests otherwise. Mr. Salinas left a legacy of political corruption, crony capitalism and economic crisis from which Mexico is still trying to recover.
And when the war on cocaine replaced the war on Communists, Washington's drug czar, retired Gen. Barry McCaffrey, praised his Mexican counterpart in the war on drugs as a man of "absolute unquestioned integrity." Days later, the very same man, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, was arrested; he was later convicted for working for the drug lords.
What made the high and mighty misread Mexico? More than wishful thinking, it was mirror-imaging: projecting American thought processes and value systems on everyone else. Adm. David E. Jeremiah, a former vice chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has critiqued it as "this 'everybody thinks like us' mind-set," a classic American cultural assumption that underlies cockeyed intelligence and myopic policy.
So can the United States see Mexico any more clearly now?
"Things are changing," says Mexico's new foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda. For years, he said, the United States thought "Mexico was a country where what mattered was stability, whoever delivered it -- it didn't make much difference how nice or not nice they were." So when Washington wanted good things to stay stable or bad things to change, it banked on whoever was in power, a Salinas or a Gutierrez -- individuals, not institutions, since the only institution in Mexico was the Institutional Revolutionary Party, in power since 1929. The United States thought it was seeing reasonable men who thought and talked in the American way, a government minister who went to Yale or a four-star drug czar schooled in American strategy, when what lay beneath was an ancient political machine that corrupted almost everything it touched.
The machine and its facade fell apart two months ago, when Vicente Fox became president, the first opponent of the ruling order -- Aztec, Spaniard or Mexican -- to take power peacefully. The vote showed that autocracy was dying in Mexico, and the institutions of democracy were being born.
THESE days, he is not masking Mexico to make it look like what American leaders want to see. He is saying that if Mexico builds its own institutions of democracy out of the rubble of the old order -- like the conquerors built this capital from the stones of the Aztec city they destroyed -- that in 10, 20 or 30 years, long after he is out of power, people might have better lives. He means by that better wages, education, health, housing, police, courts, maybe even politicians.
He says this without saying that Mexico is going to achieve it by becoming more like the United States. And this is something else that may be changing in Mexico.
"He doesn't need to come across as an American," Mr. Castaneda said. "He doesn't want to convince Americans that he's like them. He doesn't want to convince Americans that he wants Mexico to become like them." The two countries may become "much closer," Mr. Castaneda said. "But closer doesn't mean more alike."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Americans looking at Mexico often miss the differences between their two lands. This man is in a Wal-Mart store, but in Juarez. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Liberties; 
Deja Dubya

BYLINE:  By MAUREEN DOWD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
Nothing personal, Saddam. Just bidness. Bush family bidness.
 Grab the cannoli, drop the bombs. 
 While Bill Clinton is chaotically smashing his legacy, W. is methodically renovating his dad's legacy.
Keen to protect the family honor, the new president is going back, piece by piece, working to sand away the scars of Bush I. 
Amid the Republican hosannas for 43, it is easy to forget the Republican raspberries for 41 when he lost the White House eight years ago.
The name Bush was anathema to the right for years, until the Lewinsky scandal sparked Bush nostalgia.
Thursday night, at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Virginia, the audience was giddy at every mention of the Bush restoration, and squealed and aimed cameras at Dick Cheney as though he were Jennifer Lopez. (D.Che)
Outside the banquet hall, a booth was plastered with bumper stickers alarmed about "The Homosexual Agenda" -- "Recruit Children," "Destroy the Boy Scouts," "Take Over Public Schools."
Under the heading "Devaluing Life," were stickers shrieking about the "Morning-After Pill," "Baby Body Parts for $ ale" and "Stem-Cell Research."
Inside, over steaks and wine, Charlton Heston, head of the N.R.A., was offering the new president (back in the White House) advice in the voices of some of his movie characters.
As Long John Silver of "Treasure Island": "Aye, the battle was nip and tuck, we was all a-swearin' blue fire, but ya didn't falter. You ran our colors back up the mast -- eight long years now that fine emblem's been missin'. But let down your mates, sir, and you'll face the plank." 
As Bill Tyler of "The Mountain Men": "Keep your powder dry, Mr. President. Take a deep seat in the saddle and don that faraway look that marks a true man of vision."
As Col. George Taylor of "Planet of the Apes," Mr. Heston brandished a banana and advised: "Please, no monkeying around, Mr. President. We had enough of that during the last administration." 
W.'s political career rose from the ashes of his father's '92 loss. He learned from his father's mistakes. Now he wants to correct them.
If the Bush name was tarnished by leaving Saddam in power, W. can fix that. He has brought together the Bush I players Cheney, Powell and Rice to see if that unfinished war needs to be finished. (Not to mention the pleasure of payback for Saddam's assassination plot against Poppy in '93.)
If the Bush name was tarnished by breaking the no-new-taxes pledge in an honorable effort to cut the deficit, W. can fix that. He can ignore the deficit and cut taxes.
If the Bush name was tarnished by the airy-fairy Points of Light (Pints of Lite) office, W. can fix that. He instituted a faith-based social services program so serious it is a threat to the separation of church and state.
If the Bush name was tarnished by schizophrenic attempts to be Greenwich blue blood and Midland barbed wire, with Maine weekends colliding with invocations of pork rinds and "Hee Haw," W. can fix that. He can stay home on the Crawford range.
If the Bush name was tarnished by a recession that Mr. Clinton took credit for vanquishing, W. can fix that. He is blaming Mr. Clinton for the slowdown, so he can get credit for the eventual recovery.
If the Bush name was tarnished by association with the name Quayle, W. can fix that by associating with the name Cheney.
If the Bush name was tarnished by a lame attempt to be the Education President, W. can fix that with a dedicated attempt to be the Education President.
If the Bush name was tarnished with conservatives who thought the family more Rockefeller than Reagan, W. can fix that by modeling himself on Reagan. With appointments like John Ashcroft and Gale Norton, he is dancing with the ones who brung him.
If the Bush name was tarnished with oilmen friends by a decision to limit offshore drilling, W. can fix that by pushing to open the Arctic refuge and other areas to exploration.
If the Bush name was tarnished by "Don't cry for me, Argentina" Bushspeak, that fractured syntax that could render the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band into "the Nitty Ditty Nitty Gritty Great Bird," well, W. can't fix everything.

HEADLINE: DATA BANK; 
As Warnings Flash, Buyers Hit the Brakes

BYLINE:  By DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN 

 BODY:
The markets lost ground last week, undermined by bad earnings news and troubling economic reports.
 The slide began on Tuesday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, indicated that the Fed was not likely to cut interest rates before its next regular meeting. 
 Evidence of continued weakness among technology companies flashed again on Thursday, as Nortel Networks, the communications equipment maker, announced layoffs and reduced earnings forecasts.
 On Friday, a widely watched barometer of consumer confidence dropped to a seven-year low. And a report on the prices of finished goods showed that they rose at their fastest pace in more than 10 years.
 The Nasdaq suffered the most, ending the week at 2,425.38, down 45.59 points, or 1.8 percent. The Standard & Poor's 500 also declined, finishing at 1,301.53, off 13.23 points, or 1 percent. Only the Dow industrials escaped, though barely, reflecting an investor shift to companies better able to weather tough economic times. The Dow ended at 10,799.82, up 18.37 points, or 0.2 percent.
 The bad news also hurt the bond market. The yield on the 10-year bond finished at 5.09 percent, up from 5.02 percent the previous week. DYLAN LOEB McCLAIN

HEADLINE: Praised by Bush, A Church Center From the Streets 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE GOODSTEIN 

 BODY:
When George W. Bush was campaigning for president, he stopped in downtown Los Angeles at the Dream Center and praised it as the kind of religious antipoverty program he wanted his administration to support. Now that Mr. Bush is president, a close look at the Dream Center suggests how such charities might use public money in their work. 
 The center is a church for worshipers and a ministry for people in need. It was founded more than six years ago by a father-and-son team of Pentecostal pastors, Matthew Barnett, now 27, and his father, Tommy Barnett, the leader of an Assembly of God church in Phoenix. 
 Matthew Barnett said he wanted "to build a church that never sleeps" to serve the community. "All the programs are born by walking the streets and seeing the need." 
The group bought a former Franciscan hospital and renovated one wing. The center houses about 200 volunteers and 200 recovering drug and alcohol addicts, gang members and ex-convicts who call themselves BADD -- Born Again and Delivered Disciples. They rely on intensive Bible study and cold-turkey detoxification. Of those who make it through the first 30 days, when there is the greatest attrition, about half stay through the full year and finish the program, the center says.
The Dream Center is a virtual shopping center for social services, offering an emergency shelter, an AIDS hospice, volunteer doctors, a center for teenagers, a private school and a food program that the center's administrators say provides 20,000 meals a week.
The center costs more than half a million dollars a month to run, they say, raised from private donors and profits from the albums recorded by the Dream Center's band in its own recording studio. The only support the Dream Center receives from the government is surplus food.
The center is asking the state of California and the federal government for $700,000 in grants to start a job training program.
In the past, churches have complained that although they are eligible to receive government aid, they are sometimes discriminated against because their programs are too religious. The Bush administration is scheduled to open an office on Tuesday that would encourage cooperation between government agencies and religious social programs like the Dream Center. LAURIE GOODSTEIN

HEADLINE: YOUR TAXES; 
Swinging for Lower Rates

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
THE size is in flux, and the timing is under review. New components may be added. Other provisions may fall out or be scaled back. And at a time of sharp partisan division here, there is always some risk that politics, ideology and economics will combine to create gridlock.
 Nevertheless, chances are good that by summer Congress and the Bush administration will agree on the biggest tax cut in two decades. And while business groups are scrambling to increase their share, the bulk of the tax cut is all but certain to go to individuals. 
 "It's at least 75 percent that it's going to happen," said Stanley E. Collender, managing director of the federal budget consulting group at Fleishman-Hillard, a public relations and consulting firm. 
President Bush's proposal to cut taxes by $1.6 trillion over the next decade will be the starting point as Congress begins work in earnest on taxes and spending. His plan would reduce all income tax rates, double the child credit, provide a break to many two-income couples and phase out the estate tax.
What emerges at the end of the legislative process, however, will no doubt have been substantially altered in detail, if not in size, from the outline that Mr. Bush sent to Capitol Hill earlier this month.
"If you look back, Congresses have tended to give presidents the tax and spending targets they have requested," said Clint Stretch, the director of tax policy at Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm. "If the president asks for a $1.6 trillion tax cut, it's very likely that that's what he's going to get. At the same time, Congress has typically reshaped those tax packages."
Many Republicans in both the House and Senate want to increase the size of the tax cut and to make it retroactive to the beginning of this year. Democrats want to scale back Mr. Bush's plan, perhaps halving it to $800 billion, and to refocus its benefits, primarily on low- and middle-income people. And members of both parties are hearing from companies, interest groups and individuals who want to insert pet provisions into the bill.
The political debate is shaping up to be intense, and the lobbying is already furious. In trying to handicap the outcome, there is another wild card: the economy. 
The recent slowdown has made it easier for Mr. Bush to sell his plan as inoculation against recession. Continued deterioration in the economy may provide additional impetus to speed up and enlarge the tax cut. If the economy rebounds quickly, the push for a bigger, faster tax cut may lose some steam.
Further, some members of both parties are concerned that a big tax cut could lead to a fiscal mess if the projected federal budget surplus does not materialize as expected. 
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, suggested that Congress consider phasing in the tax cut so that it would take effect only if the surplus was realized on schedule and the national debt was reduced according to plan. A bipartisan group of five senators is trying to build support on Capitol Hill for a similar approach.
A TRIGGER mechanism that ties the tax cuts to the actual surplus -- not an estimated surplus based on long-range predictions -- is the only way we can be sure we are voting for fiscally responsible tax cuts," Senator Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, said.
For all the political and economic uncertainties, the basic components being considered for any tax cut are well established.
The heart of Mr. Bush's proposal is a reduction in all personal income tax brackets. There are now five of them: 15 percent, 28 percent, 31 percent, 36 percent and 39.6 percent. Mr. Bush's plan would reduce that to four -- 10 percent, 15 percent, 25 percent and 33 percent -- and tax more income at lower rates.
The change would be made over five years, under Mr. Bush's proposal, and the effect would be to cut income taxes for everyone who pays them.
BUT the Bush plan would give far bigger cuts to people at the upper end of the income scale than to people in the lower- and middle-income brackets. And it would do nothing for low- and moderate-income families who pay no income taxes but must still pay the payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare.
The Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal research group, calculated overall effects of the Bush income-tax proposals -- including reducing rates, expanding the child credit and limiting the marriage penalty. The group says that if the proposals were fully phased in, the top 1 percent of married couples filing jointly, who have an average income of $1.38 million, would get an average tax cut of $44,757, while the lowest 20 percent, with an average income of $18,450, would get a cut of only $116.
Republicans contend that it is only fair that wealthier people get a bigger portion of the tax cut, because they pay a bigger share of income taxes. In 1998, the most recent year for which figures are available, the top 5 percent of taxpayers paid 53.5 percent of the individual income taxes, according to the Tax Foundation, a business-oriented group, while the bottom 50 percent of the taxpayers paid only 4.2 percent.
But Democrats, objecting to so large a reduction to the well-off, say less-affluent people need the money more and would be more likely to give the economy a lift by spending any additional money they received through a tax cut.
Because of the concern over fairness -- and because the rate reductions account for about one-third of the cost of Mr. Bush's $1.6 trillion plan -- some analysts say it is possible that Congress will scale back the proposed rate cuts.
Democrats are considering plans that would create only one new bracket, 10 percent, or expand the current 15 percent bracket to higher incomes. They are also studying proposals that would effectively grant lower-income workers a rebate to offset some or all of the payroll taxes they pay. Some moderates in both parties are discussing plans that would reduce or delay any change in the top marginal rate of 39.6 percent.
"The rate cut is likely to be changed so it skews more toward lower- and middle-income families," Mr. Collender said. "As it is, the value of the tax cut for lower-income families is very small."
Two other aspects of Mr. Bush's proposal are likely to be included in any final tax bill this year. One is reducing the so-called marriage penalty, the quirk in the tax code that causes many two-income couples to owe more taxes than they would have if they had remained single. The other is an increase in the child credit, now $500 a child.
To ease the marriage penalty, Mr. Bush's plan would create a deduction for married couples filing jointly of as much as $3,000 -- 10 percent of the lower-earning spouse's income, up to a maximum of $30,000. 
Congress passed a bill last year that would have addressed the matter differently. The bill, vetoed by former President Bill Clinton, would have increased the standard deduction for married couples filing jointly so that it was twice the deduction for single people. And it would have increased the taxable income covered by the 15 percent bracket for couples filing jointly to twice the level for single filers.
That approach was more generous to married couples than Mr. Bush's, but it would also have been costlier -- $292 billion over 10 years, versus $88 billion. It is unclear which approach Congress will settle on this year, but some action on the marriage penalty is likely.
"That one's a done deal," Mr. Collender said. "Voting against it makes it look like you support living in sin."
Mr. Bush's proposal to double the child credit, to $1,000, is also likely to win support on both sides of the aisle. But his proposal contains a provision that is likely to be criticized by Democrats. 
The provision would allow married couples earning as much as $200,000 to claim the credit, up from $110,000 under current law. Some Democrats want to see the benefits of the increased credit focused on lower-income people.
THE part of Mr. Bush's plan that will probably draw the most fire, however, is the proposal to repeal the federal tax on large estates. 
Repealing the tax has long been a cherished goal of conservatives, who say it is unfair for the government to levy what amounts to a tax on death. But liberals say repeal of the tax would be an expensive giveaway to a relative handful of extremely wealthy families. Only 2 percent of all estates, those valued at more than $675,000, are subject to the tax; in 1998, more than one-fifth of all estate-tax revenue came from just 374 estates worth more than $20 million each.
Analysts say that there is ample room for compromise on the estate tax. Democrats supported an alternative last year that would have effectively exempted two groups that are often cited as its primary victims, small-business owners and family-owned farms, while continuing to levy the tax on most multimillion-dollar estates.
In the last few weeks, Mr. Bush has made it clear that he wants Congress to keep the total tax cuts to the $1.6 trillion he has proposed. But there is considerable pent-up demand on Capitol Hill for additional types of tax reductions. Some of them may make it into the final legislation, even if it means displacing or cutting back on some of Mr. Bush's provisions.
ONE that is certain to get a serious hearing is scaling back the alternative minimum tax. The A.M.T. was established three decades ago to prevent upper-income people from escaping income taxes through sophisticated tax strategies. 
But because of complexities in the tax code, the A.M.T. increasingly applies to people who earn as little as $30,000 a year.
Other ideas that could end up in the tax bill this year include a reduction of the long-term capital gains tax, an expansion of the individual retirement account and 401(k) retirement savings programs and a reduction in taxes on Social Security recipients who have substantial earnings aside from their retirement benefits.
Business groups are pressing for a reduction in the corporate income tax rate of 35 percent and an acceleration in the rate at which companies can write off their investments in equipment.
"When you add up all the things that aren't in the president's proposal, we're talking about real money," said Mr. Stretch at Deloitte & Touche. "Congress will insist on putting some of those things in the package, so something will have to give."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
A Questionable Crutch for a Limping Economy

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
HAVE investors lost faith in Alan Greenspan's magic?
 In early January, when Mr. Greenspan cut interest rates by one-half of a percentage point, stocks roared as investors exuded confidence that the market could indeed be saved. And when the Federal Reserve Board cut rates once more at the end of last month, strategists said again that the market was poised for recovery. 
 Now, however, investors aren't so sure. The Nasdaq, which has taken the brunt of the beating from fearful investors, lost 5 percent of its value on Friday and is down 1.8 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average is flat so far in 2001. 
A month or so ago, investors seemed certain that any economic slowdown would be quick and relatively painless. They argued that earnings weakness would pass and that share prices would rebound.
No longer. A steady drumbeat of dreary earnings reports from technology stocks -- Dell Computer and Nortel Networks most recently -- have investors concerned that the hangover from the bull-market party may last much longer than they previously thought. 
That is a reasonable view, said James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. He compared the economy today to that of 1990, the last time the United States endured a recession. That downturn ended quickly, in 1991. But while the Federal Reserve chopped the federal funds rate from 9 percent in 1990 to 3 percent by 1993, it wasn't until 1994 that the economy got out of a sluggish growth mood. 
What worries Mr. Paulsen today is the possibility that the Fed's rate cuts may not be able to rouse technology spending. "If the tech sector is driven more by new-product introductions, whether the Fed lowers or raises interest rates may have no impact," he said. "That was O.K. when tech was contributing 5 percent or less to economic growth. Now it's one-third of the growth rate and it becomes critically important." 
Indeed, Mr. Paulsen thinks that the United States has avoided two recessions in recent years solely because of the economic growth provided by new technologies that won the hearts of corporations and consumers. One near miss occurred in 1995 after the Mexican peso devaluation; then, sales of personal computers bailed out the country. Later, in 1998, when the rest of the world was in turmoil, buying into the Internet boom helped the nation avert the crisis. 
"Even though we think the Asian crisis ended in 1999," Mr. Paulsen said, "signs that we hadn't really exited the crisis remained." Among them are excessive stock market volatility; depressed commodity prices, other than those that are energy-related; continued corporate layoffs; and persistently wide corporate bond spreads. "Maybe all those things indicated that most of the world didn't get out of economic crisis, but it was masked by the boom in technology," Mr. Paulsen said.
This picture has troubling implications for corporate earnings in 2001. "Normally, we go into a recession after a period where pricing power has been strong," Mr. Paulsen said. Not this time. On Friday, the report on producer prices showed that raw goods, excluding food and energy, actually fell in price by 7.4 percent, year over year. While energy prices have spiked, companies cannot pass along the price increases. "This will put a unique pressure on profits," Mr. Paulsen said. "It's a tough place to be."

HEADLINE: Burmese Junta in Talks With Democracy Leader 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Feb. 17 

 BODY:
The first sign that something unusual was going on was the disappearance of editorial cartoons pillorying Myanmar's pro-democracy leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, as a "democracy princess," a "political stunt actress" and a "Satan of destruction."
 Then the diatribes against her that have been a staple of the state-controlled press became more muted and indirect. Soon after that, newspapers stopped printing periodic announcements of forced "voluntary resignations" of members of Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's political party. 
 "The papers are even less interesting now than they were, if you can imagine that," said a Western resident of Myanmar, formerly Burma.
During the last month the reason has emerged, and it has stirred a tremor of excitement among experts watching the long, sad political standoff in Myanmar, a police state.
For the first time since 1994, the military junta that runs the country has begun holding talks with Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi. Both sides have suspended their war of words in a tentative period of what diplomats call confidence building.
Small convoys of government vehicles have been observed entering and leaving Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's home, where she has been confined for the last four months. Diplomats say she has been talking with top leaders of the junta who in the past refused to deal directly with her.
But beyond this, almost nothing is known: why the military government has decided to talk, what subjects are being discussed or where this new approach might lead.
Most experts agree, though, that there is still a clear bottom line. The military that has ruled Myanmar since 1962 and the current junta -- in power since 1988 -- have no intention of giving away or sharing any substantive power.
"At this point, the most we can expect is some loosening up around the edges," said Josef Silverstein, an expert on Myanmar who is an emeritus professor of political science at Rutgers University.
It is still possible that the talks are just a ploy to make the government appear flexible in the hope that international sanctions will be eased and foreign aid from countries like Japan will begin to trickle in again.
The United States and Europe have been squeezing Myanmar for years with political pressure and sanctions. The United States has banned new business deals there by American companies and refuses visas to Myanmar government officials. The European Union has scaled back contacts with an Asian regional grouping that includes Myanmar.
They are responding to the quashing of a democratic movement that swelled in 1988 with a peaceful nationwide uprising. Thousands of people were killed in massacres by the military. 
Two years later, in a monumental miscalculation, the military held a parliamentary election in which Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy, won 88 percent of the seats. The junta quickly annulled the results and instituted an even more thorough political clampdown.
Late last year, it appeared that the government was determined to eliminate once and for all the National League for Democracy, jailing its members or forcing them to resign and isolating Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi from her supporters.
Now the government seems to have changed tack sharply. In its first substantive gesture, last month it released 85 members of the party who had been imprisoned during the last year. It is still believed to be holding as many as 1,700 political prisoners, including 35 people who were elected to Parliament in 1990.
The news has touched off a debate over whether the sanctions have caused this new softening.
If the talks are more than public relations, several factors may be at play, and economic pain appears to be chief among them. Myanmar's economy is a mismanaged shambles and getting worse, with inflation rising and the currency rapidly losing value, some of the last foreign investors pulling out and economic growth slowing to a crawl.
Monopolies run by the military and its cronies have skewed and sapped the economy. The World Bank recently described Myanmar as "trapped in abject poverty."
A European diplomat in Myanmar who has not supported sanctions said he had come to believe that they were decisive. One final straw, he said, was a recommendation last November by the International Labor Organization to its 175 member nations to reconsider doing business with Myanmar.
But other experts disagree.
"The difference in analyses is whether the sanctions were at the heart of the economic downturn and therefore of the willingness of the government to make concessions," said David I. Steinberg, director of Asian studies at Georgetown University, who visited Myanmar last month. "I say the sanctions played a minor part."
A parallel source of pressure has come from the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the regional economic grouping that admitted Myanmar as a member in 1997 and has mostly pursued a policy of economic and political engagement.
The Asian financial crisis that same year dashed hopes in Myanmar for a surge in regional trade and investment. And the continuing political intransigence of the government has soured some of its neighbors on forging closer ties.
The push for a more flexible approach to the opposition may have come from Myanmar's strongest backer in the region, Malaysia, whose prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, visited early last month. Myanmar has become a liability to the 10-member Asean grouping, straining relations with Western nations and embarrassing the Malaysians who insisted on its admission.
More broadly, it may be that both sides, like a pair of exhausted boxers, are ready to seek a way out of their futile 12-year standoff.
Despite all its efforts, the military government is still reviled by much of the population, still struggling for legitimacy, beset by enemies on all sides, and by reported internal rifts.
It continues a seemingly endless battle against ethnic insurgencies and is so nervous about dissent that it has kept most universities closed for years.
The democratic opposition, ground down and unable to function openly, has won nothing, although it maintains high respect abroad and continues to draw young recruits into its ranks. It has come under increasing criticism for promoting sanctions and boycotts that have contributed to the hardships of the population and failed to force reforms.
A number of experts say that at least some members of the military government would like to compromise. The junta has said for years that it wants to shift to civilian government -- though these civilians may mostly be military men in suits. 
The trick is to find a way to loosen its grip without losing everything. The examples of Russia and Eastern Europe are not encouraging. And so the junta hangs on for dear life.
"Once you begin to pull that thread, the whole sweater can unravel," said Mr. Silverstein of Rutgers. "That's what the military is worried about."

HEADLINE: Architect of Bush Presidency Still Builds Bridges of Power 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE and FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 

 BODY:
Inside the White House Cabinet Room on Thursday evening, President Bush waited to receive Republican senators. But his guests were in no hurry. Just outside the door, there was something of a logjam because they wanted, first, to pay respects to the aide who is widely viewed as the principal architect of the Bush presidency: Karl Rove.
 "The line backed up because every one of them stopped and said, 'Hello,' " Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee said. "They know how important he is. Everybody knows that in terms of putting it all together, in terms of the politics, in terms of strategy positions and also policy, that Karl is the hub, the central node of activity that surrounds the presidency." 
 Many Republicans, some of them advisers to President Bush, say that although Mr. Rove, a political operative from Austin, Tex., has not worked in the capital for more than two decades, he has already created a profound sphere of influence here. He is proving that his role as a mastermind of Mr. Bush's political career did not stop at the Texas border. 
More than any other person in the Bush administration, Mr. Rove, who plotted Mr. Bush's run for the presidency and was his chief campaign strategist, has been the driving force in setting out how Mr. Bush spends each week, and even each day, including whom he sees and what he talks about.
Officially, Mr. Rove is the president's senior adviser, with purview over the offices of political affairs and public liaison. But he is also in charge of a new Office of Strategic Initiatives -- something of a research group in the White House -- and that role allows him to dive into almost every facet of the administration. "Basically, Karl Rove has carte blanche to stick his nose into anything he deems appropriate or necessary," Ed Gillespie, a Republican strategist who worked on the campaign, said.
Mr. Rove is commanding attention as a new power in this town. Even as he arrived late for a recent interview over dinner at the Oval Room, a restaurant two blocks from the White House, he could be seen lingering on the sidewalk to conduct just a bit more business on his cell phone.
Once inside, Mr. Rove indulged in fried calamari (he never drinks) and reflected on his new role. He carried with him a binder titled "Long Term Planning Sessions," but refused to let reporters have even the quickest of peeks inside. He flashed a meeting card that showed a day crammed with meetings in the West Wing.
In a subsequent interview, Mr. Rove dismissed whispers among Republicans on Capitol Hill that he was, in the words of one, building "the Karl Rove empire." He groaned and said his response to that was "to laugh and chortle a little bit."
"Look," he said, "I work for the president and my immediate superiors are Josh Bolten, the deputy chief of staff, and Andy Card, the chief of staff." When he was asked if he truly had to get Mr. Card to sign off on things, his response fell short of a yes. "If I'm smart, I do. Listen, I do what I'm told."
It is true that Mr. Card has far more Washington seasoning than Mr. Rove does, and sees the president more often. Vice President Dick Cheney, of course, enjoys the president's deepest trust and has dealt with Washington power players far longer than Mr. Rove has.
And Karen P. Hughes, the president's counselor, oversees a fief that is larger than the 30 or so aides under Mr. Rove, and enjoys a firmer claim to the president's ear, say Bush advisers who call her probably his closest staff confidante. It was Ms. Hughes who was Mr. Bush's guest at the head table at the exclusive Alfalfa Club dinner in late January.
Even so, Mr. Rove, 50, is integrating himself into a broadened Bush political operation because he has succeeded in exerting influence in and outside the White House. He arrived in town with a vast network, having done direct mail work and other consulting for many Congressional campaigns. "Karl has one advantage over Andy and Karen, and that is that he is truly a strategic thinker," one prominent Republican said. "And he's as good as they are at operations, but better at strategic planning."
While others around Mr. Bush were distracted by the Florida recount and by planning their own moves to Washington, Mr. Rove plotted in daily detail the first five to six weeks of the Bush presidency, several administration officials said. The first week, they said, it was Mr. Rove who choreographed Mr. Bush's meetings with members of Congress, arranging that the Republican leadership come to the White House first, followed by the Democrats. It was Mr. Rove who suggested that Mr. Bush address a Democratic House retreat.
It was Mr. Rove's idea for the president to summon Democratic elders to the Oval Office on Mr. Bush's first Monday in office, they said. "It was Karl's sense that that would dramatize a sense of bipartisanship," one White House official said.
It was Mr. Rove, apparently, who urged the president to resist injecting his tax proposal with provisions pressed for by corporations. "Karl was the one who said, 'No, let's send this up exactly as it is,' " one prominent Republican official with close ties to the administration said.
It was Mr. Rove who intervened and persuaded Representative Charlie Norwood, a Georgia Republican and an important player on health care issues, to back off from taking part in a news conference he had scheduled to announce a compromise he had developed on a patients' bill of rights. It was Mr. Rove and not Nicholas E. Calio, the White House Congressional liaison, who ran the strategy session at the White House on the matter.
Denying that he strong-armed Mr. Norwood, Mr. Rove said: "You can't squeeze Charlie Norwood. He is a person of enormous strength."
Mr. Rove, who inherited his office from Hillary Rodham Clinton, does not usually sit; he operates standing, from a tall reading desk. And his reach extends far beyond the White House.
He has become the administration's bridge to conservatives, economic and religious. He made calls assuring influential conservatives that Mr. Bush was not about to abandon John Ashcroft when his nomination as attorney general was under fire. He was involved in the effort to appease conservatives with Mr. Bush's executive order on abortion on his first full working day in the White House.
And he moved fast in helping create the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives, an office that is an emblem of the compassionate conservative political philosophy that Mr. Rove, as much as anyone else, brought to Mr. Bush's attention years ago.
When Mr. Cheney had to cancel as the dinner speaker at the Conservative Political Action Conference on Friday night, Mr. Rove agreed to step in.
"He didn't need to do it, because he's moving this weekend from Texas," said David A. Keene, the group's chairman. "He said he'd cancel his trip to Texas and be there because he thought it was important enough. Rove's role has been to really lock in the support that Bush, in the eyes of most conservatives, earned during the campaign." (Mr. Rove said that it did not make sense for him to fly to Austin when much of his house had already been packed.)
As part of his broader political portfolio, Mr. Rove essentially controls the Republican National Committee. It was at his behest that Mr. Bush installed Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia as the party chairman.
"Karl called and said, 'We think it would be a good thing to do if you'd like to do it,' " Mr. Gilmore recalled. "I presume that the idea sounded like a good one to Karl Rove or it probably wouldn't have occurred."
Republicans who know Mr. Rove said he has tried to make himself indispensable by being well informed and thinking ahead. His approach is to come to the table so prepared, and with so many suggestions, that he ends up having an imprint. Michael K. Deaver, who was President Ronald Reagan's image consultant, said Mr. Rove began seeking his advice two years ago on matters like "the importance of television and visuals."
White House officials said he planned the first days of the administration by assigning each of six staff members to research one of the past six presidents' first 100 days: how many news conferences they held, how many foreign trips they took, how many domestic trips they took. Each person produced a 10-page report, collected into a book Mr. Rove brought to the initial meeting on the first week of the Bush presidency.
The question about Mr. Rove, who is sometimes seen as an almost Pygmalion-like figure in Mr. Bush's life, is whether he can remain as powerful in an arena where he is competing more for the president's time -- and where his new strategic office has much potential but is undefined.
Mr. Rove sees the president just about every day, but not as instantaneously as during the campaign. "I'm impressed by how precious the president's time is," he said.
Asked about the danger that Mr. Rove and other aides will collide, Mr. Calio said, "You have to be careful. Inevitably, I think, we'll step on each other's toes -- but not maliciously."
A Republican operative who knows Mr. Rove well added, "There are enough checks and balances over there right now with seasoned Washington hands that he can't run roughshod and be the Austin cowboy." 
Yet while Mr. Rove usually tries to maintain a humble profile, at times he does not succeed. Some Bush advisers said that another side of Mr. Rove surfaced and he committed a subtle breach of Bush-world etiquette at an election post-mortem at the University of Pennsylvania last weekend, when he took responsibility -- and credit -- for many of the candidate's moves.
Mr. Rove also took the opportunity to flash his often disarming humor. He teased other Bush and Gore campaign officials there for getting paid -- and said he was bound by ethics rules. "You can't accept an honorarium," he said. "You can't accept expenses. You've got to pay for the transportation yourself. So I'm here, unlike the rest of your presenters, having paid every single nickel."
Just a few days earlier, as he relaxed with his wife, Darby, at the Oval Room, Mr. Rove savored how far he had come. Working in the White House, he said, was "awe-inspiring and humbling at the same time." Sometimes, Mr. Rove said, he thinks, "I'm going to wake up from a nap and MSNBC will be on and there will be another ruling from the Florida Supreme Court!"

Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, looked on. (Susana Raab for The New York Times)(pg. 22)

HEADLINE: A Decade Beyond the Gulf War 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 17 

 BODY:
Soon after the 1991 Persian Gulf war came to an end, senior aides to President George Bush predicted that Saddam Hussein would be overthrown within six months. A decade later, much of the old Bush national security team is back in power -- and still trying to fashion a plan to contain the ambitions of the Iraqi leader. 
 The American and British air strikes carried out Friday against radar installations and antiaircraft sites near Baghdad will reduce the growing risk to pilots who patrol the southern no-flight zone. 
 And they also send the message that the administration of George W. Bush is determined to keep the pressure on Iraq -- even as Washington ponders its options. Since Iraq fired more surface-to-air missiles in January at American and British patrols than in all of last year, officials here say a riposte was necessary. 
But the Friday air strikes do not decisively change the military situation in the Persian Gulf or provide a guide for how the new Bush administration hopes finally to dispense with the man whose survival has haunted Washington for years.
The United States has been reasonably successful in containing Iraqi power. But it has yet to figure out how to oust Mr. Hussein, or compel him to allow unfettered United Nations weapons inspections. The latest high-tech air strikes are more of a signal than a strategy. 
President Bush and his aides are, of course, just at the beginning, still hammering out a new and, they say, more muscular Iraqi policy. There are no easy answers. 
Economic sanctions are already in place and could no doubt be more strictly enforced. But it will take considerable lobbying by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell just to maintain them in the face of France, Russia, Middle Eastern and Asian states who see business in Baghdad.
The new Bush administration seems to be pinning much of its hope on the Iraqi opposition, which will soon receive $29 million in aid. So far, the opposition has not amounted to much. No one in the American political or military establishment has the appetite for another war with Saddam Hussein that might settle things once and for all.
That leaves air strikes, already a well-tried option. In 1998, for example, the United States and Britain carried out a four-day raid, after United Nations weapons inspectors withdrew from Iraq in the face of Iraqi intransigence.
Standing alongside President Vicente Fox of Mexico on Friday, Mr. Bush called the air strike routine. In fact the attack, which involved two dozen strike aircraft firing missiles at targets close to Baghdad and approved at the highest levels of the American and British governments after careful planning, was anything but routine. But, with no quick fixes for its Iraq problem, the Bush administration is evidently wary of raising expectations at home or anxieties among nervous allies abroad.
"Operations such as the one last night would not be needed if Saddam stopped attacking us," Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today. "But as long as he does, I will continue to take the steps necessary to protect our forces and to prevent Saddam from once again wreaking havoc, suffering and death." 
For now, Mr. Hussein may not even be America's most dangerous foe. Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born extremist who is the FBI's most wanted terrorist suspect, has in recent years struck with more deadly effect at American interests, orchestrating the August 1998 bombing of two American Embassies in East Africa, and is suspected of being behind the bombing last October of the destroyer Cole in Yemen.
Saddam Hussein, in contrast, is confined within his country, visibly defiant, seemingly determined to preserve some modicum of Iraq's programs for developing chemical, biological or nuclear weapons -- and apparently interested in shooting down an American or British pilot. 
That Mr. Hussein has held onto power for so long is a testimony to the ruthless way in which he runs Iraqi society. While the first Bush administration never explicitly set his ouster as an objective in the 1991 conflict, American military planners did what they could to loosen his grip on power. American warplanes and missiles struck his bunkers, intelligence services and political apparatus in the hope that his rule would be shattered. But he hung on without major internal challenges.
In one of history's perhaps more curious twists, the senior Mr. Bush's administration relaxed the military pressure against Mr. Hussein at a time when it was in the best position to squeeze the Iraqi leader.
Concerned in 1991 that the American military would be portrayed by the media as piling on in a one-sided rout, the Bush administration halted the ground war at 100 hours, a move that allowed much of the Republican Guard in Iraq, the most effective and loyal force in Mr. Hussein's military, to escape.
Nor did the Bush administration rush to impose a no-flight zone in southern Iraq when Shiite rebels were attacked by Iraqi helicopters in the wake of the gulf war. The senior Mr. Bush did not declare a southern no-flight zone until August 1992, some 18 months after the end of the war. 
Officials in that administration later explained that they were initially wary of establishing an air-exclusion zone in the south to parallel the one they set up in northern Iraq in 1991 to protect the Kurds. A second no-flight zone, officials initially worried, might entangle the United States in an Iraqi civil war or encourage the breakup of Iraq, which Bush strategists saw as a counterweight to Iran.
Having put the world on notice that it has the will to keep the pressure on Iraq, the new Bush team faces the task of explaining its broader strategy, particularly when General Powell visits the Middle East later this month.
President Bush, however, is not the only one to make Iraq the target of his first major military action. President Clinton's first military strike was also against Iraq: a June 1993 attack in which 23 cruise missiles were fired at an intelligence headquarters in Baghdad.
Mr. Clinton ordered the strike in retaliation for an assassination attempt against George W. Bush's father, which Mr. Hussein was accused of sponsoring. General Powell is familiar with that attack as well. He was the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff at the time and delivered the Pentagon briefing on the raid.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 INTERNATIONAL 3-15

China's Crackdown Raises Concern Over Psychiatry
The Chinese crackdown on the Falun Gong spiritual movement is focusing new attention on Beijing's practice of imprisoning dissenters in psychiatric hospitals. Hundreds of followers have been forcibly hospitalized and medicated in the government's campaign to discredit Falun Gong, human rights groups say. 1

Toll Rises in Serb Bus Bombing
British peacekeepers and United Nations police raised the death toll to 11 from a bomb that tore through a bus escorted by Swedish peacekeepers in Kosovo on Friday. Dozens were wounded, 21 of them seriously, British peacekeepers said. The attack was one of the bloodiest on Serbs since NATO-led peacekeepers took control of Kosovo 20 months ago. 4

Bush Selects U.N. Ambassador
President Bush has selected John D. Negroponte -- who has served in some of America's most sensitive diplomatic posts -- to become the next ambassador to the United Nations, an administration official said. If confirmed by the Senate, Mr. Negroponte would succeed his friend, Richard C. Holbrooke. 14

Kurdish Refugees Discovered
Migrant smugglers deliberately ran aground and abandoned a rusting freighter with more than 900 Kurdish refugees crammed in squalor in its holds off the French Riviera, the police said. 10

A senior naval commander said that he would convene a formal court of inquiry to investigate the collision of the submarine Greeneville and a Japanese vessel off Hawaii, setting the stage for what amounts to a public trial of the submarine's captain and crew. The inquiry, to be led by three admirals, could begin as soon as this week with the first public hearings. 1

Cell-Phone Restrictions
Lawmakers across the nation are submitting proposals for controls or outright bans on the use of cell phones while driving. At least 11 such laws have been enacted by local governments, but none statewide. 1

Karl Rove is proving that his role as a mastermind of President Bush's political career did not stop at the Texas border. 1

Pitfalls of Stock Options
Recipients are learning that stock options can come back to bite them. If the stock values plummet, the high taxes owed remain unaffected. 1

HEADLINE: Pardon Is Trouble for Clinton Library 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 15 

 BODY:
It seems fitting somehow. Bill Clinton's presidential library, which will be charged with telling the story of a presidency compromised by self-infliction, is now itself caught in a storm created by Mr. Clinton's own hand.
 Because of the last-minute pardon granted by Mr. Clinton to Marc Rich, and the subsequent revelation that Mr. Rich's former wife, Denise Rich, contributed $450,000 toward building the $200 million complex here, the library's fund-raising practices are now at the center of a Congressional investigation. 
 On Tuesday, the House Committee on Government Reform, led by Representative Dan Burton, an Indiana Republican, subpoenaed records of all contributions and pledges of more than $5,000 to the William J. Clinton Presidential Foundation. The foundation, the fund-raising arm for the library that is led by Mr. Clinton's longtime friend Skip Rutherford, has until noon on Thursday to respond.
The Congressional demand presents the foundation with a lose-lose proposition. 
If it responds to the subpoena, it would break its pledge to contributors who were guaranteed anonymity unless they chose to publicize their gifts. Some, Mr. Rutherford said, prefer anonymity because they are publicity shy, while some want to avoid solicitation by other groups.
By revealing its donors, the foundation would set a precedent that could make anonymous donors think twice before opening their checkbooks to all manner of charities. And it would set off inquiries by Congressional Republicans and journalists, who would scrutinize the foundation's records for evidence that donors were granted presidential favors.
But if the foundation refused to comply, it could be cited for contempt of Congress and drawn into a lengthy court battle. And the foundation would create an impression that it and Mr. Clinton had something to hide.
Mr. Rutherford, the volunteer president of the board, is clearly exasperated by the choice facing the foundation, which has among its board members Terry McAuliffe, the newly elected chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Ann Jordan, the wife of Mr. Clinton's friend Vernon E. Jordan Jr. Now, Mr. Rutherford can only joke about the former president's propensity for complicating the lives of his friends.
"Given my over-25-year friendship with him, why would I expect it to be easy?" he asked in an interview. "It's like the movie 'Jaws.' Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the water." 
The Congressional subpoena is not the only headache afflicting the William Jefferson Clinton Presidential Center. It is the subject of two lawsuits, each challenging the City of Little Rock's role in buying and clearing the land for the center, on 27.7 acres of dilapidated riverfront. 
One lawsuit challenges the city's decision to finance the $16.5 million land deal with revenue bonds, which did not require a referendum, and to pay off the bonds with fees from the city zoo and golf course. The other objects to the city's use of its eminent domain powers to condemn land needed for the library project. The city won both cases in the lower courts but both are being appealed to the state Supreme Court.
Mr. Rutherford also heard plenty of grumbling from Arkansans when it was revealed last week that the library foundation was planning to spend $300,000 to subsidize the $738,700 taxpayer expense of renting a New York office for Mr. Clinton in Carnegie Hall Tower.
Mr. Rutherford argued that because Mr. Clinton would be based in New York, it was appropriate for the foundation to help him conduct its work there. That did not go down easily at home.
"When you hear about it from your wife, your children and people at the Central High School ballgame, you realize it was an issue that people have concerns about," he said.
Mr. Rutherford said he hoped that Mr. Clinton's decision to seek less expensive office space in Harlem would make foundation money unnecessary. As a prominent public relations executive in Little Rock, Mr. Rutherford has constructed an interesting spin about the travails of Mr. Clinton and the library project: they will be good for business.
"Controversy for presidential libraries is a gold mine," he told a Chamber of Commerce leadership forum today. "It's the dull libraries that have trouble," he said.
One of his listeners could not resist a dry comeback: "You must be pretty happy." 
With nearly 77 million pages of documents, 75,000 artifacts and 1.8 million photographs, the Clinton library will house the largest collection of any presidential archive. And given the foundation's $200 million fund-raising goal, it probably will be the most expensive of the country's 12 presidential libraries.
Mr. Rutherford declined today to discuss the size and number of donations to the foundation or to say how much of the fund-raising goal had been pledged. He said the foundation's troubles had not yet hurt fund-raising, and speculated that they might encourage Clinton loyalists to give even more.
An estimated $100 million is to be spent on the library, a bridgelike structure designed by James Stewart Polshek to extend over the banks of the Arkansas River. The design includes a 5,000-square-foot penthouse for the Clintons.
The rest of the money could be used to create an endowment, landscape a surrounding park, rehabilitate a railroad bridge, help establish a school of public service affiliated with the University of Arkansas and create a retreat out of a house in Hot Springs that once belonged to Mr. Clinton's uncle.
City leaders expect the library to anchor a vibrant River Market district that is already attracting galleries and restaurants. They estimate its direct economic impact at $12 million a year and say that the planned library has already lured several significant developments to downtown.
Depending on the resolution of the lawsuits, ground could be broken late this year, with the center's opening projected for 2004. About 625 tons of archival material were flown from Washington to Little Rock on eight C-5 transport planes between November and late January, said David Alsobrook, an experienced presidential archivist who is directing the processing of the Clinton materials. The records are being stored in a former Oldsmobile dealership that has been converted into a temporary archive. 
Boxes holding the documents are stacked 10-high in secure, climate-controlled rooms. One room is crowded with crates bearing gifts to Mr. Clinton, including 14,000 books. Mr. Alsobrook has put a sampling of the gifts on display, including a mother-of-pearl rendition of "The Last Supper" given by Yasir Arafat and a mosaic of Rome's Colosseum given by Pope John Paul II. Then there is the dancing Elvis Presley telephone, donor unidentified. 
By federal law, none of the records will be open to researchers for five years, except for records relating to the failed Clinton health care proposal that have already been made available. The full processing of the papers will not be completed for generations. 
"It won't be in my lifetime," Mr. Alsobrook said, "and some of the younger archivists who just started will be retired from the government by the time it's finished. We've never had this much material."

HEADLINE: Writers Strike May Not Be Inevitable 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 

 BODY:
The Writers Guild of America has been sequestered for four weeks in talks with the major studios and television networks, allowing a gradual, creeping sense of optimism to build in Hollywood that perhaps, just perhaps, a settlement may yet be reached to forestall long-dreaded dual strikes this summer by the industry's writers and actors.
 Initially, John Wells, the guild's president, said that the writers would only negotiate for two weeks, unless significant progress was being made. Without such progress, he said, talks would be halted until closer to the expiration of the contract with producers on May 1. 
 Under a news blackout, few concrete details have emerged. But now that the talks have extended into a third week and a fourth, a strike which many had come to see as a fait accompli has begun to lose some of its air of inevitability. 
Some of those involved in the talks late this week began to rain -- ever so lightly -- on that parade, putting out the word that while progress was being made, the gap between the two sides remained huge.
"I hear they're putting on a good face, but they're making no significant progress," said Mark Gordon, the producer of "Saving Private Ryan" and "The Patriot." "A lot of people are going to get hurt very badly in this thing. The trickle-down effect will be unbelievable."
Of course, there was no way to know how much of this nouvelle pessimism was a sincere attempt to dampen expectations and how much the usual brand of brinkmanship that inevitably flows out of labor talks as they approach a climax.
The two sides exchanged proposals on some of the key economic issues in the strike last week and decided to spend the three-day holiday weekend studying them before meeting on Tuesday, in separate caucus groups, to discuss their reactions.
A strike by the 11,000 members of the guild, especially if followed by a walkout of the 135,000 actors affiliated with the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, would almost certainly cause large cutbacks throughout the entertainment industry as production on new films and television programs ground to a halt. 
The Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation estimates that more than a quarter-million people work in the entertainment industry in Southern California, but that figure does not account for the other businesses, like restaurants that cater to those Hollywood workers.
Studio officials said last week that recent estimates by the development corporation of a strike's impact -- about $250 million a week in direct impact and $257 million in additional, indirect impact -- were pretty much on the money, if not conservative.
Film production has been proceeding at a frantic pace for six months, with actors and crews ricocheting from one project to another.
"What happened is that the writers guild managed to convince everyone that they were serious this time about going out on strike," said one studio executive. "So for the first time, everyone got organized and got ready for it. And now the producers are trying to make it clear that they're serious about weathering a strike, too."
The contract talks between the writers guild, which represents most of Hollywood's screen and television writers, and the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers, which represents the studios and networks, began on Jan. 22 at the guild's glass-lined offices overlooking the farmers' market here.
The talks have been split into two groups, one discussing economic issues and the other so-called creative rights issues.
Writers, who have increasingly chafed under what they see as their second-class status in the filmmaking world, have demanded such concessions as a guarantee that they will be intimately included in the making of their films, including visits to the sets. They also want significant cutbacks in the use of the "film by" credit, which originally was meant to go to the most accomplished, veteran directors but in recent years has gone to untested first-timers as well. 
People with knowledge of what has been discussed in the talks, from both sides, say that compromises on these issues have been discussed.
One was to change contract language to make clear that writers are automatically invited to visit a film's set unless specifically not invited by the studio
Another was to grandfather the "film by" credit so that any director who has thus far received one would continue to do so, but future directors would need to meet some set criteria, like winning an Oscar or racking up a sizable total at the box-office, before joining the club.
While such creative-rights issues -- with their whiff of Hollywood ego run amok -- have dominated much of the early discussion about the talks, most believe that, in the end, the economic issues will be decisive.
The crux appears to be residuals, the money paid to writers for subsequent use of their films or television programs, whether in reruns, on videocassette and DVD, on pay television, in foreign markets or on the Internet.
Part of the issue is the wide array of formulas for determining different types of residuals -- five for motion pictures and seven for television, and that does not include the Internet, for which there is no residual formula as yet.
Concerning sale of material to foreign countries, for instance, the formula, negotiated when foreign sales were relatively minuscule, involves a series of payments based on a percentage of the minimum salary in the writer's guild contract. Now, after years of explosive growth in foreign sales, the guild wants a larger share of the additional revenues.
In videocassettes and DVD's, the guild wants higher residuals reflecting lowered manufacturing costs.
Studio officials say such demands fail to account for the increasing costs of producing movies, which have made the film business riskier than ever and have collapsed profit margins. The added money from those foreign markets and DVD's is needed to bolster sagging margins, they contend.
If the talks falter, attention will shift immediately to the actors' negotiations. The Screen Actors Guild's contract with the studios and networks runs out on June 30, but the union has yet to begin its negotiations, or even to choose its lead negotiator.
