HEADLINE: Patents; 
In health emergencies, Brazil allows the copying of drugs, to the dismay of American companies.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand; Patents may be viewed on the Web at www.uspto.gov or may be ordered through the mail, by patent number, for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil 

 BODY:
COUNTLESS pharmacies serve the nearly 20 million people living in this enormous city, including a chain called Drogeria Sao Paulo that features 24-hour franchises nestled next to all-night gas stations. Inside one of those drug stores on Vincenzo Rao Street, a large red and white sign hanging from the ceiling declares: "We have generics. Look at our list." An arrow points down to a six-page list printed from a Web site and propped on a counter display. 
 Generic drugs are crucial to the many poor and working class people in this urban sprawl, and the list is meant to help them find what they need. It provides the generic names of drugs, their corresponding brand name and identity of the original manufacturer, the name of the Brazilian pharmaceutical producing the generic, and whether it is generally dispensed at a hospital or pharmacy. 
 Here, however, the pharmacist and his assistant dispense generic drugs without asking for a prescription, and at a fraction of what the same brand-name medicine might cost in the United States.
There was a time when the drugs would probably have been outright knock-offs of American or European medications. Before 1996, drugs could not be patented in Brazil, so local manufacturers were free to replicate them. Even now, patent law in Brazil covers only those drugs invented since May 1997.
But Brazilian law now gives inventors exclusive rights for 20 years, protects drug inventions still in the development pipeline and brings Brazil into line with the World Trade Organization treaty called TRIPS, or Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights, a requirement for all W.T.O. members before 2006. And it settles most of a long-running dispute with the United States that at one point looked like it might lead to sanctions against Brazil.
But five years after the Brazilian law was enacted, irritations between the United States and Brazil persist. It is a continuation of the struggle between Western pharmaceutical companies and public health advocates over who has the right to produce and market life-saving drugs. And AIDS has sharpened the point of this battle in countries like Brazil, Thailand, and South Africa.
The 1996 Brazilian law says that to maintain a patent, an owner must make use of his technology in Brazil, and it makes clear that importing a product into the country is not enough to satisfy this requirement. American pharmaceutical companies complain that the requirement violates the W.T.O. treaty, and they have asked the trade body to intervene. They have also asked that Brazil be placed on a United States government watch list that is usually a first step toward sanctions.
To make matters worse for the giant American drug makers, in 1999 Brazil's president decreed that his government could license patents in case of a national emergency. Other countries, including the United States, have such a government-decree provision; in the United States it is often used in antitrust cases, when the courts order a company to share its technology to break up a monopoly.
The Brazilian decree has been exercised to ensure affordable access to AIDS medications. American companies object to the decree because it requires patent holders to turn over the secrets of their inventions if an emergency is declared to government officials and local manufacturers which might then produce the drugs.
American drug companies already lose hundreds of millions of dollars every year to product knock-offs and patent infringement. And they do not want to make piracy any easier. They also say only 3 of 10 new drugs prove successful, and the cost of developing all 10 are such that they cannot drop prices on the few that hit big. Instead, they have to earn back the costs of research, which the industry puts at $500 million per new drug, as well as the cost of marketing and lobbying, while leaving something for profits. 
Patents confer on those companies the right to charge whatever they choose for drugs they spent so much time and money to develop. But critics complain that they charge too much for crucial drugs and leave millions of sick people in poorer nations without medications. Intense international pressure in recent years had led to plans to give away doses of drugs to poor nations, and set up funds to purchase AIDS medicines and develop new ones.
Brazil, the largest market for American drugs in South America, is hardly a wild outpost of intellectual property. The country has had a patent law since 1809, when it became the fourth nation to adopt such legislation, and that law became part of Brazil's Constitution in 1824. But Brazilian patent law has always differed from United States law. In the early 1800's, patent applications could be rejected because the inventions were considered too complicated for laborers in Brazil's then overwhelmingly slave work force.
Brazilian patent law is based on the first-to-file principal, meaning whoever first applies for a patent will be its owner if it is granted. The United States operates on the first-to-invent rule, awarding patents only to the proven original inventor. Unlike American patent law, Brazilian patent law does not allow patents for inventions based on laws of nature or biological material, mathematical theories or works of art. And unlike United States law, it also excludes commercial or financial schemes, computer programs, the presentation of information, medical or surgical methods, the human genome, or rules of games. 
Brazilian law also allows authorities to reject a valid invention if it is morally offensive, or violates customs, public order or public health. The latter may be the central issue in what remains of the intellectual property battle between Brazil and the United States. 
The Brazilian law says a national emergency might arise from a threat to the public's health or nutrition, the environment, or the country's social, economic or technological development. American pharmaceutical makers say that leaves the door open for Brazil to decide that high drug prices are a "public interest" issue, and use that as a basis for awarding patent licenses.
And they are unhappy about the part of the 1999 decree that states that a patent owner must "transmit the necessary and sufficient information for the effective reproduction of the protected object, and other technical and commercial aspects applicable to the case."
In defending the decree, Brazil has only to point to its successful AIDS treatment program, in which the government has made generic medications available free of charge to anyone who is H.I.V.-positive. The ambitious program has made Brazil a showcase in the fight against AIDS and a model for countries. It has driven down both drug prices and deaths from AIDS. 
But the program's success has been possible only because of the very laws that American drug companies fear most: Brazil began copying expensive AIDS drugs patented abroad before 1997, when its new law went into effect. And declaring a national health emergency, it has been licensing AIDS drug patents awarded since then to government laboratories, which make generics for the free drug program.

HEADLINE: Some Hard Lessons For Online Grocer 

BYLINE:  By SAUL HANSELL 

DATELINE: FOSTER CITY, Calif. 

 BODY:
For anyone setting out to revolutionize the grocery business using the Internet, here's a tip, courtesy of Webvan, which has spent $1 billion so far trying to do just that.
 Do not bother putting a 100-foot-long computerized lazy susan in the freezer case, even though it can let one person load 8,000 types of items into one order without taking a step. At 20 degrees below zero, the thing turns so slowly that you are better off having workers jog through the freezer with shopping carts pulling items off shelves. 
 Here is another of Webvan's hard-earned lessons. If you figure your revolution will cost $2.5 billion, better get all the money up front. No matter how hot investors are for the idea one day, there is no telling when their pockets will be as tough to open as a frozen turkey. 
With the $1.2 billion it has raised, Webvan is the second-biggest online retailing bet after Amazon.com. But delivering groceries right to the kitchen counter is far more complex than sending books out by U.P.S. And Webvan, as the only major player still standing in the online supermarket field, is finding out there is a lot to learn when you are trying to change everything about the grocery business -- an entrenched bricks-and-mortar industry that earns razor-thin margins on half a trillion dollars year in sales. 
Debugging the mechanical devices and the computers that run them has been hard enough. But even harder has been changing consumer grocery-shopping behavior.
In San Francisco, the company's first market, 6.5 percent of the area's households have ordered from Webvan. That is great for the first year and half, but more than half never placed a second order. The system is so expensive to run that the company says it needs annual sales in the region of more than $125 million a year to break even, and so far it has reached only two-thirds of that.
Webvan's biggest problem, though, is that it is going to run out of money before it has time to see if it can solve the others. With operations in 10 cities, the company has been burning through $100 million in cash a quarter, and it only has $212 million left. Webvan missed its key goal of turning a profit in its first market, San Francisco, by the end of September 2000. And the investors are not going to put up any more cash until it does.
"If you had asked me two years ago, does this dot-com thing make any sense, I would have said, no, the bubble will burst," said George Shaheen, who left his $4-million-a-year job running Andersen Consulting, now known as Accenture, to become chief executive of Webvan in 1999. "But I didn't have any idea of the blood bath that would ensue."
But analysts say Webvan, based in this Silicon Valley city, has been tripped up as much by its own grandiosity as by the market. It bet on a highly complex and expensive automated distribution system. And it set out to enter 26 cities long before it had proved that its model worked.
"They needed to operate in one market, get their model perfect and show they could have a positive cash flow," said Lauren Levitan, an analyst with Robertson Stephens. "No one has ever gone public with a national rollout with zero markets performing to plan."
Suddenly, all of the grandiosity is gone from Webvan. Its programmers are no longer developing the kitchen of the future and are just trying to build electronic coupon systems that can increase sales in the present. It has long abandoned plans to enter 26 cities in three years, and now will not even open the $35 million warehouses it has already built in Glen Burnie, Md., and North Bergen, N.J. With these pullbacks and several rounds of layoffs, if everything goes according to the company's plan, it will end the year with $1 million in the bank.
But that may not be enough. Webvan's shares are trading for 34 cents each, down 99 percent from their high, valuing the company at less than the cash it has in the bank. Nasdaq has moved to suspend trading in Webvan shares, as it does for all companies with stocks consistently below $1. But Webvan figures that if it cannot improve its business improve enough so that its shares rebound, the delisting will be the least of its problems.
Indeed, if Webvan fails, it will be far and away the biggest financial disaster the Internet has yet seen. Investors, including Benchmark Capital, Sequoia Capital, Goldman, Sachs and CBS, pumped $793 million into Webvan. Another equally prestigious group put $430 million into HomeGrocer, the Seattle-based rival Webvan bought last year.
What is amazing in retrospect is that all that money was invested with almost no research into whether consumers would want its service. Its founder, Louis Borders, the reclusive mathematician who had started the bookstore chain that bears his name, focused exclusively on building the complex inventory management and distribution system.
Mr. Borders believed simply, said Mr. Shaheen, that "if we build it they will come." (Mr. Borders, who resigned last week from Webvan's board, declined requests for comment.)
There certainly were examples of people who had already tried to build online grocery delivery services. In every case, very few customers came.
Kroger, for example, ran an online shopping service in Columbus, Ohio, for five years with the long-struggling Internet company Peapod. "We had a core group of customers that loved it, but so few of them you could know them all on a first-name basis," said Rodney McMullen, Kroger's executive vice president for strategy. "A lot more customers tell you they want to use it than actually use it. It turns out that customers enjoy shopping and in any case they aren't good enough at planning to shop on the Internet." 
But Mr. Borders was convinced he could do what predecessors could not by offering more items at lower prices with far better service. Most significant, Webvan promised to arrive within 30 minutes of its promised time while Peapod and others specified only a two-hour delivery window.
Mr. Borders found support for his idea from David Beirne, a headhunter turned venture capitalist with Benchmark Capital, the brash Silicon Valley firm that had backed eBay, the online auction company. Mr. Beirne was a leading advocate of the "go big or go home" philosophy of Internet investing. And even now Mr. Beirne defends Webvan's breakneck pace.
"It's easy to say, 'Man, you could have done a few less markets,' " he said last week. "But there was a Catch-22. There was a unique opportunity to raise a huge amount of capital in the public market so we could build a business far faster than Sam Walton rolled out Wal-Mart. But to raise the money, you had to get above the noise level, build a brand name and make big promises to investors."
What was more, he said, the company feared that if it did not move first, competitors would outrun it. Indeed, in addition to the struggling grocery pioneers, Peopod and Streamline in Boston, Amazon.com and Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers, the prestigious venture firm, were backing HomeGrocer.
This created an arms race mentality on both sides.
"We had every investment banker and financial commentator pushing us to go further and faster than we were really comfortable," said J. Terrence Drayton, the founder of HomeGrocer. "They assured us that money was available in unending supply."
Last summer, as the market for Internet stocks began to slide, HomeGrocer agreed to be bought by Webvan.
The competition now looks much tamer, as several Web-based food delivery services have folded, including Streamline, Shoplink and Urban Fetch. Peapod has been transformed to the online affiliate of the store chains controlled by the Dutch company Royal Ahold. Most of the major supermarket chains have tiny pilot delivery projects that they do not intend to expand any time soon.
To some of HomeGrocer's backers, its sale was a frustrating turn of events because its model -- which relied on cheaper, less automated warehouses -- appears to be more in line with the realities of the market.
"We were bigger, doing better in the marketplace and were a lot closer to being profitable," said one of HomeGrocer's early investors, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "But Webvan spoiled it by telling such a big story to Wall Street. Now the business is on the verge of going away."
Webvan executives say that in retrospect HomeGrocer's design for $10 million warehouses was smarter than its $35 million wonders.
"If I were going to start over again, I would go with an infrastructure that would allow us to serve a market and add features as it grows," said Robert Swan, Webvan's president. 
But the company has little time for recriminations and has to run as much business as possible through its existing operations.
In San Francisco, for example, the warehouse was built to handle 8,000 orders a day, which would be more than 3 percent of the region's total grocery sales. To break even in 15 months according to plan, the company needed 3,300 orders a day. The average order size and average profit margin have been higher than the company expected, so it only needs 3,000 orders to break even. But as of the end of last year, it was only handling 2,150 daily orders.
Webvan has cut costs by imposing a $4.95 delivery fee on orders under $75. And it now will only promise an hour-long range of delivery times. (That is still giving consumers too good a deal, say Webvan's rivals at traditional supermarket chains.)
It is capitalizing on underutilized daytime capacity by going after the office market, delivering lunch platters and stationery supplies.
And most of all, Webvan must convince its existing customers, who only order 1.8 times a calendar quarter, to shop with it more often. It is stepping up its e-mail marketing, especially at its core audience -- busy mothers with children. And it is adding the products those customers want most. (In California, that means organic produce.)
Even though Webvan's prices matched its local rivals, some customers did not feel they were getting a good deal because the company did not accept coupons, and it did not offer the large economy packs of diapers and paper towels. (They took up too much space in the automated warehouse system.) As space is not Webvan's problem now, it has added lots of economy packages and a new electronic coupons system, too.
Relying on all this, a new ad campaign, a new loyalty reward program and perhaps no small measure of hope, Webvan has now told investors it will break even in San Francisco in the third quarter and in Los Angeles (HomeGrocer's biggest market) by the end of the year.
After looking for money last year, Webvan's board has decided to wait to see if the company can hit its revised profitability targets before seeking a new infusion. There is more than a little brinkmanship in this approach. But board members argue that letting the gas tank run almost to empty is both prudent and a great way to focus the company on efficiency.
"You either prove the model works, or you don't prove it," said James Barksdale, the former Netscape chief executive who had backed HomeGrocer and joined the Webvan board after its acquisition. "Necessity is the mother of invention."
This year's inventions must work flawlessly because it is too frigid to learn from any more mistakes.
"If we break even in two of our major markets, there is no doubt in my mind that there will be quality financing available to us," Mr. Shaheen said. "If we don't, I don't think the future is very bright. There is not a lot of forgiveness left."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: METS NOTEBOOK; 
Shades of 2000, Wilpon Has High Expectations

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 18 

 BODY:
Fred Wilpon was having a very good day. His golden retriever, Lefty, was chasing a ball around a practice field. Judy, his wife, and Sandy Koufax, his best friend for the past 50 years, were here. His manager and general manager are locked into new contracts and his team is the National League champion.
 So Wilpon, the Mets' co-owner, decided to do it again. For the second year in a row, he said he expected the Mets to win the pennant. 
 "We start every year with high expectations," Wilpon said today. "I don't think I could have stood here and said we would expect to be in the World Series in '80 or '81. But this year, yeah, I think that our expectation is that we play well enough to get into the World Series."
The reality of the game, Wilpon said, is that things change during a season and impact trades are usually made. But after an off-season in which the Mets failed to make a high-profile addition, Wilpon said he still believed the current team could get back to the World Series.
"I think our team is good enough now to compete and be the National League winner," he said.
Wilpon -- who pointed out the need for a left-handed No. 3 hitter but said the Giants' Barry Bonds is "not even on our radar screen" -- said he was surprised the Mets had not landed a premier player after pursuing so many this winter. But, Wilpon said, the team did everything it could while staying fiscally responsible.
"We didn't have a chance for some of the guys, because they had a predetermined preference to be elsewhere," Wilpon said, referring specifically to the left-hander Mike Hampton, who left the Mets to sign with Colorado.
Wilpon said the Mets were still discussing their stadium proposal with city officials and he was hopeful of reaching an agreement during Rudolph W. Giuliani's tenure as mayor. And while the plan of his co-owner, Nelson Doubleday, to refurbish Shea Stadium instead is "a valid thought," Wilpon said, "you can't renovate it so it is economically viable."

Words of Wisdom
Sandy Koufax, the Hall of Fame Dodgers pitcher, who sometimes visits the Mets' camp, gave a lengthy tutorial to the new Mets right-hander Rick Croushore. Koufax worked alongside the Mets' new pitching coach, Charlie Hough, a friend and a former Dodger.
"There's a best way to throw, and there's another way to pitch," Koufax said. "The best way to throw isn't always the best way to pitch. You can make a guy throw better, but all of a sudden, the ball's straight and he can't get anybody out. You've got to work with a guy's strengths."
Koufax said the strike zone was never very high. "I've never really seen the strike zone change as much as everyone talks about it," he said. "I think pitchers have always had the outside corner. You take away the outside corner, it's going to be an ugly thing."

Shinjo Is Impressive
Mets Manager Bobby Valentine saw outfielder Tsuyoshi Shinjo take batting practice for the first time today, and he liked what he saw.
"The ball jumps off his bat and seems to carry to the fences very easily," Valentine said. "It's a very easy swing."
Another reserve outfielder, the veteran Darren Bragg, also reported today. Bragg, who is from Waterbury, Conn., wore No. 56 for most of his career in honor of the former football Giants great Lawrence Taylor, but he dropped it because of Taylor's legal problems. Now, hoping to reverse his luck after a dismal year with Colorado, Bragg is wearing No. 56 again.

Off to a Good Start
The Mets raised ticket prices this year, but they set a record today for the first day of ticket sales. The team sold 105,000 individual game tickets and announced that the three-game series with the Yankees in June is sold out.

HEADLINE: City in a Mouse's Pocket Tries to Move Beyond Its Small World 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY 

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., Feb. 15 

 BODY:
Perhaps nowhere more than in this playground city has an economy so successfully been built on making people believe in make-believe. Now, however, it is the computer wizardry and engineering brainpower behind all those laser shows and thrill rides that the city wants to show off.
 Orlando, a place where people think Disney, not digital, is trying to diversify beyond tourism into the high-technology industry. Partly, the city fears that a slowing economy could cut ticket sales at its theme parks. Partly, there is a general sense among local officials and economic development experts that the city has long been too reliant on the lower-paying jobs of the service sector. And some people are simply tired of the Mickey Mouse jokes whenever they mention microchips. 
 At a recent trade show, executives from Digital Owl, an Orlando company that designs Web pages and electronic security technology for online book publishers, found themselves answering questions not so much about what they operate as where.
"We had people coming up to our booth and saying, 'You guys are from where?' " said Matt Gomez, the marketing communications director at Digital Owl. "Next, they'd say, 'Are you owned by Disney?' So we have to get around that."
To do just that on a broader scale, the city and surrounding Orange County have developed a strategy to strengthen the economic base here with high-skilled, high-wage jobs that they hope to create by attracting more technology businesses. As part of the strategy, the city dispatched some of its high-technology success stories to road shows intended to attract heads of venture capital firms who usually visit the city only on vacation. Orlando also gives tax breaks and other incentives to technology companies that move or expand here. And the Economic Development Commission of Mid-Florida, a partnership of government and business, has committed $17.5 million to marketing the city's technology base and vastly expanding it.
The goal is to add more than 18,000 mostly technology-related jobs over the next four years and to increase by $1.35 billion the amount of payroll local companies generate. One reason is that service jobs in Orlando's hotels, theme parks and tourist shops may be plentiful, but for most of the last decade have not necessarily been profitable, according to Commerce Department figures and local experts on economic development. In that time, per capita income in Orlando grew by 4.2 percent, lagging slightly behind the 4.6 percent national average, according to the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis.
"We grew dramatically but at a high preponderance of service-sector jobs," said Darrell Kelley, president of the Economic Development Commission, which represents four counties in central Florida. "We need to do a better job of creating high-value jobs, which is analogous with high tech." 
There have been some takers already. Milcom Technologies, a sort of incubator for high-tech startups, has created nine such companies in Orlando in its three years in business, and those firms now collectively employ more than 350 people. 
In 1995, Cirent Semiconductor, Orlando's crown jewel of high-tech, invested more than $700 million to expand and created 700 new jobs. And Digital Owl and a handful of other homegrown upstarts are beginning to secure venture capital from companies that once overlooked Florida.
Ask any adult here not wearing mouse ears and he will say that part of Orlando's problem is the good job it does of hiding its technology.
"If people come and are wowed by my technology, then they wouldn't be wowed by my shows," said Marc Watson, a Universal Studios creative director. "But the entertainment industry draws people to Orlando because we are using the most compelling technology we have."
The challenge now is to build on Orlando's existing technology base, according to a recent study of the technology industry here commissioned by the city and county. "Though Metro Orlando may be one of the most highly marketed regions in the world," the study concluded, "the current message is not targeted to high-tech companies."
To be sure, the city is in a position to do some name-dropping. It is home to the defense giant Lockheed Martin Electronics and Missiles and has businesses that develop products and services for industries like wireless communications, microelectronics and aerospace.
"I don't think people realize how deep high-tech goes here," said Kirstie Chadwick, chief executive of Digital Owl. "Disney has done their magic and overshadowed it."
Even Orlando's biggest advocates acknowledge that for the high-tech industry, moving out of the shadow will not be easy. One concern, some say, is that tourism will always command the bulk of the local resources.
"Local leaders seem to be willing to support tourism but less willing to support the high-tech industry," said Rick Foglesong, a political science professor at Rollins College here.
While the county has given $24 million in tax breaks and other financial incentives to high-tech firms in the last five years, it committed a combined $103 million for two highway interchange projects to support new Disney and Universal Studios attractions, Mr. Foglesong said. 
Those behind the diversification say the criticism is unfair, noting that Disney is the county's largest taxpayer and that the entertainment industry employs most of the workers here and pumps $19.7 billion annually into the economy, compared with $8.7 billion from technology.
"I believe the leadership in metro Orlando supports both industries and realizes the importance of diversifying our economy," Mayor Glenda Hood said. "Tourism relies heavily on technology. The two fit together nicely."
City officials and promoters resent any hint of an us-against-them mentality in envisioning a city dominated by both tourism and high tech.
"You cannot build a community by tearing down any economic sector of the community, certainly not your largest economic sector," said Bill Peeper, president of the Orlando/Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau. 
"This to me is a logical evolution of a community that does not want to sit on its laurels," Mr. Peeper said. "If we were so content just to be a tourism destination, I'd be worried."

HEADLINE: Beneath New Surface, an Undertow 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
Vivian Cabey stood on the stone porch of 60 West 129th Street, collecting her breath and her children after a bruising day at work. On this fall night, darkness had reached the block before she had, and ominous shadows played around her.
 Like Stygian guides, young men flitted in and out of the building with crackheads in tow. Mrs. Cabey barked that she would beat them or call the police. They kowtowed -- "You know we respect you more than anyone on the block, Mrs. Cabey" -- but the traffic continued. 
 Inside the building, graffiti had been lathered on. The cold had settled in the halls as if it had nowhere else to go. The stairwells were lightless. Up through seven stories, abandoned apartments were strewn with rubble and the detritus of a hundred house parties. In one empty room a child's decals still clung to the walls. For Mrs. Cabey, her children and grandchildren, this building was home. 
It had been so for seven years, more than two without heat or hot water. As Mrs. Cabey prepared for her third winter of plugging in electric heaters, the building was making her ever more nervous. The block on which the building sat, 129th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues in Harlem, gnawed at her even more. Over the years, its darker side, its underworld, had ensnared her children.
She could see, from where she stood, construction workers restoring the block's buildings. She could see white people moving in. She could see a new army of workers forged by stricter welfare laws, could see the signs trumpeting the block association's revival. 
So many signs of change -- but in Mrs. Cabey's life, there had barely been change at all. Her family, like many here, lived with, and was shaped by, the same circumstances that had long straitened lives on the block: a thriving drug trade, weak schools, early motherhood and the struggles of a single mother to care and provide for her children.
She saw the block as it still was at night, full of action and danger. She saw it as it had been when The New York Times last chronicled life on 129th Street, in 1994, when its troubles loomed large. 
In the years since, 17 buildings on the block have been rehabilitated. Shrinking welfare rolls and the expanding economy have sent dozens more residents into the work force. The falloff in the crack trade and new policing tactics have reduced violent crime. The high prices of real estate elsewhere in Manhattan, and conscious social planning, have brought black lawyers, white artists, African entrepreneurs and more to 129th Street, economically and racially integrating a block that had been almost all black, and mostly poor. 
But, like Mrs. Cabey, many on the block have felt unaffected. What is newly in sight, be it the property for sale or the $3.25 latte at the Starbucks on 125th Street, is not necessarily within reach. The setting has been transformed, but a core within remains unaltered, proof that it is easier to transform buildings than lives.
That is partly because the roots of those lives were planted decades ago, when the poorly educated children and grandchildren of slaves and sharecroppers came north, crowding into housing that quickly became substandard, and finding limitations on where they could live and work. They earned little, suffered health problems and passed those legacies, along with educational deficits, on to subsequent generations. 
By the time the poor of Harlem had the freedom to live or work where they chose, many no longer had the wherewithal. Ghetto life was made bearable by diversions that could be debilitating, from playing the numbers to drinking to, later, using drugs.
With its solid wall of tenements, 129th Street had always been different from the brownstone-lined blocks around it. It was more populous, and it was poorer. Residents of the tenements called their homes "the city"; the row houses and town houses down the block were labeled "the suburbs," a world apart. Now they are a class apart, filled with new homeowners and most of the whites on the block.
In the "city," struggle remains a constant, and that was where Mrs. Cabey was living. She was born in Harlem 54 years ago, and gave birth to 14 children. She has worked in food services at Harlem Hospital Center since 1968. Before his death in 1991, her husband watched the children. Since then, the children have watched one another.
Her children, she said, were all good kids -- Charlene a poet, Triesha a comic, Dionne a dreamer, Crystal a fighter, Fred his mother's right hand man, Iesha, at 9, the baby. But the years since 1994 have not been good for their prospects.
As crime statistics fell, three of her sons were incarcerated for drug-related crimes. As policymakers vowed that limiting welfare benefits would change the family structure of the urban poor, daughter after daughter became young mothers, usually with minimal support from the fathers. As residents rising in the information economy moved onto the block, child after child left or fell behind in school.
To Mrs. Cabey, then, 129th Street was still a wild place, which is why she dismissed the talk of a changing Harlem. The white men talking about real estate deals at Starbucks believed Harlem was a place rife with opportunity. She agreed. Too much opportunity, she said, referring to the block's web of temptations. Too much wrong opportunity.

A Paycheck Away From Disaster
If the future offered little on 129th Street in 1994, it did promise security, however measly. A young woman with a child and no means of support could pass safely from living with parents to living on welfare. 
Back then, Nadine Allen epitomized what it meant to be young on the block. Interviewed by The Times at 20, she was already world weary. Friends were dying violently. She had dropped out of school and given birth. With few skills, she seemed destined to follow her mother and many neighbors into welfare dependency. If she did not get off 129th Street, she said then, she would die. 
She did not think that six years on, it would be work that was killing her. 
In 1995, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani put into place the Work Experience Program, which required welfare recipients to work for their benefits. Ms. Allen's mother, Frances Weldon, embraced the program, saying it got her off the couch and back into the workforce. She became a payroll clerk at a home health care agency. Ms. Allen equated being forced to work for less than city wages to slavery, and left the rolls. Now she had to make a living.
For more than two years, she has done market research surveys at the Manhattan Phone Center, parsing the fine points of teas with consumers for $7.25 an hour, buying furniture with tax credits she got for working. The job bored her silly. "I'm dying slowly down there," she said, sighing.
In an era in which policymakers have proclaimed the end of welfare as we know it, the transforming powers of work -- the notion that any job, however menial, gives a life structure and meaning -- are being earnestly preached. 
But for Ms. Allen, the future stretched before her as bleakly as a shift at the phone center. She moved off 129th Street to a housing project, only to watch the murders stop and the block improve. She still had dreams of getting a high school equivalency and a law degree, but no plans to realize them. She prayed to win the lottery or "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." 
Her son's father was in prison for abusing her, and in the heat of summer, she swore she would have no more children. By fall, she was pregnant with twins. And her mother, who had said that returning to work had turned her life around, has not worked in months, citing high blood pressure.
Many 129th Street residents, meanwhile, are learning that whatever the psychic benefits of getting a paycheck, the earnings, usually under $20,000 a year, may not be enough to live on. Most still get government help with housing, and sometimes food. Those who do not, live on the edge.
In March, disinclined to work for just a welfare check, a 47-year-old resident of 129th Street named Yvonne answered an ad for a home health care agency, paid $150 for a training course, and believed that she was on her way. She worked for two patients, and much of the time was elated not to be depending on government.
But then one summer week her paycheck got lost in the mail. She was earning $5.25 an hour, 27 hours a week, and paying $442 in rent. That left just over $100 a month for Con Edison, food and subway fare. Without her check, she could not get to work. Pride forestalled asking neighbors for help (or allowing her full name in print).
So she parked herself on her building's cold front step, unlighted cigarette in hand, and waited for a friend to bring a few dollars. She watched children race down the block to see a fight, watched the flirting and the double Dutch and the sport utility vehicles go by with tinted windows rolled down, the drivers wanting to be seen and not seen. She heard the calls of "raise up," a warning passed down the block like a baton, as a police car turned onto 129th Street. 
By 11 p.m., the cigarette was still unlighted and her friend had not come. The next morning, she made a new friend: a loan shark, whom she must repay $8 for every $5 borrowed. By fall, she had a second job.
And just as former welfare recipients are learning to live on fragile, marginal jobs, another safety net is vanishing. The city, which had become the absentee and often negligent landlord of hundreds of Harlem properties, and which had taken a famously lax approach to rent collection, is putting those buildings back into private hands. The landlords taking over are less forgiving. Evictions are becoming more common. And for some residents of 129th Street, a toehold lost in Manhattan's housing market is almost impossible to regain. When it became clear that Rosenell Gladden, 39, a child care worker, could no longer live with relatives on 129th Street, she could not find even a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan for less than $900 a month. She and her daughter moved to the Bronx, joining the stream of economic refugees flowing north.

A Rub Between Old and New
The restored buildings on 129th Street -- ensconced lights, terrazzo floors -- glow with promise. New people, glowing with promise themselves, have helped fill them. Terrence Booth, 25, who moved from Florida to a corporate job and into the block's nicest building, describes New York as a place where you can move up if you want.
Mary Powell cannot move across the street. She applied twice to the developer the city picked to restore seven buildings on this block and screen their tenants. She never even got an interview. As she walks her building's garish orange hallways and climbs its decrepit stairs, she wonders why none of the fairy dust sprinkled over Harlem has landed on her.
She sees some whites, Mr. Booth among them, moving into the new buildings. Why them, she wonders.
She has cooked at the KFC outlet on 125th Street for six years. Despite raises, she still earns less than $7 an hour. She lives with the little inconveniences of poverty -- the $1 perfume, the apartment with no closet. The bigger ones are harder to swallow: an apartment so small that only three of her children can live with her, the other two stowed with her mother blocks away.
For her, every opportunity has a cost. She could take a better-paying supervisory position. But who would watch her children after school? As it was, she had to take the twins, now 8, to KFC with her after summer camp ended, lest she work just to pay a baby sitter. She could get health insurance, but that would savage her paycheck. She could get government help with her rent, but only if she entered a homeless shelter first. 
At 38 and single with five children and no high school diploma, she has concluded, "You ain't going to make it nowhere."
Of the block's many divides, the gap between the old and new economies, between outdated or nonexistent skills and high-skill jobs, may be the hardest to overcome. New residents like Mr. Booth work with numbers and computers, the new economy's brick and mortar. Many long-term residents lack high school educations. Some impoverished mothers here, terrified by that gap, have begun leasing computers for their children. The literal brick-and-mortar jobs seem out of reach, too. Harlem is the site of more construction than at any point since perhaps the boom that built it. And yet everyone, including the contractors doing the hiring, agree that the explosion is employing few Harlem residents. Only 50 percent of Central Harlem's men were in the labor force as of 1999, compared with 70 percent citywide, and more than 16 percent were unemployed, nearly three times the citywide rate.
At 7:30 one morning, as a rehabilitation crew puts the finishing touches on 47 West 129th, Kevin Evans is nearby beginning a day of scrounging odd jobs. A resident hires him for a few dollars to sweep the crab legs and beer bottles from the night before.
The construction jobs across the street might as well be across the country. Mr. Evans believes the jobs are off limits because they are union and he is not, and he does not cross the street to find out. 
In fact, most of the residential rehab work being done in Harlem is not union work, according to Thomas J. Metallo, the president of Great American Construction, which has worked on 129th Street. And yet most of their subcontractors and employees are not Harlem residents. 
Some contractors bring their own labor. Others prefer Mexicans or others who tend to work for less. And contractors say that many Harlem residents lack the necessary skills, or a work ethic, or both. Day to day, they can be used as laborers, perhaps, earning $8 to $10 an hour, but little else. 
"Everyone walks in off the street and says they want a job, but unfortunately we can't give everyone a job," one contractor, Doug Timmons, told a community board committee one night. "Unfortunately, we're not in a position to train." 
Most of the contractors are also not local; city officials say they have struggled to find Harlem contractors with the resources for large projects.
The new businesses in Harlem, meanwhile, are hiring local residents, but mostly for low-end jobs. At another neighborhood meeting, representatives of Harlem's new Old Navy, owned by the national chain, said that they could fill only 5 of 20 managerial positions with Harlem residents. 
Even Terrance Washington, a military recruiter living on the block, is struggling to find candidates with high school diplomas. 
An economic boom, and yet persistent unemployment and unemployability -- on 129th Street, the combination furthers a streak of nativism. It is voiced in the suspicion that the block's Africans are getting special government help to start businesses, or in the rumor that the Arabs who run the corner stores, but do not employ local residents, are abetting terrorists.
And changes in welfare are creating a growing gender gap of sorts. Women raising children alone must head into the labor market, and on 129th Street they have done so successfully. Men are more likely to face rejection -- racism, prison records -- or bristle at low wages. 
Since 1993, the number of Central Harlem women in the labor force has grown to more than 23,000 from 16,408. The number of men in the workforce -- 18,519 -- has barely inched upward. And so on the block, a colony of men is being left back. With manhood and livelihood at stake, they sometimes turn to the employment agency where work remains guaranteed.

Dealing and Reality
The oranges had gone stale in the window long ago. Soda suppliers never seemed to come to restock. Yet the traffic at the little store on 129th Street was unceasing. 
One Friday afternoon, that traffic came to include beefy police narcotics officers. They brought out Redman, the popular proprietor, and, the police say, a purveyor of marijuana. They put him in a van and searched his polished blue BMW as several of his daughters watched. 
"Somebody snitched," a man on the street said. 
"Somebody always snitches," the woman next to him said. And then, as the store was closed for the weekend: "That's great. They're closing the kids' candy store."
In 1994, drugs were woven into the fabric of life on this block. They still are, in the use of marijuana, packed in a Dutchmaster cigar, as the ghetto version of Prozac, or the continuing crack trade.
The reputation of 129th Street as one of Harlem's notorious drug markets has lingered. People come to the block to sell as well as to buy. Young Bronx men arrive for their shifts in livery cabs. Of the 90 arrests for drug sales on the block over one year, only 17 defendants actually lived there, according to law enforcement figures.
Some sellers are addicts, put out like bait to hand off the drugs, and then, if caught, to do the time. But some are young men who come out to "pitch" because they grew up in households where younger siblings would go without new school clothes unless drug money paid for them, and because they grew up watching older males do the same.
They also live in an era of heightened material expectations. "In Manhattan they say you have to be making $70,000 a year to live," one young man says in explaining why his friends have chosen the drug trade. "Who's got that?" 
But given that the profits from a night's hustling have diminished, thanks to police pressure and a shrinking crack market -- "I don't even think they're making Timberland money," one veteran of the game says -- the draw is more than cash. Nagi Davis, 29, a former dealer living on the block, offers one explanation as he considers the younger versions of himself: "I didn't sell drugs for the money. I sold it for the rush."
And for young men from broken families, the streets also offer peers who will watch your back in a way perhaps your parents never did. Kenny, 18, grew up in Brooklyn's Brownsville Houses. When he was 14, his grandmother, retiring after 33 years of working, retired from raising him, too. His mother, an addict, was not an option. He found little love at his father's. He says, with quiet bitterness, "I didn't ask to be born." 
Kenny landed with an aunt on 129th Street, and found a family of sorts on the block. His crew formed a home-grown rap label, naming it Famo, for "family." One by one, Famo's members, ages 17 to 25, have been arrested for hustling drugs.
They see rap as their way off the streets, but it also romanticizes life there. Young hustlers literally converse in the lyrics of rappers like Beanie Sigel ("My young bucks hugging the block, stop putting your drugs in your socks, you make it easy for the cops, they hook to that stash in the trash").
They served their time without complaint, saying they understood that the police had to meet their quotas and that they were easy prey. They are not all wrong. One narcotics officer who works the area describes continuing pressure from superiors to keep arrests up, even as the drug trade shrinks. They are grabbing "everyone for anything," he says.
For Kenny, six months in jail soured him on hustling. "It was rough," he said. "It taught me a lesson." But it also prompted him to drop out of school, steepening his climb off the streets.
This block knows well the price of success in the war on drugs. Dozens of its young men are cycling through the criminal justice system. Many leave school, although some emerge from prison with high school equivalency degrees. Many leave sons and daughters behind, fraying already weak family ties. All emerge with criminal records that may shadow them for years. 
For "Black" -- a street name is all he offers -- a 20-year-old who works around 129th Street, a criminal record becomes one more plank in the mental box convincing him there is nothing but the streets. The son of a security guard, motherless for years, he already has a felony drug conviction. He does not like the streets, is not truly mean enough.
"I like money, I like money," he often says. He also confesses he would like a normal job.
His plan is to just stay on the streets till he gets "set." But ask him what set means and he cannot articulate a plan beyond tomorrow. The one career he covets, firefighter, is impossible because of his record. Jobs for these young men become nothing more than something to keep them out of the cold and out of the way of the police way for a while. 
"Where you going?" Rachel Tew, a mentor to many young people on the block, asks a young man. 
"Job interview," he says. 
"Like that?" she asks, pointing to baggy jeans and leather jacket.
"It's just KFC," he says. "I just need something to keep me off the streets." 
The future does not exist.
The numbers suggest how heavy the past weighs on many people in this neighborhood. As of last November, 794 adults in the 32nd Precinct were on parole. (In the 20th Precinct, on the Upper West Side, 79 were.) In the 10027 ZIP code, which contains West 129th Street, 722 adults were on probation (compared with 92 in the 10023 ZIP code on the Upper West Side). For many black men and women, criminal histories have effectively closed off the already shrinking avenue of government employment, which helped build the black middle class. 
Deborah Wynns Williams, 41, a former addict trying to shed welfare, was kicked out of a nursing training program two days before graduation because of a shoplifting misdemeanor in her past. (She became a security guard.) Nagi Davis, trying to satisfy work requirements of his conditional release from prison, was fired from the Gap after his work-release supervisor called to confirm his employment, thus revealing the lie that enabled him to get the job. "Would you have hired me if I told you the truth?" he asked the manager who let him go.
Venetia Leak, 41, has no record, but she feels the stranglehold of the past nonetheless. She shed a crack addiction and got a job as a counselor at an organization that works with the homeless. Three years ago she moved from Brooklyn to a rehabilitated building on 129th Street -- a building where she had, in the 1980's, smoked crack. 
Her older son, now 23, works for the American Stock Exchange, earning more than his mother. But her younger son, now 19, dropped out of school and has been arrested and charged with participating in the block's drug trade.
She looks at him and wonders whether his young age at her addiction's onset made the difference. He was 5 when he went into foster care with her mother.
"I don't say the schools failed my son," she says softly. "I don't say I failed my son. I don't know what happened." 
It is easy to fall into the drug trade here, and with crack still almost as available as toothpaste is downtown, it is easy to fall prey to it. A woman says she went back on crack because she was fighting with her sister and facing financial trouble and didn't know how to deal with either. The block made it easy. Now she is off crack and back on the 50-cent beers. 
Bridget G. Brennan, the city's special narcotics prosecutor, says 129th Street shows what law enforcement can and cannot do. It can eliminate dealers as role models by driving home the consequences, and it can drive the drug trade so deep underground that the quality of the neighborhood improves.
"Are we ever going to eliminate the problem of addiction?" she asks. "I don't think that's possible."
And even the battle for quality of life can yield tenuous victories. Redman's store is briefly shut and he is sentenced to community service. He performs it cheerfully ("that highway needed cleaning") and the store reopens. A crack dealer who worked the middle of the block is arrested for the third time in 13 months, and sent away for several years. Soon after, another young man works his spot early in the morning, pulling his stash from a van with a "DARE to Keep Kids Off Drugs" bumper sticker.

Dads and Deadbeats
In the fall, Kenny, the young man from Famo, gets a job at a movie theater, flashing his winning smile from a uniform instead of the hooded sweatshirt he wears on the street. Of all the things that pushed him into a legal job, the most powerful is yet to come. His 19-year-old girlfriend is pregnant. In a life that has been short on good news, the prospect of fatherhood brings delight, and a sense of responsibility. "I've got to step up my game," he says.
The block -- even Famo itself -- is full of similar young men, teenage fathers wanting not to imitate what they call deadbeat fathers. Yet after the initial rush of love for a newborn, girlfriends tend to become "my baby's mother," and the relationships often become more strained. The women complain that the men cheat, or get locked up. 
On 129th Street, births to young parents are largely accepted as natural. "I had my first kid at 13, so I couldn't down them," Vivian Cabey says of her children's teenage pregnancies. "I just did what I had to do."
Policymakers believed that welfare had eliminated any inducements for marriage, but welfare reform has so far not changed that. Before, women had welfare checks. Now, they have jobs. Either way, many continue to carry their families. 
There are families headed by men on the block, and for some children the impact is clear. Jahmell Barreto, 17, hangs out and rides his bike with the rest of the young men on the block. But he is in school, wants college, and stands apart from his peers, mostly because his father orders him to. "My pops," he says, "was strict." 
And then there is Kenny, who would have welcomed some benevolent strictness. A few months after starting at the theater, he misses work one time too many, and no longer has the job. Five days later, he is arrested, charged with selling crack to an undercover officer in his building. 
Some on the block call the drug trade its own addiction. 
"I told him to stay off the streets" until his child was born, one of Famo's members says. "I said I would help him out -- give him money. We're family." 
But family cannot help him now. No one can post the $5,000 bail. Kenny pleads guilty to a felony, his second, and gets six months in the jail he hates. With luck, he will be out for his child's birth.

Cops and Exalted Robbers
At 1:30 a.m. one Saturday, a female security guard just off work -- and newly off welfare -- collects her son, 9, from the block. A woman leaving a bar collects her 13-year-old daughter, who listens to her mother's slurred words and says, "I don't need to tell you what you sound like." As a group of women unwind at a party upstairs, their children play among drug dealers and speeding cars. 
Twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week, the block is de facto baby sitter -- for mothers overworked and overwhelmed, laid low with depression or high on drugs; for grandmothers weary from two generations of raising children. 
That children can be entrusted to the block testifies to the abundance of love here, the protective eyes of neighbors, godmothers, aunts and hustlers who keep children safe and make sure that strangers are watched. But it also means that some children grow up in a world of their own making, informed by adult knowledge but devoid of adult structure.
More than 100 children under 14 live on this block. Weather permitting, they shuttle up and down in packs. There is nowhere else to go. Children's games and language reveal childhood's evanescence. Five boys, ages 8 to 11, play cops and robbers. In their game, it is better to be the robber than the cop. The robbers tie up the cops, after discovering their "wire" (represented by a key chain) and deliver bullets to their heads and mouths with a pop gun. Childhood's innocence makes a brief appearance as they wrestle -- "hey, no real hitting" -- and then the robbers break into a hip-shimmying dance of "---- Tha Police."
Girls as young as 8 tease each other about "giving up the buns" to boys and selling drugs. When the superintendent shoos Tiquana Jeter, 15, off her stoop, she says, "What are we, in the shelter?"
Aware of the pressures, some mothers keep their children indoors. There are "street kids" and "house kids," says Gwen Hill, a mother of six who so fears the block's influence that she briefly sent one daughter to live with relatives in Florida.
And those pressures outlast adolescence. The years of poverty and neglect on 129th Street created a sustaining solidarity. Feeling the world was against them, residents of 129th Street united against the world -- against the police and white culture. Strivers were identified with that outside culture, and thus rejected. 
But the block's strong sense of community, a durable asset, has its own clutches. Mental habits deeply formed -- the casual acceptance and even expectation of failure, the mocking of success, the pride in dysfunction -- can survive even with the new residents and buildings. 
So when Lloyd Estridge, a bright 18-year-old determined to go to college, encounters registration trouble, he gives up quickly and returns to the block to hang out. No one pushes him back out. Months later, he gets a temporary stock job, then returns to hanging out. 
And one legacy of years of isolation is that dramas can be magnified into life-or-death soap operas. With everyone in everyone else's business, everybody he-saiding and she-saiding, the overcrowded place can resemble a giant high school. The fights and arguments -- physical, verbal, between men, between girls -- serve to avenge slights, vent desperation and demonstrate power on the block, if not beyond.
Ask Yvette Harrell, a struggling single mother, why there are so many fights, and she says, "Because people around here are miserable." Then she gestures at the "suburbs" and says, "Except for those people down there."

Trouble at School
Thirty-four years ago, Ned O'Gorman founded the Children's Storefront School to serve the Harlem children he thought were being failed by the school system. Today, he educates a racially diverse clutch of toddlers in a preschool, the Ricardo Frazier O'Gorman Library and School, on 129th between Fifth and Lenox. 
From its cheerful interior, where yellow paint brightens the windowsills and Chinese characters hang on the wall, he looks out on 129th Street and sees how little has changed. In the midst of new buildings and redevelopment efforts, he sees what he calls "the tribes of the unschooled." He sees families shredded through generations. And he sees schools incapable of mending the damage.
The block's closest public high school is the Program for Pregnant and Parenting Teens. The closest elementary school is Community School 133, at 130th and Fifth, which made the news last year because drug-addled prostitutes prowled the sidewalk across the street. In 1999, only 35 percent of its students read at or above grade level. 
And so it is hard to find, among the better-off new residents on the block, anyone whose child is enrolled at C.S. 133, or even in the same school district. Patricia Johnson, a market research analyst, says, "I think the only kids who go there are the ones who really have to." 
So when Councilman Bill Perkins says that he sees the schools as stalling Harlem's second renaissance, and that maybe the influx of active, educated parents will "demand that the system be more accountable, more effective," he is so far hoping in vain. 
The division is not just between old and new, middle-class and poor. Any parent on the block with a modicum of time, money or will power is trying to improve his child's educational prospects. Those who succeed wear their achievement like a marker of good motherhood. 
Vivian Cabey, meanwhile, barely has time to get her children and grandchildren enrolled in and outfitted for school. It is all she can do to cook and clean after work.
And so in an economy that demands educational attainment to move up, the Cabeys, like many children on this block, are sliding. Most of the older ones dropped out. Crystal, 12, repeated the fourth grade; she blames having three teachers in one year. Dionne, 13, is repeating the seventh. No surprise, says their mother, who sees the schools as violent places.

'Thank God. I'm Off the Block.'
Vivian Cabey thought her life was impervious to the flux in Harlem. Then she was upended by it. The city decided to transfer her ghoulish building, in tax arrears by millions of dollars, to a new owner. It needed her and the other tenants out. So after long averting its eyes from her building's conditions, the city called just before Thanksgiving to say that in six days her family was being moved to a city-owned building six blocks away. 
"You can't do that to a working person," she kept saying of the short notice, but she packed. The family shared a laughter-filled last meal at 60 West, Mrs. Cabey swatting roaches as she sorted clothes. A son called from jail. Mrs. Cabey counted down his remaining sentence. "Twenty-one days," she told him, "21 days."
Outside the building, Tiquana Jeter exercised some ghetto logic. "I guess they won't be able to sell drugs anymore," she said of the young men who had used 60 West for cover. "What are they going to do -- go sell on the corner and get arrested?"
Inside, Mrs. Cabey contemplated a future with hot water, and without 129th Street. 
"Thank God," she said. "I'm off the block."
But if the outcome seemed for the good, the lesson of her removal, for a block already worried about displacement, was unsettling. Change could be arbitrary. It could sweep away families and history.
It could, too, sweep away the city's best-laid plans.
A few weeks after the Cabeys were moved, the owners of 60 West paid the city $1.6 million and reclaimed the building. "We were going to walk away," one of them, Zvi Kaufman, said. "At the last minute we realized property values had gone up so much we could pay $1.6 million." 
They were now after a "big piece of Harlem," said his partner, Samuel Kairy. "Everybody and their mother wants to live in Manhattan." 
On the new 129th Street, property is power. The owners promptly handed steep rent increases to the building's ground-floor stores, including Majester's Fish and Chips, at 129th and Lenox Avenue since 1976. Their workers began dragging the furniture of vacated families from the building's interior. The men from the block who regularly gathered by the building huddled in the cold and watched.
Six blocks away, the Cabeys unpacked. Mrs. Cabey returned to work. And the day after the move, her children, missing the block, were back playing on 129th Street.

An American Block
Six years after profiling life on West 129th Street in Harlem, the Times found a transformed block.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Mets Consider Switching Sites Of Spring Camp

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

DATELINE: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 18 

 BODY:
The utility bills in St. Lucie County include fliers for Mets' spring training tickets. When Papa John's delivers a pizza, it includes a coupon for $1 off tickets. The new Friendly's down the street from Thomas J. White Stadium sells Mets ice cream cakes. New banners hailing the team decorate the town's main strip.
 In its 14th year of playing host to the Mets' training camp, this sleepy town on Florida's Treasure Coast is making a serious effort to remain Mets Country. If the Mets decide to leave for West Palm Beach when their lease expires after 2002, it might become Cleveland Indians territory, but Port St. Lucie and St. Lucie County are trying to keep what they have. 
 "Whether it's West Palm Beach or someone else trying to attract the Mets, they will have a fight on their hands," said St. Lucie County Administrator Doug Anderson, "because we're giving it everything we have this year."
The Mets have told St. Lucie County officials that they want to decide on their future spring home by the late summer or early fall, and the county understands. "This is our last chance to make a good impression," said Sonya Smith, the county's public information officer.
Of the 20 teams that train in Florida, only the Mets, Indians, Baltimore Orioles and Tampa Bay Devil Rays have leases that expire within three years. The Orioles, who train in Fort Lauderdale, and the Mets have told West Palm Beach officials that they would be interested in sharing a facility there. The Indians may leave Winter Haven, and Anderson said Port St. Lucie is hoping to speak with their representatives to make a presentation.
But Port St. Lucie mostly wants to keep the Mets, whom they attracted from St. Petersburg in 1988. The Mets all but sold out 7,347-seat Thomas J. White Stadium the first few years, but attendance dipped when the team's performance declined and the novelty wore off.
The Mets averaged about 4,700 fans per game here last year, and they told St. Lucie County that the games must attract an average of 5,500 fans this season. If they don't, and West Palm Beach is able to provide funds for a new facility, the Mets will be much more likely to move.
Dave Howard, the Mets' senior vice president for business and legal affairs, said the gap between the highest-grossing spring training site and the lowest is about $2 million. With so much at stake, he said, the Mets have to consider all options.
"This is going to be a decision that is most likely going to be determined by the financial implications of what the alternatives are," Howard said.
West Palm Beach, one hour to the south and without a team since the Atlanta Braves and Montreal Expos left in 1998, is the most attractive alternative. It hopes to follow a trend established by Jupiter, Fla., Tucson and Peoria, Ariz., by building a two-team facility, for $45 million.
Palm Beach officials are pushing for legislation that would enable a referendum in September on a sales tax to help finance the project, which would be completed in time for spring training in 2003. The main stadium would be two miles from the practice facilities, which the Mets and Orioles would share.
Al Zucaro, the president of West Palm Beach's City Commission, said baseball would help the city develop its urban center. He estimated that each team that trains in a city brings about $24 million to that region.
Zucaro, who met with Howard and the Mets' chief operating officer, Jeff Wilpon, in New York last fall, said the attraction to the Mets is obvious. "The fact of the matter is, this is a New York marketplace down here," Zucaro said.
The Mets' co-owner, Fred Wilpon, said today that while the team could stay in Port St. Lucie, its Florida fan base is centered to the south. "This is where the people are, in this corridor," Wilpon said.
Still, Howard said, he recognizes the efforts St. Lucie is making this spring. The Mets have not promised to stay in St. Lucie if the attendance goals are met, but Howard believes the county is promoting the team better than ever. If the Mets still cannot draw 5,500 per game -- especially after a pennant-winning season -- a move might be logical.
That would be a blow to Port St. Lucie, a town whose growth is reflected in new restaurants, a 14-screen cinema under construction and a community football and soccer stadium going up across from Thomas J. White Stadium.
"Besides the economic impact, it's now part of our identity, and in addition to that it gives our community a lot of national publicity, which you can't buy," Anderson said.
Over the last three years, the county has spent $1.4 million on improvements to the facility, which cost $11 million to build.

HEADLINE: State Subpoenas Records Of Bronx Community Group 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
The New York State attorney general's office has subpoenaed the financial records of the Banana Kelly Community Improvement Association to determine whether there are grounds for a civil or criminal case against the agency, a nonprofit organization that owns or manages dozens of buildings in the South Bronx.
 The agency, which was once seen as a model for grass-roots neighborhood redevelopment, has struggled in recent years, and some former employees and board members have expressed concern about its management practices. 
 The subpoena, which was served on Banana Kelly last month and a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, demanded that its executives turn over everything from canceled checks to minutes of board meetings to itemized travel expenses for employees. One law enforcement official said it was not the first request for financial records. 
Darren Dopp, a spokesman for Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer, would say only that the subpoena was "part of an ongoing request for information."
Tenants in the South Bronx buildings Banana Kelly owns and manages have long complained of neglect. And critics with knowledge of the group's workings have described a chaotically run organization in which the board of directors rarely met, large fees were paid to consultants, and records were poorly kept.
The chairwoman of the agency's board, Yolanda Rivera, has also run the agency, an unusual arrangement for a nonprofit organization, and another board member briefly served as president. Ms. Rivera's compensation -- she has alternated being paid as a staff member and as a consultant -- has also raised questions among former executives.
The attorney general's subpoena asks for documents from Jan. 1, 1995, to the present. In addition to all financial records, it makes a number of other demands.
It asks for all minutes of meetings of Banana Kelly's board or other management committees; the group's bylaws; the identities and terms of office of all board members since 1995; and any board members employed by Banana Kelly as staff members, consultants or contractors. 
The subpoena asks for documents identifying any corporate affiliates, and correspondence with government agencies about compliance with grant or contract requirements. It asks for independent audit reports, and documentation of lawyer, accountant and consultant fees, including fees paid to officers, directors or key employees. The group has also been ordered to turn over its tax returns, documentation of compensation for key employees and an itemization of all travel expenses paid by Banana Kelly or any of its affiliates.
Further, the attorney general has required that the agency itemize certain expenses listed on a 1998 financial statement, including $173,000 for miscellaneous expenses and $102,000 in stipends. Finally, the subpoena asks for copies of written complaints from the public about Banana Kelly, and responses to them.
The investigation would appear to be the latest blow for a group that once received national, and even international, acclaim. It was founded in the late 1970's by a small group of Bronx residents who wanted to fight the fear and arson that were destroying their neighborhood. They rehabilitated a few buildings on their block, and gradually expanded to manage dozens of buildings, mostly for low-income and formerly homeless tenants, and provide social services. 
Ms. Rivera took control of the agency in 1991. She did not respond to a message left at the office yesterday seeking comment.
In recent months, Banana Kelly has clearly been looking for help. Last month, Ms. Rivera agreed to turn over the management of many of the agency's 41 buildings to another Bronx nonprofit firm, Promesa Inc. But last week, she announced that she was pulling back from the plan. Separately, 14 of Banana Kelly's other buildings, which it owns in partnership with the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a national nonprofit organization, are being turned over to an outside manager.
