HEADLINE: IN LAYOFF PLANS, REALITY IS OFTEN LESS SEVERE IN U.S. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Goodyear Tire and Rubber, Dell Computer and Nortel Networks are the latest to announce plans to lay off thousands of employees, joining companies like DaimlerChrysler, Lucent Technologies, Sara Lee and Whirlpool. But in many cases, only a fraction as many Americans will soon find themselves unemployed.
 For all the fear that these announcements generate, the reality behind each company's move is often more complicated than a single headline number suggests. 
 More than half of the 7,000 cuts planned at Sara Lee, for instance, will occur in other countries, the company says. Of the 26,000 layoffs that DaimlerChrysler announced last month, the 12,000 hourly Chrysler workers subject to layoffs in the United States will continue to receive 95 percent of their pay, because of a clause in the company's contract with the United Auto Workers. At least a third of the 16,000 jobs to be eliminated at Lucent will still exist -- as parts of other companies. 
"When a company announces 5,000 layoffs," said Patrick Carey, an economist who studies job cuts for the Bureau of Labor Statistics, "sometimes 5,000 people aren't being laid off."
Even in difficult times, many analysts say, a torrent of layoff announcements can overstate the economy's problems. Despite the attention companies attracted last month with their announcements of plans to eliminate about 140,000 jobs, American businesses managed to add a net total of more than 200,000 employees in January, according to the Labor Department's payroll survey. The unemployment rate therefore rose slightly, to 4.2 percent, during the month from 4 percent in December, as more people entered the work force.
As the economy's growth has slowed, investors expect managers to restore profit gains quickly, and cheer the announcement of major cost cuts and layoffs. Companies are therefore more apt to highlight their layoffs. Many companies, pressured by Wall Street, have recently decided that moderate cuts in overtime or a reduction in the number of part-time employees are no longer enough.
But over the last seven years, there has been little apparent relationship between the number of announced layoffs across corporate America and the unemployment rate, a recent study by Lehman Brothers found. When the number of announced layoffs -- as tracked since 1993 by Challenger Gray & Christmas, a job placement firm in Chicago -- rose, unemployment actually tended to decline, though the relationship was not strong enough to be significant, Lehman said.
To be sure, the number of job losses has risen in recent weeks, based on government data on unemployment-insurance claims. And some of the recent cuts have consisted almost entirely of quickly imposed mass layoffs, forcing thousands of workers to hunt for new jobs. 
J. C. Penney said last month that it would close 47 stores and rapidly eliminate 5,000 jobs. Hewlett-Packard plans to cut 1,700 jobs by the end of April. Gateway has already notified most of the 3,000 people who will lose their jobs as part of a cost-cutting campaign.
Last week, Nortel announced that it would cut 10,000 jobs; Goodyear announced 7,200 layoffs and Dell, 1,000.
Week in and week out, in boom times or recessions, anywhere from 250,000 to 400,000 Americans a week typically file new claims for unemployment insurance after involuntarily losing their jobs. Yet nearly every week, even more people than that are hired by companies across the country.
A single corporate layoff of a few thousand workers, likely to be spread over a few weeks to many months, has a minimal effect on the total of job losses in an economy where more than 130 million people go to work every day. Even a dozen such announcements will not cause a spike in unemployment.
Except in the midst of a severe downturn, the many new jobs the economy is constantly creating almost always outnumber old ones being destroyed. This is often true even within many companies themselves. 
"The ignored parts of these announcements are that companies are hiring while they're doing it," said Eric Rolfe Greenberg, the director of management studies at the American Management Association, a nonprofit group in New York that holds corporate training seminars. "Companies are increasingly hiring and firing at the same time."
Often, the layoff announcements are not quite what they seem. On Dec. 13, Whirlpool executives said they planned to eliminate 6,000 jobs, or about one-tenth of the work force. The number made it into newspaper headlines across the country and was included in Challenger's layoff total for December, which set what was then a record of 133,713.
The 6,000 number is not inaccurate, but when the company laid out the details of its first round of cuts last month, it became clear that their effect on the American economy would not be so direct. Of the first 2,000 cuts, 1,000 would come in Brazil and about 650 in Asia and Europe. Of the 400 North Americans losing their jobs, the company said, about half would be workers in their 50's and 60's who accept early retirement packages. 
"When companies reduce work force levels, a lot of the reduction comes in the form of attrition and early retirement -- a lot more than people expect," said Susan N. Houseman, a senior economist at the W. E. Upjohn Institute for Employment Research in Kalamazoo, Mich.
Such cuts do affect the economy, because the jobs no longer exist for others to fill. Yet attrition does not cause nearly as much pain as do permanent layoffs, which can severely disrupt families and lower workers' incomes for years.
Lucent's Jan. 24 announcement was even more confusing. The company said its work force would decline by 16,000 people, to about 90,000, as a result of a new round of cuts. Ten thousand jobs are disappearing, mostly through layoffs in the early months of this year. The other 6,000 jobs -- at plants in Columbus, Ohio, and Oklahoma City -- will still exist, though as part of companies that will be buying the plants from Lucent.
Still, 16,000 was the number of job cuts reported in several daily newspapers from New York to Chicago to San Francisco, and it appeared again on Tuesday night on ABC's "Nightline." Challenger also used the larger number in its January layoff total, which surpassed December's and set a record of 142,208.
Companies have little incentive to correct misperceptions because large job cuts appeal to investors and Wall Street analysts looking for signs of aggressive cost-cutting. And because investors tend to dismiss the importance of infrequent write-offs, or one-time reductions in reported earnings, when evaluating a company's results, executives are encouraged to lump any and all losses and cost-cutting measures into one big announcement.
Within a company, remaining employees tended to care more about how executives informed laid-off workers and what kind of severance packages were offered than about the number they read in internal memorandums or the press, said Jerry Roemisch, the president of Roemisch Consulting, a firm in Austin, Tex., that advises companies on mergers.
Still, the latest round of cuts, because they have been widely publicized when the economy has clearly faltered, does add to economic worries. 
Whirlpool employees at a plant outside Nashville, for instance, have significantly reduced costs in recent years and have received no indication that the plant is being considered for job cuts, said Jim R. Romines, a trucker at the plant and an International Brotherhood of Boilermakers official. Yet workers have begun speculating that their factory could be on the next list.
As Tom Chastain, another local union official, added, "The workers, to a man, are anxious about all these announcements."
The nervousness has also spread beyond people who work for companies making cuts, analysts say. In January, an index of consumer confidence posted its steepest drop in 10 years, largely because people expect the economy to be worse off in six months than it is today, according to the Conference Board, a research group in New York that surveys people about their attitude toward the economy.
The gap between people's opinion about the current climate and their expectations for the future was wider than it had ever been in the 34 years the Conference Board has conducted its poll. 
The difference, in part, reflects the contrast between the decent wage gains and still solid labor market of today and the fears for the future raised by the latest series of layoff announcements, analysts say. It also suggests that the announcements have a psychological effect far beyond their immediate circle.
"Bad news about the economy does influence consumers' spending," said Joseph Abate, the Lehman Brothers economist who studied job cuts. "It does tend to put a damper on their willingness to borrow."

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
For many online companies, customer service is hardly a priority. Just try to find a phone number.

BYLINE:  By Susan Stellin 

 BODY:
ANYONE who signs up to use PayPal, an Internet payment service that has become popular among users of auction sites, must provide it with a lot of personal data: name, telephone, address, e-mail and credit card or banking information.
 So far, more than six million people have registered to use the service. But for all that PayPal knows about its customers, it is remarkably guarded about its own contact information. 
 There is no street address, phone number or e-mail address listed among the contact information on PayPal's Web site -- just a post office box in Palo Alto, Calif., and a form to submit a question electronically. PayPal does not even have a phone number available through directory assistance. (There is a phone number for customer service on the site, but it takes some dedicated digging to find it.) 
As it happens, the Better Business Bureau of Santa Clara County recently rated PayPal's customer service unsatisfactory, in part because of complaints that the company is slow to respond to customer inquiries. But PayPal is certainly not the only site that has made it more than a little challenging for customers to reach a representative, or even locate contact information.
These days, "don't call us" seems to be the prevailing attitude among companies that do business online. Many require customers to fill out electronic forms to contact a representative, but rarely do they offer a phone number. And they tend to bury direct e-mail links -- if they publish them at all -- deep within their Web sites.
Companies say these forms improve customer service by sorting and directing inquiries to the appropriate department and trying to answer common questions more quickly by first referring customers to an online help section. But they are also motivated by the bottom line: providing phone support is expensive, so Internet companies under mounting pressure to achieve profitability are adopting more economical automated systems. Critics say customers may be the losers.
"None of these companies want to be e-mailed anymore," said Denton Taylor, a PayPal user who recently tried to alert it about an online scam that was aimed at its members. He was frustrated by PayPal's lack of contact information.
Reid Hoffman, PayPal's executive vice president for business development, said it was working with the Better Business Bureau to improve its rating and was planning to open a second customer service center to handle the approximately 17,000 inquiries it received each day. Although the electronic form is the primary way customers can contact PayPal, he said, members also receive an e-mail address for customer service when they register, and a phone number is on credit card statements.
Industrywide, there is little data about how much contact information companies publish online. But researchers at the Nielsen Norman Group, a consulting firm focused on the usability of Web sites, recently examined the sites of Fortune 50 companies to gauge whether it was possible to find a physical mailing address and a general telephone number.
Acknowledging that the sample was small, Jakob Nielsen, a principal at the firm, said his researchers were able to find an address at slightly more than half the sites and a phone number at just under two-thirds of them -- a pattern he said did not surprise him. 
"What surprised me maybe was the percentages," Mr. Nielsen said. "That for half of these companies you can't even find the information at all."
Even popular commercial Web sites are not much more revealing. For example, eBay lists only a street address in San Jose, Calif., on its contact information page; a search through dozens of other pages did not turn up a phone number or an e-mail address for customer service. 
EBay does offer an electronic form that customers can fill out to submit a question, but it is difficult to find and can be tedious to complete. 
Likewise, Yahoo -- which does provide a street address, phone number and fax number two clicks from its home page -- does not list any company e-mail addresses for customer support. Instead, Yahoo refers visitors to its help section, which tries to answer frequently asked questions before inquiring, "Is this enough information?" Visitors who click the "no" button are presented with a form to submit a question.
One Internet company that so far has not embraced electronic forms is Amazon.com, which provides customers with a list of e-mail contacts accessible through a link on its company information page. Bill Curry, a spokesman, said Amazon tries to minimize contacts with customer service through features that allow customers to track their orders, check their accounts and find out shipping rates and other information. But the site still offers e-mail addresses, he said, because that is how most customers prefer to communicate with Amazon.
"Personally, I think forms you associate with things like the Department of Motor Vehicles and the I.R.S.," Mr. Curry said. "And a great shopping experience -- I don't know if that calls for a form." Even so, Mr. Curry said Amazon was exploring whether forms could be adopted in a "customer-friendly way."
As for whether there are any federal regulations governing the disclosure of company contact information -- either online or offline -- "the short answer is no, there are not," said Eric London, spokesman for the Bureau of Consumer Protection at the Federal Trade Commission. "But that doesn't mean we don't think it's a good idea for businesses to adopt some of the guidelines put out by organizations like the Better Business Bureau," he added.
Last year, the Better Business Bureau Online released a code of online business practices, which the organization's 9,000 members must adopt by September to maintain the bureau's reliability seal.
The code stipulates that a member's Web site should publish the company's legal name; the name under which it conducts business; a physical address; an online method of contact (like e-mail); a point of contact responsible for customer inquiries; and a telephone number, "unless to do so would be disruptive to the operation of the business given its size and resources" -- in which case, the company must have a working phone that is listed in directory assistance.
Elizabeth Blumenfeld, director of policy and business strategy for the Better Business Bureau Online, said it had spent considerable time on this issue as it solicited feedback from businesses, government representatives and consumer groups to develop the code.
"The challenge is that a lot of businesses, particularly those that are not brick and click, but just click, feel that if you have to post a phone number or an address, then you're defeating the purpose of being on the Internet," Ms. Blumenfeld said.
It is not yet clear where a fair balance lies between the interests of consumers who need to contact the companies they do business with online and the abilities of companies to keep up with multiplying customer service requests.
But in an industry that gathers increasing amounts of information about its customers, it may no longer be a viable option for a company to use technology to effectively hide.

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
Napster Is Stirring Debate on Art and Ethics

BYLINE:  By CLEA SIMON 

 BODY:
The legal issues may still be in play, and the technical outcome is anyone's guess. But in a forum on the Napster controversy at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology last week, it was the ethical issues that took center stage. 
 "Why is Napster so interesting? Why is it so difficult?" These were the opening queries posed by Eric Scheirer, an analyst with Forrester Research, speaking to the small colloquium in Cambridge, Mass. 
 The audience was largely drawn from the M.I.T. faculty and the university's Media Lab. Napster is a music-trading Web site that acts as an index to the music libraries on users' personal computers. In a lively give and take with the group, Mr. Scheirer said that Napster had raised arguments about art and ownership that had not traditionally been part of the public discourse.
"Napster is pushing on these questions as we try to articulate the role of art," said Mr. Scheirer, who holds a Ph.D. from the M.I.T. Media Lab. He said one in four American adults had downloaded music by one means or another, making the Napster issue "a cultural phenomenon." 
For Mr. Scheirer, Napster raises four big questions: What is the appropriate relationship between the artist and fan base? Is the capitalist model the right model for creating art? What is copyright for? And what is art for in a consumer society?
Citing the band Metallica, which filed one of the first suits against Napster, he said many of the group's fans had rallied against what he called Metallica Inc., the profit-oriented business side of the heavy metal group.
He said disputes raised by digital technologies like Napster would force American society to clarify its definition of copyright. The traditional European notion, he said, considered art an inalienable part of the artist. In the United States, he said, the strict constitutional interpretation is that copyright exists to encourage continued creation.
But the more popular American understanding, he added, is that copyright exists for a more pragmatic reason: so that creators can be paid. CLEA SIMON

 BODY:
Canadian Concern Is Seen In Deal for Unilever Unit
George Weston, the Canadian food conglomerate, is expected to buy Unilever's bakery division for about $1.7 million in cash, adding Thomas' English Muffins to its brands, which include Girl Scout cookies, executives close to the negotiations said.
 The deal could be announced as early as today, ending an auction that attracted some of the industry's biggest rivals, including Sara Lee, Earthgrains and Grupo Bimbo of Mexico, to compete for brands like Entenmann's and Boboli. National Report, Section A.

Morgan Stanley Seeks an Apology
Christian L. Curry, who was fired by Morgan Stanley, is at the center of a dispute between his former employer and The Wall Street Journal. The Journal published an op-ed column by Holman W. Jenkins Jr. that accused Morgan Stanley of paying off Mr. Curry despite statements to the contrary. Morgan Stanley maintains that it has not made any payment to Mr. Curry, calling Mr. Jenkins's accusations "totally false" and demanding an apology. The Journal said it had no plans for one. C7.

The New Economy, Light on Service
These days, "don't call us" seems to be the prevailing attitude among online businesses. Many require customers to fill out electronic forms to contact a representative, but rarely do they offer a phone number. And they tend to bury direct e-mail links deep within their Web sites. Companies say these forms improve customer service by directing inquiries to the appropriate department. But providing phone support is expensive, so Internet companies under mounting pressure to make profits are adopting more economical automated systems. New Economy. C3.

Retailers Struggle With Kiosks
When traditional retailers scrambled to build defensive positions against online competitors, one strategy was to use Internet kiosks in stores. But retailers are finding that there is nothing easy about managing these kiosks. Not only are they costly to build and maintain, executives said, but they can deliver zero sales if they are not designed for specific tasks. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

Terms Change in Liberty Media Deal
Liberty Media and UnitedGlobalCom have changed their intended merger plan after bondholders rejected the transaction. C4.

U.S. Markets Closed for Holiday
The stock market and other financial markets in the United States are closed today in observance of Presidents' Day. They will reopen tomorrow. The financial markets in other countries will be open.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Like a market epicenter, Nortel Networks' decline jolts the shares of its suppliers as well.

BYLINE:  By Simon Romero 

 BODY:
LATE last year, Nortel Networks was confident enough of its standing in the communications equipment industry to rent a plane that circled over a factory operated by its troubled rival, Lucent Technologies, with a banner reading, "Are your options losing altitude?" 
 But now that Nortel's stock has crashed to earth, aftershocks are being felt in portions of the equipment industry that act as suppliers to companies like Nortel. 
 On Friday, investors hammered Nortel's shares after the company announced late on Thursday that it would report a loss in the first quarter and cut 10,000 jobs because of slower sales in the United States. Nortel's stock plunged 32 percent on Friday, to $20, leaving its share price nearly 78 percent lower than its high of $89 just six months ago. 
Because Nortel has long been considered a gauge of the general health of the communications industry, the company's problems have put analysts on alert. "We had sensed sectoral weakness in the first quarter, but we did not expect Nortel to see this much weakness and lack of visibility," said Thomas Astle, an analyst for Merrill Lynch.
On Friday, tremors spread throughout Nortel's supply chain, knocking the share prices of several companies to their lowest levels in a year.
Shares in JDS Uniphase, a large producer of fiber optic components, fell 21 percent, to $35.81, while shares in Corning, the maker of optical fiber and glass panels, declined 21 percent, to $33. Nortel accounts for about 15 percent of JDS Uniphase's overall sales and 15 percent of Corning's photonics business. (Photonics are products that harness light at a microscopic level to make communications networks more efficient.) Corning said on Friday that its photonics sales should grow 50 percent this year, down from previous estimates of 75 to 90 percent.
Besides large companies like JDS Uniphase and Corning, Nortel's quake also caused smaller suppliers to shudder. Shares in the Avanex Corporation, which makes fiber optic based products known as photonic processors, fell 17 percent, to $35.94, Allied Fiber Optic Products' stock fell 13.3 percent, to $11.06, and shares in the Finisar Corporation declined 16 percent, to $20.
Much of the alarm has to do with Nortel's suggestion that communications carriers, especially in the United States, are slowing their purchases of equipment this year. Relatively old-fashioned equipment like circuit switches, which direct traffic on voice networks, is particularly vulnerable. But it also appears that carriers are spending less than expected on fiber optic equipment to prepare networks for huge amounts of Internet traffic.
This should come as no surprise, because of the bankruptcies and other difficulties at some new communications companies in recent months. But Nortel's warning has stunned analysts, many of whom had previously offered rosy estimates of 30 percent growth for such products this year. With problems at Nortel and Lucent, though, analysts are expecting the market to expand only 15 percent or less in 2001. Although that might look like healthy growth on the surface, it illustrates how concern over a slowing economy is leading communications companies to be much more conservative now than they were a year ago.
"The fear of an economic downturn is feeding on itself," said Jeffrey Kagan, an independent telecommunications analyst. "What we should really be worried about is whether this fear, and not real economic conditions, is making companies more cautious."
Nortel's troubles could affect the finances of JDS Uniphase in at least one other significant way. On Feb. 6, Nortel agreed to acquire a fiber optic components factory in Switzerland from JDS Uniphase in a stock deal valued at about $2 billion.
For JDS, the Swiss factory deal was a way to meet regulators' conditions for its acquisition of the fiber optics equipment maker SDL Inc. Officials at the Justice Department had expressed concern that, without the factory sale, JDS and SDL would dominate the market for the tiny pump lasers used in fiber networks. 
But with last week's decline in Nortel's stock price, the shares used to pay JDS Uniphase for the facility are now worth about a third less, or roughly $1.3 billion, according to Epoch Partners. There are no signs, however, that the deal will be renegotiated.
Compared with Nortel's main rival, Lucent, which consistently warned investors quarter by quarter over the last year that it would fall short of revenue and earnings estimates, Nortel shocked its shareholders last week. Even so, analysts are cautioning investors not to let their displeasure with Nortel contaminate their views of the entire communications equipment industry.
"The entire sector shouldn't be painted with the same brush," said Mark Langley, an analyst with Epoch Partners. "There are companies out there that compete with Nortel or that provide different products that could end up better positioned."
Such companies may include the Ciena Corporation and Tellabs, which make products that allow carriers to use bandwidth more efficiently instead of spending more to expand bandwidth capacity. Ciena, in particular, impressed investors last week by raising its sales estimates for the months ahead. 
Even Ciena, however, could not escape the market's aftershocks on Friday. The company's shares tumbled 7 percent, to close at $82.63.

HEADLINE: In an Uncertain Climate, Philanthropy Is Slowing 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
Philanthropy, one of the nation's most spectacular growth industries for the last decade, is feeling the pinch of the market turnaround, several indicators suggest. 
 In a survey of the nation's largest foundations, to be published this week in The Chronicle of Philanthropy, 79 of the 142 foundations included said they expected their giving to remain flat or drop this year -- and slightly more than half said their assets had shrunk over the last year. 
 And there are scattered hints of troubles throughout the charitable world: some nonprofit organizations, like the Children's Aid Society, have had a substantial drop in donors in that time. Others, particularly those depending on dot-com fortunes, found that stock gains they expected were evaporating. In Texas, where the Austin Entrepreneurs Foundation holds stock from start-up companies, only 2 of the 12 companies that were expected to go public last year actually did so, while several corporate supporters went out of business. 
Over the second half of last year, there was a 2.7 percent decline in the Philanthropic Giving Index, a kind of consumer-confidence index compiled by Indiana University's Center on Philanthropy, based on surveys of executives of nonprofit organizations. 
In recent years charitable giving has reached new highs, and many organizations, from the American Heart Association to the American Friends Service Committee to the Museum of Modern Art in New York, say they have not yet felt any sign of the weakened economy. 
But the decline in foundation assets may herald widespread trouble. Foundation giving almost tripled over the last decade, to $20 billion -- support that is especially crucial to nonprofit organizations in lean economic times, when individual and corporate donations dry up. 
But several prominent foundations lost a substantial share of their asset value over the last year, the Chronicle survey said. With the shakeout in technology stocks, for example, the assets of the David and Lucile Packard Foundation, in Los Altos, Calif. -- invested almost entirely in the stock of Hewlett-Packard and its spinoff, Agilent -- dropped 25 percent, to $9.8 billion. 
But at least for this year, Packard is not cutting its grant budget, said George Vera, the treasurer. "If there is a prolonged bear market, we'd have to make some changes," he said, "but what we hope is that over time we will even out the peaks and valleys." 
Packard was not the only high-tech foundation to be hit hard last year: the assets of the Paul G. Allen Charitable Foundation dropped 39 percent, to $58 million. 
Other foundations where assets declined by more than 10 percent last year include the Annenberg Foundation in St. David's, a suburb of Philadelphia; the Annie E. Casey Foundation in Baltimore; the Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation in Milwaukee; the W. K. Kellogg Foundation in Battle Creek, Mich.; the Robert R. McCormick Tribune Foundation in Chicago; the Libra Foundation in Portland, Me.; and the George Gund Foundation in Cleveland. 
Over all, the median decline of the biggest foundations' assets was only 0.3 percent. But that decline would have been far steeper without the success of the nation's two largest foundations: William H. Gates made a $5 billion donation to his foundation, which has $21 billion in assets, and the Lilly Endowment's $15 billion grew on the success of Eli Lilly & Company stock. 
Private foundations are required to spend at least 5 percent of their assets, and most stay close to that level to keep from using up their money. Eventually, fewer assets translate into fewer dollars in grants. But because the tax laws allow for averaging over several years, foundations need not slash programs the year after their assets shrink. Still, some are already reducing spending.
At the Spencer Foundation in Chicago, for example, where assets dropped to about $500 million in December from about $600 million a year earlier, this year's budget for new grants is $22 million, less than half the $49 million in grants approved in 2000. 
"It's not as drastic as it sounds," said Ines Milne, the treasurer. "It's just that last year was such a big year for us. Before that, we'd never approved more than $30 million in grants in a single year. Most of our grants are multiyear, so we'll be paying them out over the next seven years. As for approving new grants, we're coming back down, gradually, to try for a soft landing, while we watch the market." 
Other charities, too, are watching the market anxiously, as they prepare next year's budgets. 
"We're feeling what is happening in the economy," said Philip Coltoff, executive director of the Children's Aid Society. "We haven't suffered a dollar loss yet, but there was a definite drop-off, about 12 percent, in the number of donors over the last year. We get 60 percent of our contributions in December and the first week of January, and that was where the big hurt was. When you have a drop-off in donors, it doesn't bode well for the future. We're now doing budget planning for the next fiscal year, and we're thinking unrestricted giving may be down 5 percent, but we're hoping to make up for it in the giving to specific programs." 
At America's Second Harvest in Chicago, a spokeswoman, Sue Hofer, said that while giving levels were "on track" last year, a few donors told the food bank that they were postponing their year-end gifts because of market conditions. 
Even groups that enjoyed increased giving last year remained alert to signs of a downturn. "We did very well last year," said Andrew Ackerman, executive director of the Children's Museum of Manhattan. "The only place we're beginning to notice any concern is in selling tables for our spring benefit April 29. One company that usually gives said they're not sure about buying a table because they're announcing layoffs." 
And many pledges based on soaring stock values have become, at best, tentative. 
On March 16, at the annual Washington Business Philanthropy summit, Michael J. Saylor, the chief executive of the Virginia software company MicroStrategy, announced with great fanfare that he was pledging $100 million to create a free online university. Four days later, the company restated its earnings for the previous two years and the stock plunged, from a high of $333 a share to around $10.
So for the time being, a spokesman said, Mr. Saylor is "very focused on MicroStrategy." Mr. Saylor said recently that he remained committed to the project, and planned to sell off his stock over the next few years and finance the university. 
The relationship between philanthropy and economic circumstances has always been a close one. In the 1975 recession, for example, foundation giving dropped 28 percent, and it did not recover for a decade.

HEADLINE: Signs of Uneasiness in Seoul Over Change at White House 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 17 

 BODY:
As President Kim Dae Jung prepares to visit Washington early next month for a summit meeting with President Bush, signs of uneasiness have been multiplying here about a possible change in direction in Washington's policy toward the divided Korean Peninsula. 
 In its final weeks, the Clinton administration made a major push to normalize relations with North Korea, and many in this country felt that life for both of the Koreas was about to take a dramatic turn, with new business opportunities and, most important, a much more secure peace. 
 But the Clinton team's diplomatic push fell short. And the change of administrations in Washington has left people here anxiously holding their breath to see if momentum for detente with North Korea created by a landmark meeting between leaders of North and South Korea last June will now be sustained or lost. 
In a statement issued Friday that seemed directed, at least in part, at the Bush administration, Mr. Kim pointedly noted that the successes of diplomacy last year toward Pyongyang "owe a lot to Seoul's bilateral cooperation with Tokyo and Washington," and he urged that "policy coordination" between the three capitals should be strengthened. 
The South Korean government has been pleased with some of the early statements from the Bush administration. Recently, for example, the State Department spokesman, Richard Boucher, said Washington was "very mindful of the work that had been done," in easing tensions on the Korean Peninsula, "and looked forward to moving forward from there."
But many of Mr. Bush's senior diplomatic and security advisers have in the recent past advocated policies toward North Korea that contrast sharply with the strategy of the last administration. In private, South Korean officials have expressed alarm that the Bush administration is rushing ahead with plans to develop a missile shield before seriously testing North Korea's willingness to abandon its long- and medium-range missile programs.
North Korea's development of medium- and long-range missiles has commonly been cited as the leading justification for the Bush administration's antimissile program. 
South Korean officials have also expressed concern that Washington will not seek to engage North Korea on other issues, and moreover, that the new administration will try to discourage South Korea from providing increasing amounts of economic aid to the North.
"The position that the administration's people have taken is that the United States has been too eager," said Selig S. Harrison, an expert in Korean affairs at the Century Foundation, in Washington. "I don't think that they are going to create any kind of provocation with North Korea. They are sensitive to the arguments of Seoul that say that we are on the firing lines here. Please be careful." 
Mr. Harrison said many in the administration believe that North Korea will eventually collapse economically. 
That is a prospect, however, that clearly frightens South Korea, which fears a devastating economic impact from the breakdown of the North's economy. Recent news agency photos from Pyongyang alarmed many here with images of crude graffiti denouncing the government of Kim Jong Il over the starvation of millions of his people. 
South Korean officials have worked hard recently to counter the argument that they are being too generous in providing aid to North Korea under President Kim's so-called Sunshine Policy, a criticism heard both from some circles in Washington and from opposition quarters in Seoul.
"The most important element of inter-Korean relations is that there is no more war," said President Kim's spokesman, Park Joon Young, in a news conference this week. "And that outweighs considerations of whether we give more or take more. Peace is the most important thing."
Hoping to influence the new administration on North Korea, South Korea secretly dispatched its intelligence chief to Washington recently, following the foreign minister by only two days as part of a series of high-level briefings.
In a briefing this week, a senior South Korean official said that while international aid had eased food shortages in the North recently, that country's energy crisis has grown increasingly dire, recently compelling the South to offer coal supplies.
"Half of the power they generate is lost because of old, corroded cables buried underground," said the official, who declined to be identified. "Kim Jong Il was shown recently visiting a cosmetics factory with a group of officials all wearing heavy parkas indoors. I ask you, can you produce cosmetics in a factory that is freezing? In South Korea we have no choice; we must do what we can to help."

Kilimanjaro's Ice Melting
New studies show that the icecap atop Mt. Kilimanjaro is retreating at such a pace that it will disappear in less than 15 years, new studies show -- one of the clearest signs that a global warming trend has exceeded typical climate shifts. A1

Global warming is expected to increase crop yields in temperate regions while harming agriculture in the tropics, scientists said. A4

Cold War Legacy in Idaho
Buried in tanks and dumped into trenches at the Idaho National Engineering and Environmental Laboratory northwest of Idaho Falls is a witches' brew of deadly chemicals and radioactive waste left over from the cold war. The area was designated a Superfund site in 1989, and the government started trying to clean it up. Now two men who audited that effort say in a federal lawsuit that government contractors who were paid hundreds of millions of dollars made the contamination worse. A10

HEADLINE: Testing the Limits of the Western Dream 

BYLINE:  By Patricia Nelson Limerick and Charles Scoggin; Patricia Nelson Limerick, a professor of history, and Charles Scoggin are on the board of directors of the Center of the American West at the University of Colorado.

DATELINE: BOULDER, Colo. 

 BODY:
As we write, we are sitting in paradise. To our west, the Front Range of the Rockies looks like a Bierstadt painting. If you want your soul to soar, this is the direction to look in. New snow has put the contours of the mountains in high relief. Once on the ground, Rocky Mountain snow almost always skips the familiar East Cost stage of blackened, sludgy heap, instead graciously melting under the bright sunlight. No wonder everyone wants to join us.
 For those, like us, who have spent any time studying the development of the West, the before-and-after contrasts between the West of 10 years ago and the West of today reawaken old temptations to bemoan the pace of change in the region. All the new housing developments, all the new high-tech companies, all the new shopping centers, all the cars on the Boulder Turnpike and along I-70. Why is it getting so crowded? Can the land sustain it? 
 Between 1990 and 1999, Colorado's population grew by 30.6 percent, adding one million people. Nevada grew by 66 percent. New York, by contrast, grew by a mere 5.5 percent. This change in demographics will bring about a shift in political power. New York may lose two Congressional seats, and Colorado and Nevada will likely each pick up one.
But this population growth has already brought us some other advantages. The shopping is better; the food is certainly better; we now have an abundant and accessible supply of world-class gourmet coffee. And the entrepreneurial energy of new companies has introduced a renewed sense of possibility and optimism to the region. The West as a setting and a theme in novels, poems, memoirs, historical writing and visual art is enjoying a resurgence. There may even be an end soon to the regional inferiority complex that has long burdened the West. (The fact that both presidential candidates wore cowboy boots has not been not lost on us.) 
Is any of this news? The westward movement -- of those driven by dreams, hopes and ambitions toward a land of magnificent scenery and open views -- is one of the nation's oldest stories. A century ago the census found almost exactly the same growth rate for the State of Colorado as the 2000 census: 31 percent from 1890 to 1900.
Throughout the 1890's, though they were a time of economic misery for many, the westward migration was, in the words of demographic historian Walter Nugent, "not rapid, but steady and endemic." The historian Frederick Jackson Turner's declaration in 1893 that the frontier was gone, and with it "the first period of American history," was proving to be decidedly premature. The conviction that the West offered health and self-improving recreational adventure, so central to the current population movement, was coming into play. The region became a haven for those suffering from tuberculosis and other ailments.
Then, as now, the growth in the percentage of the population that was foreign-born was putting ideals of equality and opportunity to the test. In 1879, the California Constitution was amended to forbid California corporations from employing Chinese workers and to allow towns to segregate Chinese immigrants into certain neighborhoods. In 1882, egged on by white workers in Western states concerned about losing their jobs, Congress passed the Chinese Exclusion Act, which prohibited the immigration of Chinese laborers into the United States. And in 1913 the California Legislature passed the Alien Land Law, aimed at Japanese-Americans, which prohibited aliens from acquiring, possessing or inheriting real property.
In addition to these manmade limits, there were other barriers to settlement in the West. In many of the homesteaders' settlements, retreat rapidly followed advance as farmers found that much of the land could not support conventional small family farms. Over the course of the early 20th century, farms were claimed, worked and abandoned across the Great Plains and through the high altitudes of Colorado, Wyoming and Montana.
Indeed, the history of the West is characterized by cycles of boom and bust. Metal mining -- of gold, silver, copper and molybdenum -- has risen and plunged with changes in the technology of mining. The oil and gas industry has seen similar changes, with a spectacular plunge in the early 1980's. Will today's Western boom continue the pattern?
Recent migration to the West has, in many ways, rested on the nation's prosperity. Many have been drawn by new, technology-based industries, which have been central to the current economic boom. If the national economy slips, the current growth in the West seems likely to slip with it. And then there is water: its limits, despite the water projects that have supported growth so far, have long been a subject of regional denial. Tree ring records make it clear that this region has been subject, in the past, to multidecade droughts, droughts that make the duration of the Dust Bowl look short. Much of our landscape does still look like a picture postcard. But a few years of drought, and we could all find ourselves abandoning the scenery and competing for the moving trucks.
Still, many here in the West are finding it hard to resist the impulse to tell our million new neighbors that the door should have been shut before they came through it, and certainly should be shut now. Initiatives like California's Proposition 187, which denied public services to the children of illegal immigrants (it was later mostly dismantled in court), signal the persistence of the urge to blame immigrants in times when the native-born feel crowded. Meanwhile, the regional fights over grazing on public lands, agricultural water transfers, fire management and mining grow more intense, heightened by the growing population. 
But our fellow Westerners should take heed: The debate over how we live in a region founded on the idea of the expanding frontier must include the voices of the millions who, driven by a latter-day version of that dream, have now made their homes among us.

HEADLINE: Fresh Dynasties Sprout in Post-Soviet Lands as Democratic Succession Withers 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan 

 BODY:
The demise of President Heydar A. Aliyev, 77 years old and a survivor of major heart surgery, is so nearly unthinkable in this former Soviet republic, which he has dominated for most of the last three decades, that the local press refers to it only as Event X.
 What Mr. Aliyev wants after Event X seems increasingly clear: his only son, Ilham, 39, deputy chairman of Azerbaijan's state oil company, should inherit his father's political throne. 
 This model of monarchy seems increasingly to be taking hold in the former Soviet lands, republics that have often become the personal fiefs of rulers who mostly were part of the Soviet system.
In many ways the autocracies are an outgrowth of the Soviet era, when regional leaders were chosen in Moscow and few people took an active role in politics. Now the leaders argue that more time is needed to build the democratic institutions necessary for stability and smooth transitions of power. 
Others criticize the absence of mature opposition voices and legitimate heirs after a decade of transition that has brought little gain for many residents of the Caucasus and Central Asia. 
Indeed, there is a widespread sense of being dispossessed as citizens who have grown increasingly impoverished watch leaders, their families and cronies prosper.
"You don't see any signs of accommodation with the rest of society, and you get more and more frustrated with the leaders as time goes on," Martha Brill Olcott, an expert on the region at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said in a telephone interview from Washington.
The prospect of instability or violence when one of the current leaders leaves office also raises the prospect of intervention by Russia, which is already reasserting its influence and could argue that it needs to act to restore order.
"Where do they draw the line when it comes to independence?" asked a senior adviser to one of the region's presidents.
The only leader in the region who has tried to train a post-Soviet generation of politicians is President Eduard A. Shevardnadze of Georgia, who is 73.
He took that course only after making his share of unsavory alliances at home and with Russia to beat back three civil wars that arose in the 1990's out of his country's deep ethnic divisions.
Those divisions continue, making succession more complicated. One of the few people identified by diplomats as a possible challenger to Mr. Shevardnadze, for instance, is Aslan Abashidze, the autocratic leader of the semiautonomous region of Adjaria on Georgia's Black Sea coast.
Already Mr. Shevardnadze has dodged several assassination attempts. Economic woes and endemic corruption are mounting, leaving his government deeply unpopular. 
On the other side of the Caspian Sea, President Nursultan A. Nazarbayev of Kazakhstan retains a strong grip on power as the prospect of oil riches increases. The mercurial Mr. Nazarbayev, 60, frequently shuffles cabinet members to keep potential rivals at bay, and last year Parliament granted him immunity from prosecution for life.
Mr. Nazarbayev's eldest daughter, Dariga, 37, who owns a media empire, is mentioned most often as a potential successor, along with her husband, Rakhat Aliyev, head of the country's internal security apparatus. 
Neighboring Kyrgyzstan was once the most promising democracy among the five former Soviet republics of Central Asia, but the government's repression of political opponents and the re-election of President Askar Akayev, 56, in October have drawn rebukes from monitors and human rights groups.
The United States, once a champion of Mr. Akayev, criticized Kyrgyzstan in January after Felix Kulov, a former vice president and popular opposition leader, was sentenced to seven years for abuse of office after a closed-door trial by a military court. He was acquitted of the same charges in August.
"After studying this case for some nine months, I have come to the conclusion that the prosecution, trial and sentence were all politically manipulated," Scott Horton, a lawyer in New York and president of the International League for Human Rights, said in an interview. "You could hardly imagine stronger evidence of judicial misconduct."
In Uzbekistan, human rights advocates and diplomats say President Islam A. Karimov exercises a degree of control unusual even in this authoritarian region, keeping a tight leash on rivals within the political elite and using mass arrests to suppress opponents.
A Swiss company, Romak S.A., discovered the extent of his control when it shipped $10 million worth of wheat to Uzbekistan. The contract was signed by the agriculture minister and the wheat was delivered, but people involved in the transaction said Mr. Karimov had refused to authorize payment because he had not approved the deal.
Romak won a court judgment in Britain, but Uzbekistan has refused to honor it, saying it had fulfilled the contract by paying a local company.
In February 1999, Mr. Karimov, 63, was the target of an assassination attempt blamed by the government on Islamic militants. Diplomats in Tashkent said it might have been the work of opponents within the establishment who saw no legitimate way to challenge Mr. Karimov.
"I look for a bodyguard bullet there," Ms. Olcott of the Carnegie Endowment said. "He will always be under risk of assassination."
President Saparmurat Niyazov of Turkmenistan, 61 and, like Mr. Aliyev and Mr. Shevardnadze, a former Soviet Politburo member, also exhibits no sign of giving up power willingly, though he said Sunday that he would not run for re-election in 2010. Two years ago, Mr. Niyazov was declared president for life and is the focus of a personality cult unrivaled since the days of Stalin.
A 75-foot gilded statue of him stands in the main square in the capital, Ashgabat, rotating so that it always faces the sun. Three new monuments dedicated to the man who calls himself Turkmenbashi, or father of the Turkmen people, were erected in January.
The issue of succession would seem to be most pressing for Mr. Aliyev, in Azerbaijan. He is the oldest of the region's leaders and underwent heart surgery in 1999.
His hospitalization while visiting the United States last fall led to a near-panic in Baku after rumors spread that he had died. People began to horde food and hole up in their apartments, remembering the chaos of civil war that followed independence in 1991.
Mr. Aliyev, the longtime leader of Soviet Azerbaijan and president of the independent republic since 1993, has insisted that he will seek another five-year term in 2003 and presents a vigorous image in the frequent televised broadcasts of his state appearances.
But aides say his unrelenting schedule leaves Mr. Aliyev weary at the end of most days, creating the possibility that he will not run in two years.
Unlike other countries in the region, Azerbaijan has a legitimate political opposition, though its latitude is restricted and parliamentary elections last November were criticized by Western monitors.
"This is a false democracy, and the president is very willing to put power in the hands of his son," Sardar Jalaloglu, general secretary of the Azerbaijan Democratic Party, said in an interview.
Still, the opposition press regularly criticizes government officials as corrupt and castigates the president's son as a playboy who is unprepared to run the country, freedoms unavailable in most other countries in the region.
Efforts have been under way to groom Ilham Aliyev to succeed his father. Business executives and diplomats in Azerbaijan maintain that such a succession is the best hope to keep the country in the Western sphere of influence and protect billions of dollars in foreign investment in its rich energy resources.
"If Ilham's succession does not come to pass, it is no clearer here than anywhere else in the former Soviet Union what will happen," a Western diplomat said.
People who have dealt with the younger Mr. Aliyev say he appears to be well versed in the energy business as an executive of the state oil company, but they said he has occasionally expressed reluctance about becoming president. He has also not faced the adversity he would encounter running a country where people earn an average of $1,600 a year and hostilities could arise on any of its borders.
No opposition figure has emerged to challenge the president, but his son could face rivals from within the political establishment, diplomats and business leaders said. 
Chief among them is Ramiz Mehdiyev, the head of the president's executive staff and the likely choice of the former Soviet bureaucrats within Azerbaijan.
The younger Mr. Aliyev will go to Washington this spring for speeches orchestrated to portray him as a worthy successor and to demonstrate to skeptics that he does want the presidency. 
A member of a faction of younger, Western-oriented technocrats that has formed around him said planning was quietly under way to develop a message of continuity and progress for him to deliver once Event X occurs.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Heydar Aliyev, right, president of Azerbaijan, with his son, Ilham, 39, and Ilham's wife, Mekhriban, at a polling station last November. A father-son succession is being prepared, and it is part of a regional trend. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Chelsea Journal; 
Where the Middle Class Shops Like the Upper

BYLINE:  By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
He stood in a line, three deep. "If they're going to take my money they should be a little faster about it before I change my mind," said Richard Turrin, a wry smile cutting across his chiseled face. Actually, Mr. Turrin, a "blissfully unemployed" investment banker, didn't give a hoot about waiting forever to buy merchandise at the first day of Barneys Warehouse Sale, a twice-a-year "New York institution," as he put it.
 As Mr. Turrin, a 39-year-old Gramercy Park resident, advanced toward a cash register, he was joined by his girlfriend, Katie Van Egmond, a journalist visiting from Melbourne, Australia, who had found a lime green sweater for her father back home. She caressed her beau's find, a brown Hugo Boss mid-thigh coat, made of leather as soft as flan, and laughed. "Richard is relieving himself of a thousand dollars for this bargain," she said. He gave her a sheepish look, then smiled. 
 There were more than a few smiles in evidence at the sale, which began Thursday (while Fashion Week was in full swing) and continues until March 4 at 255 West 17th Street in Manhattan. The good humor might seem surprising, given the frenzied nature of the hunt and the lack of amenities (no dressing rooms or chairs). 
"For Americans, shopping is a recreational outlet," Ms. Van Egmond said. "There's an urgency in seizing their bargains. I'm afraid I've lived a very sheltered background in that regard."
The sale, a New York event since the early 70's, brought out a pastiche of the city's colors and social classes, from Upper East Side doyennes to office workers from the boroughs. Patrons of every ilk pounced on purses and pumps by Prada. They fought over fashions by Armani, Isaac Mizrahi and Geoffrey Beene. And of course, the fashion cognoscenti coddled clothing featuring the Barneys New York store label as well as the Barney's Co-op brand. All merchandise, including a small number of houseware goods, was 50 percent to 80 percent off, said Jessica Taubas, a company spokeswoman. 
To make room for the racks, Barneys temporarily closes its Co-op store, which features younger designers and wide aisles, and cedes the space for the sale. Barneys, with eight stores in America, is known for its spartan civilization. But its warehouse sale is decidedly uncivilized. 
In the women's department, a sprawling open area with exposed pipes and wires, there were a smattering of men. That didn't prevent a woman in her 30's from stripping down to her bra to try on a sweater she later discarded. A woman of ample girth wearing black cotton panties was trying on several pairs of pants.
In a steady assembly line operation, cashiers rang up the goods and stuffed brown bags. One customer was caught in the crossfire. "Good Lord, she stapled the finger," said a young man as he stepped away from the cash register, examining his hand. 
Curt Weber, 28, a Crown Heights, Brooklyn, resident who works at a fashion photo production house, waited patiently in line to pay in the men's department, where the word is that shoppers are more parasitic than those in the women's section. "At least no one grabbed anything out of my hands, but they came close to it," he said, laughing.
Nearby, Ron Sharkey, a 41-year-old administrator at a Manhattan high school, said he rarely shops at Barneys but has purchased at the warehouse sale before. "I usually shop at Marshalls and Century 21," said Mr. Sharkey, who lives a few blocks from the warehouse in Chelsea. He showed off $200 Barneys New York shoes marked down to $99; $140 Turbo hiking boots marked down to $39, and a $120 Barneys New York cotton shirt marked down to $47.
Kendra Brown, a 29-year-old art teacher from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, found an abundance of designer bargains, including three sweaters, four shirts, a dress and a skirt. Ms. Brown, a designer-fashion aficianado, wore Betsy Johnson jeans, a Steven Allen bracelet, and carried an Etienne Aigner handbag. "I'm getting good deals, but I wish they had a better system," she said, glancing at a line for the cashiers that snaked around the corner.
Jill Bebar, a journalist in her 30's, bought an orange corduroy skirt with the Co-op label and two pairs of pantyhose by Barneys New York. She's a warehouse sale regular. "I don't mind that there is no dressing room," she said. "I always find good deals. I might come back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ron Sharkey, 41, a school administrator taking advantage of the annual Barneys Warehouse Sale, got $200 shoes for half that and a $120 shirt for less than $50. And a few other potential budget-breakers. (Aaron Lee Fineman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Inflation Risks Are Still Seen for Euro Zone

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
A member of the European Central Bank council, Ernst Welteke, said today that inflationary risks in the 12-nation euro zone, though reduced, were still present, suggesting that he remained skeptical about lowering interest rates.
 "Risks for price stability have diminished, but they haven't disappeared," Mr. 
Welteke, the president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, said in a speech. He cited increased food prices because of fears about mad cow disease in several European Union countries and a recent jump in oil prices. 
 The European Central Bank last raised its benchmark rate a quarter point, to 4.75 percent, on Oct. 5 -- the seventh increase since November 1999. The central bank's 18-member governing council convenes to set rates on March 1.
Most analysts say the bank's next move will be to cut rates, as growth in the euro region is slowing and the annual inflation rate declined in December to 2.6 percent from 2.9 percent in November. The bank has set an inflation ceiling of 2 percent.
Still, the bank has indicated that for now it will wait before lowering rates, as it wants to gauge how much the euro zone will be affected by a slowdown in the American economy.

HEADLINE: Foreign Stocks Ease Their Recent Volatility 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
With Wall Street closed in observance of the Presidents' Day holiday, foreign financial markets were fairly quiet yesterday -- moving in subdued patterns of the sort of volatility that governed trading last week.
 Markets in Asia generally slid, especially in Taiwan, with its heavy dependence on technology issues. European markets were off slightly over all, as telecommunications stocks continued lower amid worries about debt, while old economy stalwarts like steel, oil and chemicals showed modest strength. 
 A surprise earnings warning on Thursday by Nortel Networks, the world's leading supplier of fiber optic equipment to telecommunications companies, had effects elsewhere. Nortel's warning had driven down Nasdaq stocks 5 percent on Friday.
Patrick Shields, an analyst with BNP Paribas, said, "Last week's technology stock performance on both sides of the Atlantic suggests that there is still downside risk, and that the market still has an appetite for bad news."
Nortel's French rival Alcatel fell 3.4 percent yesterday, among the sharpest declines of in a European blue-chip stock. France Telecom fell 1.6 percent to a new low for the year. The Vodafone Group of Britain shed 3.1 percent, reaching a two-year low on reports that its planned sale of Infostrada, an Italian subsidiary, was in jeopardy. But Deutsche Telekom rose from two-year lows on hopes that it would sell assets.
And Nortel itself improved in Toronto trading more than 5 percent, with buying by bargain-hunting investors helping it recoup a small part of the 33 percent decline it suffered Friday. The benchmark Toronto index rose 0.79 percent for the day.
Among old economy issues, news that Usinor of France would merge with two rivals to create the world's largest steelmaker, and the prospect that industry overproduction might ease as a result, gave a lift to rivals like Corus, which gained 5.7 percent, and Thyssen Krupp, up 3.9 percent.
In currency dealings, the euro rose nearly 1 percent against the dollar and the yen after the Group of Seven leading industrial nations lent weight at a weekend conference to expectations that European economies would grow faster than the United States or Japan this year.

HEADLINE: For Cardinal-to-Be, a Busy Day in Rome 

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
On his first day here, Archbishop Edward M. Egan encountered only one hitch today in his preparations to become one of 44 new cardinals on Wednesday. The red ceremonial robes that he had ordered turned out to be a few inches too long and had to be sent back to the tailor.
 The rest of his day was a smooth if somewhat hurried round of press interviews and visits to old haunts, from the seminary where he was ordained and later taught, to Vatican offices and to the Holy Roman Rota, the church court where he once was a judge. He had a pasta and roast veal lunch at the Villa Stritch, the Vatican residence for American priests where he lived for 14 years before being made an auxiliary bishop of New York in 1985. 
 Archbishop Egan, 68, said he did not find that former Vatican colleagues were treating him more deferentially since he was named a cardinal. "I've been here a long time. I really became an Italian, and I think they kind of think of me as a friend," he said. Nor has he been smothered with his new title of respect, "your eminence." Archbishop Egan said, "they haven't started that yet."
Yet the process is well under way. On Wednesday, Pope John Paul II will crown 44 new cardinals with the red zucchetto (skullcap, or "beanie" as Archbishop Egan described it early in his New York tenure) and red biretta, a four-cornered hat.
Two other Americans, Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Washington, and the Rev. Avery Dulles, a theologian at Fordham University, were also named. The record number of new nominations raises the number of cardinals eligible to vote in a conclave for a new pope to 135, well above the limit of 120 set by Pope Paul VI. 
Rome is already teeming with cardinal-designates and their entourages from all over the world, and bracing itself for limousines, dinners, receptions and streams of official delegations. Consistories, or ceremonial gatherings of cardinals, traditionally combine solemn religious pageantry with festive celebration. 
Lindy Boggs, 84, the former Louisiana congresswoman and outgoing United States ambassador to the Holy See, will hold a reception for the three new American cardinals and described the weeklong round of ceremonies and parties as "a cross between a Washington inaugural and the debutante season in New Orleans." 
Some 850 people are expected to fly in from New York to witness Archbishop Egan's elevation, and by some standards, his is a modest delegation. Archbishop Crescenzio Sepe, an Italian Vatican official, has invited 5,000 guests from his hometown, Carinaro, to Wednesday's ceremony. 
As early as last Friday, switchboard operators at Santa Marta, the hotel-like residence inside the Vatican where many cardinals are staying, were entangled in high-powered calls. "Eminence, his excellency is calling. Your excellency, his eminence is on the line."
Archbishop Egan, who will have dinners for special guests on both Friday and Saturday nights, because no hotel ballroom in Rome is large enough to fit all 850 in one sitting, said he intended to keep down costs. "If I have seemed to not be overdoing it, it is because, as I see it, I am here as a servant to the 413 parishes of New York." He described his hospitality plans as "pretty much standard operation," adding, "We haven't added anything or embellished, but I think we are doing rather nicely with what is usually done." 
When in Rome for a consistory, cardinals usually stay in Vatican housing, or at church residences around the city. Archbishop McCarrick is staying at the Pontifical North American College, a seminary for American priests. Father Dulles is staying at the main residence of his Jesuit order. Archbishop Egan is staying at the five-star hotel Crowne Plaza Rome-Minerva, but not at the expense of New York parishioners -- the hotel's chairman is an old friend of Archbishop Egan's, and offers him free rooms when he is in town.
One reason for the pared-down approach is that when he took over the New York Archdiocese after Cardinal John O'Connor's death last May, Archbishop Egan inherited a huge deficit. He declined to disclose the sum. 
"We have very, very serious deficits to face. We'll face them and take care of them," he said, after explaining that he had decided to close John A. Coleman, a Catholic high school in Ulster County, because of its $800,000 deficit and shrinking enrollment. "It is not the first time I've had to face this kind of thing, and I will face them again. It is not something that cannot be handled, but it is very significant and has to be attended to seriously." 
It was partly his fiscal track record in Bridgeport, Conn., where he consolidated and closed economically failing schools and parishes and also proved himself as a deft fund-raiser, that prompted the pope to put him in charge of New York. Archbishop Egan allowed that he and Cardinal O'Connor were "very different," but praised his predecessor, saying, "I hope I can be half as good." 
Archbishop Egan credited New Yorkers with his elevation to cardinal. "I think the archdiocese sees itself as honored by this event; that's exactly the proper way to see it," he said. "Cardinals choose the pope, the successor of Peter, and I think everybody likes the idea that their particular religious leader would be involved in the choice. It is an honor, and people treat you in a very loving way, but really, the honor is to the archdiocese." 
But he said he felt a new sense of responsibility as cardinal. "As a person who has been given this particular honor, I can safely say that the obligation to do it well has become more obvious, more compelling."

HEADLINE: CHANGE STIRS HOPE FOR LEGAL STATUS AMONG IMMIGRANTS 

BYLINE:  By JANE GROSS 

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Feb. 18 

 BODY:
An obscure change in immigration law passed in the waning days of the Clinton administration could lead to legal status for as many as half-a-million illegal immigrants, but it could also lead to disappointment for millions more who have misinterpreted the change as a general amnesty. 
 The crucial part of the law temporarily reinstates a provision, in effect from 1994 to 1998, that allows illegal immigrants with certain family relationships or with the backing of some employers to petition for legal status without having to go to the American consulate in their home countries. That is significant because most illegal immigrants are prohibited re-entry -- for anywhere from 3 to 10 years -- if they leave the country, dissuading those who might otherwise legalize their status. 
 The change in the law also establishes a four-month window for qualified immigrants to file the extensive paperwork necessary for the petitions. The challenge now facing those who meet the requirements of the change is finding scrupulous legal advice and a willing sponsor by the April 30 deadline. 
That task has been made much more difficult as the nation's illegal immigrants -- 5 million to 6 million, according to Immigration and Naturalization Service estimates -- hear of the legislation in the ethnic news media, misunderstand it to be a general amnesty and then herd into hastily scheduled community meetings to find out who qualifies and what they must do by the deadline. The confusion is compounded by advertisements from lawyers and non-lawyers alike in the ethnic press, from East New York to East Los Angeles. The ads, in boldface type, and containing multiple exclamation marks, trumpet "Immigration Amnesty Alert!!" or "This Could Be Your Last Chance!"
In its advisories, the I.N.S. also uses boldface, underscored type to emphasize that the law -- clause 245(i), which was intended as a mere tweak in a huge budget bill passed last December -- is "not amnesty for all persons unlawfully in the United States," like the broad federal amnesty of 1986. Of the 700,000 people -- most of them Latinos -- who could move toward permanent residency and citizenship under this law, I.N.S. officials estimate that anywhere from 200,000 to 500,000 of those will benefit from clause 245(i).
To clarify the law, and to protect immigrants from fly-by-night promises, advocacy groups, legal service agencies and religious organizations have been scrambling to organize informational seminars. A sampling of those who have run these forums suggests crowds beyond anyone's expectations and expectations among those attending that bear little relation to reality.
This northern Westchester town, a magnet for Latino day laborers, is one such place. The other night at the Mount Kisco Elementary School, dozens of men in denim jackets and dirty work boots dashed to the front of the lunchroom, shouting questions and grasping for business cards from Philip E. Berns, an immigration lawyer who had just spent two hours explaining the technicalities of 245(i).
A janitor had started mopping the floor and stacking the folding chairs, but the immigrants were oblivious, nearly trampling Mr. Berns in the rush to ask follow-up questions. "They come to me totally desesperado," Mr. Berns said, slipping from one language to the other as he described the hopelessness of his potential clients. "It is muy, muy dificil."
Mr. Berns said this was the 20th of his presentations in northern Westchester and Connecticut at churches, technical schools, Head Start programs and even a commercial bakery. His office telephone has been ringing nonstop, his secretary is hoarse and his waiting room is full of people without appointments. 
The forum for immigrants here in Mount Kisco, and another down the hall in English for interested employers, were put together by Carla Rediker, a bilingual social worker, who plans additional sessions in Ossining, Peeksill and Brewster. Catholic Charities, in New York City, with six attorneys and nine paralegals, is running seminars every Thursday at its headquarters on First Avenue in Manhattan, and is sending the equivalent of circuit-riders elsewhere. The New York Immigration Coalition, with help from the borough presidents, has similar sessions scheduled in the Bronx and Queens. 
Most everyone who has run a forum reports huge crowds and widespread misinformation. At the Southside Community Mission in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, for example, 1,000 people showed up at 9 a.m. for an 11:30 meeting last month. At a subsequent meeting, Sister Peggy Walsh, who leads the immigration project, set up 30 folding chairs, had to add 20 more and let the 25 latecomers stand. But of the 75 immigrants who came, Sister Walsh said, only 3 had qualifying family members. 
Mario Russell, director of immigrant services at Catholic Charities, reports similar ignorance of the law, which says legal permanent residents can petition for spouses and unmarried children, for example, but not for parents or siblings, as citizens can.
The Southside Mission, like virtually all nonprofit agencies in the region, is handling only family petitions, which are generally cut-and-dried. Partly because of the extensive involvement required of employers, labor certifications, as the employment petitions are known, are complicated and often ambiguous. Catholic Charities tried to take on employment cases, along with family petitions, using one part-time labor lawyer. The available appointments filled within days. 
"At a time like this lack of legal services is thrown into high relief," said Margie McHugh, executive director of the New York Immigrant Coalition, who warns immigrants to avoid "notarios" -- which means "lawyer" in Latin America but notary here -- as well as the travel and real estate agents who often take on multiple roles in Latino neighborhoods. 
In New York City, with an estimated 500,000 illegal immigrants, there are only 30 immigration lawyers working at nonprofit agencies, Ms. McHugh said, adding that the ratio is even worse in the suburbs. The nonprofit agencies charge $200 to $1,000 to process a petition, Ms. McHugh said. Private lawyers, surveys show, charge about $2,000 for a family petition and $3,000 to $7,000 for a labor certification.
Experts agree that clause 245(i) is a more promising tool for those with qualifying relatives than it is for those with employers who may be reluctant to tackle the onerous paperwork or take on the risk, however remote, of being sanctioned by the I.N.S. or the Department of Labor for hiring illegal workers.
Just a birth certificate establishes a family connection to someone who is generally enthusiastic about petitioning. But employment cases, for unskilled and semiskilled laborers, are messy. There must be proof, via concerted advertising, that there are no Americans available for the job. 
The position must be full time and at the prevailing wage, which means union scale in certain building trades, far more than what most illegal immigrants command. Then the job much be matched to another job that is listed in a two-volume Department of Labor compendium to determine its skill classification. Skilled jobs, like computer programmers or auto mechanics, have more visa slots and thus shorter waiting periods. 
The documentation must come from the employer. A landscaper from Armonk, daunted by the seminar here, said he had one employee, out of dozens, he would apply for. Mr. Russell at Catholic Charities said the landscapers and construction workers in the suburbs had the worst chance because most employers considered them replaceable "commodities." The best chance, he said, would be a small business, like a florist or a deli, where the worker and boss had a "committed personal relationship." 
Close ties brought several women with trusted household help to the employers' seminar in Mount Kisco. They were told by Michael J. Boyle, a private lawyer who does labor certifications, that the wait for a visa for a nanny was now 10 years with the backlog of applications growing. A groan rose in the room. 
But all is not lost, Mr. Boyle told the crowd. A family with sufficient resources and a certain set of needs could label the job of nanny as cook, which has virtually no waiting list. Or an employer might petition for a nanny and meet the April 30 deadline, thus giving a valued employee the ability to transfer the petition to a more favorable category, say spouse, if during the years of waiting the employee married a legal resident. 
Experts say it is possible to submit a family petition without legal help, but not a labor certification. Mr. Boyle said there were rare employers willing to pay the expenses, usually wealthy professional families living in affluent areas like Westchester or Fairfield Counties, whose households might founder without the hired help.
Upgrading a job is perfectly legal, assuming an employer can prove need and pay the prevailing wage, an I.N.S. spokesman, Bill Strassberger, said. Also legal is using an immediate petition as a place-holder. If the hypothetical nanny who later married a legal resident had not filed before April 30, Mr. Strassberger noted, she would have to go to a foreign country after her marriage to apply and would be denied re-entry for 10 years. Thus the urgency to file a petition.
"My job is to make a way when there is no way," Mr. Berns said. "I can't imagine a case that is absolutely, guaranteed a failure. Long-shot applications are very different than bogus ones. Unless the economy goes sour and people are lined up to cut lawns and burp babies."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Philip E. Berns, in tie, an immigration lawyer, was deluged with questions about changes in the immigration law at a forum in Mount Kisco, N.Y., last week. Many people are confused about what the law entails. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)(pg. B6)

Collapse of Health System Adds to North Korean Crisis
The country's grossly undersupplied health system is one victim of the continuing deterioration of North Korea's infrastructure, which has left many residents in a downward spiral despite relief efforts that have included huge amounts of food. Interviews with foreign aid workers and medical experts who travel extensively in North Korea bolster evidence of dire health conditions. A1
