HEADLINE: Wildlife and Derricks Coexist But the Question Is the Cost 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL 

DATELINE: VENICE, La., Feb. 15 

 BODY:
At the mouth of the Mississippi, at Louisiana's far southern tip, a marsh that is home to alligators, herons, egrets, ospreys, spoonbills and more than 200 other species has since 1935 enjoyed protected status as the Delta National Wildlife Refuge.
 For nearly all of that time, the wildlife has shared its watery quarters with oil and gas wells, pipelines and pumping stations built by energy companies, which have also dredged countless canals, almost always acting with federal permission. 
 The cohabitation is not altogether unusual. From Alaska to North Dakota to Louisiana, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service permits oil and gas exploration or production at 29 of its 530 refuges, even though habitat conservation is supposed to be the agency's primary mission. Out of sight to all but wildlife, oil workers and the rare outsider, the infrastructure includes some 1,400 wells. 
But now, with the Bush administration considering other federal sanctuaries, notably the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, as sources of new energy supplies, questions about what has and has not worked in places like the Delta refuge have suddenly become a focus of both interest and contention.
"I'm not saying that what's happened in Louisiana has been perfect, because nothing in life is perfect," said Senator John B. Breaux, the Louisiana Democrat who is among a handful in his party to support drilling in the Arctic refuge. "But with all the oil that's at stake in Alaska, it's time to take a look."
But environmentalists and others opposed to drilling in the Arctic refuge say the record of oil and gas developments at other refuges should, at best, be regarded as an unfortunate exception. Even if it is subtle, they argue, the harm inflicted in refuges in Louisiana and elsewhere will be long-lasting, and not worth the short-term economic gain of exploiting nonrenewable oil resources. The Arctic tundra may be even more sensitive to an industrial footprint, conservationists say.
"By definition, a wildlife refuge is a special place -- it's a place that wildlife need," said Noah Matson, refuge program manager for Defenders of Wildlife, a national environmental group. "So why damage it by oil and gas activity that, one way or another, is bound to be harmful?" 
Accessible only by boat, 10 miles from the nearest port, the 400,000-acre Delta refuge may be the clearest example of the coexistence that people like Mr. Breaux argue can prudently proceed in the Arctic.
"I guess if you want primitive, this is the place to come," said David Patterson, production supervisor for the Jetta Production Company, whose employees work seven days and seven off, operating from an industrial island in the marsh that is linked by pipeline to 64 wells.
Jetta and Texaco operate some 78 oil and gas wells in the refuge, making the operation the largest at any wildlife refuge in the lower 48 states.
Under these companies and Jetta's predecessor, the Chevron Corporation, there have been a number of small oil and gas spills here in the last 10 years, during which a concerted effort at environmental recordkeeping began. wildlife service officials describe several as having been significant, killing vegetation and affecting 40 to 80 acres of marsh. But the agency says there was no indication of harm to wildlife. 
That record is roughly comparable with those of other refuges where oil and gas activity is under way, with no major spills or widespread death of wildlife in recent memory, wildlife service officials say. Still, at the Kenai National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, oil and gas exploration has led to evidence of PCB contamination, these officials said, while at the D'Arbonne refuge in northern Louisiana, the use of improper equipment was linked to mercury contamination in the late 1980's.
At the D'Arbonne refuge and others in the South, environmental problems arise when drilling brings to the surface saltwater that is not part of the natural habitat. And in the Delta refuge and others along the Gulf Coast, the dredging of canals has contributed to the loss of wetlands.
Over all, cautioned Jim Kurth, deputy director of the national wildlife refuge system at the wildlife service, "we don't have a fair sense systemwide of the impact of oil and gas drilling in the refuges." 
But energy industry officials say what is known about the record should demonstrate that energy exploration and wildlife can coexist.
"I think you can do your operations in a way that protects what a wildlife refuge is designed to protect and, in some cases, enhance it," Elliott Laws, Texaco's president for safety, health and the environment, said in a telephone interview, describing the lessons he said his company had learned since drilling its first well in the Delta refuge in 1941.
As Mr. Bush's allies, including Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who heads the Energy Committee, have been eager to point out, at least one environmental group, the Audubon Society, has appeared to condone drilling on wildlife refuges. Until 1999, the group permitted oil and gas production on a private refuge it owns on the Louisiana coast. The society has been a vocal opponent of new drilling in the Arctic refuge, but its officials have insisted that the two stances are not incompatible, on grounds that it had decided long ago to end the energy operation as soon as a lease expired.
"It's something we did, and it's why we have the position we do in Alaska," John Bianchi, an Audubon spokesman, said.
By law, national wildlife refuges enjoy a level of protection that may be second only to areas set aside by Congress as wilderness areas, off limits to all but hikers and pack horses. While national forests and most other federal land is set aside for varied purposes that include logging, mining and drilling, and national parks and monuments must be accessible to the public, refuges are supposed to permit only activity compatible with protecting wildlife.
But until about a decade ago, the rules governing refuges, first imposed in 1966, have sometimes been honored in the breach, with little effort made to determine whether operations like those in the Delta refuge were harming animal habitat. Even now, records are spotty, leaving the actual effect debatable. 
In a survey of wildlife service managers by the agency in 1991 and 1992, a substantial number described oil and gas operations at their refuges as incompatible with wildlife protection. But in many cases, federal officials say, nothing can be legally done to halt the energy operations, because the subsurface rights are in private hands.
In most cases, when the federal government owns the mineral rights to land beneath the refuges, it no longer offers them for lease. But an exception is made when, as with many of the Delta wells, the government concludes that it has an obligation to taxpayers to extract the oil and gas because otherwise, a neighboring drilling operation on nonfederal land would be able to do so first.
"If you ask, Is a refuge better off with or without oil and gas development, I'd say probably without," said Dan Ashe, chief of the national wildlife system for the wildlife service. 
The Arctic refuge is a special case -- and not just because of the sheer volume of oil estimated to lie beneath, which at 5 billion to 19 billion acres ranks as the largest single discovery in the United States.
The refuge has been off limits to drilling, as part of a compromise reached in 1981. But Congress holds the power to authorize the start of oil development on 1.8 million acres along the coast, and Mr. Bush has said he will push for just such a vote as part of what he says is a broad effort to reduce dependence on foreign oil.
In the Senate, Mr. Murkowski is expected to introduce his own proposal in the next 10 days, as a rough draft for a Bush plan that is not expected until April. And opponents have begun to gear up for a fight about whether it is possible, as Mr. Bush has asserted, for drilling in the Arctic refuge to proceed "in an environmentally sensitive way."
At the refuge in Louisiana, wildlife managers say, oil companies have been quick to report even the smallest spill and willing to shift pipelines and even drilling sites to meet environmental concerns.
In the last 10 years, said James O. Harris, supervisory biologist for the federal refuges in southeast Louisiana, the wildlife service has collected about $1 million in fees from the oil companies to mitigate damage in the Delta refuge. That, Mr. Harris said, has been enough to help the agency recover more than 1,000 acres in wetlands, or 10 times the amount lost to energy operations in the period.
"There were times when you had spills when you wish they weren't there," Mr. Harris said of the oil companies from his office in New Orleans. "But because of their presence there, we've been able to do some restoration projects that we might not have been able to do." 
Still, Jim Graham, until recently the wildlife biologist at the Delta refuge, said that as cooperative as relations were, he could never quite escape the feeling that the oil companies did not belong.
"You have a pristine area, like a refuge out there, and then you have these structures," Mr. Graham said. "They may not be doing any harm to the refuge, but you're putting an object into the area that's foreign to it."

A front-page article on Tuesday about the effect of oil exploration on wildlife refuges misstated the measurement of the oil estimated to lie beneath the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska. It is 5 billion to 19 billion barrels, not acres.

HEADLINE: AUTO RACING; 
Earnhardt's Death Turns Nascar Talk to Safety

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

DATELINE: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 

 BODY:
In the moments after Dale Earnhardt hit the wall Sunday, a voice in his headset, crackling with static and rising concern, said: "You O.K., Dale? Talk to us, talk to us."
 But there was no answer. Crumpled in his famed No. 3 black Goodwrench Chevrolet, the Intimidator, bleeding from his ears, nose and mouth, was probably already dead. As red tow trucks and white ambulances swarmed around the black car, the voice on Earnhardt's radio frequency, also heard by thousands at the track with race radios, seemed to quiver with panic. "Talk to us, Dale." 
 Talk to us, Dale. In the coming days, the 49-year-old Earnhardt's sudden, sickening death in the Daytona 500 will be used to attack, justify or obscure some of the problems Nascar is facing in a new season in which network television is supposed to make stock car racing mainstream entertainment. Those problems include rising costs in a sagging economy, the equitable distribution of television money, and keeping teams competitive when some owners are financed by petroleum corporations and others by the family gas station. Safety issues, a constant Nascar concern, have become controversial as some older drivers, including Earnhardt, have refused to adopt new devices. 
Typically, Earnhardt died the way he always drove, with a bold move to hold his position and protect the lead of his son and protege, Dale Jr., as they entered the last turn of the last lap of the Daytona 500, stock car racing's premier event. His death leaves a hole in the heart of a sport as close and insular as a traveling carnival.
Nascar scenarios that are not about new rules or money are usually about sons and brothers. Lineage is very important in a sport still controlled by the family of the man, Bill France, who organized it. And so, the story lines were about bloodlines. For starters, Michael Waltrip, kid brother of the retired champion Darrell, would finally win a race. Ward Burton would slingshot out of the shadow of his brother Jeff. Kyle Petty, son of the King, Richard, would find strength after the death of his teenage son, Adam, last May. And the Dale Earnhardts would drive each other to glory; Junior would find maturity, Senior rejuvenation. 
For about 375 miles yesterday, those story lines took shape and promised a season of absorbing speed opera. Ward Burton, in one of the 10 new Dodges, led the Daytona 500 for 53 laps. Kyle Petty was not a factor in the race, but his own new Dodge was running well enough to give hope for future races. And for the 200,000 fans in gorgeous weather here and millions more watching Fox's telecast, the signature event of this new national pastime was a thriller. Fourteen drivers would change the lead 49 times -- 40 more than last year -- before the race ended.
But it was too thrilling for the gearhead cognoscenti. They were already murmuring along pit road that Nascar, which tinkers with its universe the way crews tweak a car, had gone too far. New rules designed to "manage competition" had created a dangerous situation in which cars ran too close together without the horsepower to surge out of harm's way. It had created what one of the sport's best chroniclers, Monte Dutton, calls "the world's fastest and most dangerous game of chess." One spasm in a bunched pack would cause a pile-up accident. Of course, as drivers say with more wryness than resentment, "our fans sure do love their wrecks."
"Our fans," a group portrayed as whale-bellied, beer-sucking, weekend Confederates, really comprises a rainbow of American sports fans. The 200,000 spectators at Daytona (an estimated 167,000 in the stands, thousands more in the vast infield encampments), included many executives (some even in suits) of the hundreds of sponsors, associate sponsors and clients in this most commercialized of sports. There are many multigenerational family groups who travel to several races a year. There are hard-core gearheads who keep up to date on gossip and wind-tunnel tests in weekly newspapers like The Winston Cup Scene and on Web sites like jayski.com. And there are yuppies, frat boys, good ol' boys and girls, and those tattooed, shady-looking young people who come to races to party hearty. 
They enjoy the races in two basic ways: with the assistance of the favored beer, Budweiser, or certain plants and chemicals, they view the 200-lap, three-hour race as a streaming video of color and sound, a "trip"; or with the assistance of a radio scanning the conversations between driver and crew, they can get so deep into the race they squirm to avoid hitting the wall.
When the fans got their beloved wreck on the 174th lap, it was Mark Martin who brought his totaled car to the grass with a laconic, "Guys, we're done." Robby Gordon, Ward Burton and Tony Stewart got tangled up, setting off the 18-car wreck. Amazingly, Stewart was the only one with injuries, and they were minor. 
There was relief as the race restarted sixteen minutes later. Lightning had struck. The damage was mostly financial. But would Nascar take the lesson?
Lectures on restrictor plates and aerodynamic packages tend to draw yawns outside the grease pits, but they are critical to understanding the sociology. Fans do not want to see a boat race, a follow-the-leader for three hours. They want at least the illusion that in any given race, any car has a chance to win.
On a two-and-a-half-mile superspeedway like Dayona, restricting horsepower with plates between the carburetor and intake manifold reduces speed; imagine running with your mouth and one nostril closed. Then strips of metal called spoilers to limit or redirect air flow further equalize the cars. Typically, spoilers are reconfigured and the holes in the restrictor plates are changed as the season progresses; the Nascar rule book, they say, if it even exists, is written in pencil. And now, with a $2.6 billion television contract, the stakes are even higher, increasing the pressure to assure exciting, competitive races. 
When the race resumed, it was even more exciting. Waltrip and Dale Jr. were both dueling for the lead and driving nose to tail on the straightaways to take advantage of the "dirty air" that lets two cars together go faster than one alone. Waltrip and Dale Jr. were also friends and teammates on Dale Sr.'s racing team. Earlier in the race, the elder Earnhardt -- he hated Senior and liked being called Big E -- had aggressively blocked other cars from passing his son and Waltrip. 
But on the last turn of the last lap under the fluttering white flag, Big E was also making a move for himself, trying to hold his position. For years we will see how he died, losing control of his car after it made contact with Sterling Marlin's, then spinning up toward the wall at more than 180 miles an hour. Touched by Ken Schrader's car, No. 3 then slammed head-on into the concrete.
Because of Waltrip's sentimental victory and the assumption that old Ironhead was indestructible, it was awhile before the seriousness of Earnhardt's crash became apparent from the emergency swarm and the silence on the radio to the frantic "Talk to us, Dale."
And now there will be talk again of death, a fact of racing life. The close-knit stock car community tends to deal with it through fatalism and evangelical Christianity (Nascar has its own circuit riding preacher) and to avoid dealing with it through denial. 
Last week, in an interview with George Michael on his Sports Machine show, Richard Petty was asked about the death of his grandson Adam. He said that one could die in a crash on the drive to the track. Darrell Waltrip agreed, but added that there were procedures and devices that could help avoid serious injuries and death. That will be the poles of the coming discussion.
Could Big E have been saved? There will be debate over so-called soft walls that can absorb impact, and about safety devices, which Nascar promotes, often to the resistance of older drivers. Earnhardt, would not wear a helmet that fully protected his face or the HANS (Head and Neck Support) device that keeps the head from snapping forward in a potentially lethal whiplash that severs the spine. Kyle Petty promotes the device; his son died of an injury to the base of his skull. Earnhardt suffered such an injury as well as part of the blunt force head trauma that killed him. The director of emergency medical services at Daytona said there was no way of knowing whether a HANS device would have saved Earnhardt's life. Still, this could be Nascar's opportunity to mandate such protection.
In that way, Dale may yet talk to us. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Michael Waltrip, who won the Daytona 500, discussing a safety device yesterday. (Associated Press)(pg. D3); Stormy Jermann, from Vancouver, Wash., paying tribute to Dale Earnhardt yesterday in front of a makeshift memorial in Daytona Beach, Fla. (Associated Press)(pg. D1)

HEADLINE: Our Soldiers Didn't Volunteer for Poverty 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I was encouraged by your Feb. 15 editorial about improving the "economic status and living conditions" in the armed forces. I recently left active duty, and have experienced firsthand the difficulties of making ends meet while in the service. 
We who serve tend not to attract attention to the difficulties we face at home; in fact, were I still in uniform, I would not write this letter. 
 Pay and benefits are important for the retention of highly qualified and difficult-to-replace personnel. But dignity and morale are even greater incentives to serve a full military career. No one goes into military service with the idea that it will bring wealth; choosing to serve means accepting sacrifices and compromises to meet mission requirements. It shouldn't mean actual poverty and loss of dignity. These conditions are a cancer on morale and have been key factors in the continuing exodus from military service.

ENRIQUE A. VITUG
Vacaville, Calif., Feb. 15, 2001

HEADLINE: Detroit's Answer to 'Hybrid' Cars; 
Cheaper Than Japan Models, But Far Less Fuel Efficient

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Japanese automakers have led the way in selling "hybrid" cars, which have improved fuel economy and reduced tailpipe emissions by running on either gasoline or electricity. But the Toyota Prius and Honda Insight, on the American market for a year, are costly to produce and sold in limited numbers at a loss. So Detroit is trying a middle ground.
 American automakers will offer some "full hybrids," capable of running on battery power alone at low speeds, but are putting their main focus on electrically assisted gasoline engines. Such engines, which cost little more than conventional engines but use a less ambitious technology than some environmentalists want, will become an option or standard equipment on dozens of models in coming years. 
 General Motors and Ford executives say they expect to offer various levels of electrically assisted engines at least as an option on most models, though in some cases it may take a decade or more. Other automakers are more cautious, but with G.M. and Ford together accounting for half the American market, their rivals are likely to follow suit. 
G.M. is "committed to being an absolute leader in putting that kind of technology in our vehicles across the board -- not each and every vehicle, because we still have customers that want to make choices, but having that option across the board," said Harry Pearce, G.M.'s vice chairman.
Despite a preference for full hybrids, environmentalists are mainly pleased by automakers' latest ideas. They are particularly surprised given that federal fuel-economy standards have been virtually unchanged since the late 1980's, and say the planned hybrids and voluntary pledges by G.M. and Ford to improve the gas mileage of sport utilities show that the industry is changing its ways.
"If you'd asked me what I'd have expected at the beginning of the Clinton administration, it would have been governmental action followed by a response from automakers," said Daniel Becker, energy director at the Sierra Club. "What we have is government inaction and a response by automakers to pressure from a number of sources," notably environmentalists, consumers, foreign automakers and the media. 
Auto executives say most of the vehicles are likely to be less fuel-efficient than the lightweight Insight coupe and Prius sedan, which get 48 to 65 miles a gallon. That high mileage, however, partly reflects their small, light bodies. Compared with gasoline-only models, Ford estimates that Detroit's more modest new hybrids can improve fuel economy by 10 to 20 percent, while the more ambitious designs, like those in the Insight and Prius, will gain up to 60 percent.
The new approach will be to install electrical systems that are of lower voltage than for full hybrids and are recharged by the brakes. These will allow cars' gasoline engines to turn off automatically when a vehicle stops and turn on instantly when the driver's foot touches the accelerator, improving fuel economy and reducing emissions.
Auto executives say lower-voltage hybrids offer many of the advantages of full hybrids at a small fraction of the cost. "It'll probably improve fuel economy -- the downside is it doesn't improve fuel efficiency as much as a higher-voltage system," said Lawrence J. Oswald, DaimlerChrysler's vice president for hybrid electric vehicles.
The new systems will also be able to run water pumps, power steering and heaters with less energy than is now required, and to provide extra acceleration when needed.
But in contrast to the Insight's 144-volt system and the Prius's 274-volt system, the smaller systems, with 42 volts, are not powerful enough to provide much help in actually turning the wheels. Vehicles with these systems are becoming known as "minihybrids" or "mild hybrids."
The degree of fuel-efficiency improvement from adding a 42-volt system depends on how many of a car's functions are redesigned to run on electrical energy. A full-hybrid vehicle, like the Ford Escape sport utility, which will go on sale in 2003, offers the biggest gain.
Most big automakers say they plan to offer some full hybrids along with many minihybrids. Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler have announced plans in recent months to sell full-hybrid sport utilities by 2004. G.M. plans to sell some full-hybrid pickups and midsize cars then, too.
Ford said in early January that it would begin installing 42-volt systems in 2004 on many Ford Explorers, the nation's best-selling family vehicles. Many other automakers have been working for several years on similar vehicles, though they have yet to commit themselves to mass production.
The 42-volt systems should add only $1,000 to $1,500 to a vehicle's price, much less than for a higher-voltage system, Mr. Oswald said. Consumers should be willing to pay extra because electrically assisted engines, aside from getting better mileage, have better acceleration and can heat a car faster on cold days, several auto executives said.
G.M. built a prototype of a full-hybrid midsize car a year ago that got 80 miles to the gallon, but found the effort enormously expensive. John F. Smith Jr., G.M.'s chairman, said that for cost reasons, most hybrids "will be mild hybrids rather than enormously technology-changing hybrids."
Standard & Poor's DRI, a consulting firm in Lexington, Mass., estimates that 42-volt vehicles will account for at least 30 percent of sales in North America, Europe and Japan by 2010 -- a short time by industry standards. Full hybrids will account for an additional 5 percent of the market in industrialized countries, predicted Philip Gott of DRI.
Automakers' interest in hybrid technology increased greatly after Ford vowed last summer to improve the average fuel economy of its sport utilities by 25 percent, and G.M. countered that no matter what Ford did, it would do more. "The war between G.M. and Ford over whose S.U.V.'s are more efficient is feeding right into that -- S.U.V.'s and pickups will be first" to get hybrid technology, Mr. Gott said.
Adding hybrid technology is one of the few fuel-efficiency improvements that can be made without redesigning a vehicle. This is becoming a real option now because many automakers, with research heavily subsidized by the Clinton administration, have finally mastered the complex computer controls needed to coordinate electric and mechanical power.
Hybrids do not need to be plugged in overnight for recharging, the biggest drawback of electric cars. The batteries in hybrids are recharged partly by the engines and partly by "regenerative" braking: a third of the energy from slowing the car is turned into electricity. 
Much higher-voltage systems, like those found in the Insight and Prius, allow engineers to install electric motors that can actually propel the vehicle from a standing start to 20 or 30 miles an hour. Then gasoline engines, which are more efficient at higher speeds, kick in. The addition of powerful electric motors means that automakers can use smaller, lighter, more efficient engines, considerably improving fuel economy.
The electric motors in higher-voltage systems can also be used to propel the front wheels while the gasoline engine propels the rear wheels, or vice versa, providing all-wheel drive without the complexity, weight and expense of current four-wheel-drive systems.
Mr. Becker and other environmentalists said that while they welcomed any hybrids, they still had concerns. They prefer higher-voltage hybrids, and they want automakers to use all the extra battery power to improve gas mileage. Automakers instead plan to use some of the electricity for videocassette players, dashboard computers and other accessories, and to improve acceleration.
Michael Tamor, Ford's manager of vehicle electronics research, said accessories like dashboard computers draw little current, so most new energy will go to improving fuel economy. But manufacturers, he said, may also put three-prong electrical outlets in back seats.
If people start plugging in hair dryers, portable televisions or even portable washing machines, the engine must work harder to recharge the battery. "The energy has to come from somewhere," he said.
Outlets will probably not be installed in front seats, to discourage people from plugging in devices that might distract them while they drive, Mr. Tamor said. But he acknowledged that some motorists might try to plug hair dryers in the back seat and then stretch the cord up to the front. 
American manufacturers are most interested in offering hybrids for gas-guzzling sport utilities, rather than selling the high-mileage small cars preferred by many environmentalists. Mr. Becker said manufacturers were too interested in preserving the social acceptability of sport utilities. The full-hybrid Dodge Durango, for example, will get 18 miles a gallon when it goes on sale in 2004, DaimlerChrysler says. That is better than the 15 for a conventional Durango, but it is still worse than a typical large car or minivan, to say nothing of a subcompact.
The Insight gets 61 miles to the gallon in the city and 68 on the highway mainly because it weighs even less than a Chevrolet Metro.
As electric systems become more sophisticated, they have begun to mystify auto executives with mechanical backgrounds -- to say nothing of executives with finance and marketing backgrounds. Ronald Zarrella, a marketer who is now president of G.M.'s North American operations, said that when G.M.'s automotive strategy board was given a two-hour briefing recently on 42-volt systems, "it was at a level that while we all understood the philosophy and objectives, few of us understood the technical dissertation."
Auto executives say they are responding to a market dominated by affluent consumers who want big vehicles with lots of power. "Customers don't care about fuel economy, and they hardly care about emissions," Mr. Oswald of DaimlerChrysler said.
Full hybrids have initially appealed to drivers who like new technology and care about the environment, said Steve Sturm, Toyota's vice president for marketing.
Robert Ward, a retired career consultant and engineer who worked in the 1940's and 1950's on engine valves for cars and aircraft, said he bought an Insight partly because he liked the car but also to save energy.
"I think it's marvelous, but I also think we as a people need to have something that uses energy more efficiently," said Mr. Ward, who is 82 and lives in Portola Valley, Calif.
Mr. Pearce of G.M. said the auto industry was nonetheless concerned about emissions of both global-warming and smog-causing gases. "We know that our product impacts air quality; the solution has to be high-volume, most-efficient vehicles across the board," he said.
But small improvements in the fuel economy of the least-efficient vehicles can do more to reduce the nation's total fuel consumption than seemingly larger improvements for already efficient vehicles, Mr. Pearce pointed out.
If a sport utility with a conventional engine gets 15 miles a gallon, it needs 40 gallons for a 600-mile trip. Improving that to 20 miles a gallon will mean only 30 gallons are needed, saving 10 gallons.
By contrast, if a midsize car's mileage is improved to 40 from 25, its gas consumption on the same trip will fall to 15 gallons from 24, saving just nine gallons.
"The best surrogate for emissions," Mr. Pearce said, "is how much fossil fuel you burn."

HEADLINE: Court Papers Depict Scheme In Drug Billing 

BYLINE:  By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
As Congress debates whether Medicare should be expanded to cover all prescription drugs, prosecutors have laid out evidence in court of how one drug company used the federal health care program and private insurers to make indirect payments to doctors who prescribed its drug.
 Prosecutors in the United States attorney's office in Boston have charged a urologist with conspiring with a drug maker, identified in court filings as Company X, to receive excessive payments from Medicare, which investigators said were indirect kickbacks and bribes for writing prescriptions for Lupron, a drug used to treat prostate cancer. 
 Lupron is sold by TAP Pharmaceutical Products, a joint venture of Abbott Laboratories of Abbott Park, Ill., and Takeda Chemical Industries of Japan 
Details of the drug company's prolonged involvement appear in court documents filed by the government against the urologist, Dr. Joseph Spinella, of Bristol, Conn. 
One person close to the case said prosecutors were negotiating a settlement with TAP to resolve accusations that it had illegally used the Medicare system to help hundreds of doctors profit from prescribing Lupron. The person said the company might be required to pay penalties of hundreds of millions of dollars.
Federal prosecutors and executives at TAP declined to comment on the case.
Under federal law, it is a crime to bill the government, patients or others for free drug samples. It is also a crime to pay kickbacks, bribes or rebates to doctors to induce them to prescribe a drug that Medicare pays for.
The system of helping doctors profit by prescribing Lupron has helped spawn a black market for the drug. In January, the United States attorney's office in Connecticut filed charges against two Florida doctors who ordered excess supplies of Lupron and then resold them at higher prices in other states, according to court papers. The two urologists have agreed to forfeit $1.1 million to the federal government.
Lawyers watching the case involving TAP said that it and a similar case involving the Bayer Corporation are the first of what would most likely be many more cases aimed at marketing tactics used by the pharmaceutical industry to have doctors prescribe their drugs.
"I think there is tremendous concern about the relationship between physicians and pharmaceutical companies," said Kathleen McDermott, a former federal prosecutor who works at the law firm of Blank Rome Comisky & McCauley in Baltimore. "I think you'll see many more investigations of those relationships."
Already, federal and state officials are investigating whether other drug companies may have used the Medicare and Medicaid programs to help doctors get excessive government reimbursements for certain drugs.
Last month, Bayer agreed to pay $14 million to settle charges that it had caused doctors and hospitals to submit inflated claims for prescription drugs used by Medicaid patients.
Last fall, after an 18-month investigation, the House Commerce Committee concluded that many drug companies were behind similar excessive claims because they publicly reported an average wholesale price for their drugs that was much higher than the price they actually charged doctors and pharmacies.
Both the Medicare program, which covers seniors, and the Medicaid program, which covers the poor, have long reimbursed health care providers based on a percentage of the average wholesale price. When drug companies charge doctors far less than the average wholesale price to buy the drug, the doctors can profit from each prescription they write.
The system has been repeatedly criticized over the years, but the rules have not been changed. And many doctors and other health care providers say that the high reimbursements for prescription drugs are justified because Medicare and Medicaid do not adequately cover the other costs of patient care.
But with Lupron, federal prosecutors said the drug maker allowed hundreds of doctors to profit when they prescribed the drug.
According to the case filed in December against Dr. Spinella, a drug maker identified as Company X "deliberately and intentionally" charged doctors prices that were substantially less than the average wholesale price. While prosecutors did not identify Company X by name, they said it "sold and provided the drug Lupron to urologists across the country." TAP is the only company that sells Lupron. 
Prosecutors said the company told Dr. Spinella to bill the government the average wholesale price for Lupron rather than the lower amount it charged him.
Prosecutors said the company also gave Dr. Spinella free samples of Lupron, which he then charged to Medicare as if he had paid for them, netting thousands of dollars.
"It was Company X's objective, in part," court papers said, "to use the Medicare program as its checkbook for the indirect payment of kickbacks and bribes to physicians like Joseph Spinella."
Dr. Spinella, who declined to comment, is charged with conspiring with the drug company to receive kickbacks. His lawyer, George C. McMahon, said Dr. Spinella was working with prosecutors "to straighten this out."
Early last year, another urologist, Dr. Rodney Mannion of Michigan City, Ind., was charged with conspiring to bill insurance companies for free samples of Lupron that he had received from TAP. Dr. Mannion pleaded guilty in April and is awaiting sentencing.
In November, prosecutors made a similar charge against Dr. Jacob Zamstein, a urologist in Bloomfield, Conn. Dr. Zamstein did not return phone calls. Dr. Mannion referred calls to his lawyer, who did not return several messages.
Michael A. Pretl, general counsel for the American Urological Association, said federal investigators looking into the marketing of Lupron have asked to see the financial records over the last two years of at least 100 urologists. Most of the doctors have not received further inquiries from investigators, Mr. Pretl said.
Medicare now pays for only a limited number of prescription drugs, but Congress is discussing proposals that would expand Medicare to cover most prescription drugs. Many of those drugs are injectible medicines for cancer patients that are given in a doctor's office. Medicare also covers vaccines like those for influenza or hepatitis B. In 1999, doctors and other providers billed Medicare $620 million for prescriptions of Lupron. Medicare paid 80 percent of that amount, while patients or insurance companies paid the rest.
Lupron is not the only drug available to treat prostate cancer. For the last decade, TAP has been in a marketing battle with AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals, which makes Zoladex. Lupron is preferred by many prostate cancer patients because it is less painful when injected, but Lupron is more expensive than Zoladex.
In the case against Dr. Spinella, prosecutors said that the drug company referred to the additional Medicare reimbursements that doctors could make by prescribing Lupron as its "Return to Practice" program, and referred to the inflated government reimbursements as money going to the doctor from the company's "checkbook."
According to court papers, the company manipulated the average wholesale price so that doctors would receive more money from Medicare by prescribing Lupron than they could by prescribing Zoladex. 
In August 1995, prosecutors said, an employee of Dr. Spinella told the drug company that the doctor had switched 26 of his patients to Zoladex from Lupron. A drug comany employee then left Dr. Spinella with a document that described how the doctor could earn as much as $7,000 in extra Medicare reimbursements by prescribing Lupron rather than Zoladex, court papers said.
In October 1995, Dr. Spinella told the company that he understood he could earn a greater profit by prescribing Lupron, but that he also wanted free samples of Lupron. A month later, Dr. Spinella told the company that he had 30 patients on Zoladex and that for each free monthly dose of Lupron that he received, he would switch one patient back to Lupron. The average wholesale price for a monthly dose of Lupron in 1995 was almost $500, according to court papers.
Prosecutors said Dr. Spinella and the company "knew, understood and expected" that the doctor would then bill Medicare and patients for those free samples and that those payments "would be a kickback and bribe" paid in exchange for the doctor's business.
Prosecutors said that Dr. Spinella received 30 free doses in late November and early December 1995, and that he later received $15,000 in reimbursements for those samples.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Powell's First Memo

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Wouldn't it be interesting if Secretary of State Colin Powell sent the following memo to President Bush? 
 Dear Mr. President: I'm glad you decided to bomb Iraq to re-establish our deterrence there, but we shouldn't let these fireworks fool us into believing that we have a sustainable Iraq policy. We do not. Right now we're getting the worst of all worlds -- we're being blamed and isolated in the Arab world for something that we're not even succeeding at doing -- either toppling Saddam or inspecting his weapons facilities. It's time for a radical new approach. We need to remember that while getting rid of Saddam is our preference, rendering him harmless to his neighbors -- in a way that does not isolate us in the region -- is our strategic interest. 
 I'm off soon to the Middle East and I would like your permission to explore a whole new approach to Iraq. I would declare the following: The U.S. is ready to resume full diplomatic relations with Iraq, and to lift economic sanctions, under three conditions: First, that all U.N. weapons inspections in Iraq will be resumed -- but with a twist. All the weapons inspectors will be from the United States and the United States alone -- no Russians, no French, no Indians, nobody else. Our strategic interest is to ensure that Iraq cannot develop and is not developing weapons of mass destruction, and we will not entrust anyone else with that mission. We have to do it ourselves, and we have to do it as long as is necessary to ensure that Iraq remains free of nuclear weapons and delivery systems. So we're offering U.S. relations for U.S. inspections.
Second, Iraq, and the U.N., would have to agree to a ban on all sales of major weapons and dual-use items to Iraq, with the U.S. again free to use its inspectors to ensure compliance. Third, Saddam would have to continue abiding by limitations on his troop movements, either north or south, and if he violates any of these conditions the sanctions and bombing would resume. If he agrees, Iraq would be welcomed back into the family of nations.
What are the advantages of this approach? To begin with, we put the onus on Saddam instead of on ourselves. The message to the Iraqi people and to the Arab street is that the U.S. is not out to get rid of an Arab leader, however evil, it is not out to starve the Iraqi people, and it is not out to isolate Iraq forever. It is out to guarantee that Iraq cannot threaten its neighbors or global stability, and if Iraq meets that test it can end its isolation and even have relations with America, which is what the Iraqis really want.
Moreover, we put the onus on our Arab allies. They will no longer be able to escape bringing pressure on Yasir Arafat, or more openly cooperating on peace, by hiding behind the excuse that because we're always bombing Iraq their publics won't let them work with us on Israel. Right now our Arab allies are drifting away from us and Israel and toward Iraq. This policy would create a magnet to pull Iraq toward our Arab friends and Israel, something Ariel Sharon would love.
Finally, nothing, Mr. President, and I mean nothing, could change the strategic landscape in the Mideast more than bringing Iraq back into the equation, with diplomatic relations with the U.S. The hard-liners in Iran would be terrified and more isolated than ever. Syria would be much more willing to cooperate with us. And the Russians and the French would go nuts, because they want the sanctions on Iraq to just crumble, and for Iraq to continue having no relations with us, so their oil companies and exporters will have Iraq all to themselves.
In sum, Mr. President, this approach would make clear to everyone that your foreign policy isn't just a clone of your father's -- but that it will be hard-headed, imaginative and capable of overcoming the contradictions in our Middle East policies that have plagued us for a decade. If Saddam accepts this proposal, it would give us the best means possible to control Iraq's military capabilities. And if Saddam rejects this proposal, it would give us the best reason possible for further isolating him instead of ourselves.
Sure, some of your advisers will tell you it makes us look weak, but no one is going to accuse an administration with me, Dick Cheney and a president named Bush of being weak on Iraq. And even if anyone does, we still have time to blame it all on Bill Clinton.
Looking forward to your reaction. 
Colin

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Mergers in Australia Stir A Debate Over Competition

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Caught between the competing pressures of global consolidation and energetic antitrust enforcement, many Australian companies are coming to the uncomfortable realization that they may have become both too big to merge and too small not to. 
 Australia is a prosperous and attractive market, but with a population of 20 million people and an economy roughly half the size of California's, successful companies in many industries here can run out of room to grow at home before they have reached a globally competitive scale. 
 The usual alternative for such companies is a cross-border merger, but those are problematic in Australia. Its sprawling land mass and geographic isolation limit the pool of plausible partners and potential savings from a merger. 
And having home-grown businesses move their headquarters overseas or be swallowed by foreign owners is becoming a political sore point.
The prime minister, John Howard, said last week in a television appearance that he was determined to ensure that Australia "doesn't become a branch-office economy."
These factors are leaving companies here increasingly unable either to buy or to find a buyer, domestic or foreign, who can pass political and antitrust muster.
"It's a direct conflict of globalization and sovereignty," said Chris Mackay, head of corporate finance at UBS Warburg in Sydney.
Australia's banking industry, for instance, is dominated by four institutions, which together control 75 percent of the market. The government has told them that they may not merge with one another. Yet even putting all four together into one bank would yield an institution smaller than HSBC.
The story is similar with airlines, (two major national carriers), grocery retailing (three big companies), steel (three), iron ore (two) and others. "It is a dilemma," said Robert L. Joss, dean of the Graduate School of Business at Stanford University, who headed Australia's sixth-largest company, the Westpac Banking Corporation, from 1993 to 1999. "How do you avoid creating a cozy situation?"
Allan Fels, chairman of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, tries to prevent cozy situations, and he takes an activist approach to the job -- as when the commission ruled last month that neither Qantas Airways nor Ansett Australia, which is a unit of Air New Zealand, the two national airlines, could buy Hazelton Airlines, a regional carrier they both wanted.
Geoff Dixon, who takes over as the chief executive of Qantas next month, criticized the decision and dropped the bid. "The A.C.C.C.'s apparent view that a multiplicity of competitors be available in all sectors of the Australian market, regardless of financial viability, is disturbing," Mr. Dixon said. "Particularly in view of the rationalization and consolidation taking place in the global aviation industry."
Hazelton's management wanted the company to be taken over because, without a deal, "competitive pressures, government policies and capital requirements will further restrict the growth of Hazelton and limit its ability to be a strong and viable competitor," said the airline's chairman, Stan Quinlivan. 
Ansett Australia has continued accumulating commitments from Hazelton shareholders despite the commission's ruling, but there is no assurance that a revised takeover plan will be approved. 
If it is not? "There is a real chance that Hazelton will die," said Peter Harbison, managing director of the Center for Asia Pacific Aviation, a research firm and consultancy in Australia. And given global consolidation, Mr. Dixon of Qantas said, Australia's carriers risk being "relegated to cottage-industry status." 
Regulators do not accept that assessment. "Every applicant for a merger cites globalization arguments," Mr. Fels said. "As a matter of fact, I've never not heard it."
The commission is far from reflexively antimerger. It has blocked only 25 deals of 500 examined the last three years, and its guidelines favor consolidation in some cases, such as when imports hold a substantial share of the Australian market for a product. 
Yet the commission stops some deals before they are even put together. As Cable and Wireless tries to sell C & W Optus, its Australian telecommunications unit, it received strong interest from Vodafone Pacific, a unit of the Vodafone Group of Britain. But because Vodafone is already No. 3 in the Australian cellular market with 19 percent, Mr. Fels weighed in quickly with a declaration that combining it with Optus, which is No. 2 with 33 percent, would "raise serious problems."
Vodafone responded with a proposal earlier this month to buy Optus and immediately resell a chunk of its mobile phone business and other assets to Hutchison Telecommunications (Australia) Ltd., reducing Vodafone's ultimate share to about 40 percent and preserving a substantial third presence in the market. Regulators are reviewing the proposal.
Mr. Fels also moved to pre-empt any possibility that the country's biggest supermarket retailers, Coles Myer Ltd. and Woolworths, which is unrelated to the former United States company of the same name, might bid for stakes in the third-biggest, Franklins, which is struggling financially and is widely expected to be sold by its parent, Dairy Farm International Holdings of Hong Kong.
Because Coles Myer and Woolworths together have 70 percent of the market, Mr. Fels has said in interviews that the commission would have "great difficulty" letting either one get a share of Franklins. 
Mr. Fels wields the commission's power with considerable autonomy because he enjoys political support from both major parties in Australia -- first appointed in 1995 by a Labor government and given another term in office last year by the current conservative coalition government. Fear of a backlash among voters has helped align politicians with the commission on issues like bank mergers, which are unpopular. 
Left with little choice, the four big banks have so far found ways to grow and cut costs without merging with each other. They have created joint ventures to share some back-office functions, and have expanded overseas, where the National Australia Bank Ltd., for instance, now gets nearly half its revenue. 
The commission, too, has done some adapting to new realities, Mr. Fels said, and it is not wholly unresponsive to arguments that in some industries, Australia may no longer be big enough for as many viable competitors as in the past. "The real job of the regulator," Mr. Fels said, "is to try to distinguish between the valid and the invalid claims."

HEADLINE: Air Traffic Paralysis 

 BODY:
The nation's air traffic congestion can no longer be thought of as merely an annoyance, or a nettlesome transportation issue. It is a growing economic ill as well, and the Bush administration ought to address it as such. Instead of seeking to cut the Federal Aviation Administration's 2002 budget by some $568 million, as proposed by the Office of Management and Budget, President Bush should develop a comprehensive long-term strategy to meet the growing demand for air travel. Thinking of ways to speed up the development of new satellite navigation systems and the building of new runways at major airports would be a good start. 
 What any frequent flier could guess from experience is now official. Last year was the worst on record for flight delays. More than a quarter of all flights nationwide were delayed. The airport with the most delays was New York's La Guardia. 
 An analysis performed by the Department of Transportation for The Times shows that half of the 100 most frequently canceled or severely delayed flights last year were scheduled to land at or take off from La Guardia. That includes 7 of the top 10. Newark claimed two of the remaining three, meaning 9 of the 10 most delayed flights nationwide inconvenienced New York area travelers.
La Guardia is a microcosm of the crisis confronting the nation's aviation system. The system's existing infrastructure is incapable of meeting the burgeoning demand for air travel. That is certainly the case at La Guardia, with its limited runways and terminal areas. 
Yet last year Congress lifted a longstanding curb on further growth at La Guardia to encourage service to new markets, and some 400 daily flights were added. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey rightly prodded the Federal Aviation Administration to intervene, and cut that number to a more manageable level. As a result, La Guardia is expected to be slightly more tolerable this year. The Port Authority and the F.A.A. can further ameliorate matters by urging airlines to be more realistic in scheduling flights and by creating market incentives to shift some flights to off-peak hours.
There is no short-term relief in sight for the overall system, as Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta, the lone Democrat in the Bush cabinet, warned in his confirmation hearings last month. Barring a prolonged recession, the demand for air travel should continue to explode. Last year 655 million passengers boarded a flight, some 200 million more than in 1991, and the number is expected to surpass a billion in this decade. 
Mr. Mineta is a proponent of speeding up the building of new runways and of enhancing the air traffic control system. But he will accomplish little if President Bush decides not to make this a budgetary priority.

HEADLINE: National Park Status Sought For Paterson Waterfall Site 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT HANLEY 

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 19 

 BODY:
New Jersey's two United States senators and one of its House members opened a campaign today to create a national park around the Great Falls, Paterson's landmark and the essence of its birth as a major manufacturing center after the Revolutionary War.
 "You're standing on hallowed ground; it's precious land," Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., a former mayor of Paterson, told about 50 preservationists and local government officials as the falls in the background tumbled 77 feet into a gorge. The group was clustered on a promenade beneath a statue of Alexander Hamilton, who founded Paterson in 1792 on the dream of harnessing the falls' power for industry. 
 Senator Robert G. Torricelli said that Hamilton's vision led to the Industrial Revolution, likening its historical importance to Thomas Jefferson's vision of Washington as a cradle of democracy. Designating the falls as a national park would create a "window into America's industrial past," Mr. Torricelli said.
New Jersey's other senator, Jon S. Corzine, was not there but released a statement saying he hoped the campaign for a park would produce the best way to "create living history" of the community's technological and social innovation in the 1800's.
The three lawmakers have introduced legislation that would require the federal Interior Department to explore the suitability of the Great Falls for a national park. Designation as a park, they said, could lead to millions of dollar in federal money to speed restoration of old factories that decades ago hummed with the production of silk fabrics, locomotives and Colt revolvers.
They said they also envisioned restaurants, museums and other attractions for schoolchildren and tourists near the site. Designation as a park would also provide badly needed full-time staffing for the site by the National Park Service, they said.
The Interior Department declared the Great Falls and about 118 acres around it a national historic landmark in 1976. Nine years earlier, the department dedicated the falls as a natural landmark. During the 1990's, the federal government provided about $7 million for renovation of old factories and construction of pathways and bridges for visitors. 
Senators Torricelli and Corzine and Representative Pascrell, who was mayor of Paterson from 1990 to 1996, said they hoped their legislation would bring millions of dollars more and quicken the pace of revival.
Mr. Pascrell suggested that Paterson's current leaders were less than enthusiastic about working with the Interior Department and about providing local money to help with the renovations the federal government financed in the 1990's.
"My goal is to create a partnership between Paterson and the National Park Service," Mr. Pascrell said. "I'm confident the City of Paterson is up to the task."
Paterson's mayor, Martin Barnes, who attended today's ceremony, said he endorsed the idea that a national park would be good for Paterson's economy.
"We will give everything we can possibly give," Mr. Barnes said, "because it's the right thing to do."

HEADLINE: Tax-Cut News for Mr. Bush 

 BODY:
For a while, President Bush's proposal for a $1.6 trillion tax cut seemed to be immune to the rules of legislative reality. Republicans who wanted to make it bigger seemed to outnumber Democrats wanting to cut it back. Last week, however, Mr. Bush got some sobering news from a leader of his own party, Senator Pete Domenici, chairman of the Budget Committee. He reported to the White House that critics of the tax cut had begun making headway even among Republicans with the argument that it is too big, unfair and unlikely to help the economy. We have been urging Democrats to stick together and fight the tax cuts. Today we urge moderate Republicans to listen to the tough appraisal of their own party colleagues. 
 It is Mr. Domenici's job to count votes in the Senate and to count numbers in the budget. The word he carried to the White House was that Senators Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island and Jim Jeffords of Vermont had defected from the Republican camp and decided not to support the tax cut as it is now constituted. On top of these Republicans, Senators Olympia Snowe of Maine, George Voinovich of Ohio and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania have expressed varying degrees of dismay about the tax cut's cost and its reliance on surpluses that may not materialize. Waiting in the wings is Senator John McCain, who appears ready to revive his presidential campaign opposition to the Bush proposal. In a Senate evenly divided between the two parties, these Republican misgivings are balanced so far by the premature defection of only one Democrat, Zell Miller of Georgia. 
 Mr. Bush was said to have replied to Mr. Domenici that he hoped to persuade doubting senators that the tax cut was affordable when he unveiled his own budget projections at the end of this month. But the betting among many experts is that his budget will, if anything, do the opposite. The administration has signaled that it will not project any increase in the size of the surplus, but that it will show increases in aid for education and defense. In other spending areas, the budget director, Mitchell Daniels, has publicly advocated a return to some kind of budget caps to rein in spending. The administration wants to put a stop to the increases in discretionary federal spending that it estimates have averaged 6 percent over the last few years. 
What that means is that the administration will almost certainly come in with budget cuts in some areas that it considers peripheral to its agenda. On Capitol Hill, the heads of appropriations committees can already be heard complaining that Congress might have to impose budget ceilings in the spring to help pay for the tax cut. Such spending cuts -- for example, in key areas like housing, transportation and the environment -- would make it clearer than ever that the Bush tax-cut proposals are too costly because they use up the federal surpluses for a giveaway to the wealthy.
The Democrats finally presented a counterproposal last week on using the 10-year surplus of more than $2 trillion generated outside Medicare and Social Security. They would tap a third of it for tax cuts, a third for extra spending and a third to pay down the debt. The Democrats' proposal for a tax cut is more than double what Vice President Al Gore was willing to embrace in the recent hard-fought election campaign. It is testimony to the hard political reality that with White House pressure, a sizable surplus and a possibly sagging economy, some tax cuts are inevitable. But the Democrats' proposal sounds to us like a reasonable starting point.
We have argued that the tax cut is too weighted to the wealthy, and that Congress must as a first priority rewrite its provisions to make sure that its benefits go at least as much to the working class and middle class as the wealthy. Right now the proposal heaps its bounty on the very people who have benefited the most from the economic gains of recent years, and it has badly shortchanged nearly half the taxpaying population at the lower end of the scale. But if the tax cut is not scaled back in size altogether, it runs the risk of leaving no extra money for other purposes, even those like defense and education where the administration says it wants to increase spending. The numbers demonstrating the inequity of the tax cut are likely to become even more clear in the weeks to come, and Republicans who ignore them risk a bare-bones budget and booming deficits.
