HEADLINE: Chinese Fiber-Optic Work Linked to Raided Iraqi Sites 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
Chinese workers were helping the Iraqi military build a fiber-optic network linked to radar stations and other targets attacked by American and British warplanes last week, defense and intelligence officials said today, raising a new challenge for the Bush administration just as it is communicating for the first time with the Chinese leadership.
 The Chinese assistance, which was first reported over the weekend by The Washington Post, apparently violated United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in 1990, officials said today. It was part of what American officials have described as furtive efforts by the Iraqis to evade sanctions and rebuild their military. 
 Administration officials said that the bombing in Baghdad on Friday night was timed to avoid injuries to the workers. That is an especially sensitive subject in the Pentagon after the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May 1999. Three Chinese were killed, and despite the insistence of the United States that the incident was an accident, diplomatic relations were set back by months. 
China's seeming involvement in military programs in Iraq raises diplomatic difficulties for the Bush administration, which was hesitant today to discuss China's role in the fiber-optic project.
President Bush had his first exchange of letters with President Jiang Zemin last week, a general exchange that apparently contained no reference to the project in Iraq. Mr. Bush has been seeking to establish a personal relationship with Mr. Jiang gradually before tackling the usual array of differences, on issues like human rights and arms exports.
Now that slow start may not be possible. The State Department said today that it was sending an official inquiry to the Chinese government about the presence of workers at the site.
"We are obviously concerned about reports that the Chinese have provided assistance to the Iraqis," a State Department spokesman, Philip T. Reeker, said. "We have asked the Chinese government to look into it and are awaiting their response."
The Chinese Foreign Ministry said today that it had no knowledge of the project.
An administration official said that reports of cooperation with Iraq in telecommunications were raised with China in the last days of the Clinton administration. At that time, too, China denied any involvement.
Other government officials noted today that in one recent case, in which a Chinese company was providing test equipment to the Iraqi military, it was impossible to determine whether these sales were taking place with the knowledge of Chinese officials.
China has worked in Iraq before, helping build a number of major projects, like bridges, before the 1991 gulf war.
It is not clear whether the fiber-optic network is commercial in nature, if it was specifically designed for the military, or if it is being used for both purposes, what the military calls a "dual use" technology.
"We do have some indication the Chinese were building a fiber-optic network," a defense official said today, declining to discuss details of the work. "They could claim it has some dual use, but it's pretty clear it was connected" to the radar sites struck last Friday.
A United Nations official said today that Chinese companies had been allowed to provide services in a variety of contracts approved as part of the "oil for food" program.
That program, begun as a way to allow imports of food, medicines and other items to meet civilian needs, has expanded in recent years to include construction projects and the rebuilding of Iraq's electrical grid.
However, any work that aided Iraq's military would be a clear violation of the sanctions rules.
The committee that reviews the contracts permitted under the "oil for food" program has put on hold three telecommunications projects, but those involve two French companies and a Russian one.
Today, four days after the strikes, Pentagon officials declined to discuss the success of the attacks except in the broadest terms. But one official said the strikes had only mixed results, representing something of a disappointment.
The attack resulted in "only moderate disruption" of Iraq's air defenses, the official said.
Over the weekend, Iraqi forces again fired antiaircraft artillery and surface-to-air missiles at patrols in the southern "no flight" zone, but the American and British aircraft did not respond.
The Pentagon's spokesman, Rear Adm. Craig R. Quigley, said that the strikes were intended to weaken Iraq's ability to threaten the patrols, but that Iraq was expected to rebuild its defenses, as it has in the past.
"The targets were the radars, and the command, control and communication nodes that controlled and integrated the air defense system," he said. "We think we had an impact on that. Is it permanent? No. But we think we had an impact on that."

HEADLINE: Rash of Gaffes And Scandals Shakes Party's Grip on Japan 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
When Yoshiro Mori was chosen by a secretive conclave of governing party leaders 10 months ago to become prime minister after Keizo Obuchi's death, Mr. Mori was thought to be a safe interim choice to lead the government.
 What has followed has been a roller coaster ride full of gaffes and spills for the Liberal Democratic Party. Members say that all this might have provided grist for a good political comedy if it were not for the fact that the party's grip on power is now in serious doubt. 
 The latest -- and many feel most egregious -- of Mr. Mori's political blunders was to continue playing golf for nearly two hours after he received word that an American submarine had hit a Japanese fishing-school vessel off Hawaii and that nine people were missing. 
Since then, approval ratings for Mr. Mori have fallen to the lowest ever for a prime minister -- 5.4 percent in one television poll, and 9 percent in one by the newspaper Asahi Shimbun. On Monday, the party elder most responsible for Mr. Mori's selection, Hiromu Nonaka, said that the prime minister should "prioritize the people's peace of mind," which in the muffled language of Japanese politics was widely interpreted as a call to resign.
Japanese prime ministers have typically enjoyed little executive-style muscle, but one power that they do have -- and Mr. Mori is exercising it with unaccustomed zest -- is to cling to office against all manner of calls for a resignation.
"What I must accomplish at any cost is to revive the economy," Mr. Mori told Parliament on Monday. He also cited work to be done in "educational reform and the advancement of information and technology."
In fact, almost no one expects that he will be around long enough to do much, if any, of this. Political analysts say a state of grace may be granted to pass a new budget, which must be done by early next month, but beyond that, few expect Mr. Mori to be able to survive.
Mr. Mori's own party has no mechanism for the removal of a prime minister for reasons of lack of popularity. But if the coalition parties desert him, the government will fall and new elections will have to be organized.
A senior member of the New Komeito Party, the Liberal Democrats' largest coalition partner, told the Yomiuri Shimbun that the momentum exists to force Mr. Mori's resignation. "We now have to decide how to make it honorable," the official said.
Mr. Mori's 10 months in office have followed an unusually hapless rhythm of roughly one major political blunder per month. The streak began in June during memorial services for Mr. Obuchi, who was felled suddenly by a stroke. Of all the national and international figures present, the new prime minister alone seemed not to know how to perform a customary deep bow.
Soon afterward, Mr. Mori called Japan a "divine country," a statement that had troubling echoes for many of militarism and imperial rule. Then, he was embarrassingly put on the defensive by news reports that he had been arrested at a brothel while in college. There have also been persistent reports that the prime minister has mob ties, and a magazine has printed photos of him drinking with a known member of the criminal syndicates.
Later, it was reported that Mr. Mori surprised the British prime minister, Tony Blair, with the unusual suggestion that North Korea could be persuaded to release several Japanese people it was believed to have kidnapped if only there were an agreement to pretend to find the missing people in a third country.
Three of Mr. Mori's hand-picked ministers, meanwhile, have been forced to resign because of scandals.
In one of those scandals, a government-sponsored program to recruit temporary workers from other Asian countries began bribing senior officials in order to gain support for its expansion. One of the accused officials, Fukushiro Nukaga, Mr. Mori's minister for economics and fiscal policy, resigned last month.
The other scandal was a Foreign Ministry travel office corruption case in which it was recently revealed that a midlevel official in charge of making overseas travel arrangements for officials, including the prime minister, had falsely billed the government for nearly $5 million.
This may have been the more costly scandal for the governing party, because it appears to have knocked the foreign minister, Yohei Kono, out of contention for the prime minister's job.
That leaves the Liberal Democrats, who have ruled almost without interruption since 1955, with few appealing choices to replace Mr. Mori.
"The most clear-cut characteristic of the current political situation is that the Liberal Democratic Party, which has enjoyed a very strong hold on power over the last several decades, is declining," said Minoru Morita, a political analyst. "With Mori, their electoral base is collapsing."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Nasdaq Leads Stocks Lower In a Technology Sell-Off
Technology stocks plunged, leading the market lower, as investors tried to adjust to the economic slowdown. Market strategists said the interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve were not yet stimulating a strong recovery.
 The Nasdaq composite index fell 107.03 points, or 4.4 percent, to 2,318.35. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 22.59 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,278.94, while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 68.94 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,730.88. Page C10. 

Diageo Hires Chief for Burger King
Moving a step closer to its goal of leaving the burger business, Diageo hired John H. Dasburg, the chief executive of Northwest Airlines, to take over Burger King, rejuvenate it and eventually take it public. C2.

Intel Takes Steps to Cut Costs
Intel announced a wide range of cost-saving measures, including delayed raises for employees but not layoffs, intended to counter the effects of a slowing economy. Intel, the world's largest chip maker, said it hoped to save "hundreds of millions of dollars" without having to scale back spending on research and development, an area the company is counting on to stay ahead of its competitors. Shares of Intel fell $2.94, to $31.44. C6.

Rich to Merge Commodities Empire
The international commodities trading empire run by Marc Rich, who was pardoned by former President Bill Clinton, will be merged with Crown Resources, an energy trading concern owned by Alfa Group of Russia. C2.

Napster to Start Charging Users
Napster plans to start charging users this summer to exchange music files online, and the company said it had proposed giving $1 billion over five years to record companies, including the five labels that accused Napster of abetting copyright infringement. C6.

EBay Seen in Deal for French Rival
EBay is close to acquiring the French online auctioneer iBazar Group for just less than $100 million, people close to the talks said. C7.

Talks Intensify for Absolut Rights
Vin and Sprit of Sweden has begun final negotiations with Fortune Brands and Maxxium, a consortium of liquor companies, for the distribution rights to Absolut vodka. C4.

Persuasion and Persistence
In college, Andrew J. McKelvey, founder and chief executive of TMP Worldwide, a recruitment advertising agency, unhappy with the quality of movies at the local theater, convinced the owner to let him rent the theater, renovate it and play popular movies. "I made about $1,000 a month," he said. "I bought a car and paid some of my tuition." When he was working for a small ad agency in New York, he gained permission from his boss to start a Yellow pages advertising company, giving his boss 49 percent ownership. Ultimately, he bought his boss out. The Boss. C8.

Trading Firm to Pay for Some Orders
Tradescape, one of the largest day-trading firms, said that it would pay its customers to place certain stock orders with MarketXT, the company's electronic trading network. C15.

Wal-Mart Net Up; Home Depot Falls
Wal-Mart Stores said that its fourth-quarter profit rose 4.5 percent, while Home Depot said its earnings fell 20 percent as the slowing economy prompted consumers to spend less. C4.

PERSON: Stanley Kramer 

HEADLINE: Stanley Kramer, Filmmaker With Social Bent, Dies at 87 

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
Stanley Kramer, the producer and director of socially groundbreaking films like "The Defiant Ones" and "Judgment at Nuremberg" and one of Hollywood's most respected filmmakers in the late 1950's and early 60's, died on Monday in Woodland Hills, a section of Los Angeles. He was 87.
 Mr. Kramer never liked being described as a "message filmmaker," but that was the tag that stuck to him throughout his long career. He retained this reputation even in the 60's and 70's, when many of his films faltered at the box office and changing tastes persuaded a new generation of critics, weaned on the French new wave and the auteur theory, to view his work as sentimental and simplistic. 
 Mr. Kramer, who had been living at the Motion Picture Home, a retirement community for those who had worked in the movie industry, died of complications from pneumonia, said his wife of 35 years, Karen Sharpe Kramer. 
He began as a passionate Wunderkind, an independent producer eager to shake up the status quo with a string of socially conscious films in the early 1950's that raised many of the issues, like racial inequality and juvenile delinquency, that mainstream film companies were often too timid to explore.
For instance, his acclaimed "High Noon" (1952), though a western, was actually a thinly veiled attack on the anti-Communist purges of the McCarthy era. He was also known for being economical, shooting polished-looking films on a budget only a fraction the size of that of most major films.
In 1949 "Home of the Brave" explored racial intolerance in the context of a war film. "Champion," released the same year, was about destructive and unbridled ambition, personified in the film by Kirk Douglas as a doomed prizefighter. In 1950 "The Men," a tragic drama about wounded war veterans, introduced Marlon Brando to the screen. "The Wild One," also with Mr. Brando, in 1954, was the first biker film and among the first to deal with juvenile delinquency, themes that spawned dozens of imitations.
"I firmly believe that the independent producer today can select material which will return vitality to the motion picture industry," Mr. Kramer wrote in 1949. "I think people are completely fed up with the pattern. The independent has simply got to destroy that pattern. If our industry is to flourish, we must break away from formula thinking."
In 1951 Mr. Kramer moved inside the studio gates with a production deal at Columbia Pictures, fleeing two years later in revulsion to return to independent filmmaking and to direct his own films. 
He reached his zenith as a Columbia producer with the classic "High Noon," which starred Gary Cooper as an embattled hero. The New York Times film critic Bosley Crowther called it "Stanley Kramer's brilliant and electric production," giving the producer top billing over the film's director, Fred Zinneman.

Taking the Director's Chair
Initially, Mr. Kramer faltered as a director. His first effort, "Not as a Stranger," was viewed as a fairly ordinary romantic drama about the tribulations of a young doctor, played by Robert Mitchum. And the second, "The Pride and the Passion," was a big-screen epic that was more famous for its on-set squabbles than its plot, which was described as "Pride without Passion" in the Times headline that accompanied the review.
Soon, though, Mr. Kramer returned to tough themes and social issues and regained his footing, insisting on making movies that daringly raised the sensitive subjects that a prosperous postwar America frequently preferred to ignore.
He was often asked why he gravitated to socially conscious stories, and usually he pointed to his coming of age during the early years of the Franklin D. Roosevelt administration. But just as often, he ducked the question.
"Well, I suppose the best answer is that emotionally I am drawn to these subjects," he told The Times Magazine in 1961. "To determine why, I'd have to examine my whole youth." He broke off, then added: "But we won't go into that now. Nor have I ever bothered to give it any deep or prolonged thought."
But it is there, the dominant thread that runs through his entire career.
In 1958 "The Defiant Ones" raised questions of racism and intolerance in the story of a pair of escaped convicts, one black (Sidney Poitier) and one white (Tony Curtis), who were chained together on the run. 
In "On the Beach" in 1959, he was among the first mainstream directors to explore openly and bleakly the notion of nuclear holocaust. And "Inherit the Wind," released the next year, remains Hollywood's most influential exploration of America's enduring social fault line over the issue of teaching evolution. 
In 1961 "Judgment at Nuremberg" was about the tendency of many in the postwar era to forget Nazi atrocities in the drive to battle Communism and get on with business. 
In his Times Magazine profile of Mr. Kramer, Crowther wrote: "Newsmen and film critics from all over the world will assemble with German brass and bigwigs in West Berlin to witness the world premiere of 'Judgment at Nuremberg.' They will be in attendance at something more than the gala opening of a film: They will be spectators at another performance of Mr. Kramer's celebrated act of placing his head in the mouth of a lion."
Although Mr. Kramer chafed at being labeled, he never denied that he was always trying to make what he called a "strong film," a goal that often put him at odds with studio chiefs and backers who wanted him to soften his message.
"I take a very reluctant and conservative view on what a single film can do in affecting our lives," he told an interviewer in 1960. "I don't make films to stir the world. I am not conscious of a responsibility to society or even to my own social consciousness when I make a film. My motivation can be as simple as saying, gee, this would make an exciting picture."
By the early 60's, though, Mr. Kramer said that he felt the need to prove that he could make a movie that was neither socially conscious nor serious. In fact, if anything, "It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World" was socially disruptive and goofy, the story of a group of over-the-top comic characters driven to slapstick insanity in a race for hidden loot. It was his biggest box office hit, with a cast that included Sid Caesar, Milton Berle, Jonathan Winters and Ethel Merman.
The film world was changing, though. The rise of foreign language films, popularized by directors like Vittorio de Sica, Federico Fellini and Ingmar Bergman, blended into the ascent of the French new wave in the early 60's, spearheaded by new voices like those of Francois Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard.
At the same time, the French-inspired auteur theory, which held that the director was the prime creative voice on a film and that those directors with distinctive voices throughout their body of work were the greatest artists, turned critics and audiences away from journeymen like Mr. Kramer.
Most of his final films failed with critics and at the box office. In 1965 "Ship of Fools" drew some Oscar nominations but was blasted by many critics as pretentious. "The Secret of Santa Vittoria" (1969), "R.P.M." (1970), "Bless the Beasts and Children" (1971) and other later efforts were almost all labeled sentimental and middlebrow. At this time, when Mr. Kramer tried to raise social issues, he was often criticized as preachy. 
His 1977 assassination thriller, "The Domino Principle," drew scathing reviews. The Times critic Vincent Canby described it as "without doubt the definitive work to date in that growing body of screen literature devoted to instructing us in how to make a suspense film totally devoid of tension, intelligence, excitement, imagination, wit, reality and surprise."
"Like the prose in many how-to manuals," he continued, "it is complicated without being informative, and it's also rigorously humdrum."

60's Turmoil Shakes a Career
Mr. Kramer also seemed unsure how to respond to the social turbulence of the 60's, when many of the issues that he had been a pioneer in exploring suddenly exploded on the social stage. The campus drama "R.P.M.," which tried to capture the mood of discontent on college campuses in the 60's, fell flat. The film, Canby wrote in his Times review, "is about one of the gut questions of our time."
"Should Ann-Margret," he explained, "a graduate student in sociology, continue to sleep with Anthony Quinn, her bleeding-heart liberal of a professor, after he becomes acting college president and sends the pigs in to clear out the administration building?"
In a 1991 interview Mr. Kramer acknowledged that some of his films, particularly those involving racism, were "oversimplified." This approach was necessary, he said, to make the stories more palatable to mainstream white audiences.
But for the most part, he stuck to his guns. In a three-hour two-part examination of his career broadcast on ABC in 1975, he defended his work vigorously.
Mr. Kramer was also frequently critical of some of the directors who emerged in the 60's, describing some of them as con artists who were trying to put one over on a credulous audience.
"The put-on leads to the adoration of technique," Mr. Kramer wrote in 1968. "The nouvelle vague, the neo-realists and the angry young men have opened the gates to interrupted dialogue, mismatching, jump cuts, super-imposures, split screens and the camera as primary weapon in the director's bag. Technique covers a multitude of sins."
The only respite from such criticism in his final years as a director came in 1967, with "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner," a film in which he recaptured some of the glory of his heyday. Though many critics found the film, about an interracial romance, overly simple and pitched to mainstream sensibilities -- it starred Spencer Tracy, Katharine Hepburn and Sidney Poitier -- it was a smashing success, nominated for 10 Oscars and the winner of two (for Ms. Hepburn's lead performance and William Rose's original screenplay).
Mr. Kramer complained in the 60's that the rise of foreign voices and the growing youth culture had changed the artistic landscape from what it had been in his own youth. No longer, he said, were writers or filmmakers interested in creating the Great American Novel or the great American film, or indeed with exploring what it meant to be American.
"The reason has to do with the purposeful widening of the generation gap, the desire of the young to move as far as possible from the common denominators they and we have known," he wrote. "The student of cinema wants to be Godard, not William Wyler or George Stevens or John Ford."
Mr. Kramer was nominated for nine Academy Awards -- six as a producer and three as a director -- though he never won one. He was given the Irving G. Thalberg Award for distinguished contribution to filmmaking at the Oscar ceremonies in 1962. And the New York Film Critics Circle chose him as best director of 1958 for "The Defiant Ones."

A Hero to His Actors
Mr. Kramer, however, was always popular with actors, working with some of the top stars of the era, including Humphrey Bogart, Cary Grant, Frank Sinatra, Gregory Peck, Fred Astaire, Spencer Tracy, Fredric March, Gene Kelly, Sophia Loren, Van Johnson, Fred MacMurray, Richard Widmark, Burt Lancaster, Lee Marvin, Vivien Leigh, Mr. Brando and Mr. Douglas.
Part of the reason was Mr. Kramer's well-known success in helping his actors to win Oscars -- including ones for Gary Cooper in "High Noon," Jose Ferrer in "Cyrano de Bergerac," Maximilian Schell in "Judgment at Nuremberg" and Ms. Hepburn in "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner."
His last film, "The Runner Stumbles," about a romance between an older priest (Dick Van Dyke) and a younger nun (Kathleen Quinlan) earned him some of the most scathing reviews of his career in 1979. "Heaven help anyone who tries to take this story at face value," wrote Janet Maslin in The Times.
Not long after, Mr. Kramer announced that he had had enough and was abandoning Hollywood for Seattle. "We chose Seattle because my wife read somewhere in a consumer magazine that it was the ideal American city," he said.
Stanley Earl Kramer was born in Hell's Kitchen in Manhattan, the only child of a divorced mother who worked as a secretary for Paramount. His grandmother, a Polish-Jewish immigrant, had the largest hand in raising him. 
Besides a mother at Paramount, the young Mr. Kramer also had an uncle in the movie business, who worked in distribution for Universal Pictures. But as a boy, he said, he never really dreamed of Hollywood, aiming instead for a career in law.
A precocious teenager, he graduated from DeWitt Clinton High School at 15 and attended New York University as an undergraduate, where he earned a degree in business administration. The turning point in his life came in 1933, at the height of the Depression, when his articles for a university magazine won him a job as a junior writer at 20th Century Fox, earning $70 a week.
For the next 14 years, Mr. Kramer bounced around the movie business in Hollywood. He was a set dresser and film cutter at MGM, a writer and researcher for Columbia, a writer for Republic and an associate producer with Loew-Lewin.
Just as he was about to form his own independent production company, Pearl Harbor took the United States into World War II and he was drafted, eventually making training films for the Army Signal Corps in Astoria, Queens. 
"Hollywood is like a boardwalk," Mr. Kramer told an interviewer. "You're always looking for a loose board to stick your head up through, and there are about 60 guys waiting to hit you."

Seeking Big Films, Small Egos
Not until after the war, in 1947, were Mr. Kramer and two partners, the writer Carl Foreman and a film sales veteran, George Glass, able to have his first movie produced, a low-budget adaptation of a Ring Lardner story called "So This Is New York."
Mr. Kramer never looked back. He kept a sign above his desk that read: "Please God, make the pictures big and the heads small."
Finding investors in places like a Midwestern department store and a lettuce-growers syndicate, Mr. Kramer financed one film after another in the early 50's. "I'm a bit of a shill artist," he told an interviewer.
By the mid-50's, his reputation for frugality and his successes had won him a deal at Columbia Pictures. He chafed under the studio strictures, he later said, producing films that never made as much money as the studio wanted nor roiled the waters as much as he desired. 
"The Caine Mutiny" in 1954 is a case in point: It is justly celebrated for its performances, particularly that of Humphrey Bogart as the paranoid Captain Queeg, but managed to erase from Herman Wouk's best-selling novel the central emotional thread of Jewish persecution by the Nazis.
It was in 1980 that Mr. Kramer retired from filmmaking and moved to Seattle, where he wrote and taught at the University of Washington and Bellevue Community College. In 1987, however, the new head of Columbia Pictures, the British producer David Puttnam, invited Mr. Kramer to develop new film projects for the studio. 
"I decided that somewhere between the films on outer space and Sylvester Stallone, there is a place for me," Mr. Kramer said at the time. "I was always associated with films that had an opinion. I don't believe films change anyone's mind, but I was spawned during the Roosevelt era, a time of great change, and I still believe in trying to get people to think. I'm very excited about being a participating mule again -- that's mule, with a kick."
Mr. Puttnam's tenure at Columbia was short-lived, however, and Mr. Kramer's deal with the studio resulted in no new films.
In addition to his wife, Mr. Kramer is survived by a son, Larry, and three daughters, Katharine, Jennifer and Casey, whom he named after one of his heroes, Casey Stengel.
"A motion picture has a strange chemistry that you can't explain," Mr. Kramer once said. "How do you explain how every once in a while an absolute conclave of idiots will come together and make a film that's just wonderful, while a group of talented people will turn out something that's nothing? Maybe it just depends on the roll of the dice."

 CORRECTION:
An obituary of the film producer and director Stanley Kramer on Wednesday misidentified the studio that distributed his 1952 western "High Noon." It was United Artists, not Columbia Pictures.
The obituary also misspelled the surname of the film's director. He was Fred Zinnemann, not Zinneman.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Teenage Drug Use Higher in U.S. Than in Europe 

BYLINE:  By KATE ZERNIKE 

 BODY:
American teenagers are far more likely than their European peers to use marijuana and other illicit drugs, but European teenagers are more likely to smoke cigarettes and drink alcohol, according to a study of 31 nations.
 The study, released yesterday at a meeting of the World Health Organization in Stockholm, compared the results of 1999 surveys answered anonymously by 14,000 10th-grade students in the United States and 95,000 10th-grade students in 30 European countries. 
 Among the European students, 37 percent had smoked at least one cigarette in the previous 30 days, compared with 26 percent in the United States. Sixty-one percent of the European 10th graders had consumed alcohol in the previous 30 days, compared with 40 percent of the students in the United States. 
Forty-one percent of 10th graders in the United States had tried marijuana, compared with 17 percent of those in Europe. And 23 percent of the students in the United States had used other illicit drugs, compared with 6 percent of Europeans.
Researchers said that the study, the first to make such broad comparisons, would help them and policy makers determine the effects of culture and other factors on drug use.
"We tend to think within national boundaries," said Thor Bjarnason, a sociologist at the State University of New York at Albany and a co-author of the report, the European School Survey Project on Alcohol and Drugs. "If you're having a war on drugs, one measure is within a comparative perspective. If drug use is increasing at a slower rate in your country, that could be a victory."
The study was developed by the Council of Europe, an intergovernmental organization focused on social and economic issues, with the help of researchers at the University of Michigan's "Monitoring the Future" project, which has surveyed students on a variety of issues for 26 years and is considered the most reliable barometer of student drug-use trends. The European survey was designed in such a way so the two could be accurately compared. 
Dr. Bjarnason called the differences in illicit drug use "very striking."
"That's one in four students in this country," he said. "Even in the European countries with the highest rates, it's only one in 10."
Yet while a smaller percentage of European students used illicit drugs, that percentage rose from 1995 to 1999, particularly in former Eastern-bloc countries.
By contrast, much drug use in the United States has declined or held steady -- with the exception of Ecstasy use, which has risen sharply.
Researchers offered little analysis to explain the differences. That, they said, would come in the second phase of the study.
But, they noted, the widespread use of marijuana and other illicit drugs began in the United States and spread to Europe so it might be that Europeans simply follow the American trend. 
Others cited the more relaxed rules governing alcohol and cigarette use in many European nations, as well as other cultural differences.
Researchers said they were particularly interested in the survey results of marijuana use in the Netherlands, known for its relatively permissive drug laws.
While marijuana use was relatively widespread there -- 28 percent of 10th graders had tried it, compared with the European average of 17 percent -- four other European countries, Ireland, France, the Czech Republic, and Britain, had higher rates, as did the United States.

HEADLINE: Lines That Divide, Ties That Bind 

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
One hundred preachers are on 100 Harlem corners, and Michelle Ramirez is on hers: Fifth Avenue and West 129th Street. She positions her microphone, aims her voice at the tenement opposite, and opens fire. 
 "Drugs, drink can't take away the pain you have inside," she bellows. 
 The four young hustlers swigging Hennessey and sharing a fat blunt on the building's front steps scowl. They curse. And they continue allowing soiled men and women clutching small bills to pass inside to buy crack. 
That drugs are being sold from this building is the worst-kept secret on the block. The tenants know it. The police know it. And Michelle Ramirez, 28, a born-again Christian who lives on 129th Street between Fifth and Lenox Avenues, knows it, too. So when her church dispatches preachers one Saturday throughout Harlem for Operation Spiritual Thunder, she thunders at the young men, "Every time you're selling drugs, you're killing a whole family." 
"Wrong," they sing out, in a perverted call and response. "Wrong."
She presses on. "Why are we acting like all black people can do is smoke weed, drink beer, and listen to rap music all day?"
"She is really getting on my nerves." The voice belongs to a young man who gives his name as Pimp Daddy Corn Chips, and gives his story: One mother, five children, one room, so you can't even breathe. Stomachs hurting, doors slamming, welfare cut to the bone. "She going to put a plate on my table?" he asks, nodding toward Ms. Ramirez. 
One of his friends, Caveman, stalks across the street. "You judging us?" 
"If you all are taking this offensive, that's on you," she answers. 
He returns to the steps and succumbs to nostalgia. "Back in the day, she couldn't do this."
Back in the day, Ms. Ramirez, a black singer and student raised in Greenwich Village, would not have been paying $572 for a studio apartment on this block, let alone challenging its dealers. 
The fact that she is says a lot about how far this block has come since 1994, when The New York Times chronicled life, then bleak and ominous, here. Buildings have been rehabilitated, violent crime reduced. New tenants have come by the dozens. 
But that the young men still see Ms. Ramirez as an interloper, that they feel as angry at her words as she does at their actions, says how far the block has to go. Not just because drugs are still being sold here, although that troubles residents old and new. But because this block's now dizzyingly diverse populace must negotiate a whole new series of relationships -- across class lines, racial and national divides, cultural experiences, and personal trajectories.
Those relationships are playing out across Harlem, where a vast amount of vacant housing means that perhaps 40,000 new residents could be absorbed without displacing anyone. So far, then, Harlem has largely defied the familiar gentrification process, in which newer, or lighter, or wealthier arrivals push out the locals. For now, they must learn to live together.
On 129th Street, longtime residents must learn how to live among whites for the first time. The white owner of an art gallery must learn how to be an asset, not a threat. African-Americans and Africans and Hispanics must find what common ground they share. And blacks who share nothing but skin color must build a community.
For Michelle Ramirez and others, it is partly a battle over what being black means, what Harlem is, and who it is for. For the old-timers, who have spent decades nostalgically remembering what Harlem was, it is a realization that Harlem finally is changing -- but not changing back. Something new is being born.

Renovating Buildings, Not People
First came the letters.
Posted on the door of 35-37 West 129th Street, they warned tenants not to sit on the stoops. Doing so, the new management company warned, attracted "undesirables." 
The tenants sat anyway, as they always had. The stoops were urban versions of Southern porches, places for sharing meals and watching children, taking on new beaus and tearing apart old ones.
Then came the spikes. 
No number of swinging children could dislodge the spikes, attached to guard rails implanted on the stoops. No amount of green paint could camouflage their hostility. No small detail said more about how this Harlem block was changing. 
New buildings have brought new rules, many imposed by Gregory Pascal, the entrepreneur to whom the city has given seven buildings on this block to renovate, manage, and eventually own. As he and some new residents see it, the front of a building is for coming and going. 
There are the culture wars of the elites and the culture wars of the streets. As middle-class habits take root here, newcomers and property owners are reclaiming private spaces -- posting "No Loitering" signs on brownstones all over -- and imposing new rules on public spaces. 
Longtime residents welcome the renovation of old buildings. The enforcement of new behavior is a different story. 
"These tenants have been sitting on that stoop for 20, 30, 40 years," a young woman says one night in an indignant aria. "Because you renovated the building you think you're going to renovate the people, too?" 
The sitters move to the buildings with still-open stoops.

Creating the Hamptons in Harlem
"I been there already -- I been down -- but I don't need to smoke, drink, 'cause he fills me up," Michelle Ramirez had told the young men on the corner. A few years ago, Ms. Ramirez was a punk singer prowling the East Village in black leather and doing her own share of drugging. 
She has since found Jesus, but is still trying to find her place. Musically, she resists categorization, singing what she calls spiritual folk. As the daughter of a mixed-race mother, she fights racism from blacks and whites. And she is trying to reconcile the romance of historical Harlem with the reality outside her window. 
Like many young blacks, Michelle Ramirez was drawn here partly by Harlem's cultural heritage. She moved into a studio with high ceilings and stained-glass windows, filled it with plants and religious art -- and found herself looking out on a ghetto where children played around lines of crack buyers. There's nothing up here, she says, except the drugs. "How are you supposed to have hope if there's nothing around?" 
Last spring, she started praying for the block. Soon after, the crack lines disappeared, although the drugs have not. Harlem, though, is inspiring her after all. She looks out her window, and sees people putting art to poverty. Being born poor and black, she says, means making the best of it. The street can become home if it has to. A dollar is stretched farther than it has any right to go. You barbecue on a raggedy little grill, and you think it's the Hamptons. 
"They make their Hamptons," she says. "That's what I like about Harlem."

A Great White Influx?
The owner of Ms. Ramirez's building is a Swedish-born artist named Lars Westvind who lives one block north on historic Astor Row. He owns three adjoining row houses on 129th Street, and he has stocked them with European and American whites, along with some black tenants. 
His rents -- $450 for one room, $1,500 for an apartment in a 130th Street brownstone -- boggle many Harlem minds. They effectively shut out most longtime residents. 
Mr. Westvind believes in free enterprise's consequences. He says of those wanting to keep Harlem black, "I think that's pretty strange, to tell you the truth."
But in Harlem, not to see color can be provocative in itself. When Mr. Westvind purchased one of the 129th Street buildings, he received threats and a 4 a.m. smoke bomb in his mailbox. It was bad, one of his neighbors, Juanita Washington, says, "but not as bad as what would happen to a black person moving into a white neighborhood."
At one meeting on his block, neighbors expressed concern to his artist wife, Gulsen Calik, first about her lush, untamed front yard ("it's not an eyesore, but it's different," said one woman) and then about her husband's rents. They spoke with a frankness born of friendship. 
Miss Washington, a 40-year resident of 130th Street, said that when developers come in and see a mix of ethnicities and tenures, they "should do as the city does, as the state does, as the federal government does -- have a happy medium, high rents, low rents, so people who have been here can afford to stay in the community." 
Ms. Calik (pronounced CHEL-ick), in turn, wondered why the neighbors didn't see the value Mr. Westvind's rehabilitations brought. The buildings had been largely abandoned. Nor, she said, does the law allow them to displace those paying low rents. 
"Don't just talk about people coming in -- white versus black, rich versus poor -- you put blinders on," she said. "People are trying to make a buck, but who isn't? If you live by other values, good for you. But recognize the value in a renovation."

New Images, Framed by Suspicion
One warm morning, a white man, pale as the moon, sweeps 129th Street's sidewalk. It is a startling image, and one that was not, initially, well received here. But the night before, a group of bored children had shattered glass in front of Mr. Westvind's three row houses with their painterly trim. In the morning, it fell to Didier Catoliquot, Parisian photographer in his previous life, Harlem superintendent in this one, to clean up. 
Mr. Catoliquot (pronounced KAH-toe-lee-koh) is 46. He followed a girl to New York, and fell in love with the city. He rented a room from Mr. Westvind, then began working for him, "changing completely" his life. 
This job is temporary, a means of adaptation. "You cannot enjoy your life if you think you will clean the street for all your life," he says, sounding much like the block's women now working for their welfare.
He likes the block's residents. He knows the children in the street have nowhere else to play. But he does not want to sweep up their glass. The week before, he told them to go away. They burned his garbage. He would not speak to their parents, though. His English is not good enough. And, he says, his skin is the wrong color.
Gulsun Erbil, a Turkish artist, opened Gallery X in 1998 in one of Mr. Westvind's buildings, where she also lives. She has a dream of a Harlem Biennale in 2002, but finds that the color of her skin sometimes mutes the enthusiasm toward her project. 
"They should look at it not like I'm a white woman," she says. "They shouldn't put me down." 
She does not see herself as an activist, but she welcomes anyone to her openings. The children come, for the art or for the free food. 
"Do you think exposure changes people?" asks Pat Simon, who runs a community office on the block for the Abyssinian Development Corporation, the nonprofit organization that has helped redevelop the area, as she observes one opening. 
To Ms. Erbil and others, the answer is yes. "If white people do things here it has benefit," says Franz Vila, an artist exhibiting last summer. "It contributes to the lives of these black kids. White people don't need this gallery. They have galleries in SoHo." 
Few adults on the block come to the gallery, however. The mothers, Ms. Erbil concludes, do not want art. 
For some on the block, it is not about not wanting art, but about needing so many other things. "How does it help the community?" says Rachel Tew, a longtime resident, of the gallery. "It doesn't bring jobs."
The block's Southern intonations and the palette of pigmentation transport Fred Mitchell back to his Mississippi childhood. He is 77 and white, an Abstract Expressionist artist and an accomplished raconteur. But his connections on the block seem few, even after some three years here. After a racially tinged encounter with a neighbor, he has kept to himself. His motto now toward his neighbors: like ships in the night. 
In 1930, James Weldon Johnson wrote that Harlem was, unlike most black ghettos consigned to cities' borders, at the "heart of Manhattan." For that reason, he warned, it would probably not last as a black area. 
For Mr. Mitchell, such change is the natural order of things. The photographer Alfred Stieglitz said to him that he had seen seven different New Yorks out his window. Harlem itself was once Irish, Jewish, German. 
"This is New York," Mr. Mitchell says. "Change sweeps across whole parts."

'Holding On to What We Have'
For many blacks on this block, veteran or new, Harlem's integration cannot be brushed off as just another turn of history. The place means too much.
Janice Anderson is a deeply religious retiree with a vivid feel for language and a youthful glow. She has 30 years on the block. She welcomes the new faces, the new attitudes. She loves the redone town houses, and their "sophisticated air." 
But she has mixed feelings about the "prospectors," the whites walking through her neighborhood, looking property over as if it were theirs for the taking. She watches them taking "before" pictures of buildings. By now she knows there will be an after. 
Nowadays, she says, Harlem "seems to just pop open like a popover" -- an image both comforting and threatening. "There's only but one ethnic group that's always lived here," Ms. Anderson says. "Now there's another."
She was used to the Chinese, with their restaurants and laundries. But she had never before lived among white people. They can become neighbors, she says, if change comes gradually. She grips her fists. "We are holding on to what we have."

A Melting Pot, Stirred
Each Sunday morning, in a one-story brick building on 129th Street, black and white converge. The whites do not live in Harlem; the blacks do. Religion unites them.
The Harlem branch of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints started three years ago, first meeting at Sylvia's Restaurant on Lenox Avenue. It now draws 40 to 60 members a week. And so two years ago, the church bought property on 129th Street from the Jehovah's Witnesses. 
This church seems an unlikely place for building bridges, and not just because the Mormon Church was long seen as a white bastion. The Mormon religion is a patriarchal culture, with well-defined roles for men and women. Many families joining the church here are largely without men. 
And yet that is partly how the bridge is being built. Use the church, one white member urged during a Sunday lesson on what it means to be a Latter-day Saint woman, explicitly addressing the struggles of single mothers. Invite its men -- the priests, the elders, the home teachers -- to come to your home, talk to your children.
Their discussion touches, in a deep way, on the generational nature of the relations between men and women in Harlem: fatherless young men grow up believing women can do everything on their own, then as adults believe they are not needed and fade away. That reality -- strong women, absent men -- is inscribed even in the neighborhood's new face. The building and block associations developing around 129th Street are, in most cases, the work of women.
Black and white is not the only new interchange on 129th Street. Hispanics, too, are settling in growing numbers in central Harlem, and on this block.
One family, Puerto Rican transplants from Brooklyn, moved into one of Mr. Pascal's buildings but was gone within months. Local stores did not stock the food of the islands. The Catholic churches did not offer Spanish Masses. Then a son was beaten by youths apparently coveting his Cincinnati Reds cap. The family fled to New Jersey. 
Urania Muniz, who with her husband, Huascar Pimentel, and two daughters moved to 129th Street from Queens, has come to love it, finding a friendly sense of community she had never before experienced. She does not like the drug dealing, but she confesses that as she returns home late at night, the dealers make her feel safe. "They're thugs," she says. "But they look out for me."
Then there are the dozens of West Africans, the first major foreign presence here since Caribbeans arrived in force during the Harlem Renaissance. Then, there was outright hostility between Caribbeans and African-Americans. Today, the disdain, elitism and resentment are controlled, but present nonetheless.
Ibrahima Diop, an import-export entrepreneur from Senegal who lives on the block when he is in New York, paints his neighbors with a broad brush. Black New York, he says, is about drugs, alcohol and prostitution. Blacks don't work or educate their children. They have four children from four different fathers. He knows this from his neighborhood and what he reads in the newspapers. 
Some residents of the block believe the Africans think they are superior. The young people call Aminata Kone, 17, an "African queen" because she does not socialize with them even as they themselves say the Africans' food smells and that they do not bathe. 
But connections are spun. Rachel Tew persuades Oley Sarr, a mother of three from Gambia, to enroll her gregarious children in the block's summer camp so that they will learn to socialize with African-American children. By winter, the little boy belts rap tunes as he skips, without fear, down the block.
Ralph Acosta, who sits near the corner of 129th and Lenox every day, greeting everyone who walks by, confronts the block's African women, who from shyness or rudeness are ignoring him. 
"I'm the mayor of the block," he tells them. "If you can't say hello, get on the boat and go back to Africa." They start saying giggling hellos, and more. 
When Amadou Bah, a 73-year-old Liberian refugee settled on 129th Street, is hospitalized, Mr. Acosta watches Mr. Bah's 1-year-old baby so Mariama Bah can visit with her husband. When Mr. Acosta moves to a new apartment on the block, his first guests are the Bahs, who live on a few hundred dollars each month, and who ravenously devour his string beans and stew.

Changing the Mind
Sharlon Dean does little socializing on this block. She enters her brownstone apartment, shuts the door, and revels in the light and air and possibility of her backyard. It makes her feel she is not in Harlem, and Harlem -- as it exists on her block -- is somewhere she does not want to be. 
She came for the easy commute and cheap rent, but found herself right back in what she was fleeing. She is 31, black, and was raised in the projects. She lived briefly in a homeless shelter as a child. 
But she recently got her bachelor's degree from City College. She works for the city, monitoring domestic violence shelters, and is aiming at law school. She has cultivated a taste for greenleaf lettuce, rather than the iceberg she was raised on. She flips through the dictionary to self-educate. 
This block, with its enduring street life, its drugs, does not comport with the life she is building. She turns the corner and gets depressed.
She is a student of signs. On the subway, she observes that the black men lack wedding rings. "How," she asks, "can we commit to making the block better if we can't even commit to being in a relationship?" 
Sometimes, she says, it is hard being black if being black means living the life she sees around her. Sometimes, though, her anger melts to sympathy. How can people be different when they were never told they could be more? "Often I think can I do this? Am I smart enough? It wasn't instilled in me." 
Still, she hopes soon there will be enough new people to force the block into line. "I got to see some serious change out there to feel change up here" -- she points at her head -- "in the membrane."

Life in the Streets
Each afternoon, except when the cold becomes too cruel, a group of men, brown-bagged beers in hand, scratchy boombox providing the soundtrack, sit in front of the well-trafficked little stores near Lenox Avenue. A routine image captures much: how this block's residents have become family, how they cope with crowded living spaces and cramped lives by coming to the street, where laughter, action and air are guaranteed.
For people who grew up here, the block, and all its dramas, have been a life, not just a place to live. They know the lore of each building, remember the birthweights of babies, play off one another's crackling wit.
The scene provides moments of unexpected sweetness, as when a car stereo cranks out a Brook Benton song and a couple, maybe high on more than life, but maybe not, starts dancing and grooving together on the sidewalk, him clapping, her smiling so widely it is as if she has the sun in her mouth.
The scene, too, presents contradictions: a man who spends his afternoons drinking to excess rises at 2:30 a.m., 365 days a year, Christmas included, to sweep sidewalks and deliver newspapers. 
And as the day wanes, particularly in summer, the old block asserts itself, creating unbelievable noise. 129th Street has always been a magnet -- an addiction, one woman says, a place where something is always happening. At night, it can coalesce in what feels like a film set -- dozens of people looking for action on a well-lighted street with prettified buildings and young trees, hanging until the early hours. 
For some on the block, who have pulled themselves up from addiction or crime, the scene is threatening. For some of the new people, the "endless noise" is irritating enough that they contemplate moving off the block. For others, it is insulting. 
Quietly, anonymously, black police officers -- almost all from another Harlem precinct -- have settled here, mostly in Mr. Pascal's buildings. And they have a few quality-of-life complaints. 
For one officer, children who disrespect his property by leaning on his car are a minor irritant. The drug deals he regularly watches from his window are galling.
Like most frustrated citizens he looks to the 32nd Precinct. In a year on the block, he says, while narcotics units have been active, "I can count on one hand the number of sector cars I've seen drive through." He has never seen an officer walk the block. 
One night, Officer Eric Josey went to a meeting between residents of West 130th Street and the 32nd Precinct, to speak for the officers living in the neighborhood.
He had already made the bold move of sending a letter to the 32nd Precinct commander -- and a copy to the chief of department -- saying that the precinct needed to do better. "The officers in my precinct didn't appreciate it," he says. 
In polite terms, he repeats it at the meeting: the precinct must increase the pressure, particularly on 129th Street. He wants a strengthened undercover narcotics presence, and a heavy quality-of-life crackdown by uniformed officers. "There has to be a shake-up on that block," he says. 
Officer Josey does not dispute that the block is better. But how it was before is not a litmus test for how it is now, he says. The people who hang out, stubbornly, purposefully, must be dealt with. It is harsh, he says, "but maybe there's a certain regime of people that has to be relocated."

'I Like a Working Man'
Each day, around 6 p.m., the man in the suit, a small boy dangling from his hand, rounds the corner onto 129th street. He weaves through the block's building cacophony, its budding party. He does not break stride until he hits 35-37 West 129th Street. 
Milton Brown is home. 
The women outside sometimes make jokes -- "Ooh, I like a working man. Want me to come up and rub your back?" The jokes suggest to him that a new working ethos is developing. It is hard to gauge how much Mr. Brown's mere presence may shape his neighbors' lives. His ability and willingness to help them find jobs -- he is an employment specialist for those moving from welfare to work -- surely could.
Economic integration is a core strategy for nonprofits and policy makers these days. In economically mixed neighborhoods, the thinking goes, the poor will have role models to inspire and instruct them. 129th Street is like a petri dish now; the mix is here. And a few years of experience suggest that coexistence may make a difference, but real interaction would mean more. 
Loretta Jeter, a mother of five on welfare and trying to figure out her future, says she doesn't even know what the new people in her building -- Mr. Brown's building -- do. 
"The new people aren't sociable," Nadine Allen, who grew up on the block, says. "We had a lot of community participation when the community wasn't so nice."
But moments of contact do occur, the beginnings of change that may take years to ripen. When Urania Muniz first arrived, she wondered whether she could influence the block's children. She now thinks it is possible. When she works late, the children comment that she works hard. "I have to pay my bills," she explains. "I like to buy nice things." She gets at least one youth hanging on the block into a computer training course at City College. 
In a sense, the new people here are reinforcements for old-timers who tried for years to fight the hopelessness and peer pressure that dragged down the young. Rachel Tew, on the block for 22 years, retired from the Board of Education, serves as an unofficial employment agency and den mother. She lectures Fred Cabey, out of school at 17, to get his working papers. When she suggests a job at a McDonald's on 125th Street, and he says he does not know if it is taking applications, she goes and finds out. He no longer has an excuse.
"Fred could do a lot of things," she says. "He's a gifted little kid. But he's stagnating, like all of us."
The resources that have infused this block since 1994 are a start toward breaking that stagnation. Some, like a youth council that helped find children summer jobs, have come from the community office placed on the block by the Abyssinian Development Corporation. But some resources have come from new residents. A photographer taught the block's youngsters how a camera could transform their neighborhood's prosaic landmarks into glossy poetry. Mr. Brown, a single father to 7-year-old Justin, one fall afternoon took 13 children to a free showing of "Pokemon 2000" movie at the Apollo Theater, simply to get them off the block.

Meetings, and Mediation
It didn't take long for the residents of Mr. Brown's building to realize that their renovated home was stacked like a layered dip. The first two floors are mostly elderly residents; the next two, working people; the top two, "fixed income" or those on welfare, most of whom are veterans of the block.
Almost all of them are black. Many have similar backgrounds. But they think and live differently. Now they must live together. 
There are adjustments. Mr. Brown's suit drew looks at first. As a 30-year-old black woman with no children, Terra Lambright, a mortgage consultant, is unusual here. When she first moved in, she heard some neighbors saying so. She got attitude for working. She was accused of talking white. 
She, in turn, flinched at the way longtime residents in her building regularly leave their doors open. Then her mother, who lived in Harlem long ago, told her that open doors were a tradition even then; it was how the family made some of its best friends. 
Ms. Lambright makes friends, too. Her neighbors, in fact, become a family in a city where she, like many ambitious young migrants, is essentially on her own. When she returned from a long business trip, one neighbor, Frances H., held a welcome-home fish fry. When Ms. Lambright travels, Frances calls her regularly to provide comfort and a link to home. And when they walk the neighborhood together, Ms. Lambright marvels that Frances, 47, on the block since age 12, knows "everybody" anywhere near 129th Street (although she would rather be known by only a first name herself). 
When Danielle Cato, 31, moved in, she heard her neighbors saying "the new people better understand what we're like." She set them straight. She was born in Harlem and raised on 131st Street. She is a single mother and was once on welfare. 
But she put herself through school, earning a master's in social work at Fordham University. Her family owns homes in Harlem, and she plans to also. She knew this block from her childhood, and was reluctant to come. She forbids her daughter to go to the store alone. 
But she needed cheap rent, and squeaking in under the low income limit, she pays $525 for a three bedroom. "Even though I'm part of the 'working crew' here, I'm still poor," she says. "Working poor." 
Believing that she could change her building, if not her block, she joined with other tenants to start a building association. Its first meetings were chaotic and cantankerous. There was yelling -- about Mr. Pascal, the stoops and the superintendent's barking dog.
To the tenants, Ms. Cato defended Mr. Pascal, telling them that unless they maintain the building better, they cannot make demands of him. She tried to teach them how to get what they want. "You can't yell at Pascal," she said at one meeting. "He doesn't know how to handle that." 
And Ms. Cato defended the tenants to him. She chewed Mr. Pascal out for being condescending to the tenants he has labeled as "bad." "I don't like his tone," she says.
The continual littering in the building's halls made Ms. Cato crazy. She established a children's tenant council to help maintain the building. Pumped up by the responsibility, the children, for a time, swept and mopped with glee, knocking on her door at midnight to point out gleaming stairways. 
She has tried to find jobs for the block's teenagers, and tries to get them to understand how the police think so that they can stay safe. She worries about her neighbors who have not worked before, about what will happen to them if rents rise and welfare benefits are cut off. Life is hard on her, and she's been working for years.
She will not stay on this block, she says. But she will not turn her back on it while she is here.

Private Wars, and Scars
Not long after Michelle Ramirez's preaching stint, her prayers appeared to be answered. The four young men disappeared from the corner. The crackheads came, but encountered the equivalent of a gone fishin' sign -- no one working. About a dozen of them, middle-aged men and women, gathered in a desperate knot, banging on the building's door.
Soon enough, though, business resumed. The hustlers were in place early in the morning on the first day of school, saluting children in new backpacks and uniforms, and checking out their mothers. 
But their days appear to be numbered. Narcotics units, responding partly to complaints from the officers on the block, are bearing down. One officer says they will drive the trade from the block, although they know it will just go elsewhere. 
And in the fall, the city decided to turn the building over to Mr. Pascal. It was not the first building in which he confronted drug dealers. In another, two blocks away, a dealer angry that the superintendent would not let him use a vacant apartment shot the super in the head. Mr. Pascal and his other superintendents shipped the body back to Honduras. "He paid the ultimate price for the neighborhood to come back," Mr. Pascal says. "I am going to win -- for him. I'm not going to give up because there are people who want to live decent." 
Some, however, are giving up. The Kones, one of the African families who had come to 129th Street because it was no longer a violent place, plan to move to escape the drug dealing in their building's hallway. 
In the same building, a resident who asked the dealers to leave was stabbed in the face. The head of the drug crew offered to pay his medical bills if he would not press charges. Among neighbors, far from police eyes -- these are the private wars being waged.

Contradictory Visions
A young man, just turned 15, out of school and already working the streets, complains about the renovations on the block as he smokes a joint. "They're cutting off all the alleys so we got nowhere to run" when the police jump out, he says. "They should bring the vacant lots back."
Of all the challenges on 129th Street, one of the greatest is how to reconcile contradictory visions of the same place. 
So when the block's new association met, it set a goal: "to create relations with the veterans so they feel comfortable with the new people." Its first step was to have residents vote the block a name. 129th Street, once known as "the problem block," is now "Strutter's Row."
The second plan was a Christmas tree lighting ceremony. Janice Wilson, who had helped restart the association, persuaded local stores to donate food and jazz musicians to play. Pamela Gartrell, an arts teacher with three years on the block, volunteered to forge a children's hip-hop troupe. Each Saturday they rehearsed, feet flying and hearts pumping to the sounds of Destiny's Child. Ms. Gartrell tried to instill professionalism along with the fancy footwork: "You cannot just roll up when you want to."
On Dec. 9, the day of the tree-lighting, 129th Street feels electric. In Gallery X, it looks as if a crate of art supplies has exploded, as Ms. Erbil, Ms. Gartrell and others help the children make ornaments. The hip-hop posse rehearses one last time, Ms. Gartrell pushing hard: "You are the 129th Street dancers -- it's time to act like it."
Janice Anderson, the longtime resident, puts garlands on the block's tree guards. Mr. Pascal's superintendents string white lights on every tree and bush in the gathering darkness. Even Sharlon Dean is dazzled.
The city-donated tree is placed in a once-vacant lot, now a verdant plot named the Harlem Village Green. Sonja Manly, another new resident, hangs ornaments against a backdrop of four still-empty buildings. From one comes the sound of scraping, preparation for renovation. From the street comes the smell of marijuana -- the young men lining the block's south side getting high as heaven. 
The temperature is under 30, the crowd over 200. "The block looks good," Ralph Acosta says from a sidewalk chair. "The block looks very good." 
Councilman Bill Perkins toasts the revival of 129th Street's housing and spirit. He celebrates the young in attendance, saying, "There was a time when it looked like we were not going to have any more young people on this block." As if in affirmation, the children dance better than they have ever rehearsed. 
The crowd counts down: "Ten, nine, eight . . . " the shouted voices soaring above the empty buildings. The switch is pulled, the tree comes on, colored lights glowing in the night. 
This block is like a hologram, and in January it will show its darker side. The 12-year-old son of Zoila White, a five-year resident of the block, accidentally wounds his sister, 7, with a gun he finds in his mother's drawer. In her bedroom, the police say, officers find more than 100 vials of crack. 
The children are taken. The mother, a woman with a decade of nursing home work and no criminal history, who had boasted of keeping her children off the block and in the house, is jailed. The other mothers shake their heads knowingly. For all the change, for all the hope rising in the air, 129th Street can still pull you down. 
But for tonight, the shivering residents hover as if the cold can freeze this moment of promise in time. When the crowd disperses, and two young men begin a profanity-laden argument, Rachel Tew cuts them off.
"Fellas! Fellas! Fellas! You can't be using that language. You see what we're trying to do here." 
From the darkness and toward the marvelous light.

An American Block

Six years after profiling life on West 129th Street in Harlem, The Times found a transformed block.

HEADLINE: Hard Realities On the Rio Grande 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Pamela S. Falk ("Easing Up at the Border," Op-Ed, Feb. 15) recommends a mass amnesty for Mexicans illegally residing in the United States, implying that it is "the right thing to do, both economically and morally." Yes, a steady supply of cheap foreign labor financially benefits some businesses. 
And providing the world's desperately poor with the opportunity to move to our high-consumption society feels morally right to many people. 
But no debate on an amnesty is complete without reference to a new Immigration and Naturalization Service study showing that amnesties encourage illegal immigration. And a Gallup Poll this month indicated that only 5 percent of respondents were "very satisfied" with current immigration policy.

LIN SUN
Middle Village, Queens, Feb. 15, 2001

 Late Edition - Final

SECTION: Section C; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1635 words

HEADLINE: Management: Discarded Dreams Of Dot-ComRejects; 
Growing Indignation Results From Recent Brusque Dismissals

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

 BODY:
They are young, smart and bitter. They are the victims of the recent wave of layoffs in the high-technology industry, and many of them cannot believe how clumsy their former employers were in delivering the bad news.
 Patrick Mannion learned his fate on Dec. 20 when he returned with his wife from a two-week honeymoon in Hawaii to their home in Montclair, N.J. The pink slip telling him his job was eliminated days earlier was waiting for him in a FedEx envelope sent by Organic Inc., an Internet consultant in San Francisco. 
 "For someone who had been with the company for two and a half years, getting a notice just five days before Christmas after having just spent several thousand dollars of my own money was a bittersweet experience," said Mr. Mannion, a creative director for Organic, one of 270 of over 1,200 to lose their jobs. "My wife was absolutely crushed." 
Mr. Mannion said he had recently turned down a lucrative offer from a competitor before he was dismissed. But now, with dot-com jobs scarce, he has decided to do freelance work. An Organic spokeswoman said the company had not made the decision to lay off people lightly and acknowledged that employees "may feel pain or anger as a result."
Companies have always let employees go in hard times, but Internet start-ups that only one year ago could not hire fast enough now have a special problem, employment lawyers and job consultants say. The people in charge are themselves often young and inexperienced in the art of management, they say, and are so used to devoting all their energies to relieving the stresses and strains of fast growth that they do not know how to cope with decline gracefully.
As a result, they can be insensitive to workers and even ignorant of their legal obligations to them. The result is a growing tide of indignation that threatens to tarnish the reputations of some companies and put others in legal predicaments, labor lawyers say. Already, court filings by aggrieved workers and settlements with their former employers are increasing sharply, they say, and the number of lawsuits is expected to grow. "Since around the first of November, we have been receiving maybe two or three times as many calls we did during the good economic times," said Mark Rudy, an employment lawyer with Rudy, Exelrod, Zieff & True in San Francisco who handles plaintiff claims. "There is a lot of frustration and anger."
Most people who contact him do not have a case that would hold up in court, though, he added.
Much of the problem results from the seat-of-the-pants management mind-set that worked well in the Internet boom of the 1990's but that can be a disaster when applied to the sticky task of dismissing people. "Sometimes, we get a call from companies that say, 'We're doing this layoff tomorrow. Is there anything you want to tell me?' That's kind of scary," said Raymond Hixson, an employment lawyer with Fenwick & West in Palo Alto, Calif., which focuses on high-technology.
Sometimes, it is less the abruptness of the layoffs than the seeming crassness of their bosses that infuriates departing workers. Just ask Marlinda McPhail, 30, of San Francisco who lost her job at Wheelhouse, a consulting company, along with 10 percent of her colleagues in early January. As she and another victim were packing up their belongings in their office, Ms. McPhail recalled, people who had escaped the downsizing started streaming in.
It turned out that management had called a meeting in their office to discuss the layoffs. "I was like, 'You've got to be kidding me,' " she said. She stormed out, leaving her computer, wallet and bag behind. "They're just idiots," said Ms. McPhail, who remains unemployed.
Paul McNulty, Wheelhouse's vice president for marketing, said, "If someone feels they weren't treated with respect, we apologize for that."
Or take Collaborative Media, a San Francisco company that runs an online product review site, Etown. The company announced on Valentine's Day that it would lay off all of its 101 employees, because financing from a major investor had been cut off. Not only were employees surprised by the abrupt notice and lack of severance pay, they also were not paid for the last week and a half they worked there.
"People feel as if they have been betrayed, that they have been lied to and that the company used them," said Tim Lefkowicz, former vice president for business and corporate development, who also missed his last paycheck.
The company has referred employees who say they have not been paid for hours worked over the last two weeks to the investor, Best Buy. Workers say that they plan to appeal to the state labor commissioner. Robert Heiblim, former chief executive of Collaborative Media, said the company had little choice. "We couldn't touch the assets and we couldn't pay the employees," he said.
What rankles many who suddenly find themselves on the unemployment rolls is the way their once-highflying employers apparently hide the truth of their financial straits. David Wadler was laid off without severance pay and almost no warning by an online entertainment start-up in New York City in early December when it suddenly announced that it had run out of money.
"It was literally like getting smacked in the face," said Mr. Wadler, 26, who is still unemployed. "It was like getting dumped."
When push comes to shove, even the longest-serving employees find they can be let go. It happened to Lorraine Cheu when SpotLife.com, a San Francisco site that helps consumers broadcast videos on the Internet, dismissed her with 25 percent of its staff in January. "I was employee No. 1 right after the founders," she said. "I felt like we were cattle led off to the slaughter," she added. Ms. Cheu, who has not yet found another job, said she held off signing a severance agreement that would relinquish her right to take legal action "to kind of make them sweat."
Like other casualties of the dot-come meltdown, Ms. Cheu has vented her anger on a Web site -- in her case, her own -- and says she has gotten a sympathetic response from readers.
SpotLife declined to comment.
Venting -- not litigation -- is probably the most realistic response for most laid off employees. After all, to get the best severance package possible, many of them agree in writing not to sue. And besides, employment contracts in the high-technology industry generally give employers discretion to dismiss employees at will.
"Americans instinctively believe that they can only be fired for doing something wrong, or not performing," said Bill Quackenbush, a labor lawyer in San Mateo, Calif., who represents plaintiffs. "One of the hardest parts of my job is explaining to people that they don't have a legal claim because of the at-will clause."
Even so, lawyers say high-technology start-ups will be vulnerable litigation targets for a variety of factors: their freewheeling culture that sometimes resulted in a skirting of workplace laws, the high levels of shattered expectations and the intelligence and drive of the aggrieved ex-workers. "They tend to bring a more aggressive litigation response than in a less educated blue-collar work force," said Victor Schachter, who heads the employment group at Fenwick & West.
That is what Juliana Rubenstein did. She was a former vice president at HSX Holding Inc., parent of Hollywood Stock Exchange, in West Hollywood, Calif., a market for trading shares of celebrities, movies and music using a virtual currency.
Mrs. Rubenstein filed a complaint last fall with the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing charging her former employer with wrongful termination, retaliation and pregnancy discrimination. According to suit, Mrs. Rubenstein was told by executives in September that she was selected for a December layoff because there was no way to guarantee that she would ever return to work following her pregnancy leave. Subsequently, she filed a civil action in Los Angeles Superior Court accusing the company of discrimination and retaliation in violation of the Fair Employment and Housing Act.
Despite her strong performance reviews, the company said it made sense to lay her off, and offered to give her a severance package. Days after she faxed a copy of a complaint that she had filed with the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing to the human resources department at HSX Holdings, Mrs. Rubenstein said the company dismissed her and withdrew its severance package.
HSX said it could not comment on pending litigation except to say it would vigorously defend itself.
Another company that finds itself in legal trouble these days is Walker Digital, a cousin company to Priceline.com in Stamford, Conn., that handles inventions and patents. On the Tuesday before Thanksgiving, Walker Digital told employees that it would be laying off a substantial number of them the very next day.
"The week before they told us to pack our bags, they were telling us things were great," said Kari O'Toole, an administrative assistant who was one of those who lost her job. "They didn't even give us a full last paycheck. They paid you up to the minute you worked. The employees were left without severance pay, and only were belatedly paid for their unused vacation days."
As it turns out, Walker Digital may have acted too rashly. In January, Connecticut's attorney general charged it with violating a federal law that requires companies above a certain size to give 60 days' advance notice of a plant closing or mass layoff. Walker Digital contends that it was exempt from the law because it was seeking financing. "We feel the lawsuit is without merit," said Kevin Goldman, a spokesman for Walker Digital.
Ms. O'Toole is still job-hunting, and the experience has left her dispirited. "It's terrible out there," she said. "You can't trust any one."
