HEADLINE: A Chief Exporter, and Not at All Pleased About It 

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: MOORESVILLE, N.C., Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Factories just like the Matsushita plant here made North Carolina an industrial colossus less than a decade ago, the state with the largest percentage of its workers in manufacturing jobs. Surrounded by fountains and landscaped nature trails, that pristine compressor factory seemed to embody the state's economic promise when it opened with fanfare in 1991.
 But North Carolina lost 27,800 manufacturing jobs last year -- by far the largest such loss in the country -- and the trend continued last month when the Matsushita factory's Japanese owners announced that they would close it in March, putting 530 employees out of work. Air-conditioning compressors will instead be made in China and Malaysia, the company said, and stunned workers now contemplate a future of sporadic, lower-paying jobs. 
 "Look at this place -- I thought I would retire here," said Helen Dishman, a 48-year-old line leader for Matsushita, gesturing at the 10-acre factory on its lush 100-acre lot, the town's largest employer last year. "Now I'll be lucky to find something that doesn't even pay as much." 
Probably more than any other state, North Carolina has been shaken by a drain of low-wage factory jobs overseas in the last five years. One by one, the pillars on which the state's economy was built 20 years ago -- textiles, furniture, apparel -- have begun to fall to foreign competition, and its growing high-tech centers are usually out of the reach of laid-off workers.
The loss of those jobs last year and 30,000 in the previous four years, along with the closing of the factories that provided them, contributed greatly to the tax revenue shortage that forced Gov. Michael F. Easley to declare a fiscal emergency two weeks ago in order to close a budget gap of nearly $800 million.
Western North Carolina, though still the nation's furniture capital, lost 2,200 furniture jobs last year as imports rose and plants closed. More than 13,000 textile workers were laid off when big plants shut, three in Greensboro alone, and today there are fewer than half the 400,000 textile and apparel jobs that dominated North Carolina employment in 1980.
The erosion of its base has made the state all the more vulnerable as the national economy begins to slow, economists say, and in that sense it may offer an early warning signal to the rest of the country.
"North Carolina has been losing manufacturing jobs for a long time, but up to now it has also been able to create new jobs," said Patrick J. Conway, an economics professor at the University of North Carolina. "What's worrisome about this new downturn is that the new sectors are not able to absorb those losses anymore. People who might have moved to the new jobs before will now have to sit longer and train harder and probably drive farther."
Here in Mooresville, a town of 17,000 half an hour north of Charlotte on Interstate 77, Burlington Industries laid off 600 people in 1999 when it closed a huge denim plant. In the last few months, the town has also lost a mobile-home factory and a truck-parts supplier. Even its economic prize -- the racing car manufacturing industry, which was recruited here to replace textiles and now employs 1,400 people -- is starting to suffer: about 15 of 65 Nascar teams here have shut their doors in the last six months, and many of the others are worried as the slowdown begins to hurt the corporate sponsors whose logos festoon the cars.
As melancholy tourists milled around the area this week mourning the death of the racing star Dale Earnhardt, who lived outside Mooresville, many of the team owners expressed concern that the economic slowdown's effect on Nascar could hurt the town.
"If the racing industry gets hit like I think it's going to get hit, it will devastate this area," said Don Miller, president of Penske Racing, where a flag drooped at half-staff across the street from the North Carolina Auto Racing Hall of Fame. "Racing is one of the first things the sponsors cut when hard times come. There's two or three more teams that are on the ropes now, and every one of us can see it coming."
The unionized heavy industry of the Upper Midwest never took root in North Carolina. Instead, the state became the South's most industrialized through thousands of low-wage, low-skill jobs like those in textile mills. In some ways, it actually preferred such jobs to those that paid better; in 1990, a group of business leaders told United Airlines not to build a maintenance plant that would have added 5,000 high-paying jobs to the state, because its union shop would not be welcome. The airline instead built in Indianapolis.
North Carolina thrived in the 1980's: as factories in Ohio and Indiana closed, many workers moved South to take nonunion jobs at less than half of what they had been paid. But global competition eventually caught up with the state's manufacturing advantage, and seized it.
"The Northern states shed these low-end jobs 20 years ago, and they came here," said Colin Austin, a work-force expert with MDC Inc., researchers in Chapel Hill. "But now technology is replacing a lot of workers, and the cheap labor isn't here anymore -- it's overseas."
As the plants started closing, however, a very different North Carolina was rising: the financial center, Charlotte, and the research and development center in the Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill triangle. The state added nearly 700,000 service and technology jobs from 1978 to 1997, more than making up for the loss in manufacturing employment. 
North Carolina's overall economy grew so briskly that state budget planners seemingly forgot they were much more vulnerable to a downturn now that they were without their old economic foundation. But this month, when tax revenue fell far short of estimates at the same time that Medicaid costs skyrocketed, the state encountered its worst budget crisis in a decade.
The state's job growth continues, but that growth is significantly slower than it was, and unemployment, while low, is beginning to edge up. The 4 percent jobless rate in December was the highest in more than four years and the first since 1982 that was as high as the nation's.
A huge disparity remains between the economy of the growing metropolitan areas and that of the rural counties, where more than 60 percent of the manufacturing layoffs have occurred. Many of the laid-off workers lack the education to compete in the new economy, and their counties lack the infrastructure and other resources to grow along with Charlotte and Raleigh-Durham.
A state rural development task force headed by Erskine B. Bowles, former chief of staff to President Bill Clinton, recommended bringing high-speed Internet access to every county, as well as spending more state money to improve roads, schools and housing in rural areas. Rick Carlisle left his job as North Carolina commerce secretary last week to lead a state fund that will invest $150 million in growth companies outside urban areas.
But promises of Internet access and investment, however much they may assist the state's long-term strategy, sound rather empty to the assembly-line workers at the Matsushita plant, who filed into the parking lot on a shift change the other day grumbling about Asian companies and broken promises.
"We've got plants closing right and left, and I don't know who's going to hire us," said David Peters, a pump repairman at the factory. "If something doesn't happen soon, this whole area's going to have a lot of vacation time and no vacation pay."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Workers at a Matsushita plant in Mooresville, N.C., that opened only 10 years ago. HEADLINE: Judge Approves Auction House Settlement 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
A federal judge gave final approval yesterday to a $512 million settlement of the lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses by customers who said they were cheated in a price-fixing conspiracy that lasted several years.
 While attaching two conditions to the approval, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan, in a 44-page decision, called the settlement "eminently reasonable by any standard." 
Richard Drubel, a plaintiffs' lawyer, said, "We are delighted with Judge Kaplan's opinion and expect it will not be difficult to meet his conditions."
Approval of the settlement begins to close one chapter in a scandal that has roiled the secretive and rarefied art and auction world for more than a year. 
The civil suit grew out of a four-year-old criminal antitrust investigation by the Justice Department that heated up last year when the former chief executive of Christie's provided documents detailing how officials of the two companies colluded to fix rates on commissions and on other matters. Prosecutors are continuing their criminal investigation, but lawyers in the civil case said the judge's conditions would be met by March 1 and that payments could be made to more than 130,000 auction house customers within months if there were no court challenges.
Officials at Sotheby's and Christie's declined to comment on the approval. 
One of Judge Kaplan's conditions on the $512 million settlement is that customers who bought or sold at auctions outside the United States be compensated "even if only in a very small way." Initially the suit would not have provided any specific payments for transactions abroad.
The second condition by Judge Kaplan was that the auction houses publicize the existence of the discount certificates that would be issued to sellers by Sotheby's and Christie's as part of the $512 million payout. In order to stimulate a market in the certificates, the judge said he wanted notices about them included in auction catalogs and on sellers' invoices.
The settlement calls for the auction houses to pay $256 million each. Last September, Sotheby's and Christie's agreed to pay $50 million each in the form of the certificates, which could be sold, but could only be used to reduce commission costs on future consignments. 
Judge Kaplan was skeptical that the certificates were worth their face value. Last month after economic analyses ordered by the judge and pressure from the lead plaintiffs' lawyers, David Boies and Mr. Drubel of Boies, Schiller & Flexner, the auction houses agreed to increase the value of the certificates to $125 million.
Sotheby's and Christie's also agreed that class members could redeem the certificates, which will be issued to plaintiffs with claims of more than $500, for cash after four years. 
When the judge preliminarily approved the settlement last November, the companies had 30 days to deposit $100 million in cash in an escrow account. The balance will be paid within 30 days after the judge's two conditions are met. 
But just when customers will begin to see the money is uncertain, with estimates ranging from months to years if someone were to appeal the approval. 
The judge also approved a $26.7 million payment to the Boies firm, 20 percent of which will be in the discount certificates. The lawyers were named lead counsel in an unusual bidding process held by the judge to designate the lawyers who would accept the lowest fees and therefore disburse the most money to the class. 
In the decision, Judge Kaplan wrote that he believed that the plaintiffs would have received "hundreds of millions of dollars less" if his bidding process had not been used. Only 916 class members, or fewer than 1 percent, have requested to opt out of the settlement and only 61 filed objections, the judge wrote.
The criminal side of the case, in which Sotheby's and its former chief executive have pleaded guilty and Christie's has received conditional amnesty, continues with federal prosecutors focusing on A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's largest shareholder and its former chairman. Mr. Taubman denies wrongdoing.
Prosecutors questioned Sotheby's employees in New York as late as last week and talks are being held in Washington between Mr. Taubman's lawyers and antitrust prosecutors.

HEADLINE: Letting Out Market Fear Elsewhere 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Turkey's devaluation of its currency yesterday seemed to take some of the pressure out of the latest emerging-markets crisis. Most damage in other nations' financial markets came earlier in the week as the crisis grew.
 And emerging-markets experts said that they did not expect the events in Turkey to have much of a continuing effect on other markets. "The direct impact of Turkey should be very limited," said Desmond Lachman, director of emerging-markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney. 
 Joyce Chang, global head of emerging markets at J. P. Morgan Securities, said Turkey was "not a Russia in 1998," alluding to the devaluation of the Russian ruble and Moscow's default on some debt that year. That led to a wide sell-off in other emerging markets.
"But it is not as benign as the Brazilian devaluation in 1999," she added, referring to the modest effect then. By January 1999, many investors had already turned their backs on emerging markets. In addition, the Brazilian devaluation had been anticipated.
The devaluation in Turkey, which sent the exchange value of the lira down more than 25 percent, contributed to further weakness in the euro against the dollar, currency analysts said. In New York, the euro settled at 90.57 cents, down from 90.82 cents on Wednesday.
Other analysts said that the declines in some Eastern European stock markets came from investors' selling to cover their losses in Turkey. The Polish stock market dropped as much as 2 percent during the day but rebounded to end down just 0.7 percent. It fell 2 percent on Wednesday. The Russian stock market, in dollar terms, ended 4 percent higher after falling 7.9 percent on Wednesday.
The prices of emerging-market bonds, which had fallen earlier in the week, moved slightly higher as the yield, moving in the opposite direction, declined. The yield on Brazil's widely traded C bond, which jumped to 12.38 percent on Wednesday from 11.88 percent last Friday, slipped to 12.24 percent yesterday. Russian bond prices also moved higher.
There are several reasons analysts expect the fallout from Turkey to be small. One is that Turkey's bonds make up only 1.9 percent of the Emerging Markets Bond Index Plus compiled by J. P. Morgan. As a point of comparison, Argentina's bonds make up 23.1 percent.
According to the index, the spread between the yield on emerging-market debt and that on comparable United States Treasury securities slipped to 7.25 percentage points yesterday. It had jumped to 7.31 percentage points on Wednesday from 6.90 percent last Friday. And it had fallen from a spread of more than 8 percentage points early in December, when the Federal Reserve first signaled that it was ready to cut short-term interest rates to spur growth in the United States.
Another mitigating factor is that Turkey does not trade with many other emerging-market countries. And Turkey, unlike Russia in 1998, is not a place where large numbers of foreign investors have flocked in hopes of big returns.
But this does not mean that there will not be some fallout in the future as Turkey tries to put together a new economic plan with the International Monetary Fund.
Devaluing the currency is a good step, Ms. Chang said, but added that Turkey still had many other problems to deal with -- including a weak banking system that would be hurt further by the devaluation, a slowing economy and rising borrowing needs.

HEADLINE: Memories Chiseled in a Cathedral's Stone 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
Twenty-two years ago, the idea rang out like a clarion.
 To resume work on the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, British masters would come to New York and train jobless youths in the ways of medieval stonemasonry. Together they would revive a dying craft. And lo, a stoneyard arose on the edge of Harlem. The cathedral began to grow again. 
 It was an idea at once grandiose and simple, and well covered in the national news media. But a decision to commercialize the operation just before an economic downturn drove the stoneyard under in 1994. The young masons, who had the promise of a lifetime's work, scattered. 
So whatever happened to them? 
It turns out that a surprising number of the cathedral masons remained in the trade or on its edges. More broadly, the stoneyard left a deep mark on the group, who themselves, through hammer and chisel, left a mark on the physical city. 
"It opened me up to a world -- of God, passion, people, possibilities," said Dennis Reed, 45, a former cocaine user raised in Harlem who now does freelance stone work. 
And while there is little evidence the program has created a stone carving renaissance in the city, it nourished the craft by seeding alumni throughout the profession.
The Kincannon brothers, Joseph and D'Ellis, operate a stone carving business in Austin, Tex. Timothy Dunlap Smith also has a masonry concern, in Philmont, N.Y. Nelson Otero and four others found jobs at a decorative stone company in New Jersey. Chris Pellettieri and Treese Robb are struggling on as independent carvers. Michael Orekunrin works as a master mason at a Mount Vernon, N.Y., stone company and taught a carving course at Bard College.
But many more drifted off into different lines of work. Eddie Pizarro works for an art moving company. Jessica Lowrie designs Web sites, and so does Joseph Chiffriller, who still carves decorative pieces on the side and sells them on the Internet. 
Albert Rivera is a technician at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. James Jamerson lives in his boyhood home in Harlem and works as a messenger. Carol Hazel, who raised four children as a single mother while at the yard, plans to graduate this year from Mercy College with a degree in education. Still others have fallen into oblivion, untraceable and unremembered. And inevitably, a few found sad fates. One died in a motorcycle accident, another died of AIDS. Several served spells in jail, former officials of the stoneyard said.
About 100 apprentices passed through the program, staying from a few months to 12 years and learning how to transform blocks of limestone into ornamented bits of architecture and, for the talented, into sculpture.
They arrived as young men and women in their 20's, either adrift or intent on learning the trade. Now paunchy and pushing middle age, with spouses, divorces and children, they remember the friendships formed hammering rock, the soccer games in the stoneyard, the rivalry between carvers and masons, the occasional drug-taking that prompted the phrase "stoned yard." 
The former apprentices have some sour memories, revolving around the yard's increased commercialization and its closing. But overwhelmingly, they look back at that time as the happiest of their lives.
"I remember I used to say, 'I'll grow old working here,' " Mr. Pizarro said. "Now I'll grow old looking at it." 
Mr. Rivera said he thought about stonecutting every day: "It's something that caught my heart." He still has his mallet 10 years after leaving the cathedral.
The stoneyard was the brainchild of the Very Rev. James Parks Morton, the cathedral's energetic dean from 1972 to 1996. Work on the building had begun in 1892 and sputtered on until it stopped with the onset of World War II. The cathedral then squatted on Amsterdam Avenue minus its towers and with only part of one transept until Dean Morton decided it was time to continue work.
In 1978, he recruited five young people, including two former street gang members, for the first apprentice class. By taking in neighborhood youths, the Episcopal Church sidestepped the charge that it was ignoring people in need while spending money on a building.
"It was showing that this great cathedral is not a thing of the past, showing that cathedrals have got to be completed," he said recently. And it was also a way to revive a fast-fading tradition, he said. 
Word filtered out. Ms. Lowrie saw it on the television news. Mr. Orekunrin, a wood carver in his native Nigeria, was driving by in his gypsy cab and stopped out of curiosity. Pedro L. Colon stumbled on it while delivering flowers to the cathedral for a florist shop. 
The apprentices, some of whom were sent for study in England and France, cut across race and economic background, and later generations included Europeans with carving experience. The stoneyard became a crossroads, a sometimes odd mix of streetwise New York, artistic endeavor and heavy lifting.
Dean Morton became the yard's spiritual father. He buried and baptized apprentices, proselytized about its virtues and cheerfully extracted money from donors.
"It made me get up in the morning," he said. "It was the most exciting thing going. I took everyone I knew to see it, and they all went bananas."
Mr. Pizarro arrived in late 1979. He was 20, with a rough upbringing in Spanish Harlem and a vague idea to pursue carpentry. His brother's junior high school graduation at the cathedral changed that.
"I was so amazed. I was looking at this place like, 'How do they do these things?' " he said. "I started looking into it, getting more information. I realized then: Wow, I was meant to do this. It came so natural. Not only that, I was building a cathedral. It was overwhelming."
David M. Teitelbaum, a real estate developer with a preservationist bent, also became captivated by the stoneyard. In 1989, Dean Morton invited him in to expand it and form a partnership, Cathedral Stoneworks, with part of the profits from outside work plowed back into the cathedral. 
"The idea was very romantic, and it was wonderful," Mr. Teitelbaum said. "I felt this was one thing I could do that would be really an imprint on my life."
He invested heavily in advanced machinery. But a real estate crash in 1990 dried up financing for cathedral building, and Mr. Teitelbaum said he had trouble paying for his investment. Construction stopped in 1991. Mr. Teitelbaum hung on for three more years before going out of business.
"Our big baby died," said Dean Morton, who founded and now runs the Interfaith Center of New York. So did about 70 jobs. 
Some blamed Mr. Teitelbaum for the stoneyard's demise, or at least ruining its spirit.
"It turned basically into a factory," said Joseph Kincannon, who worked at the yard from 1980 to 1992. "The work became much simpler and less interesting."
Mr. Teitelbaum counters that he was providing training and jobs, and that the machinery created more time for carvers to carry out detail work.
After the stoneyard closed, the masons wandered off. Mr. Pizarro did some renovation work and drove a U.P.S. truck. He spent three years restoring works at an antiques dealer in Manhattan before his current job moving art.
Many of the former cathedral masons want the cathedral building to continue, with or without them. The prospects seem unlikely, at least for the moment. The administration that followed Dean Morton decided to focus on conservation rather than on new building. A new dean and bishop are expected soon, and supporters of building are placing their hopes in the change.
"The cathedral needs to be built," said Mr. Reed, the freelance stonemason. "I've dedicated my life to it."
"We build nuclear plants and weapons," he added, "why not a cathedral? This is the most prosperous nation at its most prosperous time. Why not build?"
Now 45, Mr. Reed started his apprenticeship in 1986, in the aftermath of his brother's murder and during a respite from the intravenous cocaine habit that he says gave him the AIDS virus. The cocaine habit came back while Mr. Reed was at the cathedral. He even broke open a collection box with a masonry hammer. Officials from the cathedral got Mr. Reed into rehabilitation. 
Mr. Reed, speaking through lips swollen by an AIDS-related infection, is a lay minister at his church in Brooklyn and is hoping to start a landscaping business.
AIDS claimed Ruben Gibson in 1988, at age 39. He is remembered as a fiercely dedicated carver with a strongly religious, almost monastic, bent. On a recent visit to the cathedral with other former apprentices, Mr. Reed contemplated a rough-hewn lion's head poking out of a stone block. It was Mr. Gibson's last work.
After the stoneyard closed, Mr. Teitelbaum established Stoneworks Gallery, which produces inscribed stones, fountains, benches and patios in Closter, N.J. Five former apprentices went to work for him. Mr. Otero is the only one still there.
Of the others, Henry Espinal moved to Rhode Island at the end of last year, with hopes of doing masonry, Mr. Teitelbaum said. Mr. Colon went on disability last summer because of alcohol-related illnesses. Julio Kuong is in a nursing home. He suffered an aneurysm helping someone move furniture, Mr. Otero said. Jorge Subervi opened a grocery store in the Bronx last year.
Before they dispersed, the apprentices did raise up the cathedral's south tower by 50 feet and carve much of its central portal. Cathedral Stoneworks worked on dozens of places around New York and elsewhere, including the Jewish Museum, Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church and Rockefeller Center.
Though the stoneyard is defunct, it brought new blood to the field, and demonstrated that highly skilled conservation work on historical stone buildings was possible.
For the human beings who passed through it, the stoneyard left a profound mark. "It's like it's in your blood, the rhythms, the sound, the smell, the scale of things," said Ms. Robb, who along with Mr. Pellettieri still uses space in the cathedral close, working amid forlorn stacks of partly carved limestone blocks. 
"Everybody loved the cathedral, and it was central to the entire experience," Ms. Robb said. "And that was the thought behind putting this program together: the medieval concept of community. That's what we had.
"And it was gorgeous."

HEADLINE: Turkey Floats Currency, and It Falls 25% 

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS FRANTZ with DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Sixty-five million Turks awakened this morning to find their national currency in a free fall that stripped away more than 25 percent of its value by the end of the day and sent a wave of concern -- but so far no panic -- through many foreign markets.
 While investors and political leaders worried about whether Turkey's financial problems would be contagious, Turks waited for prices to skyrocket and wondered whether the crisis might bring down the government. 
 "Those who are responsible should pay the price," a statement from the Civil Initiative, a coalition of labor unions and business groups, said.
The leaders of the two main opposition parties demanded that Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit resign and call early elections, though few officials or diplomats in Ankara, the capital, expected either. 
The new turmoil resulted from the decision by Turkey -- in hopes of averting a financial meltdown -- to let the value of its currency, the lira, be decided by market forces. The lira had been pegged to a mixture of the dollar and the euro. The decision was announced at 3 a.m. today after a 12-hour meeting of Mr. Ecevit and his senior cabinet members.
In Washington, officials at the United States Treasury and the International Monetary Fund, with bitter memories of the collapse of Thailand's currency in 1997, issued a series of statements intended to calm the markets by expressing support for Turkey's decision to let the currency float.
But in private, these officials were much more critical. American officials noted that in the autumn, before the I.M.F. worked out a $7.5 billion emergency loan deal to support economic change in Turkey, many at the Treasury thought the effort to maintain a fixed exchange rate was doomed. And a senior I.M.F. official said: "There was a lot of doubt that they could make the reforms stick, and that they were playing with global markets they didn't entirely understand. They didn't have the political cohesion to make it work."
The officials noted that there was no evidence of Turkey's problems spreading to other emerging markets.
Here in Istanbul, the financial markets responded quickly and harshly, sending the lira lower even as stock prices rebounded somewhat from Wednesday's decline. The lira had been trading at 685,000 to $1, but by the end of the business day here it dropped to a rate around 925,000 to the dollar. A few hours later in New York, the Turkish currency weakened further, settling at 962,499.
Analysts here said that there were few large currency transactions even at that price and that the volatility made it difficult to determine a fair price for the Turkish lira.
The financial crisis erupted on Monday after a public dispute between Mr. Ecevit and Turkey's president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer. The prime minister left a meeting of senior government officials in a huff after President Sezer accused him and his ministers of not being tough enough on corruption in the banking industry.
With the risk of political instability, interest rates soared and the stock market plummeted, leading to the decision to allow the lira's exchange rate to float to market value.
The decision was a blow to the economic package that the Turkish government instituted a year ago with backing from the International Monetary Fund. Trimming inflation was a key goal, but freeing up the lira is expected to cause a sharp jump in inflation and the cost of imports.
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill were briefed on the crisis early today, and Mr. O'Neill issued a brief statement saying he supported the Turkish government's decision to float the lira. "Turkey is an important ally and good friend of the United States," he said. "The United States continues to back the I.M.F.'s ongoing support for Turkey's economic reform program."
The briefing of General Powell was notable because it indicated that the State Department, mindful of the Mexican and Asian currency crises, was now significantly more sensitive to the possibility that a financial crisis could breed new political and security problems.
The managing director of the I.M.F., Horst Kohler, called on private investors and commercial banks to back Turkey in the financial markets. Mr. Kohler indicated that the lending agency might speed up delivery of the next installments of its $7.5 billion emergency loan.
The biggest fear among many foreign leaders is that Turkey's new round of problems could set off a crisis of confidence in emerging markets elsewhere, leading to investor flight and a repetition of the panic that started with the devaluation of the Thai baht in July 1997 and spread widely.
The decision to free up the lira was part of an effort to stem the outflow of foreign investment capital from Turkey. The nation's central bank spent $7.5 billion of its cash reserves early in the week as investors fled and commercial banks faced difficulty making payments.
On Tuesday, Turkey sold $2.7 billion worth of lira-denominated bonds, which dropped sharply overnight with the devaluation. Some analysts said the lira is likely to bounce back in the coming weeks, but the timing and the level are uncertain. 
The three parties that form the coalition government had staked their political future on curbing Turkey's chronic double-digit inflation and reducing spending. Economists and analysts said there would be pressure to come up with strong new measures to restore investor confidence, but they questioned whether the government had sufficient public trust to demand more sacrifices.
Kamil Yilmaz, an economics professor at Koc University in Istanbul, said: "Working people and fixed-income people have really suffered under the inflation-fighting program, and now they are going to suffer more. They have lost confidence in the government."
Concerns were evident across this city as the lira plummeted. Crowds gathered outside currency exchanges in the busiest neighborhoods and seemed dazed as the currency's value dropped. Many money exchanges refused to sell dollars at any price, encouraging fears that inflation was going to soar again.
"All the prices will jump in a couple of days," said Cevat Demirci, as he surveyed the shelves in his small grocery store near the Bosporus. "The rich will be more rich and the poor will be more poor."
A more immediate concern for the government will be the effect of the floating lira on the country's banks, which are suffering from falling profits and face a wide corruption investigation. Turkey's 80 banks have an estimated $18 billion in open foreign-currency positions.
Indeed today, Deutsche Bank warned, "The currency adjustment and the losses accrued over the past few weeks on the securities portfolio could cause even some large banks to face very serious problems."

HEADLINE: Spy Drama Survivor Watches as Story Unfolds 

BYLINE:  By RALPH BLUMENTHAL 

 BODY:
Boris Yuzhin could be called the third man in the unfolding F.B.I. spy drama, the only survivor of a trio of named Russian agents for the United States who the government says were exposed by Robert Philip Hanssen.
 On Monday, the day before the espionage scandal broke, Mr. Yuzhin received a cryptic call at his home in Northern California. "Watch the news tomorrow," an F.B.I. contact said. 
 And so Mr. Yuzhin, a mild-mannered former Soviet K.G.B. operative who worked secretly for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the 1970's and 80's before being unmasked in Moscow and imprisoned in Siberia, learned with the rest of the world on Tuesday of Mr. Hanssen's arrest. 
"They always catch them on my birthday," Mr. Yuzhin, who turned 59 on Wednesday, told a friend, who later recounted the conversation in an interview. 
It was exactly seven years earlier, on Feb. 21, 1994, that the F.B.I. arrested Aldrich H. Ames, a senior official of the Central Intelligence Agency, and his wife, on charges of selling the Soviet Union and later Russia some of the nation's most sensitive secrets. Although working independently of each other, Mr. Ames and Mr. Hanssen corroborated each other's information for the Russians, the Justice Department has charged. Mr. Ames is serving a life sentence.
In an affidavit in support of the criminal complaint and arrest and search warrants, the F.B.I. named Mr. Yuzhin and two K.G.B. officers in the Soviet Embassy in Washington -- Valery F. Martinov and Sergei M. Motorin -- as having been exposed as American spies by Mr. Ames in 1985 and then several months later by Mr. Hanssen. 
The two senior K.G.B. officers were recalled to Moscow and executed. Mr. Yuzhin, back in Moscow for reassignment, was arrested in 1986 and spent more than five years of a 15-year sentence in Perm 35, a Siberian prison, before being released in an amnesty after the fall of Communism in 1992. 
He later immigrated to the United States and was resettled with the help of the F.B.I. in the San Francisco area, where he had been assigned by the K.G.B. a quarter century ago to monitor student activities and work under the cover of being a Tass correspondent -- and where he decided to volunteer his services to the F.B.I.
Why wasn't he executed? "He was never in residency in the K.G.B. offices," said one of his former F.B.I. handlers. "He was able to convince his interrogators he knew nothing about operations and cases."
Mr. Yuzhin, who first recounted the story of his double-agentry and his arrest to The New York Times in 1994, said yesterday that he did not want to discuss the latest developments, largely over concern with jeopardizing family ties in Russia. He said, however, that he had never met Mr. Hanssen and had long thought that it was Mr. Ames alone who had betrayed him.
Friends of Mr. Yuzhin's, including some longtime F.B.I. agents who worked with him, said he lived with his wife and grown daughter, an occupational therapist, in an attractive house he bought about five years ago in Santa Rosa, Calif. His mother, sister and a married son, an economist, with children of his own, live in Russia. Mr. Yuzhin has not been back to Russia since his release from prison in 1992, but his son and grandchildren come for visits. 
Supported by a modest American government stipend, he writes, does historical research and augments his income with occasional lectures.
According to one listing carried on the Internet, Mr. Yuzhin spoke last October in Palm Springs, Calif., to the Southern California Fraud Investigation Association. His topic: "The Russian Mind."
One project that long absorbed Mr. Yuzhin was researching the cases of other former Soviet prisoners, including Raoul Wallenberg, the anti-Nazi Swedish diplomat who disappeared into the gulag after World War II. Working with an American, Susan Mesinai, in the Ark Project, a human rights organization dedicated to finding lost political prisoners under the Soviets, Mr. Yuzhin helped establish that Mr. Wallenberg did not simply disappear but was secretly held by Soviet authorities until his death in prison, a fact that Russian authorities subsequently acknowledged.
Mr. Yuzhin also worked with Ms. Mesinai and others to track down missing American prisoners, including a defector from the National Security Council, Victor Hamilton, who was found 30 years later, in 1992, in a Soviet psychiatric hospital. 
Friends of Mr. Yuzhin's said that they had encouraged him in recent years to look for other work that would occupy his mind and offer him income but that he found it difficult to find the right thing.
"He's not going to flip burgers," one retired F.B.I. agent said. "His attitude was that he would not start at the bottom."

HEADLINE: Breezy Point Journal; 
Neighborly Place Hits a Sewer Line in the Sand

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW

 BODY:
It might be too simple to blame the whole mess at Breezy Point on the toilet, but it wouldn't be far off.
 There have been arrests, shouting matches, a hunger strike and a $15 million lawsuit. There was an 16-year legal battle that finally drew to a close last month as a judge, quoting Descartes, dismissed the complaints that fueled a sewer imbroglio. 
 Years ago, when the Breezy Point Cooperative, a serene and highly secured gated community on the western tip of the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens, was a summer resort -- known as the Irish Riviera -- there was a lot less toilet flushing. 
But things changed about two decades ago, when many residents of the community, between Jamaica Bay and the Atlantic Ocean, began living there year-round. The summer bungalows were winterized and renovated. New families flocked to buy into the cooperative of 2,800 single-family homes, a kind of seaside suburb in the city, with sandy walkways and hardly any crime.
With the people came, well, heavy flushing, which put a strain on the septic tanks and cesspools. In the mid-1980's, the leadership of the cooperative started studying the possibility of putting in sewers, the cost of doing so, and whether the city, which pays for sewer lines on public property, would foot the bill.
But to Tom Young, a 63-year-old resident and retired firefighter, sewers would be the first step toward rapid development of the 500-acre property, some of the most pristine beachfront in New York.
The issue has become even more contentious because Breezy Point is actually growing wider, raising the prospect that developers would seek the new property. The area gained more than 100 acres in the last four decades, as the ocean's westward drift moved sand from Fire Island and the Hamptons to its shores.
But Breezy Point officials have consistently said there are no plans to further develop the property. Mr. Young won't buy it. "You been down to Atlantic City?" he said recently, as he stood on the cooperative's half-mile-wide beach, with the World Trade Center just a speck in the distance. "It's all high-rises. They built right up on the sand."
In 1991, a narrow majority of the residents rejected the idea of installing sewers. But the case was far from closed. Mr. Young, who claims that he was harassed and assaulted by residents and cooperative leaders for his vociferous crusade against sewers, sued the cooperative in 1985 and sought $15 million in punitive damages. 
In 1987, the cooperative, whose chairman then was the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, who owns a summer home there, sued Mr. Young for abuse of process, alleging that he was misusing the judicial system to oppose sewers. 
The two cases, which were combined into one, dragged on for years, with Mr. Young going on a two-day hunger strike last spring and standing outside the State Supreme Court courthouse in Kew Gardens demanding a trial. The case went to trial last fall. Then, in December, Mr. Young was arrested and charged with threatening Mr. Hynes, saying he was going to "get" the district attorney. Mr. Young, who denied saying that, was released without bail. 
Justice Thomas V. Polizzi dismissed the case last month, saying that although Mr. Young had "exhibited a total disrespect of the judicial system," the cooperative had not proved that Mr. Young had abused the legal system. Mr. Young said he planned to appeal.
Cooperative officials declined through their general counsel, Robert E. Lee, to discuss the case and possible sewer plans.
But in a newsletter distributed to residents last spring, the cooperative's chairman, John V. Hudson, said, "We must explore every possible avenue for obtaining public funds to pay for the installation of a sewer system."
The city would probably pay for a main sewer line along the public road that runs through the cooperative. But to secure city money to attach houses to the sewer main, the cooperative would have to make the streets, many of which have individual gates that require access cards to enter, public property, said Charles G. Sturcken, chief of staff at the city's Department of Environmental Protection.
Mr. Sturcken said city officials had met with cooperative officials several times but were unable to agree on a plan.
Residents of Breezy Point jealously guard their privacy and few would speak with a reporter about the sewer situation. But those who did said the crux of the issue was cost, not Mr. Young's fears of development.
"We're not expanding into the dunes," said Rita Shea, a retired marketing consultant and a sewer supporter who turned her summer home into a year-round home in 1989. "I think we're dealing with economics. And it's like anything else you do to improve the community. You do it to make your life better, not because you want to become something you never were before."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Children walk home along Bedford Avenue, one of many private pathways through Breezy Point. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hartford Worst in National Study Of Births to Unmarried Mothers 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
The statistics tell the damning story of this city: nearly 80 percent of all babies born in 1998 had single mothers, double the national average and 10 times the state average. A quarter of all births were to teenage mothers, and a quarter of those teenagers had given birth before. 
 In each category, Hartford topped a list of 55 cities included in a nationwide child health report published Tuesday by the Annie E. Casey Foundation in Baltimore. The survey, which also included statistics for New York City, New York State and New Jersey, further illustrated Hartford's decade-long struggle to overcome social and economic problems that public health experts and elected officials have not been able to solve. 
 "What this report suggests is that the state and city elected officials have done the worst job in the nation, of these 55 communities, tending the needs of Hartford," said Paul Gionfriddo, executive director of the Connecticut Association for Human Services in Hartford, which helped the foundation compile its report. "For Hartford, it is as dismal a picture that could be imagined."
Hartford's rankings were no surprise to Gov. John G. Rowland, said his spokesman, Dean Pagani. "He's known for some time that Hartford and some other cities in the state lag behind the rest of the country," Mr. Pagani said. 
Asked what the state could do to improve child health in Hartford, Mr. Pagani noted that the governor, a resident of the city's far west end, has made urban renewal a focus of his administration's second term.
"The governor thinks that the place where you can have the biggest impact is the schools," he said, especially in combination with job-training programs that help residents rise above poverty. 
Asked if there were cultural reasons for Hartford's high rates of single mothers and teenage pregnancies, Mr. Pagani said, "From the governor's point of view, he's more interested in fixing the problems than looking at what caused them."
The foundation's report, "The Right Start," used 1998 data to rank the 50 states, the nation's 50 largest cities and 5 others -- Hartford; Des Moines; Louisville, Ky.; Providence, R.I.; and Savannah, Ga. The report was based on eight child health indicators, including the number of births to teenagers, births to unmarried mothers of all ages and the prevalence of low birth weights and prenatal care. The data, the latest available, were taken from the National Center for Health Statistics in Hyattsville, Md., an arm of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 
The report is a part of the Annie E. Casey Foundation's larger annual Kids Count survey, due in May. 
In contrast to Hartford, a chronically impoverished city of 128,000 that is the capital of the nation's wealthiest state, statistics for Connecticut as a whole showed that it had the fifth-lowest percentage of births to teenage and single mothers. In fact, for seven of the eight indicators used in the survey, Connecticut's ranking was better than the national average and better than the rankings for New York and New Jersey. 
New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were among the states with the lowest percentage of births to teenage mothers, but in most other categories, such as the number of low-birthweight babies and the prevalence of births to mothers who received late or no prenatal care, New York and New Jersey were slightly worse than the national average. Likewise, while New York City had a relatively low number of births by teenage mothers and a low rate of births to mothers who smoke, it ranked in the middle of the city survey for most of the indicators. 
The report did not report statistics for any cities in New Jersey.
William P. O'Hare, the director of the Kids Count program, said New York City's constant flow of immigrants, who tend to marry quickly and stay in the city for years afterward, helped the city avoid the child health problems evident in Hartford, where financial investment is fleeting and residents have long tended to leave for jobs in places with brighter prospects. 
"There's a strong correlation between poverty and negative birth outcomes," Mr. O'Hare said today.
The grip of teenage motherhood and poverty develops into an insidious cycle, he said. According to the foundation's 1999 Kids Count report, a child born to an unmarried teenage high school dropout is 10 times as likely to be living in poverty as a child born to a mother with none of these three characteristics. 
Katherine McCormick, Hartford's health director, said the city's high number of pregnant teenagers could be attributed to a mixture of causes, including poverty, school dropout rates and cultural factors.
But she disputed the accuracy of some of the foundation's statistics regarding teenage pregnancies in Hartford, saying the majority of those were for women 18 or 19 years old, not for girls 13 to 17 years old. If the city's teenage birth numbers were broken down by age, she added, they would show that the percentage for girls 17 and younger is 10.8 percent, a less troubling figure than the 24.8 percent listed in the report for all teenage mothers.
Eloisa Hernandez, the director of the Association for Children of New Jersey, a child advocacy group in Newark, said a pregnant teenager was a problem at any age. 
"These are kids who are more than likely still in high school, more than likely under their parents' roof, and more than likely not able to properly care for a child," she said.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Approves Budget, Putting Capital Plan in Motion 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday approved a $4.6 billion budget for 2001, from which it will begin spending on a $14 billion, five-year capital plan that is the largest in the agency's history.
 Officials of the bistate agency said the agency would spend $2.05 billion of the new budget to begin buying new PATH trains, modernizing airports, dredging harbor channels and improving bridges and tunnels. 
 Much of the rest of the capital plan will be financed by issuing bonds that will be repaid from proceeds of the higher bridge and tunnel tolls and PATH train fares that the agency approved last month. 
Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the agency board that approved the budget, said the agency planned to "take on the most ambitious agenda in its 80-year history." 
The capital program is expected to generate 15,000 jobs, largely in the construction industry, and generate about $2.3 billion in economic activity. "The Port Authority's 2001 budget provides funds to improve the commutes of millions of New York and New Jersey residents as well as the airports and seaports on which our region depends," said Robert E. Boyle, the agency's executive director.
In approving the budget, the agency also reported that it had amassed reserves of $1.6 billion in 2000 and had net revenue of $2.6 billion. Traffic volume at bridge and tunnel crossings was 1.6 percent higher than in 1999, agency officials said, while PATH ridership increased by 10 percent. The passenger traffic at La Guardia, Kennedy International and Newark International Airports was 92.6 million in 2000, an increase of 3.3 million. 
The amount of spending devoted to long-term capital projects this year is nearly double that spent on capital programs last year, when the Port Authority was embroiled in a dispute between New York and New Jersey representatives on the agency's board over allocation of its funds. 
The dispute was resolved last June, paving the way for the toll and fare increases, and the start of the ambitious five-year plan.
Included in the spending approved yesterday was $30 million to soundproof 21 New York schools and 12 New Jersey schools affected by aircraft noise at the three commercial airports and the one general aviation airport, Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, that the agency operates. The program is jointly financed by the Port Authority and the Federal Aviation Administration, which pays 80 percent of the cost.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Oracle defies wisdom by using itself to pitch its software products.

BYLINE:  By Bernard Stamler 

 BODY:
THEY are hardly an advertising novelty, but whether they are offered by movie celebrities, sports stars or plain citizens, testimonials are usually about products that are made by third-party companies and not by the person who is delivering the pitch. 
 Except for weight-loss gurus, toupee salesmen and the occasional iconoclastic maker of vacuum cleaners or electric razors, hardly any advertisers promote their experiences with their wares as proof of their merit. Who, after all, would believe them? 
 Enter Oracle, the software company in Redwood City, Calif., that is second only to Microsoft in size and the industry leader when it comes to database or information-management products. Instead of using software from 10 or more companies and having to spend the time, and the money, to integrate them, Oracle says it has saved more than $1 billion over the last year by using its E-Business Suite of software in its business operations. 
And, says Mark Jarvis, Oracle's worldwide chief marketing officer, the company is so proud of this accomplishment that it is defying common wisdom by making its experience the centerpiece of its advertising campaign. It is an effort that is costing $100 million worldwide, $40 million in the United States, Mr. Jarvis said, and was highlighted by two recent conferences, both titled AppsWorld 2001.
The campaign began last fall with direct mail, direct e-mail and Internet banners. In print, it has appeared in technical publications and many with a more general business focus, including Business Week, The Economist, The Financial Times and The Wall Street Journal.
The print ads are simple, with black-and-white type and only a few lines and the name Oracle printed in red. One ad sets forth, in chart form, 10 applications that Oracle's software can handle, together with the names of 10 vendors, listed alongside, to whose nonintegrated software the tasks might otherwise be entrusted. 
"Oracle saved $1 billion in 1 year," the ad states. "How much will you save?"
Another ad, following the same form, omits the $1 billion figure but provides additional details about Oracle's assertions on its software. It is "engineered to work together," the ad says. "Systems Integration costs a lot more than software. Think about it."
In an age when many advertisers seek attention by shocking consumers or by using drama, the straightforwardness of the Oracle ads is striking. It is also deliberate, said Dave Tutin, executive vice president and executive creative director at the San Francisco office of Grey Worldwide, part of the Grey Global Group, the agency handling the Oracle account. He and Casey Jones, executive vice president and managing director for technology at Grey, are in charge of the campaign.
"The ads are laser-focused at the most rational business-decision-making part of customers' brains," Mr. Jones said. The idea is to underscore the simplicity of the concept with ads that are equally simple and direct.
"What Oracle is selling," Mr. Tutin said, "is the corporate equivalent of plug and play."
That is also the message at the conferences, both sponsored by Oracle, Mr. Jarvis said. The first, for European clients of the company, was two weeks ago in Paris. The second, for North American customers, began in New Orleans on Monday and is scheduled to end today. 
Mr. Jarvis said yesterday that 6,200 people had attended the conference in Paris and 11,000 were in New Orleans, where they were able to talk with one another and hear Oracle's praises sung by industry luminaries like Marc Andreessen, a founder of Netscape Communications, and John Chambers, president of Cisco Systems, the computer network company. And it was not all business; in New Orleans, conference highlights included a speech by former President Bill Clinton and a concert featuring the Bangles and Third Eye Blind.
The total cost, not including advertising, was about $10 million for the New Orleans event and $2 million to $3 million for the one in Paris, although Oracle expected to break even after receiving registration fees of up to $1,000 a participant as well as exhibitor and sponsorship fees from companies like Hewlett-Packard and Compaq Computer. It was worth the effort, Mr. Jarvis said.
"We are absolutely delighted by the success of AppsWorld," he said yesterday. "And next year will be twice as good."

CORRECTION-DATE: February 27, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about a campaign for Oracle software, misstated the affiliation of Dave Tutin at the agency handling the account. He is executive vice president and executive creative director of Grey Worldwide, New York, which is part of the Grey Global Group -- not of Grey Worldwide's San Francisco office.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
System Is Planned to Send Prescriptions Electronically
Three companies that operate most of the nation's managed-care drug plans agreed to establish a joint system to make it easier for doctors to send prescriptions to pharmacies electronically or over the Internet.
 The companies -- AdvancePCS, Express Scripts and Merck-Medco -- said the system would increase safety by reducing mistakes and misunderstandings. They said it would also save time and money for doctors, pharmacies and health plans. Page C2. 

Auction Settlement Is Approved
A federal judge gave final approval to a $512 million settlement of the lawsuit against the Sotheby's and Christie's auction houses by customers who said they were cheated in a years-long price-fixing conspiracy. The approval begins to close one chapter in a scandal that has roiled the secretive and rarefied art and auction world for more than a year. Judge Lewis A. Kaplan called the settlement "eminently reasonable by any standard." Shares of Sotheby's Holdings fell 49 cents, to $23.86. C10.

Nasdaq Finishes at a Two-Year Low
Technology stocks were shaken by more signs of weak profits, dragging the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest point in more than two years. The Nasdaq composite index fell 23.98 points, or 1 percent, to 2,244.96. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up just 0.23 point, to 10,526.81, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost 2.45 points, to 1,252.82. C5.

Two Sentenced in Income Tax Case
A California couple who helped people evade at least $13.8 million in federal income taxes were sentenced to long prison terms, sentences the judge extended after they both said that tax laws did not apply to them. C11.

Change Urged in Air Traffic Control
Eight former top-ranking aviation and transportation officials said in a letter that the Federal Aviation Administration would never be able to cope with growing air traffic control problems and that the government should give the job to a nonprofit corporation. A13.

Leading Indicators Increase 0.8%
The index of leading economic indicators edged up 0.8 percent in January, after three consecutive months of steady decline, indicating that the economy is cooling off rather than tipping into a full-fledged recession. C10.

Rise and Fall of Korean Tycoon
The meteoric rise of Kim Woo Choong, the founder of the Daewoo industrial empire, as one of Korea's most powerful tycoons and his equally spectacular fall have come to symbolize both the Korean miracle and the prolonged crisis that threatened to blow it all apart in 1997 and still hangs over the economic landscape. World Business, Section W.

UBS Warburg Hires Key Executive
UBS Warburg took another step toward raising the profile of its United States investment banking business by hiring Jeffrey A. Sine, a key executive from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. His hiring comes three months after UBS recruited Kenneth Moelis, a top deal maker at Credit Suisse First Boston. C11.

Recall Erodes Bridgestone Profit
Bridgestone of Japan said that its fiscal year profit tumbled 80 percent as a result of its sweeping recall of Firestone tires in the United States. World Business, Section W.

Optimism for Telecommunications
While the financial markets remain pessimistic about the mobile communications business, telecommunications suppliers are showing no signs of retreat at the 3GSM World Congress in France, where more than 14,000 people have converged. World Business, Section W.

Weak Sales Hurt Two Retailers
Weak holiday sales led to a second consecutive quarterly loss at J. C. Penney and a 59 percent decline in profit at Nordstrom. C12.

HEADLINE: Sub Accident Shakes Japan's Security Ties With U.S. 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
When George W. Bush won the White House, people on both sides of the Pacific predicted that the new administration's plans to give greater emphasis to relations with Japan would usher in an era of closer security ties.
 But before the Bush administration's plans could take shape, the accidental sinking this month of a Japanese fishing vessel by an American submarine off Hawaii has decisively shifted the landscape in one of the United States' most important military alliances. 
 Not only has the incident provided new ammunition to those who resent the American troop presence here, but it has also reinforced the perception in some quarters that the United States is a less than reliable guarantor of Japan's security interests. This sentiment could accelerate the trend of recent years toward a more independent defense posture, with Japan less willing to follow Washington's lead in the region and rethinking its longstanding restrictions on the use of military force. 
The latest revelations about the circumstances surrounding the sinking of the Ehime Maru on Feb. 9, in which nine people are still missing and presumed dead, unleashed new anger today in Japan.
Reports that the ship had been detected an hour before the submarine Greeneville surfaced and struck it indicate "grave negligence" by the American crew, said the chief cabinet secretary, Yasuo Fukuda, adding that the Japanese government could press for "strict disciplinary steps on the U.S. side."
His comments came against the backdrop of demands by many politicians for a new, much stricter Status of Forces Agreement, which governs the legal rights of the 47,000 American soldiers in Japan.
Those in Okinawa, the southern island province where most American troops are based, have stepped up their longstanding demands for a reduction in American forces. Today, for the first time, Okinawa's governor, Keiichi Inamine, joined those calls.
And Kantoku Teruyu, a member of Parliament from Okinawa, said: "The reduction of the marines' presence is the general desire of the Okinawan people. The marines can go somewhere else, and conduct their drills in Guam and Hawaii. We cannot accept the presence of the Americans here as inevitable."
Beyond angry words like those, primarily inspired by a spate of crimes committed over the years by American soldiers in Okinawa, many here feel that the Ehime Maru sinking will make it far more difficult for Tokyo and Washington to pursue the enhanced security collaboration envisioned by some Bush advisers.
Instead, some say, the fallout from the accident could encourage Japan to push for more autonomy in security matters and bolster its military. 
"The public increasingly feels that Japan cannot fulfill its defense obligations anymore," said Masashi Nishihara, president of Japan's National Defense Academy. But then he listed some of the steps Tokyo has taken lately to strenghten its armed forces.
"A couple of years ago we decided to launch our own intelligence-gathering satellite," he said. "We have launched a large transport ship, which some people have claimed is a kind of aircraft carrier. And we have just approved purchase of in-flight refueling tankers, which expand Japan's defense perimeter."
"Of course," he added, "the government doesn't talk about a defense perimeter, but says that it is meant to increase our ability to support peacekeeping operations."
Under its post-World War II Constitution, written in large part by the United States, Japan is prohibited from any military activity except self-defense. Despite this, Japan has long boasted one of the world's largest military budgets, and its 237,000-member Self-Defense Forces easily rank among the world's most capable military establishments. 
Significantly, many of Japan's major new weapons systems, which include a fleet of antisubmarine aircraft, increase the country's ability to project force.
Late last year, in a widely circulated report, a bipartisan group of American scholars and defense experts headed by Richard L. Armitage, now Mr. Bush's deputy secretary of state, called Japan's military restrictions "a constraint on alliance cooperation," and urged Tokyo "to become a more equal alliance partner."
But Washington jealously guards its leadership role in the alliance, as seen by its unease when Tokyo decided to develop its own intellience-gathering satellite rather than buy one from the United States or rely entirely on American intelligence.
"Some of the displeasure about the satellite intelligence one also picks up about the antisubmarine aircraft," said Benjamin Self, senior associate at Henry L. Stimson Center, a research group in Washington. "You hear questions like, 'Why aren't they investing more in the alliance?' "
"But as long as Japan is operating in the model of very light Gaullism," he added, referring to France's more independent status in NATO, "I think the Armitage team is willing to swallow that and say: 'Oh well, O.K., we trust you. You recognize that the alliance is the best guarantee of your security.' "
Shingo Shuto, director general of defense policy in Japan's Defense Agency, would not comment on the Armitage report, except to say, "During the Clinton administration we were already enjoying very close cooperation over security guidelines, and we expect a continuing strengthening of the relationship."
The last decade has been a very trying time for Japan's national image and sense of security, however, and not just because of the country's shrinking population and economic doldrums.
Throughout this period, China has loomed ever larger as a military and economic rival and potential superpower, while even tiny North Korea, with its medium-range missiles and possible nuclear arms ability, has emerged as a threat. 
While no mainstream Japanese politician openly opposes the alliance with the United States, some are beginning to suggest that, in a world that looks increasingly insecure, it is not enough.
"Let me ask you a question: What would the United States do if China were to attack Japan?" said Tsuyoshi Yamaguchi, a member of Parliament. "We cannot totally depend on Washington. That era is coming to an end, and Japan must do more to ensure its own survival."
Others, however, played down the need for greater autonomy, and praised the Armitage report as a reasonable road map for increased cooperation.
"I would say that U.S. bases in Japan will never leave -- unless Americans go back to the isolationist principles of the Monroe era, said Kazuhisa Ogawa, an independent Japanese defense analyst, "because, of the 50-plus countries that are the United States' allies, only Japan is a power-projection platform." 
"Japan is supporting the activities of the United States military from Hawaii to Cape Town," he said. "And if Japan nullified the alliance, the U.S. would never have that kind of platform again."
He added: "But America is also the most valuable country to Japan. For Japan's national interest, it should learn to make use of America more. Not in the conventional way of America proposing and Japan always responding, but by Japan coming up with ideas and proposals sometimes and letting the United States consider whether or not it likes them, too."

HEADLINE: BUSH FAULTS CHINA ON ITS AID TO IRAQ FOR RADAR SYSTEM 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that evidence of China's aid to Iraq in building radar systems to use against American and British warplanes had "risen to the level where we are going to send a message to the Chinese," a statement that put Mr. Bush at odds with Beijing only four weeks into his presidency.
 Mr. Bush made the comments during his first solo news conference at the White House, called somewhat hastily today so Mr. Bush could sum up his first month in office before an address to Congress next week. 
 While he repeated his call for tax cuts and his education program, he also used the moment to declare that last Friday's bombing of the radar sites -- which the Pentagon said was timed to avoid killing Chinese workers there -- was intended to send a "clear signal" to Saddam Hussein and to reduce the capacity of Iraqi radar. Excerpts, Page A10. 
"I believe we succeeded in both those missions," Mr. Bush said, although new indications from the Pentagon suggest that the bombing was not as effective as American officials had initially stated.
While Mr. Bush's harshest words were reserved for Iraq, he struck a tough tone with China saying, "It's troubling that they'd be involved in helping Iraq develop a system that will endanger our pilots."
Two hours later, Mr. Bush's national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, softened the president's statement a bit. She said the White House and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell had sent inquiries to Beijing through the new Chinese ambassador here, Yang Jiechi. "I want to make clear that we are not accusing, at this point, the Chinese of anything," she said. "But we are telling them that we have tremendous concerns about what's going on."
Ms. Rice said that China had not yet responded to the inquiries. But in Beijing a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said, "China, as a permanent member of the U.N. Security Council, has always strictly and seriously implemented all the resolutions of the Security Council concerning Iraq."
American military and intelligence officials say that Chinese workers are helping Iraq build a fiber optic communications network that links the radar stations and other targets attacked by American and British warplanes last Friday.
The Chinese actions could violate United Nations sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait in 1990, administration officials said. 
The confrontation with Beijing puts a chill on Mr. Bush's first high-level exchanges with the Chinese leadership. Only a week ago he exchanged polite introductory letters with President Jiang Zemin in which both leaders described in the most general terms their goals for their relationship.
The Chinese know the Bush family well: Mr. Bush's father was the American representative in Beijing before the two countries opened diplomatic relations, and Mr. Bush spent six weeks there in the 1970's, his longest stay abroad.
Now Mr. Bush's stance suggests that the United States and China may be headed to tougher exchanges, after the Clinton administration had finally succeeded in repairing most of the diplomatic damage done by the accidental American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade during NATO's air war against Serbia in 1999.
In its first weeks, the new administration has signaled that it will sponsor a resolution condemning China's human rights violations at an annual conference in Geneva. And it has promised to go ahead with a national missile defense plan despite China's vehement opposition and its promises to build up its own nuclear forces to defeat the system.
In his appearance today, Mr. Bush seemed by turns relaxed and somewhat uneasy, especially when the subject turned to problems in foreign policy. He also used the event to argue anew for his tax cut proposal, which will be the subject of an address to Congress on Tuesday.
While Mr. Bush claimed that the raids on Friday against Iraqi air defenses served as a warning on Mr. Hussein, Iraqi forces appear undaunted. They continued to fire at American and British jets patrolling the no-flight zones over southern and northern Iraq, including those that flew today. 
In fact, an American fighter jet attacked a missile defense battery today near Mosul, in northern Iraq. The strike was carried out against a French-made mobile antiaircraft battery purchased before the gulf war. It was not specifically authorized by President Bush but was carried out under standing orders that the pilots can defend themselves when they feel threatened by Iraqi forces in the no-flight zones.
Pentagon officials have said last week's attacks -- against 20 to 24 radar sites and five to seven command or communication centers at five sites ---- disrupted Iraq's air defenses, but they acknowledge that the damage was moderate.
The mixed success was attributed to problems with the Joint Standoff Weapon, or J-SOW. Navy F/A-18's fired more than two dozen of the relatively new J-SOW's at radar stations but "the vast majority" missed their precise targets, a military official said.
That was in sharp contrast to the early reports from Lt. Gen. Gregory S. Newbold, director of operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who said on Friday after the raid, "We have no indications that there were any of the strikes that might have gone amiss."
Pentagon officials said the strikes had weakened Iraq's air defenses, and a spokesman said today that only two of the radars attacked had resumed tracking allied patrols.
He said the Pentagon had still not completed an assessment of the damage, but other officials said the raids had severely damaged five command or communications sites. In the case of the radar sites, which included some mobile systems, the success was less clear. One official said only that more than half showed damage visible from aerial or satellite photographs. 
General Powell leaves for the Middle East on Friday, and the president said today that piecing together a consensus on how to rebuild a coalition to isolate Iraq is high on the agenda.
"The secretary of state is going to go listen to our allies as to how best to effect a policy, the primary goal of which will be to say to Saddam Hussein, 'We won't tolerate you developing weapons of mass destruction and we expect you to leave your neighbors alone.' "
But he conceded, as he did in an interview last month, that "the sanction regime is like Swiss cheese."
