HEADLINE: Quiet on the Lobbying Front; 
Sudden Halt to Coalition's Bid for Corporate Tax Breaks

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 

 BODY:
With a determined tax cutter moving into the White House and Republicans still in charge on Capitol Hill, the stage seemed set early this year for Charls E. Walker to help lower the taxes paid by corporate America once again.
 The most enduring and perhaps best known of the scores of lobbyists who push tax cuts for business, Mr. Walker began making plans for a major effort to rally corporations around tax breaks that could be added to President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax reduction plan. 
 He had reason for optimism when he was invited to the White House a few weeks ago for lunch with President Bush and a group of executives. Not only had he helped shape tax legislation as a government official and lobbyist for four decades, but he was well connected to the new administration. 
At 77, he had been friend, adviser and political supporter of three generations of Bushes, including the current president. The new Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, had served on the board of Mr. Walker's research and advocacy group, the American Council for Capital Formation. He counted Vice President Dick Cheney an ally.
But within days after that lunch at the White House on Feb. 7, Mr. Walker, who has been fine-tuning his political antennae in Washington since the Eisenhower administration, came to an unexpected conclusion: now is not the time to press hard for business tax cuts.
The reason was not opposition from Democrats or infighting among business groups or the possibility of a populist reaction against special-interest tax breaks -- all factors that have complicated or doomed prior efforts to cut corporate taxes.
This time, the roadblock was Mr. Bush. As he settled on a strategy for promoting his tax cut, which would direct its benefits overwhelmingly to individuals, Mr. Bush sent the message that he would not countenance changing or enlarging his proposal, and was willing to use the powers of his office against anyone who defied him.
"I have made it clear to the business interests that the best tax policy is one that reduces taxes on the people," Mr. Bush told a news conference at the White House today. "I hope they listen to me, and I hope they help me get the tax plan through that I have proposed." 
For Mr. Bush, taking a hard line is a way to signal that he is serious about enacting the tax package he promised voters during the campaign. Some business executives say they suspect they have become a politically convenient foil for the administration, which by standing up to corporate lobbying can portray itself as the defender of the ordinary taxpayer and as intent on keeping the tax bill from becoming fiscally irresponsible.
In any case, Mr. Bush's strategy has left Mr. Walker and other proponents of reducing corporate taxes in a bind.
Disinclined to take on a new president whose ideology is generally in sync with their own, they have gone out of their way to pledge support to Mr. Bush's plan. But they have also made clear that they are not completely giving up, either, on the kinds of broad tax relief Mr. Walker is seeking or on the specific tax breaks for companies and industries that other lobbyists are pushing.
Mr. Walker said his coalition had gone into research mode, assembling arguments to back up its efforts so it would be ready to strike if and when Mr. Bush backed down or another tax bill came along.
"It's a matter of timing," Mr. Walker said. "It also reflects a very significant change in the atmosphere with respect to the president's ability to keep his tax bill clean."
"There's been a significant lineup of support in the business community of groups that earlier were planning to hit the Hill pretty strongly, where they have now said they will wait," he added.
As Congress prepares to begin work in earnest on what could be the biggest tax cut in two decades, Mr. Walker's judgment is widely -- though not universally -- shared among trade groups and lobbying firms in Washington that until recently had regarded this year as a golden opportunity to reduce taxes on business.
"The business community is waiting at the corral door," said Bob Packwood, the former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee who is now a lobbyist. "If the gate opens and the herd is coming out, they want to get on a horse, too. But they're not going to open the gate, especially with the president saying he'll drill the first guy who tries."
The White House has been blunt to business. Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, met recently with some executives about taxes. Ignoring criticism from Democrats that the president's plan would primarily benefit the wealthy, Mr. Lindsey told the executives that Mr. Bush was intent on focusing his tax cut on the needs of the single mother struggling to make it into the middle class.
"I went around the room and asked them if any of their pet ideas were more important than solving her problem," Mr. Lindsey recounted. "No one raised a hand. If you look at the priorities the president laid out, they are the right priorities."
The situation is one of the trickier to have faced Mr. Walker since he set up shop as a lobbyist in the early 1970's after a stint as deputy Treasury secretary in the Nixon administration and an earlier tour in the Treasury Department at the end of the Eisenhower administration.
Mr. Walker's first big triumph was in helping shepherd through Congress in 1978 a reduction in the top capital gains rate to 28 percent from an effective rate of 50 percent.
Three years later he played a critical role in shaping the main business provisions in President Ronald Reagan's 1981 tax bill, the establishment of an investment tax credit and a depreciation schedule that stepped up the pace at which companies could write off their capital investments. Although they were later scaled back, the business provisions eliminated taxes for many companies and added up to as much as $50 billion a year in tax savings.
The next big tax bill, in 1986, was a major defeat for Mr. Walker, however. The bill reduced individual income tax rates, but also repealed the investment tax credit, effectively increasing the tax bill for many companies. "I got my butt beat," Mr. Walker said.
Mr. Walker helped build support in Congress for the provision in the 1997 bipartisan budget deal that reduced the top capital gains rate to 20 percent from 28 percent.
In recent years, Mr. Walker has stopped lobbying for clients. And he has gradually scaled back his involvement in the American Council for Capital Formation, which he founded in 1974 to develop economic research in favor of tax cuts and serve as an umbrella group for trade associations and companies who want to promote corporate tax reductions. He has largely turned over management of the council to his longtime No. 2, Mark Bloomfield.
When the council's board met in Washington on Dec. 13, Mr. Walker decided to skip it and remain at his winter home in Georgia. With Mr. Bush's victory having only become final the previous evening, the board quickly decided that it should mount a substantial effort on behalf of corporate tax reductions. 
Members of the board called Mr. Walker and urged him to jump back into the fray. He immediately agreed.
"I said if I had anything left in strength, skills and contacts, I should do it," Mr. Walker said.
In addition to having a Republican back in the White House, Mr. Walker had another factor working in his favor as he began to plot strategy: the pent-up demand for business tax cuts is considerable. 
Small-business groups are seeking to make health insurance premiums fully deductible for self-employed people, up from 60 percent today, and to repeal a surtax on employers that helps finance unemployment compensation. 
Technology companies are pressing for tax credits to help pay for the broadband networks that provide high-speed Internet access. 
Financial services companies want to expand the individual retirement account and 401(k) retirement savings programs. Multinational corporations want a change in the way their foreign subsidiaries are taxed in the United States. The National Association of Manufacturers wants repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax and an acceleration of the rate at which companies can write off their investments in capital equipment.
Some of the proposals sought by business groups would be very expensive. An acceleration in the write-off schedule, especially for technology equipment, could reduce federal revenue by $250 billion or more over the next decade. The expansion of the retirement programs would cost more than $50 billion over 10 years.
The one significant tax break for business included in Mr. Bush's plan -- the permanent extension of the credit for research and development expenses -- is valued at $30 billion over 10 years.
But from Mr. Walker's perspective, the danger was that business would not be able to present a united front, and would end up fighting with itself over whose favorite provisions made it into the tax bill.
So along with Mr. Bloomfield, the council's president, Mr. Walker decided to try to put together a coalition of business interests that could unite behind a limited set of tax issues.
"We wanted a proposal that would make economic sense," Mr. Bloomfield said. "It would attract all sectors of the corporate community. It would be revenue-responsible. And it would help avoid a Christmas tree," when a tax bill becomes so laden with special-interest provisions that it runs the risk of collapsing under its own weight.
To appeal to Wall Street, they included the proposal to expand the retirement savings programs, and they signed up Marc Lackritz, president of the Securities Industry Association, as coalition co-chairman.
To attract multinational corporations, they decided to seek a change that would limit corporate income taxes levied in the United States to income generated in this country. And to give their efforts as broad a cast as possible, they included in their agenda a call for a reduction in the maximum corporate income tax rate to 25 percent from 35 percent, or an acceleration in business depreciation.
The hope was that the coalition would be a vehicle for bringing together other groups and companies with similar views. But within a week after announcing the coalition on Feb. 6, Mr. Walker made his decision that the political terrain had become too uncertain to push ahead aggressively.
Some lobbyists say Mr. Bush may need help from business groups to get his proposal through the evenly divided Senate, help that could translate into a chance to insert some favorable provisions in the bill. Others say members of Congress will inevitably begin attaching pet ideas to Mr. Bush's bill in response to pressure from constituents and contributors, setting off a free-for-all.
Having seen presidents and members of Congress come and go for four decades, Mr. Walker says he can afford to be patient.
"We'll be ready with our studies and models if and when the opportunity to move ahead occurs," Mr. Walker said. "If the dam breaks, all I will say now is that we would have to reconsider our position."

HEADLINE: Transcript of President Bush's White House News Conference 

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

MR. BUSH
 Good afternoon. It's been about a month now since I've taken office. And I thought it appropriate to come by and have a press conference. 
 Before I do so, though, I'd like to make a few comments. One of my missions has been to change the tone here in the nation's capital to encourage civil discourse. I think we're making pretty good progress. I want to thank the Democrats and the Republicans who have been coming up to the White House to hear me make my case. I appreciate their responsiveness. 
I just hope they vote for my agenda that I'll be submitting next week in a budget address to the Congress. I have a reasonable and balanced budget. It meets growing needs with a responsible rate of increase in spending. It funds priorities. 
And my administration has no higher priority than education. Yesterday I announced that the Department of Education will receive the largest percentage increase of any department in the federal government, a little more than 11 percent increase. But with new money will come high expectations. We must insist on results and support programs that work. It is in the best interest of American children that we reform our public schools by having strong accountability at its core. 
Our budget will honor commitments of America's senior citizens. Social Security and Medicare funds will be protected for Social Security and Medicare. We're now spending $216 billion on Medicare. Under my budget, Medicare spending will increase by more than $21 billion in 2002. My budget also locks away $2.6 trillion of the $5.6 trillion surplus for Social Security over the next 10 years. 
Our budget is fiscally responsible. If enacted, it will reduce debt by an unprecedented amount over the next four years. Altogether, about 60 percent of the projected federal surplus will be used to fund priorities and to reduce debt. 
After we've funded our priorities, after we have paid down an unprecedented amount of debt, we'll still have money left over. Which leaves us with two options: First is to spend it on bigger government, or return it to the taxpayers who earned it. I believe it should be returned to the taxpayers. It's the people's money and the government ought to be passing it back after it's met priorities. 
It's also necessary because these are uncertain times -- increasing layoffs, growing consumer debt, lower consumer confidence. And lower taxes will help our economy. 
This will be a responsible and fair budget that reflects the nation's priorities. 
I invite the American people to listen to what I have to say to the Congress. I'd be glad to answer any questions you have.

QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS

Q. Mr. President, in light of the latest spy scandal, should a senior F.B.I. official be required to take polygraph tests? And secondly, what, if any, responsibility should the F.B.I. director, Louis Freeh, bear for this breach of national security?

MR. BUSH. I have confidence in Director Freeh. I think he does a good job. I have confidence in the men and women who work at the F.B.I. I am deeply concerned about the current spy case, as is Director Freeh. He has made the right move in selecting Judge Webster to review all procedures in the F.B.I., to make sure that this doesn't happen again. We ought to be concerned about espionage in America. In the statement I made the other day, I said we will be diligent; we will find spies and we will prosecute them. I am pleased that they caught the spy. Now the courts must act.

Q. Do we need polygraphs so we'll be able to catch ----

MR. BUSH. I look forward to seeing what Judge Webster has to say. I presume he's going to review that issue and will make a recommendation to the director and to me.

Presidential Pardons

Q. Do you believe that pardons were for sale in the Clinton White House? And what, specifically, do you think should be done to look into, to investigate, the circumstances of the president's brother-in-law accepting money to lobby him on pardons?

MR. BUSH. As far as this White House is concerned, it's time to go forward. I've got too much to do -- to get a budget passed, to get reforms passed for education, to get a tax cut passed, to strengthen the military -- than to be worrying about decisions that my predecessor made. I understand there's going to be some people on Capitol Hill that are going to be asking questions. That's their right to do so. But I can assure you our White House is moving forward.
And to the extent the Justice Department looks into this matter, it will be done in a nonpolitical way. During John Ashcroft's confirmation process I said that the Justice Department will conduct its business in a nonpolitical way. And we will do so.

Q. Can I just follow up?

MR. BUSH. Sure. Yes.

Q. Other presidents are commenting on this matter. On the Rich pardon specifically, former President Carter said that in his opinion, it was, quote, disgraceful. Do you not have an opinion on a power that is absolute and is vested in you as the president?

MR. BUSH. My opinion is, should I decide to grant pardons, I will do so in a fair way. I'll have the highest of high standards. But the president made the decisions he made. And he can answer the questions raised by the American citizens and the press corps. This White House is moving forward. We've got a lot to do. We've got a lot of people to convince on our agenda. I think we're making pretty good progress but there's a lot of work to be done.

Q. Mr. President, do you think that U.S.-Russian relations have been damaged by the new spy case? And secondly, are the Russians showing any flexibility on a missile defense system?

MR. BUSH. I intend to deal with Mr. Putin in a very straightforward way, to be up front with him on all matters. I am, of course, disturbed about the spy, the espionage, the alleged espionage that took place. I'm mindful that there are people who don't particularly care what America stands for. And people are interested in our secrets.
Secondly, I was pleased to see comments from Russian leadership that talked about missile defense. Their words indicate that they recognize that there are new threats in the post-cold war era, threats that require theater-based antiballistic missile systems. I felt those words were encouraging. When I meet with Mr. Putin, I'm going to talk to him about exactly what he meant by those words. We have no meeting set up yet, I might add. But I took that to be encouraging, Steve. It reminded me of what happened after I met with Mr. Ivanov Igor S. Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister shortly thereafter. Mr. Putin also talked about theater-based systems and the ability to intercept missiles on launch. And to me it's indicative of his recognition of the realities of the true threats in the post-cold war era, threats from an accidental launch or threats as a result of a leader in what they call a rogue nation trying to hold ourselves or our allies, or Russia for that matter, hostage. So I was pleased with what I saw.

Iraq and Sanctions

Q. Sir, the secretary of state is departing for the Middle East tomorrow. One of the things that he will be discussing with Middle East leaders is the possibility of modifying sanctions on Iraq. And I'm wondering what message he will take from this administration to leaders in the Middle East in the area of sanctions that matter, sanctions that are effective on the regime but do not carry with them the same level of criticism the current sanctions have had in that they affect the Iraqi civilian population more than they do the regime, sir.

MR. BUSH. We're reviewing all policy in all regions of the world and one of the areas we've been spending a lot of time on is the Persian Gulf and the Middle East. The secretary of state is going to go listen to our allies and as to how best to effect a policy, the primary goal of which will be to say to Saddam Hussein: We won't tolerate you developing weapons of mass destruction and we expect you to leave your neighbors alone. I have said that the sanction regime is like Swiss cheese -- that meant that they weren't very effective. And we're going to review current sanction policy and review options as to how to make the sanctions work. But the primary goal is to make it clear to Saddam that we expect him to be a peaceful neighbor in the region and we expect him not to develop weapons of mass destruction. And if we find him doing so, there will be a consequence.
We took action last week. And maybe on your mind is that decision I made. The mission was twofold. One was to send him a clear message that this administration will remain engaged in that part of the world. I think we accomplished that mission. We got his attention. And secondly the mission was to degrade his capacity to harm our pilots who might be flying in the no-fly zone. And we accomplished that mission as well.

Q. How would you characterize sanctions that work, sir?

MR. BUSH. Sanctions that work are sanctions that, when a -- the collective will of the region supports the policy. That we have a coalition of countries that agree with the policy set out by the United States. To me, that's the most effective form of sanctions. Many nations in that part of the world aren't adhering to the sanction policy that had been in place. And as a result, a lot of goods are heading into Iraq that were not supposed to. And so a good sanction policy is one where the United States is able to build a coalition around the strategy.

Q. Mr. President, go back to the controversies surrounding former President Clinton and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Are you at all concerned that these controversies are serving as a distraction for your administration's agenda? Are you concerned that further Congressional hearings will mean that lawmakers are spending more time on those matters than are working on your policies?

MR. BUSH. As I said earlier, I've got a lot of work to do. And I think I've got the Congress's attention. I certainly hope so. There's been a lot of discussion about tax relief. And I'm pleased with the progress being made on that important subject. There's a lot of hot debate that has already taken place. And we've just begun to make the case. I'm beginning to travel around the country to important states -- all states are important, of course. But some states may be more important than others right now in trying to convince some lawmakers to hear the message of the people. And this is an issue that affects everybody who pays taxes. Congress is listening to the debate. They're participating in the debate. There's a lot of discussion about education reform on the Hill. And I'm confident that the focus will be the right focus. And my speech Tuesday night I hope will help keep the focus on the agenda.

Q. Mr. President, why do you refuse to respect the wall between the church and state? And you know that the mixing of religion and government, for centuries, has led to slaughter. The very fact that our country has stood in good stead by having this separation -- why do you break it down?

MR. BUSH. I strongly respect the separation of church and state.

Q. Well, you wouldn't have a religious office in the White House if you did.

MR. BUSH. I didn't get to finish my answer, in all due respect. I believe that so long as there's a secular alternative available, we ought to allow individuals who we're helping to be able to choose a program that may be run by a faith-based program or can -- will be run by a faith-based program. I understand full well that some of the most compassionate missions of help and aid come out of faith-based programs. And I strongly support the faith-based initiative that we're proposing because I don't believe it violates the line between the separation of church and state. And I believe it's going to make America a better place.

Q. Well, you are a secular official.

MR. BUSH. I agree. I am a secular official.

Q. Sir, on the air strikes in Iraq, the Pentagon is now saying that most of the bombs used in those strikes missed their targets. Given that, what is now your assessment of how successful those strikes were, how much danger do the remaining installations that we missed in those strikes pose to our forces? And would you hit them again if commanders in the field ask for authorization to do so?

MR. BUSH. We had two missions. One was to send a clear signal to Saddam and the other was to degrade the capacity of Saddam to injure our pilots. I believe we succeeded in both those missions. The bomb assessment damage report is ongoing and I look forward to what the Pentagon has to say as they fully assess the mission. And I will continue to listen to the commanders in the field. My job as commander in chief is to get input from the commanders in the field. And we will do everything needed to protect our pilots, to protect the men and women who wear the uniform.

Tax-Cut Proposal

Q. You said that your $1.6 trillion tax cut is reasonable and responsible within the outlines of the budget you're going to present. If, when that gets to Congress, things start getting layered onto it like corporate tax cuts, capital gains, would you still support it? And if it reached your desk at a higher number, would you sign it?

MR. BUSH. As you know I shy away from hypotheticals. I am going to resist the Christmas-tree effect of tax policy. I don't want people putting ornaments on my plan. I have made it clear to the business interests that the best tax policy is one that reduces the taxes on the people. And I hope they listen to me and I hope they help me get the tax plan through that I have proposed. And the reason I feel so strongly about that is one, a marginal cut will help the economy. Secondly, I am deeply concerned about high energy prices and their effect on the working people in the country. I am concerned about consumer debt. I know there's a lot of talk in Washington about paying down the national debt. And that's fine and good and our budget will do so. But I am very concerned about the fact that a lot of consumers in our country have got high consumer debt. And I believe we need to share some of their money with them so they can help manage their own personal finances. And I will resist the temptation by folks to pile on their pet projects onto our tax cut.

Q. But if they do pile on?

MR. BUSH. Well, first of all, I'm not willing to admit defeat right here, before I've begun to fight or persuade -- let me put it to you that way. I think I've got a pretty good case and I think that many of the business interests will hear that case.

Relations With Latin America

Q. Mr. President.

MR. BUSH. Yes, sir.

Q. You've shown a lot of interest in Latin America issues.

MR. BUSH. Si.

Q. I have a double question for you. The first one has to do with Colombia. You've got a big meeting on Tuesday with Colombian President Andres Pastrana and a lot of people are still worried about the implications of Plan Colombia, which your predecessor set in motion about possible future military involvement of the United States. I want to know your impressions of Plan Colombia. And my second question has to do with the free trade agreement. You're going to be going to Quebec in April. Are you going to ask for fast-track approval so this thing can get going again, because it's been kind of dormant lately?

MR. BUSH. I appreciate that question. I'd love to have fast-track approval. I think it's going to be important to work with our neighbors to the south and Canada to the north to promote free trade throughout the hemisphere. I spoke to the prime minister of Canada this morning and that subject came up about the summit -- upcoming summit. And so we're going to begin the process in Congress of Ambassador Robert B. Zoellick the United States trade representative will be working with members of Congress to lay the groundwork for the ability for the president to have what they call fast-track negotiating authority. Secondly, I look forward to meeting with President Pastrana. I'm looking forward to the briefing that he'll be bringing from Colombia. And I, too, am worried about ever committing the United States military to an engagement in that part of the world. I know we're training and that's fine. But the mission ought to be limited to just that. And so I share the concern of those who are worried that at some point in time the United States might become militarily engaged. Now, in terms of the success of the mission, the president's going to bring me his firsthand account of what's taking place in the country. I am concerned about the amount of acreage in cultivation of -- for the growth of coca leaves. We've got to do a better job of working with the Colombia government on its eradication program. I had a long talk about the Andes with President Vicente Fox of Mexico . I'm convinced President Fox will be a stabilizing influence for that part of the world. Fortunately, I've got a good relationship so that he will share with me his insights as things develop. He has had meetings with Mr. Pastrana, Mr. Chavez Hugo Chavez, the president of Venezuela and I believe Vicente Fox is going to be a stabilizing influence and a positive influence in the Andes.

Q. Mr. President, on Iraq, what is your understanding of the Chinese presence in Iraq, especially with regard to constructing military facilities? And do you see anything that you see as a violation of U.N. sanctions?

MR. BUSH. Well, we're concerned about Chinese presence in Iraq. And my administration is sending the appropriate response to the Chinese. Yes, it's troubling that they would be involved in helping Iraq develop a system that will endanger our pilots.

Q. And that is what they're doing sir? You think ----

MR. BUSH. Well, we think that may be the case. Let me just tell you this: It's risen to the level where we're going to send a message to the Chinese.

Q. Mr. President, I know you want to move forward on this question of pardons.

MR. BUSH. Correct.

Q. But when you campaigned you talked about the legacy of the 60's, where leaders didn't stand up and take their moral role and say something's been done wrong here. You want to move forward but on the question of these pardons do you feel there's any moral obligation in terms of your office to stand up and say to those who may be watching this say, look, something has been done wrong here?

MR. BUSH. I think the press corps will ferret out any wrongdoing. My job is to assure the American people that this administration will have the highest ethical standards and we're going to move forward. The president made decisions he made and I've made the decision in this White House to move forward and we will.

Q. President Bush, given the questions that are being raised about the involvement of Senator Hillary Clinton's brother in the pardons process, what kind of guidance would you give members of your own politically active family in not only seeking pardons but seeking any other influence on any other issues with your administration?

MR. BUSH. My guidance to them is behave yourself, and they will.

Q. Mr. President, to follow up on your answer on the tax question, perhaps looking at it through the other way, some people are saying that perhaps it's too large a tax cut and that ----

MR. BUSH. Some are saying it's too small, some are saying it's too large and I'm saying it's just right.

Q. But are you willing ----

MR. BUSH. I interrupted him.

Q. You were not willing to be flexible in terms of people who want to increase the size. Are you willing to be flexible with people who want to lower the size of your tax cut?

MR. BUSH. I think it's just right. We've thought long and hard about the right number. This is a well-planned-out tax relief package that addresses the concerns of working Americans. It is needed, it is necessary, it'll make a very positive difference in the lives of people who pay taxes. And our country can afford it. There is a choice we have to make: Once we meet priorities, do we increase the size of the government or do we increase the amount of money in the pockets of the people who are working for a living? It is the right size and it the right time for tax relief in the country.

Q. Mr. President, on that same subject, your tax and budget package, how can you be sure that as you put it there'll be money left over? All it would take would be a less than one percentage point drop in productivity for that out-year surplus to dwindle or maybe even vanish. And also nobody, including Alan Greenspan, thinks that it would provide much of a current stimulus.

MR. BUSH. First of all, I think given the choice between increasing the baselines of the budget, the extent to which it had been increased in the past, and passing money back to the people, I think Mr. Greenspan -- not to put words in his mouth -- but it seems like -- why don't I just put some words in his mouth -- it seems like what he said in his testimony is he'd rather see tax relief rather than increasing the size of the budgets beyond the needs of the country.
Now secondly, I believe we can do a heck of a lot better in growing our economy than the basic assumptions in the 10-year plan. I believe that good monetary policy, good fiscal policy, good regulatory policy, good trade policy will enable our economy to grow beyond the scope that is envisioned in the current budget projections.
Secondly, I believe as well that if we don't pass some of the money back to the people that pay the bills, it is going to be spent. And I worry about a bloated federal government serving as a drag on economic growth.

Relations With Europe

Q. You have a meeting with Prime Minister Blair tomorrow ----

MR. BUSH. Correct.

Q. There are some concerns in this country about the European plan for what they call the rapid reaction force, their own military capability. What will you tell Prime Minister Blair about the American attitude to this rapid reaction force?

MR. BUSH. I first look forward to the visit. I'm anxious to meet the prime minister. We've had a couple of good conversations on the telephone. I'm thankful that he's coming across the -- actually coming down from Canada -- but coming across the sea to visit us. Laura and I are looking forward to having a private dinner with he and Mrs. Blair Friday night. We'll be having a press availability after our meeting and ----

Q. unintelligible

MR. BUSH. Well, why don't we wait until after he and I visit, so I don't have to give the same answer twice.

Q. But just on the outline of the question of the European defense ----

MR. BUSH. You bet. I understand. You're trying to get me to tell you the answer twice. But Britain and the United States have got a special relationship. We'll keep it that way. I look forward to talking to the prime minister about the importance of NATO. It is -- anyway, let me visit with him first and I promise to call upon you tomorrow. Nice try.

Q. You've talked a lot about areas of the budget that are going to increase: education, today you talked about Medicare, you talked before a little bit about defense. You haven't talked much about the areas where to come in with a budget that's going to be responsible you'll have to do some cuts.

MR. BUSH. Yes.

Q. Where might we see you take the red pen to the budget?

MR. BUSH. Let me remind you and the people who are listening that accounting in Washington's a little different than the way normal -- I shouldn't say normal people -- the average person accounts. This is a town where if you don't increase the budget by an expected number, it's considered a cut.
We are going to slow the rate of growth of the budget down. It should come as no surprise to anybody that my budget is going to say loud and clear that the rate of growth of the budget, for example, from last year was excessive. And so we'll be slowing the rate of growth of the budgets down. And that evidently is a cut. In my parlance it's not a cut. When you increase spending is not a cut.
I will be glad to explain some of the slowdowns and some of the increases and perhaps a decrease or two after we put the budget out. Let me submit it to you, let me submit it on Tuesday and then I'll be glad to answer your questions. Thank you for this. I look forward to this -- I look forward to future press conferences.

Q. unintelligible

MR. BUSH. Well, yes, of course. Oh, you don't want to see me once a week. You'll run out of questions. Oh, twice. I'll be running out of ties. Thank you very much.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Revises Its Estimates Downward

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems said yesterday that many of its large customers had sharply cut back on investments in computer equipment, making it likely that it will fall well short of projected sales and earnings in the current quarter.
 "We are gaining market share," said Ed Zander, the president and chief operating officer of Sun. "We're disappointed in one and only one thing -- the U.S. economy." 
 Sun said that it now expected revenues to grow 10 percent to 13 percent in the current quarter, down from 35 percent a year ago and a previous projection of at least 20 percent for the current quarter. The expected squeeze on its profitability is likely to result in earnings of 7 cents to 9 cents a share, at least 40 percent lower than the 15 cents a share that had been the consensus of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial. 
The warning came after a rocky day of trading for technology stocks on Wall Street following an announcement yesterday morning from EMC, the leading vendor of large data storage systems, that its growth this year might be slower than previously expected. Coming after a more pointed warning to lower earnings projections late Wednesday from Brocade Communications Systems, a leading supplier of networking equipment for storage systems, EMC's uncharacteristically cautious note helped send storage stocks sharply lower.
EMC was one of the most heavily traded stocks on the Big Board yesterday, falling $2.60, to $40.35. Its shares are down 47 percent this month. Brocade fell $2.75, to $41.94, on the Nasdaq.
The selling pressure also hit Veritas Software, a leading vendor of software that manages storage systems, even though Veritas announced strong quarterly earnings Wednesday and raised its projections for the year. Its shares fell $6.88, to $65.50.
Sun's shares rose $1.19, to $20.81, in trading on the Nasdaq yesterday before the company's cautionary conference call with analysts. Investors initial reaction to the news was negative, and Sun tumbled as low as $18.81 in after-hours trading, falling below the 52-week low of $19.88 the company had touched on Wednesday.
Sun painted a picture of its customers' senior managers as nearly paralyzed with uncertainty about the direction of the United States economy. "Anything to do with capital spending is being slowed down," said Thomas Lehman, Sun's chief financial officer.
EMC said that major customers continued to plan on spending heavily but it fretted that such decisions seemed perilously close to being delayed.
"It points out how important it now is for these companies that Europe and Asia continue to be strong," said H. Clinton Vaughan, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in San Francisco. "But you have to ask how likely that is if the U.S. economy weakens."
Michael Lehman, chief financial officer of Sun, said that Sun would cut back on hiring and administrative expenses to try to raise profits but he said that the company intended to continue investing heavily in research and development. He also announced that Sun would buy back $1.5 billion worth of stock, asserting that the company was undervalued at current prices.
Sun and the storage companies still expect to grow at rates that would be the envy of most other businesses. Sun projected that revenues would grow anywhere from 20 percent to 35 percent this year. Noting that the company last year passed I.B.M. to become the largest vendor of server computers, according to recently published research by Dataquest, Sun executives said that the company's competitive position in server markets would be even stronger as this year progressed. Sun is scheduled to roll out long-awaited upgrades to several computer lines this year and expects the chip shortages that are crimping sales of recently upgraded products to ease by this summer.
Sun singled out storage as an area where its sales have been weak. But the better barometer of the outlook in the storage sector is EMC. And the reaction to EMC's guidance yesterday showed how little confidence many investors now have in the argument of companies that specialize in storage -- heartily endorsed by many analysts until this month -- that their products are so essential to information managers that storage stocks are a relatively safe haven.
"They've taken away the illusion that any area is immune," said Andrew J. Neff, who follows EMC and its rivals for Bear, Stearns. 
EMC said that sales have already slowed to dot-com ventures and other companies having trouble raising capital.
EMC said that its ability to compensate by increasing sales to the big businesses that account for a vast majority of its market could be hurt if corporate managers listen to predictions by "pundits" that the economic slowdown will worsen. That could lead those customers to delay or cancel investments, EMC said, making the slowdown a "self-fulfilling prophecy." 
EMC's guidance was couched in upbeat trappings. "Thus far in the first quarter of 2001, global demand for EMC's information storage systems, software and services is strong," the company said in a statement yesterday morning, making it clear it was not about to issue a rare quarterly earnings warning. The statement also said that EMC, which is based in Hopkinton, Mass., "continues to march toward its revenue goal of $12 billion in 2001." 
Having thus cleared its throat, EMC finally got around to its real mission of telling Wall Street that a 35 percent growth rate, which would work out to more than $12 billion in sales, now represents its most optimistic projection for the year. The 33 percent to 38 percent growth projection the company put out with earnings last month has now shifted to 25 percent to 35 percent growth. At the low end, the result would be $11 billion in revenues and substantially lower profits than analysts' current estimates. 
Thomas Kraemer, who follows the company for Merrill Lynch, called the message "mixed or at least unclear." But any sort of caution from EMC, which has not specifically warned analysts to lower estimates since 1995, was viewed as a novel development.

SECTION: Section B; Column 4; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 1758 words

HEADLINE: Screwdriver Scholars And Pencil Punditry 

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN 

 BODY:
After decades of languishing in obscurity, the zipper finally got its lucky break in 1921. That year, an engineer at the B. F. Goodrich Rubber Company in Akron, Ohio, decided to attach the metal contraption to a pair of rubber galoshes. The result was the popular Goodrich Zipper Boot, and its so-called hookless fastener went on to trounce the button and the snap.
 Life without it seems inconceivable now. But for a good deal of the zipper's existence the success of the device was far from assured. "It was very much a superfluous invention," said Robert Friedel, a historian at the Uni versity of Maryland at College Park. "It didn't do anything you couldn't do more simply and cheaply with buttons, hooks and eyes or snaps. It took 20 years to invent the zipper -- to make the thing work. It took an additional 20 years to get anyone to buy it. And 40 years is a very long gestation period for a thing this trivial." 
 Decidedly trivial, the zipper seems hardly worth thinking deeply about. But society's low-status objects have become scholarship's hot properties. On campus, objects -- the more banal the better -- are in. 
Across the humanities, in fields like art, architecture, history and even English, a growing number of experts are turning to things in an effort to better understand the past. In addition to Mr. Friedel's "Zipper: An Exploration in Novelty" (W. W. Norton, 1994)," which records the fastener's unlikely ascent to wardrobe mainstay, the last few years have seen scholarly accounts of such ordinary artifacts as the pencil, the book, the chair, the screwdriver and the mirror, not to mention such basic foodstuffs as coffee, sugar and chocolate. 
The academic name for the stuff of everyday life is material culture. The concept itself is not new. It first came to prominence in the 1970's in the work of the French historian Fernand Braudel, whose path-breaking approach to such subjects as the rise of capitalism combined an analysis of large-scale forces like geography and the environment with detailed accounts of daily life for various social classes.
Until recently, however, material culture was largely the province of folklorists and museum curators. Over the last decade the field has gone mainstream. The University of Delaware now has a Center for American Material Culture Studies. Scholars in Yale University's material culture study group meet once a week. Critical Inquiry, a top scholarly journal, is publishing a special issue on things this fall, with essay topics ranging from Renaissance gloves to aluminum in Fascist Italy.
"The field of material culture is breaking out into the world of historians more generally," said Leora Auslander, a professor at the University of Chicago and the author of "Taste and Power: Furnishing Modern France" (University of California Press, 1996), a history of French furniture from 1720 to 1920.
Experts offer various reasons for academe's current object obsession. Some stress a discipline-wide turn away from production, the main focus of historians since Marx, to consumption. "So much of the literature on change in the 18th and 19th centuries had been focused on revolutions in production, on factories and machines," Mr. Friedel said. "We're realizing there had to be a revolution in consumption at the same time." 
Others stress the influence of several decades' worth of social history, with its emphasis on ordinary people. "In the 1950's and 1960's, culture typically meant high culture," said Jeffrey N. Wasserstrom, a professor of history at Indiana University and the acting editor of the American Historical Review, a leading journal in the field. "Now people are interested in culture again, and everyday objects becomes a way of combining an interest in culture with doing history from the bottom up."
Then there is the impact of the Internet. Witold Rybczynski, a professor of architecture at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of "One Good Turn: A Natural History of the Screwdriver and the Screw" (Scribner, 2000), speculates that "electronic innovations make other things we use -- like screwdrivers -- seem historical." When you spend the day in virtual space, he points out, even books and chairs can begin to seem like artifacts from antiquity.
But scholars agree about one thing: objects tell us things people can't. "If you want to get something of the atmosphere and the mood of a time, it's through the everyday trivia rather than the pompous reflections of historians looking back or government edicts," said Martin Andrews, deputy director of the two-year-old Center for Ephemera Studies at the University of Reading in England, where researchers study disposable printed matter.
Last year the center published the first "Encyclopedia of Ephemera" (Routledge), which contains more than 400 thumbnail histories of throwaway items, including air-sickness bags, lavatory paper and garment labels. "We're interested in people's wastebaskets as much as anything else," Mr. Andrews said.
Objects also tell us things that people won't. "When people are engaged with objects -- whether making them or using them -- they're only semiconscious," she said. "It's true of every last object. People say things through them without meaning to." She said that by looking at someone's furnishings, for example, a historian could tell whether the person once belonged to a different social class -- a fact that an aspiring social climber might take pains to hide. 
Ms. Auslander's current project concerns the role of objects in turning monarchists into republicans in revolutionary America, England and France. "You can use language and rational arguments to change people's minds," she said. "But in order to change how they feel, you need to use objects. You make them cease loving the king and have faith in fellow citizens by creating new symbols and rituals." In the Colonies, she said, the use of coarse homespun wool was heavily promoted by the local authorities as a symbol of republican self-reliance and austerity (in contrast to the British monarchy's penchant for luxury).
Other object scholars make a similar argument: many everyday items on which people have come to depend serve not just practical needs but also social and political ones. 
The chair? It may have evolved in the West as a way of indicating rank -- kings were early users -- but according to Galen Cranz, a professor of architecture at the University of California at Berkeley and the author of "The Chair: Rethinking Culture, Body and Design" (W. W. Norton, 1998), among its values today is its function as a "sedative to create a docile population not inclined to criticize or become politically active." The verb sedate, Ms. Cranz's points out, comes from the Latin "to sit." Besides, she adds, chair sitting is bad for your spine.
The zipper? It was the embodiment of mechanized modernity, Mr. Friedel said in his book. And for that reason, it nearly failed. For many years the zipper was mainly a barometer of ambivalence about a fully automated world -- especially when it came to intimate matters like dress. The machine-run dystopia of Aldous Huxley's 1932 novel "Brave New World," Mr. Friedel pointed out, is littered with zippers -- from zippyjamas to zippicamiknicks. "To Huxley," Mr. Friedel wrote, "there was nothing at all natural about zippers, and that is just why they are such a powerful yet subtle symbol throughout his novel." 
To scholars of material culture, objects are never neutral. Instead, they are teeming with social and political meanings. As a result, it can be tempting to exaggerate an object's historical importance.
"Monocausality is a disease that very good historians fall prey to," said Anthony Grafton, a historian at Princeton University. "We call it 'the chapter in which you show that whatever you're writing about caused the French Revolution.' "
While the 19th-century French historian Jules Michelet may have been guilty of that offense -- he singled out coffee as a culprit in the French Revolution (cafe society stimulated revolutionary ardor), contemporary object scholars tend to be more circumspect. 
Thus while the German historian Wolfgang Schivelbusch links the advent of the light bulb to the beginning of corporate capitalism in his history of electricity, "Disenchanted Night" (University of California Press, 1988), he is careful not to hold one development responsible for the other, suggesting instead that they mirrored each other. "The concentration and centralization of energy in high-capacity power stations corresponded to the concentration of economic power in the big banks," he wrote.
Likewise, Lenin and Henry David Thoreau make appearances in "The Pencil: A History of Design and Circumstance" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1989). But the book's author, Henry Petroski, a professor of civil engineering at Duke University, does not claim that the pencil played any role in the development of Soviet Communism or transcendentalism. Lenin allowed the American entrepreneur Armand Hammer to open Russia's first pencil plant in the 1920's, and Thoreau made a crucial contribution to the struggling domestic pencil industry in the late 1830's. Determined to make his father's pencil factory more competitive with its European rivals, young Thoreau did some research in the Harvard library, where he reportedly stumbled across a German pencil-making formula in an encyclopedia entry. After a little experimentation, Mr. Petroski wrote, John Thoreau & Company was soon producing the "best pencil in America," one that could hold its own in the international market. 
Mr. Petroski's investigation of the pencil convinced him of the value of object studies. "There is no end of common objects whose close scrutiny rewards us with an understanding of the rest of the world as well," he said at the end of his book. (He went on to write a history of the book and the bookshelf.)
Colleagues were more skeptical. Even among everyday objects, the pencil seemed especially trivial. But Mr. Petroski knew of an 1868 essay by the British naturalist Thomas Huxley, Aldous Huxley's grandfather, about a piece of chalk.
"The man who should know the true history of the bit of chalk which every carpenter carries about in his breeches-pocket," Huxley wrote, will understand the world better than "the most learned student who is deep-read in the records of humanity." For Mr. Petroski, these were encouraging words. "When people said, 'Can you really write a whole book just about a pencil?' I said, 'Well, Huxley did it for a piece of chalk.' "

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW; 
Good Guys vs. Bad Guys, With Earnest Orations

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES 

 BODY:
If the economy really is headed downward, as so many people say, Mary Stuart Masterson's new drama series, "Kate Brasher," is ahead of the curve. From the looks of the first episode (tonight on CBS), the show is all about hard times.
 The title character, played by Ms. Masterson with her usual no-nonsense charm, is a struggling, eviction-threatened single mother of two. As another character points out, and not sympathetically, she is "trying to raise two teenage boys in the Santa Monica school district on minimum-wage jobs." By day she's the spunkiest waitress at the diner. By night she works at a bar and is part of the all-female cleaning team at a bowling alley. But the man at the bowling alley refuses to pay his workers, and a funny thing happens when Kate goes to a community action center to look for free legal help: she proves herself a natural at social work. Finally, a career break! 
 Let's be thankful for small blessings. "Kate Brasher" has an appealing cast and doesn't insult viewers' intelligence most of the time. But the main characters -- who are 100 percent good and face off against people who are 100 percent bad -- always seem to be making self-righteous speeches. "With or without you, I'm going to keep my place -- in Fantasy Land," Kate tells the center's director (Hector Elizondo), who has accused her of unrealistic expectations. "Because my boys deserve the best education humanly possible. Period." To the man at the bowling alley, she announces: "You count on people like us to be too scared to stand up to people like you. But you know what? You counted wrong. Maybe you didn't know this, but slavery is illegal in the United States of America." 
There's nothing wrong with inspiring little speeches that make audiences cheer. It was always a pleasure to see Dixie Carter get carried away with one of hers on "Designing Women." But the speeches have to say something in a fresh way, and even Ms. Carter's orations got old once the show's writers became so self-conscious about them. 
"Kate Brasher" is trying too hard. (1) To be quirky. When Kate needs guidance, she opens the Bible to a random page, hoping for a message. (2) To create a noisy "E.R."-ish atmosphere of hustle, bustle, chaos and crisis at the community center. (3) To be simultaneously uplifting and cynical. Mr. Elizondo talks about a "random universe" (Ms. Masterson, of course, disagrees) and asks, "Where was the Big Guy?" when a 15-year-old was killed. If the characters are debating theology on the day they meet, where will they go from here?
Rhea Perlman's character, a lawyer just admitted to the bar after 16 years of school, earning a living and child-rearing combined, has possibilities. At least when she addresses an unpleasant character with a spur-of-the-moment nickname (as in "Look, Barbie, this is us making an appointment") in her best Carla Tortelli snarl, it seems to come from the heart.

(Channel 2 in New York)

HEADLINE: Most Colleges Are Expected To Continue to Use the SAT 

BYLINE:  By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
As the University of California weighs a recommendation by its president to drop the SAT's as an admissions requirement, the vast majority of the nation's highly selective institutions, as well as other large public universities, are expected to rely on the tests for the foreseeable future.
 The proposal last Friday by the president of the California system, which has such flagship campuses as Berkeley and U.C.L.A. and gives out one of every 50 American bachelor's degrees yearly, has added fresh fuel to the decades-old debate within admissions offices over the merits of the SAT's. But interviews in recent days with administrators from half a dozen other colleges and universities suggest that there may be no other institution that will immediately follow California's lead. 
 "I'm not ready to throw out the SAT," said Jack Blackburn, the dean of undergraduate admissions at the University of Virginia since 1985. "I think it's a very good test. It's been given to millions of people. If used properly, it provides a good piece of information about an applicant. 
"I think the bad stories come from places that don't know how to use it."
All of the university officials interviewed, from Harvard to Stanford, and from the University of Michigan to the University of Texas at San Antonio, said they continued to regard the SAT's as the best instrument available for establishing a common national yardstick, one that allows them to compare, say, an A-student from an underfinanced high school in a rural state with an A-student in a top-flight suburban school. 
The officials cautioned that most institutions weigh the SAT differently in different situations, depending, for example, on whether the applicant is the son of an accomplished lawyer or the son of parents who never completed high school, and whether one applicant is white and another black. 
At the same time they echoed the concerns of the president of the California system, Dr. Richard C. Atkinson, about the tests' shortcomings and about the ways that the SAT's have come to dominate the lives of so many American teenagers, who often view them as nothing less than a barometer of their own potential. 
All of the officials acknowledged that the scores on the SAT I, an aptitude test (the SAT II's is an achievement text tied more closely to course work), and the ACT, a similar standardized exam, often reveal more about students' family lives, socio-economic station and school quality than about their prospects for succeeding in four years of college and beyond. But over all they said they planned to continue to consult the SAT scores.
"It's the only standard factor in every student's application," said Robin Mamlet, the dean of admission and financial aid at Stanford University since September. "But we're also aware that students from different kinds of backgrounds score very differently."
Ms. Mamlet added: "One of the things Atkinson's saying is that they're going to move to a more holistic approach. But most of the nation's really selective institutions have mastered giving a holistic approach to their admissions, while still using the SAT. It's not a dichotomy."
If the University of California system does make the SAT's optional, it would become, by far, the largest institution on a small list of defectors that includes Bates, Bowdoin and Mount Holyoke Colleges.
But California's timetable in abandoning the SAT would be drawn out. If Dr. Atkinson can persuade the faculty senate and the Board of Regents to adopt his proposal, it would not take effect until 2003 at the earliest; the full impact of the proposal, if implemented, will not be known for years.
"We are caught up in the educational equivalent of a nuclear arms race," Dr. Atkinson said in a speech last weekend. "We know that this overemphasis on test scores hurts all involved, especially students. But we also know that anyone or any institution opting out of the competition does so at considerable risk."
In taking the first step down that path, the California system is responding to immense outside political pressures. In 1996, the state's voters banned the consideration of race and ethnicity in determining college admission. Doing away with the SAT's as a requirement would eliminate a measurement on which the performances of black and Hispanic students have trailed significantly behind white and Asian students.
In 1996, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit barred the consideration of race in university admissions in Texas, Louisiana and Mississippi. Like California, Texas now guarantees a seat in the University of Texas system to all students who are ranked at a particular level in their high school class, regardless of SAT scores.
But Ricardo Romo, the president of the University of Texas at San Antonio, said he did not expect the Regents of the University of Texas system to move any time soon to drop the SAT's at any of its campuses as a way of further complying with the federal ruling.
"There's a significant number of people out there -- they're parents, they're ministers, they're business people -- who have bought into the SAT," Mr. Romo said. "They believe it is very good currency. For you to say we're not going to use this currency any more, it would come as a shock."
Nonetheless, Mr. Romo said the California proposal was already receiving serious scrutiny on his campus, and others in the Texas system.
"Atkinson's sort of landed on the moon," Mr. Romo said. "The rest of us are looking at the opportunities of space exploration."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Tumble, Then Regain Some Ground

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL BRICK 

 BODY:
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rebounded slightly yesterday after a suggestion of an imminent cut in interest rates gave hope to investors who are dismayed by the continuation of corporate earnings warnings.
 Other stock market gauges declined. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index hit a low during the day of 1,215,44, a drop of more than 20 percent from last year's highs. 
 The major market gauges were down sharply in the morning but turned around in the afternoon after Wayne D. Angell, the chief economist of Bear, Stearns and a former Federal Reserve governor, said there was a 60 percent chance that the Fed would cut short-term interest rates by half a percentage point as early as next week. He had previously maintained there was a 40 percent chance. 
For much of yesterday, though, the market was hurt by companies that warned of reduced profits. Both Sun Microsystems and Motorola warned of lower-than-expected profits and both stocks initially fell sharply, although Sun recovered to close unchanged at $20.81. Motorola, however, ended down $1.04, at $16.25.
The technology selling put early pressure on the Nasdaq composite index, which fell as much as 88 points. It recovered to close up 17.55 points, or 0.8 percent, at 2,262.51.
The S.& P. 500 index fell 6.96 points, or 0.6 percent, to 1,245.86, and the Dow Jones industrial average declined 84.91 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 10,441.90 after falling more than 300 points earlier.
With yesterday's decline, the S.& P. 500 is down 18.4 percent from its closing high in March 2000, just shy of a 20 percent loss that would signify to some market analysts that a bear market had begun. In contrast, the Nasdaq is down 55.2 percent from its record closing high, also reached in March 2000.
Weighing on the Dow, as well as the technology sector, was a sharp drop in I.B.M., which fell $4.90, to $104. Investors retreated from I.B.M. after John B. Jones Jr., an analyst for Salomon Smith Barney, lowered his earnings forecast for the company because spending on information technology in the United States "is clearly soft."
In addition to heeding profit warnings, market strategists have been waiting for the Federal Reserve to act on interest rates.
Economists have been expecting the Fed's policy makers to reduce interest rates further at their regular meeting on March 20 after making two cuts totaling one percentage point in January. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rally
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices surged yesterday, driving yields on two-year notes close to their lowest level since January 1999, as further turmoil in stock markets stirred investor hopes for aggressive Federal Reserve interest rate cuts in the near future.
With major stock indexes having losses nearly every day in the last week, investors have parked funds in shorter-term Treasuries, sending those yields, which move opposite to price, much lower compared with long-term bonds.
"With the Dow and Nasdaq down this much, there's nowhere else to go except the Treasury market," said Don Kowalchik, fixed-income strategist at A. G. Edwards & Sons.
Even a late-day recovery in technology shares was not enough to take the allure off short-term Treasuries.
The price of the two-year Treasury note rose 4/32 , to 100 6/32 . The note's yield fell to 4.53 percent.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 15/32 , to a price of 99 9/32 . Its yield fell to 5.09 percent from 5.16 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 22/32 , to 98 16/32 . The bond's yield fell to 5.48 percent from 5.53 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Budget Office's Estimates For Drug Spending Grow 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
The Congressional Budget Office has sharply increased its estimates of spending on prescription drugs for the elderly, revisions that will make it more difficult for Congress to pay for drug benefits under Medicare.
 The new estimates, about one-third higher than those made last May, reflect new information about drugs that are in the pipeline and likely to come into use in the next decade. 
 The budget office, a nonpartisan arm of Congress, presented its new estimates to Congressional aides on Thursday and today.
Prescription drugs were hotly debated in campaigns for the White House and Congress last year. George W. Bush promised to add drug benefits to Medicare as part of an effort to overhaul the program, which provides care to people who are elderly or disabled. 
A Republican analyzing proposals for Medicare drug benefits said, "Everything just got a lot more expensive." A Democrat said some of his Democratic colleagues on Capitol Hill were "in shock" over the new numbers.
One-third of the 39 million Medicare beneficiaries have no insurance to pay for prescription drugs outside the hospital. The number of beneficiaries is expected to reach 47 million in 2011, just as the first baby boomers turn 65.
The Congressional Budget Office is the official scorekeeper for Congress. Its work is widely respected by experts outside the government. Even if its estimates are wrong, they are binding on Congress, which generally must find ways to pay the costs of legislation as estimated by the budget office.
In May 2000, the budget office predicted that spending from all sources on prescription drugs for the elderly would total $1.1 trillion in the decade from 2001 to 2010. Updating its estimates this week, the budget office said such spending would total nearly $1.5 trillion from 2002 to 2011.
The difference between the old and new estimates widens each year. The budget office now says that drug spending in 2001 for people on Medicare will total $70.6 billion, which is 7 percent more than the earlier estimate for the same year. The new estimate for 2010 -- $205 billion -- is 23 percent higher than the old figure for that year.
Economists said that Medicare coverage of prescription drugs would create some additional demand, as the government would help purchase drugs for millions of people who now have no insurance to cover such costs. But federal officials have said they will seek ways to restrain costs and to prevent excessive or inappropriate use of drugs.
Last year the budget office predicted that drug spending for the elderly would rise an average of 11 percent a year over the next decade. Now, it says, the growth will average 12 percent to 13 percent a year.
These numbers have major implications for Congress as it tries to devise drug benefits for the elderly and the disabled.
If Congress decided to spend a specific amount on Medicare drug coverage -- say, $40 billion in the next five years -- the benefits would seem less generous because the money would cover less of the costs actually incurred by the elderly.
Conversely, the government would have to spend more, or charge beneficiaries more, for coverage deemed adequate by the elderly. As premiums rise, economists say, fewer people will enroll, and those who do will expect to have high drug expenses.
In the campaign, Mr. Bush said the government should pay any drug costs exceeding $6,000 a year for a Medicare beneficiary. Under the new estimates, more beneficiaries would incur such costs and would therefore qualify for "catastrophic coverage."
Drug companies are feverishly developing drugs to prevent, treat or cure ailments of the elderly including heart disease, cancer and stroke, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's disease, osteoporosis and arthritis. 
The new drugs often enter the market at prices much higher than the prices charged for the drugs they replace. A few drug products now cost more than $10,000 a year, and the number may grow as scientists exploit genetics to tailor drugs to the needs of individual patients. 
In recent years, spending on prescription drugs has grown faster than any other category of personal health spending. The Food and Drug Administration has reduced the time needed to approve new drugs, and federal officials say that advertising has stimulated demand for many medicines.
The Congressional Budget Office said spending on prescription drugs averaged $1,525 for each Medicare beneficiary in 2000, and it estimated that the average would triple by 2011, reflecting higher prices and the greater use of prescription drugs by the elderly.
The Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare, is also preparing new spending estimates, which are expected to show higher rates of growth than it anticipated last year.
Congressional aides said the new estimates reflected more up-to-date information about drug spending in recent years, as well as fresh projections of spending in the future. 
The figures on recent drug spending were derived from government surveys of Medicare beneficiaries and from commercial sources of data like IMS Health of Westport, Conn., which collects data from pharmacies across the country.
Elderly people have repeatedly told Congress that they need help paying for prescription drugs. While acutely aware of these needs, some members of Congress are also skittish about the costs.
Lawmakers recall the political fiasco after Congress expanded Medicare in 1988 to cover catastrophic illnesses and prescription drugs. Official estimates of drug spending rose within months after the law was enacted. The extra coverage was partly financed by a surtax on the elderly, many of whom concluded that the extra benefits were not worth the added cost. Congress repealed the law a year later.
